NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1988
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-11  Archbishop Tutu was arrested along with two dozen other church leaders when they marched toward the South African Parliament in Cape Town to protest the banning of 17 anti-apartheid groups last week.
Page A1


Japan Vehicle Exports
LEAD: Japanese auto makers exported 9.1 percent fewer cars, trucks and buses in January than they did a year earlier, largely because the yen's rise against the dollar shrank shipments to the United States, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.
Exports to the United States dropped by 19.4 percent, to 199,904 units.


Kuenn's Funeral Set for Thursday
LEAD: Harvey Kuenn, the former manager of the Milwaukee Brewers who died Sunday at the age of 57, suffered a heart attack, the club said today.


Farm Value Up In the Midwest
LEAD: The value of Middle Western farmland is up about 7 percent from 1986 levels, but still is little more than half the level it had reached seven years ago, a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago has found.


Soviet Reports a Major Oil Center In Azerbaijan Is Shaken by Riots
LEAD: The Soviet Union reported today that a major oil and natural gas center was shaken Sunday by rioting apparently related to recent nationalist unrest.


Pension Rise Is Voted in Albany in Rebuff to Koch
LEAD: The State Legislature, with some angry words for Mayor Koch, passed a bill tonight to increase pensions for retired New York State and City workers.


New Flu Variant Found in 41 States
LEAD: Most of this winter's outbreaks of flu have resulted from a new variant of influenza virus similar to one that was discovered in Sichuan, China, last April.
The virus caused an outbreak on a ship cruising between China and Korea in October.
Similar viruses also turned up last fall in Wisconsin, Minnesota and upstate New York, according to a report in the Journal of the American Medical


Hart Ruled Off Ballot In New York Primary
LEAD: Gary Hart's stumbling Presidential campaign was dealt a major setback today when the New York Board of Elections ruled that he had failed to qualify for the state's Democratic primary ballot.


Sale by Santa Fe
LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation has completed the sale of a timber subsidiary to Sierra Pacific Industries of Redding, Calif., for $460 million.
The two companies had announced their agreement Oct. 12 on the sale of the Santa Fe Pacific Timber Company, which owns and manages about 520,000 acres of timberland in Northern California.


TV Review; 'To Hear A Pin Drop,' On 13
LEAD: YOU don't have to visit a disco and stand by a loudspeaker to impair your hearing; everyday life may do the same thing.
Unwanted noise in an urban environment can create a new kind of pollution. ''Innovation,'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight, explains how; it also explains what technology can do about it.


CAPE TOWN POLICE ARREST CLERGYMEN AT PROTEST MARCH
LEAD: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and two dozen other church leaders were arrested today when they marched in Cape Town to protest the banning of 17 anti-apartheid groups last week.


Israel Considers Barring the Press From Arab Areas Hit by Turmoil
LEAD: Israeli officials, stung by foreign television footage showing four soldiers beating two captive Palestinians, are considering banning journalists from areas of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.


Brain-Deficient Baby Dies at Loma Linda
LEAD: An 8-day-old baby girl born with almost no brain died one day after she was taken off a respirator used to preserve her organs for transplant, hospital officials said today.


Exhibition Shows the Silents as Anything But
LEAD: The exhibition that opens today at Lincoln Center is a reflective survey of some of the most flamboyantly overstated productions ever to catch the public eye.
It is called ''Epics and Icons of the Silent Film Era,'' and it will be found, trumpeting the glories of the golden silents, in the second-floor Vincent Astor Gallery of the New York Public Library at Lincoln


Negative Campaign Spots Move to the Southern Airwaves
LEAD: The negative television advertising that has been the hallmark of the Presidential race has moved South.


Small-Town Trend Fading
LEAD: They were once small and quaint, the Olympic Winter Games, staged in areas known predominantly for their ski slopes, places like Chamonix, France; St.
Moritz, Switzerland, Cortina d' Ampezzo, Italy, and Squaw Valley, Calif.
Even Lake Placid, N.Y., gave the 1980 Games a small-town flavor.


Amnesty Sale: The Medium Is the Tortilla
LEAD: With top officers wearing sombreros, immigration floats in Chinese New Year parades, fliers placed in packages of tortillas, free videotapes and other novel tactics, immigration officials are laboring to increase turnout as the nation's amnesty program for illegal aliens enters its last 10 weeks.


Stage: 'Tapman,' With Moses Gunn
LEAD: ''TAPMAN,'' the title character in Karen Jones-Meadows's new play, is not, as one might expect, a tapdancer.
He is instead a legendary blues musician who has reached the end of the line - a familiar archetype from fiction as well as fact.
In this case, however, we know he is legendary only because other characters tell us so.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We are not defying, we are obeying, and we are going to obey God every day.''  - Archbishop Desmond Tutu, on march protestingSouth Africa's ban on anti-apartheid groups.  [ A1:6. ]

Mexico to Freeze Peso And Prices for March
LEAD: As part of a program to control Mexico's 177 percent inflation rate, the Mexican Government announced today that it would maintain the value of the peso against the dollar and freeze Government-controlled prices during March.


Americans Measure Their Performance
LEAD: If Dan Jansen is correct, the United States team at the XV Winter Olympic Games did just fine.
More than 130 athletes competed in medal sports, and all of them, Jansen said, tried their hardest.

Porter Testifies
LEAD: Kevin Porter, a former Auburn football star, testified yesterday at the misdemeanor commercial bribery trial of the former Atlanta sports agent Jim Abernethy that he got a $2,000 bonus and $900 in cash delivered in envelopes after signing with Abernethy last August.


BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1988
LEAD:  Companies


Cougar Research in Florida
LEAD: Five wild cougars from Texas will be released in a forest in northeastern Florida to see if the closely related but endangered Florida panther can survive there, wildlife officials have announced.

Colorado's High-Oxygen Fuel Test Runs Smoothly
LEAD: Colorado's first experiment with high-oxygen fuels ended today without the epidemic of clogged fuel injectors and stalled cars predicted by opponents of the smog-control program.


But Can You Say It in 1's and O's?
LEAD: IN the nightmare I'm back at the University of Mars and the final exam in computer science starts in 20 seconds.
But there must be some mistake!
I'm a poetry major and I've never been in this class before.
Suddenly the professor appears: It's Art Fleming, and I'm in Jeopardy.


A Pistol Shot in the Nation's Ear
LEAD: A commission on riots!
A national day of prayer!
People hooted at Lyndon Johnson's response to the long hot summer of 1967.
He would have done better, a cynic said, to appoint a commission on prayer and declare a national day of riot.
After all, study commissions are just devices to buy time till the problem cools.


Jupiter's Spot: A Cosmic Whirlpool
LEAD: A SPINNING tub of water has convinced experts on chaotic systems that they have figured out one of the Solar System's most baffling landmarks, the Great Red Spot of Jupiter.

Plessey Venture
LEAD: The Plessey Company and the General Electric Company P.L.C., two of Britain's biggest electronics concerns, said they had agreed to form a telecommunications group.
GEC Plessey Telecommunications will dominate the industry in Britain and will supply products to government and commercial customers globally, they said.

Merger by Holmes a Court
LEAD: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier, today announced a plan to merge his two leading companies after clearing the decks two weeks ago with huge write-offs of losses in the stock market.


'I Am Flying': Hurricane Carter Rejoices in Freedom
LEAD: After almost 20 years of protesting his innocence from grim prison confines, yesterday Rubin (Hurricane) Carter celebrated the dismissal of triple-murder charges against him amid the elegance of the Plaza Hotel.


The Editorial Notebook; The Disappearing Debates
LEAD: The Bush camp says the Vice President plans no further debates with his competitors for the Republican Presidential nomination.
That's smart; he feels confident again about his prospects and doesn't want to risk a knockout blow.
But such a blow is surely unlikely, to judge by the debates in Atlanta last weekend.


Preston Tisch Rejoins Loews
LEAD: Preston Robert Tisch, who is finishing up his stint as Postmaster General, will return to the Loews Corporation as president and co-chief executive with his brother, Laurence A. Tisch, the company said yesterday.


Pickens Bidding for Homestake
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, offered nearly $2 billion today to acquire the Homestake Mining Company, one of the nation's largest gold producers.


Curb Congress by Line-Item Veto; Pork Allowance
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Dance: Melanie Stewart Troupe
LEAD: ALTHOUGH Melanie Stewart had ideas for several different kinds of dances, she failed to find kinetic images to express them in the program that Melanie Stewart Dance, her company from Philadelphia, offered Saturday night at the Horace Mann Theater as part of the Morningside Dance Festival of Columbia University Teachers College.

Beep, Beep
LEAD: Senators may find their switchboards lighting up with more calls than usual today.
The message: ''Don't bug me!''


New Opera, in Concert
LEAD: ''Dream Beach,'' a new opera in three acts for two singers and ensemble, will be given a concert performance on March 20 at the Green Auditorium of the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, 40 West 68th Street.
The opera, by Michael Sahl and Howard Pflanzer, deals with a woman on a beach and a man on a train and their subsequent encounter.


2 Boys, Left by Parents, Die in Newark Fire
LEAD: Two young brothers died this morning when fire broke out in an apartment where they were left alone with a 12-month-old sister, the authorities said.
The girl was seriously injured.


Ancient Tree Yields Secrets Of Potent Healing Substance
LEAD: IN what could be a step toward testing a folk remedy for modern medical use, chemists at Harvard University have succeeded in synthesizing the potent substance responsible for the ancient ginkgo tree's enduring reputation as the source of varied healing powers.


A Revival to Rival a Premiere
LEAD: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will present a new piece by Mr.
Cunningham during its New York season, which opens tonight at the Joyce Theater.
There will also be a New York premiere.
But for many people, the major event of the season is the single performance, tonight, of ''RainForest.'' Last performed in New


New Arms Agency Chief Is Delayed by Helms
LEAD: President Reagan's choice to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency will not be able to assume his post for at least another month because of recent objections raised by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.


Rewards Are Few For Race-Walker
LEAD: Maryanne Torrellas will go to Indianapolis in mid-July to compete in the United States Olympic trials.
But for the 29-year-old from Clinton, Conn., who led all women this winter in Mobil Grand Prix indoor points, a victory there will not mean a trip to the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.


Ruling Clears a Psychiatrist Of Liability in Maine Slaying
LEAD: A psychiatrist who failed to commit a mentally ill man cannot be held negligent because the man killed a woman three days later, the Maine Supreme Court ruled today.


Solomon, British Pianist, 85, Dies
LEAD: Solomon Cutner, a British pianist known to the musical public as Solomon and greatly admired for his immaculate, stately renditions of works by Schubert, Beethoven and others, died on Feb. 2 in London.
He was 85 years old.


Jakarta Journal; A Colonial Legacy Comes Back, but Not to Haunt
LEAD: In Southeast Asia, where Western empires once collided in the race for spices and straits, most independent nations seem perenially sensitive about their colonial legacies.


Democrats Turn Up Volume in Debate
LEAD: With the Southern primaries only eight days away, the leading Democratic Presidential candidates turned up the volume of their debate, clashing repeatedly here tonight on a wide range of issues and seeking to strike patriotic and nationalist chords.


Mother and a Daughter, 9, Slain
LEAD: A 26-year-old woman and her 9-year-old daughter were found slain, apparently strangled, in the woman's Bronx apartment yesterday.


Correction
LEAD: A picture caption on Feb. 8 with an article about exhibitions dealing with the architecture firm of McKim, Mead &amp; White carried an incorrect order, provided by the New-York Historical Society, for the identities of the men shown.
From the left were William Rutherford Mead, Charles Follen McKim and Stanford White.

Surge in Platinum Sparks A Rally in Precious Metals
LEAD: Precious metals futures soared yesterday after a dramatic late rally caused frenzied buying among the large number of traders who had been betting on a decline in the prices of gold, silver and especially platinum in recent weeks.


U.S. Delays Brazil Action
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that it was postponing the imposition of $105 million in retaliatory sanctions against exports from Brazil, citing a new Brazilian law that may ease barriers against sales of American computers.


Advertising; Myers's Rum Tests Videos In Nightclubs
LEAD: WELL aware of the impact that motion and music can add to pictures and color in promotions, the House of Seagram since December has been testing video advertising for its Myers's Rum.

U.S. Plans Wide Use of Credit Cards
LEAD: The Federal Government is going for the plastic.


Cold Water and Fish
LEAD: The most productive fisheries are found in colder areas of the world's oceans, places like the Grand Banks off Newfoundland and the Bering Sea, and a University of Georgia ecologist may have discovered the reason.


Yanks Happy With Meulens
LEAD: Every day, the rows of seats begin to fill in the early morning, before the players even arrive.

Gooden Takes Center Stage
LEAD: The Mets staged their first full workout of spring training today and delivered some theater to their new audience on Florida's Gold Coast.
Dwight Gooden pitched batting practice for the first time and fired the heater past sluggers like Gary Carter and Darryl Strawberry.

Concert: Early Music
LEAD: IT will be interesting to see what becomes of ''early music,'' as it used to be defined, now that the avant-garde of that movement has invaded the mainstream classical and early Romantic repertory.
New York's Ensemble for Early Music does not, to all appearances, have any imminent designs upon the symphonies of Beethoven or the operas of Donizetti; Saturday's concert in Alice Tully Hall showed the group still concerned with lute, citole, gittern, shawm, pipe-and-tabor, recorders, and music of centuries before the 15th.

Weinberger to Law Firm
LEAD: Less than four months after resigning as Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger has returned to private law practice.
Mr.
Weinberger, 70 years old, is joining the international law firm of Rogers &amp; Wells, which is headed by another former Washington Cabinet member, William P. Rogers, who was Secretary of State in President Nixon's first term.


NASA Buying a Boeing To Carry Space Shuttles
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it would acquire a Boeing 747-100 jetliner to use as a second transporter to carry shuttles piggyback from landing sites back to the launching center here.


William D. Seidler, 67, Nabisco Legal Counsel
LEAD: William Dickson Seidler, a lawyer and senior vice president of law for International Nabisco Brands Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Baltic Journal; Archives Offers the Global Picture
LEAD: Except for a distant silo, the low modern building is the only break on the long prairie horizon.
But here, 20 miles northeast of Sioux Falls, in what can seem the middle of nowhere, the Federal Government is selling pictures of everywhere.


Close Vote Expected Today On Senate Panel's Bank Bill
LEAD: Senator William Proxmire will give Congress its first opportunity on Tuesday to test whether it has the will to change a 55-year-old law that separates the securities industry from commercial banking.

Jersey Democrats Plan a Slate for Bradley
LEAD: A group of New Jersey Democratic leaders announced plans today to run an uncommitted slate of candidates in the New Jersey Presidential primary June 7 ''to put as much voting strength as possible into the hands of Senator Bill Bradley.''


New Lotus System
LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation challenged its rival the Microsoft Corporation with a new system for managing information in personal computers.
The Lotus system is an alternative to the one announced six weeks ago by Microsoft, the Ashton-Tate Corporation and Sybase Inc., known as SQL Server.
Lotus, based in Cambridge, Mass., said its system would have the advantage of working closely with 1-2-3, the best-selling electronic spreadsheet that calculates rows and columns of numbers.


Music: Arditti Quartet In a Modern Program
LEAD: SINCE there were no premieres on the Arditti String Quartet's New York debut program Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, one might reverse the usual focus of contemporary music discussion and consider the performers before the composers.
That is not the way the quartet conducts its affairs, but the most immediate and most lasting impression from this bill of Oliver Lake, Brian Ferneyhough, Gyorgy Ligeti, Elliott Carter and Iannis Xenakis was of the four performers' stunning virtuosity and exciting musical grasp.


Our Towns; Where the Rich Find Comfort In Each Other
LEAD: ''Excuse me,'' said Anne Watkins ($3 million lottery winner, 1983). ''I have to go pick up the $13 million man.'' Joe Moore (actually, $13.7 million, 1985) had just arrived at the train station and was waiting for a ride to the Millionaire Circle Club.
Ms.
Watkins figured she would save him taking a cab.


Drilling Activity Grows
LEAD: The number of oil and gas rigs working in the United States increased by five last week, to a total of 983, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
A year ago the rig count was 801.


Hockey Notebook; Shakier Harvard Still First
LEAD: This was the season that some team - St.
Lawrence, in the opinion of many coaches in October - would pass by Harvard to the top of the ECAC Hockey league.
But in 132 games, that failed to happen.


Dr. Paul Ramsey, 74, a Professor At Princeton for 4 Decades, Dies
LEAD: Dr.
Paul Ramsey, a professor of religion at Princeton University for nearly 40 years and a widely recognized authority on medical ethics, died of a heart attack early yesterday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center.
He was 74 years old and lived in Princeton.


Former Officer Gets Jail Term In Drug Payoff
LEAD: Despite a tearful appeal to a judge for a chance ''to begin my life again,'' a former New York City police officer was sentenced yesterday to 1 to 4 years in prison for taking a $500 payoff from an undercover investigator posing as a drug dealer.


New Tools Are Aiding Excavation Of Sites
LEAD: Archeologists may be inspired by lofty dreams of a major find, but their days in the field are often more prosaic: as they excavate, they must record by hand the mountain of detail they unearth, in a tedious, time-consuming and error-prone process.


Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Will Rule on U.S. Drug-Testing Program
LEAD: Entering a major civil liberties dispute, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of the Reagan Administration's drug-testing program for Customs Service employees seeking certain promotions.


Bank-Report Rule Change
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has decided to require that banks give depositors easier and faster access to their call reports, the statements of financial condition that banks file with the agency.


Mikhail Naimy Is Dead; Lebanese Poet Was 98
LEAD: Mikhail Naimy, a Lebanese poet and philosopher, died in East Beirut on Sunday after developing pneumonia, his relatives said today.
He was 98 years old.


European Nations Reaffirm Backing for Latin Peace Plan
LEAD: The European Community reaffirmed its support for the Central American peace plan today and said outside interference must cease in order to end the region's wars.


G.M. Unit to Buy Control of Mtech
LEAD: Mcorp, the Dallas-based bank holding company, said it had agreed to sell its 80.1 percent interest in the Mtech Corporation for about $281 million in cash and securities to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation.
Mtech is a provider of data processing and electronic-funds transfer services.


NATIONAL GAS &amp; OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Payment by IU
LEAD: The IU International Corporation disclosed today that it had paid $14.5 million in fees and expenses to a management group led by the Dean Witter Capital Corporation after the group's $21.50-a-share tender offer was terminated.
The $650 million Dean Witter Capital offer was ended after the IU board withdrew its recommendation that shareholders tender their shares to the group, because of a $22-a-share bid by Neoax Inc.

LEAD: The prices that farmers got for raw products in February declined an average of eight-tenths of 1 percent from January's prices but were still 6.6 percent above those a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

It was a cash deal and no further details were given.

LEAD: Steel production rose to 2.002 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of 3.1 percent from the previous week's 1.942 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 93.2 percent of capacity in the week, compared with 90.4 percent in the previous week.

Security Pacific To Buy Hibernia
LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding concern, agreed to acquire San Francisco-based Hibernia Bank for $160 million, or about one and a half times its book value.
Hibernia was put on the auction block by its parent, Hong Kong-based First Pacific Holdings Ltd., last summer.

Recital: Abbey Simon
LEAD: FOR better and for worse, Abbey Simon has remained throughout his long career just on the edge of the artistic spotlight, maintaining on the basis of reliable readings of the standard piano repertory a reputation unaffected by shifting musical tastes.
Mr.
Simon plays in a fluid, polished, self-effacing way, and his performances can be counted on to provide at least reasonable satisfaction and pleasure.

LEAD: MARIANNE SCHROEDER, a Swiss pianist who specializes in new music, made a powerful case for nine recent works in a Sunday-evening recital at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street.
Connecting several of the stylistically diverse works was a concern with sonic afterimages - the thinning sound of a densely harmonized chord, or even an emphatically thwacked single note, as its overtones fade away.

LEAD: The time was June 1987.

What were the conditions going to be for the next America's Cup match?
His boss wanted to know.

LEAD: The South African Government continued its nationwide crackdown on anti-apartheid groups today by proposing legislation to block foreign financing of political groups and individuals.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration, which has blamed Federal Reserve policies of last year for much of the slowing of the election-year economy, today applauded the new policies that Fed officials disclosed last week.

Bond Prices Steady in Listless Day

Japanese Unemployment
LEAD: Unemployment in Japan fell to a seasonally adjusted 2.7 percent in January from 3 percent a year earlier, but it was up one-tenth percentage point from the previous month, the Government said today.
The number of job holders rose in the 12-month period by 1.12 million, or 1.9 percent, to 58.28 million.

Desert Partners Makes Hostile Bid for USG
LEAD: After failing to negotiate a friendly merger with the USG Corporation, a partnership controlled by the Texas oilmen Jack E. Brown and Cyril Wagner Jr. today made a hostile tender offer of $42 a share, or $1.9 billion, for the nation's largest gypsum producer.


Mets' Miller in a Utility Role
LEAD: If you ask Keith Miller why he drove 1,000 miles in the middle of December, two months early for spring training, even before the Mets' new stadium here was completed, he says with absolute logic: ''The years pass.
I wanted to get going.'' Keith Miller is a 24-year-old rookie, and he wanted to get going because he had no job on a team loaded with stars.


Political Memo; 2 Steady Courses to Super Tuesday
LEAD: With all the uproar over candidates' changing their images, styles, strategies and deeply held beliefs, one of the striking facts about the 1988 Presidential campaign is that two of the strongest candidates are coming to next Tuesday's big array of primaries with almost exactly the same strategies that their campaigns outlined last spring.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page Monday about Ann B. Wrobleski, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, misidentified her alma mater.
It is Stephens College in Columbia, Mo.


Voter Surveys Approved
LEAD: A Federal judge gave the three major television networks the go-ahead today to take polls at Georgia voting places during the Presidential primaries next week.
CBS, NBC and ABC had sued state and Fulton County election officials to stop enforcement of a 1985 law prohibiting public opinion surveys within 250 feet of a polling place.


Former Agent Is Convicted
LEAD: Jim Abernethy, a former sports agent from Atlanta, was found guilty of a misdemeanor tampering charge tonight and received the maximum sentence of a year in jail and a $2,000 fine.


Music: A Bernstein Celebration
LEAD: LEONARD BERNSTEIN will not reach 70 for six months, but his friends and admirers could not wait.
They held a party for him on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, where ''A Leonard Bernstein Song Celebration'' was presented by Composers' Showcase.
The music was all by Mr.
Bernstein, a sampling of his output during nearly half a century of composing for the voice.


Piano: Jodie Gelbogis Recital
LEAD: MOST debut artists play to forlorn rows of empty seats, but Jodie Gelbogis enjoys a following that packed Weill Recital Hall to overflowing for her piano recital Sunday afternoon.
To judge by intermission talk, the audience still represented the traditional components (family, friends, congregation), but the scale was unusual.


Metromedia Raises Its Stake in Orion
LEAD: The Metromedia Company has increased its stake in the common stock of the Orion Pictures Corporation to 39.5 percent, from 30.9 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Metromedia said it received Federal clearance last Thursday to lift its stake in Orion, the New York-based producer of movies and television programs, to as much as 49.9 percent.

Stage: 'The Boob Story'
LEAD: AS Jane Gennaro's one-woman show, ''The Boob Story,'' opens, an eerily caressing recorded voice advertises the female body, using the vocabulary of fashion design to describe its components as parts of a wardrobe in which the hands and fingers are accessories.
Out of this ingenious conceit, the writer, comedian and radio personality has constructed a cautionary seriocomic monologue about breast fetishism in America and the perils of getting too much of what one wants.


Black Official Faults Tactics Of Sharpton
LEAD: A black Assemblyman today accused one of Tawana Brawley's advisers of ''tactics that encourage race war'' and ''cavalier use of words like 'racism' and 'fascism.' ''


You Can't Stand the Noise? Get an Anti-Noise Machine
LEAD: HIGH school physics students learn that matter is composed of waves - light waves, electromagnetic waves, sound waves -and that if two trains of waves are exactly out of phase and collide head-on they can cancel each other.
Engineers have toyed with the possibility of blanking out noise by bombarding offensive sound waves with their exact opposites, or anti-noise.

He was 80 years old and had been ill for six months, said his press agent of 15 years, Jeff Lenburg.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Volcker's Future
LEAD: Seven months since leaving the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker may have decided on another job, back at his alma mater.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Rangers have signed Tony Granato, a member of the United States Olympic hockey team.
Granato, a 23-year-old right wing who played at the University of Wisconsin, scored a goal and had seven assists in the United States' six games in Calgary, Alberta. . . .
Mary Decker Slaney has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon for the first time, organizers of the 10-kilometer race announced yesterday.


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1988
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The Government's main forecasting index was revised upward for December, avoiding the three consecutive monthly declines that are viewed as a signal of an imminent recession.
The index fell 0.6 percent in January, slightly more than most analysts had expected.
But private forecasters said they still expected the economy to expand, though sluggishly, in the next few months.

LEAD: Negotiators reported no progress today in resolving three primary issues in a 21-hour session on a contract for 9,000 movie and television script writers.


Date for Decision In Soccer Shifted
LEAD: The announcement of whether Brazil, Morocco or the United States will be awarded the 1994 World Cup soccer finals has been postponed by four days to July 4, the Federation Internationale de Football Association said today.


No Quick Arrests Seen In Police Officer's Killing
LEAD: Despite what he termed ''potentially fertile leads,'' the Police Department's Chief of Detectives said yesterday that no arrests were imminent in the slaying of a rookie officer in Queens last Friday.


The P.L.O., No and Yes
LEAD: The bottom may be about to fall out of the assumption that underlies Middle East peace negotiations.
The assumption has been that Palestinians would sit at the peace talks as part of the Jordanian delegation, and that the parties thus could sidestep direct dealings with the Palestine Liberation Organization.


Microwave Cooking
LEAD: GOOD salads can be among the more pleasant parts of dieting, with only two problems: dressings tend to be very fattening, and making special ones is time consuming.
That presents a difficulty, because it is a good idea when dieting to spend as little time as possible amid temptation in the kitchen.

LEAD: Eugene H. Remmer, the founder and chairman of Chemtex Inc., an engineering company that specialized in the export of technology to developing countries, died of cancer Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital.
He was 64 years old and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.

Coaches Help Authors Talk Well to Sell Well
LEAD: Marilyn Greene expects to be on television often this summer, so on this blustery winter day she was being put through her paces. ''When you sit, put your fanny back, cross your legs and incline forward into the camera,'' her speech coach, Dorothy Sarnoff, told her. ''Think of the 10 most hostile questions you do not want to be asked, and be ready to answer them succinctly with a smile on your face.


Corrections
LEAD: The Eating Well column in Living on Feb. 10 misidentified the owner of Frieda's Finest, a marketer of unusual produce in Los Angeles.
She is Frieda Caplan.


Dukakis and Bush Win Vermont
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis easily won the Vermont Democratic Presidential primary today, with the Rev.
Jesse Jackson the runner-up.
Vice President Bush defeated Senator Bob Dole in the Republican race.

LEAD:  BASEBALL  BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Jose Mesa, pitcher.
HOUSTON (NL) - Signed Billy Hatcher, outfielder, and Jim Deshaies, Jeff Heathcock, Manny Hernandez and Charlie Kerfeld, pitchers, to one-year contracts.

7.95% Offering By Fannie Mae
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $1 billion of new 4-year, 11-month debentures through various dealers.
With a coupon of 7.95 percent, the issue is priced at par.
The top yield is 34 basis points more than Treasury securities of similar maturity.

Mr.
Reagan declared that the United States would never sacrifice Allied interests to achieve an arms accord with the Soviet Union.
Page A10. (Agence France-Presse)


G.O.P SEES DEFEAT ON AID TO CONTRAS
LEAD: Furious over procedures set by the Democratic leadership for a House vote on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, Republicans today all but conceded defeat in their efforts to win passage of a rival aid package.

U.S. Struggles With Plan to Monitor Arms Treaty
LEAD: Though both the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to try to speed work on a new strategic arms reduction treaty, the Reagan Administration is still struggling to define a plan for monitoring the pact, according to Government experts.


John Kenny, 88, Dies; Founded High School
LEAD: John B. Kenny, co-founder and principal of the High School of Art and Design, formerly the New York School of Industrial Art, died Thursday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a long illness.
He was 88 years old.


Smoke Clears And Trains Are Cleaner
LEAD: Two weeks after smoking was banned on the Long Island and Metro-North Commuter Railroads, officials say, the cars are cleaner.


Inland Steel Sets Closing of 4 Mills
LEAD: The Inland Steel Company said it planned to close four mills at its Indiana Harbor Works plant in East Chicago, Ind., in 90 days, but that it was willing to ''discuss the proposal or to receive any alternatives to the proposed course of action.' At issue is Inland's proposal to separate its bar and structural steel business and then begin a $100 million modernization.


Sports of The Times; An Ode to Calgary
LEAD: THE last day has been crossed off the Olympic calendar, and by now, the bones of the Winter Games have just about been picked clean.
It seems so long ago, but this all began Feb. 8, on a flight from New York to Chicago, the first leg of a journey to Calgary that only a travel agent unaware that the shortest distance between two points is a straight line would have booked.


Girl Attacked by Ants Dies
LEAD: A 16-month-old girl bitten last week by a swarm of ants has died, a hospital spokeswoman said today.
The girl, Tiffany Cheatham, died Monday night at Sacred Heart Hospital here, said the spokeswoman, Kathy Musial.
Tiffany was taken to the hospital on Feb. 23 after a playful dog pushed her into an ant hill near her Florida Panhandle home in Navarre, 20 miles from Pensacola.


British Mail Carries Mark, 'Jesus Is Alive!'
LEAD: The Post Office today began postmarking nearly all letters mailed in Britain with the words ''Jesus Is Alive!'' as part of a private arrangement financed by an evangelist.


Lessons
LEAD: On a sand and gravel road, a stone's throw from where a winter sea breaks hard against the rocks, the past lives.
It is a white one-room schoolhouse with seven students and a teacher who makes her way to class along an icy path through a dark pine woods.


Commissioner Chosen for Suffolk's Troubled Police Department
LEAD: Daniel P. Guido, who assumed control of the Police Department in Stamford, Conn., only eight months ago, was selected today to lead the troubled Suffolk County Police Department.

NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1988
LEAD:  International A3-12


Eastman Kodak Is Offering $1.1 Billion of Notes at Par
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company is offering $1.1 billion of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.
Proceeds from the note sale, the underwriters said, may be used for various corporate purposes, including Kodak's planned acquisition of Sterling Drug Inc.
Originally Kodak had planned to sell about $750 million of notes.

Judge Accepts Settlement in a Baby M Suit
LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan has accepted an out-of-court settlement between the agency that brokered the Baby M surrogate child-bearing contract and Mary Beth Whitehead Gould and her former husband.


New Inquiry Is Sought on Meese
LEAD: The chairman of the Senate panel investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's financial disclosures today asked the Federal ethics office to determine whether Mr.
Meese had complied with regulations on conflict of interest in his personal investments.


Citicorp Rates Fall
LEAD: Interest rates fell for the second straight week at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper yesterday at an average rate of 6.5188 percent, down from 6.567 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 6.525 percent, down from 6.6226 percent.


Troops Raid Panama Radio Station and Seize Ex-Candidate; Strike Gains
LEAD: Heavily armed paramilitary forces burst into a radio station here this afternoon, beating a former presidential candidate badly before seizing him and 10 other people and forcing the station off the air.


Film: 'A Jumpin' Night' of Klezmer
LEAD: IN case the proclaimed revival of klezmer has somehow passed you by, you can catch up with the catchy music at ''A Jumpin' Night in the Garden of Eden.'' Klezmer (the word comes from the Hebrew for musical instruments) had its origins in the Middle Ages and was popular in the shtetls of Eastern Europe.

Pistons 117, Hawks 104: The Pistons scored the road victory despite a 50-point performance by Atlanta's Dominique Wilkins.


Determined Bidders for Federated; One Success After Another for Macy Head
LEAD: It remained unclear yesterday which of the two competing bids for Federated Department Stores Inc. would prevail.
But investors seemed to agree that the newest offer, from R. H. Macy &amp; Company, was no better than the one from the Campeau Corporation.
Federated's stock rose only $1.25, to $67.75, in heavy trading yesterday.

LEAD: The dollar fell marginally against most key currencies yesterday, reflecting what dealers called a narrow trading range that has emerged in the last several days.

De Gustibus; What's American Depends on the Cook
LEAD: REMEMBER when restaurant food meant French, Italian or Chinese?
Everything else was what you ate at home.
And whatever you ate at home was called home cooking.
It probably had an exotic accent if your parents were first-generation Americans, but it took a long time for those exotic ingredients to make their way into mainstream cooking.

Makers Display New Computers
LEAD: Three companies have introduced new high-powered computers.
Apollo Computer Inc. of Chelmsford, Mass., has a work station for engineers with supercomputer power that is priced from $69,900 to $130,000.


Saturn Hiring Begins
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's new car division has begun recruiting the first 3,000 workers for its Spring Hill, Tenn., factory, the Saturn Corporation said today.
The plant will begin producing Saturn vehicles in the summer of 1990 for the 1991 model year.


G.M. to Sell Plant
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has agreed to sell its Fairfield automobile parts stamping plant to Cynba International Inc. for an undisclosed amount.
Cynba, headed by an automotive executive, Anthony Barclae, would continue operating the plant, G.M. officials said.


Prominent U.S. Jews, Visiting Israel, Voice Unease
LEAD: This is the time of year when, by recent tradition, the leaders of American Jewish organizations meet with the leaders of Israel to cement and renew a bond.
This year, more than usual, the occasion is shot through with unease and worries framed in terms of war and peace and morality.


Bilingual Education Survives in California
LEAD: A year ago, advocates of English as California's official language were cheering their landslide victory in a statewide vote on the issue.
They looked forward to ending the state's bilingual education program.


Southwest Chief Journal; For Train Passengers, A Seminar on Indians
LEAD: Crossing a landscape of vast and haunting beauty as it hurries from Los Angeles to Chicago, the Southwest Chief looks like any of the remaining transcontinental passenger trains.
But twice a week, along the 160-mile stretch from Gallup, N.M., to Albuquerque, the train becomes a speeding mini-seminar on Indian


Marcum Dismissed
LEAD: Bob Marcum, athletic director at the University of South Carolina since 1982, was dismissed yesterday after a five-member task force investigating drug testing of athletes at the university found that no random testing had been done since the spring of 1986.
The university president, James Holderman, said at a news conference that the team physician, Dr.


An Operation For The Sphinx
LEAD: Experts started work today to see if they could repair the damage to the Sphinx.


Stage: Innaurato's 'Magda and Callas,' in Philadelphia
LEAD: With ''Magda and Callas,'' at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays, Albert Innaurato returns to South Philadelphia for a story dealing with such favorite subjects as grand opera, passion and motherhood.
In a neighboring backyard can be heard the lingering laughter of ''Gemini'' (the playwright's long-running Broadway comedy) but in the world of the La Selva family, there is a definite strain of solemnity beneath the jocularity.


Senators Discuss Bank Bill
LEAD: The Senate Banking Committee adjourned this evening without taking substantive action on a bill sponsored by Senator William Proxmire, its chairman, to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 and in the process increase the power of commercial banks to engage in activities that were previously restricted to the securities industry.


Securities Firms Streamlining Computer Systems Despite the Crash
LEAD: JOHN J. MURPHY, the manager of Paine Webber Inc.'s consumer market systems, originally expected to spend last Oct. 20 proposing to a management committee that the aging stock quotation machines used by Paine Webber's 4,000 brokers be replaced with personal computer-based work stations tied to powerful minicomputers.


Construction Spending Declines
LEAD: Construction spending fell 2.9 percent in January, the biggest decline in 10 months, reflecting widespread weakness in all sectors of the building industry, the Commerce Department reported today.


Debates Are Cancelled For Want of Debaters
LEAD: The League of Women Voters said tonight that it was canceling the Republican and Democratic Presidential debates that were to be held here Sunday because some candidates would not participate.


THE SOURCES OF DRUGS
LEAD: Major drug-producing countries that have diplomatic relations with the United States and the estimated amount of drugs, in metric tons, produced in each country.
Increases in Thailand are a function of changes in methodology and improvements in data, and may not indicate increased production.
Maps are not to scale.


Gorbachev Delays Meeting With U.S. Business Leaders
LEAD: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev has asked to postpone a long-scheduled meeting in Moscow this month in which possible business deals were to be discussed with more than 500 American corporate leaders and Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr., according to American and Soviet officials.
It was unclear when the meeting might be rescheduled.


Student Convicted In a Friend's Slaying
LEAD: A 17-year-old honor student and computer enthusiast was convicted yesterday in the killing of a longtime friend during a quarrel over an $85 printer.

LEAD: The World Bank, the third world's main source of loans, today reported a $679 million profit for the last half of 1987, up from $655 million a year before.

LEAD: To The Living Section:


U.S. FINDS OUTPUT OF DRUGS IN WORLD GROWING SHARPLY
LEAD: The State Department reported today that production of coca, marijuana and opium poppies in most drug-producing countries had grown substantially in the last year and that it was beyond the ability of any single government to control.


Southern Democrats Go Home Again
LEAD: Nancy McCoy has not backed a Democratic Presidential candidate since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, but next Tuesday, she says, she will vote in the Texas Democratic primary.


Justices Back U.S. Deportation Stand
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today that the Government has broad latitude to refuse to reopen deportation cases to hear belated assertions by aliens that they would be persecuted if returned to the home country.


The U.N. Today
LEAD: General Assembly  Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.
COMMITTEE ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.
SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON THE CHARTER - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.


Merrill Lynch Buys Grimm
LEAD: W. T. Grimm &amp; Company, a Chicago-based concern that specializes in the buying and selling of small and medium-sized companies and that monitors the pace of corporate acquisitions, has become a part of its own takeover statistics.


Stage: 'Cocktail Party' By the Cocteau Troupe
LEAD: CAN a play whose heroine is crucified by cannibals and devoured by ants be a real comedy?
As the production of T. S. Eliot's ''Cocktail Party'' by the Jean Cocteau Repertory at the Bouwerie Lane Theater reminds one, the play is definitely a comedy and, after 39 years, still resilient.
It helps a lot that Celia Copplestone's grisly demise is thousands of miles off stage, of course.


Revision of Economic Index Dims Specter of an Imminent Recession
LEAD: The Government today revised upward the December figure for its principal economic-forecasting index, ending a string of three consecutive monthly declines, which is sometimes considered a signal of an imminent recession.
It also reported that the figure fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, slightly more than most analysts had expected.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Culture and Rocks
LEAD: It appears Washington will go to considerable lengths to prove it has become culturally sophisticated city.


At NATO Parley, Reagan Reassures
LEAD: Asserting that military resolve had produced a treaty to dismantle medium-range missiles, President Reagan declared today that the United States would never sacrifice allied interests to get an arms accord with the Soviet Union.


Ferrer Urges Bronx Housing Renewal
LEAD: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, delivering his State of the Borough report.
He urged spending $100 million in state and city housing funds to rehabilitate 31 abandoned city-owned buildings along the Cross Bronx Expressway.
Mr.
Ferrer said the effort would provide homes for 1,500 families and help counteract the negative image of the Bronx held by motorists who use the expressway.


Brooklyn Double Murder: Mental Patient and a Flawed System
LEAD: After waiting more than 13 hours for a bed on an overcrowded psychiatric ward at Kings County Hospital last month, Nick Gavrilou told his doctors that he had made up the story he had been telling about stabbing someone, and was ready to go home.
The doctors agreed.
Eleven days later, as neighbors listened in horror behind their locked doors, the police said, Mr.


Potvin's Garden Finale
LEAD: The Islanders' Denis Potvin returns tonight to perhaps the most difficult building he has visited in his National Hockey League career.
Barring an encounter in the playoffs, this evening's game against the Rangers will be Potvin's final appearance at Madison Square Garden.
The 34-year-old defenseman, one of the most accomplished in the game's history, is retiring at the end of the season.

LEAD: The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. after a heated and dramatic court session in which the jury saw two subtly different re-enactments of how Jennifer Levin might have died.

Economic Scene; Frequent Fliers: Will I.R.S. Act?
LEAD: IS Uncle Sam planning to take the ''free'' out of frequent flier awards?


To Plug the Social Work Drain
LEAD: In the battles to erase poverty's terrible consequences, those on the front lines are apt to be social workers.
Yet low salaries are forcing professionals who staff voluntary human services agencies to flee the field by the thousands.
Interface, a group that analyzes public policy issues in New York, offers some imaginative ways to lure them back.


Robertson Seeks to Withdraw Libel Lawsuit
LEAD: Pat Robertson announced today that he was seeking to withdraw his $35 million libel suit against Paul N. McCloskey Jr., the former California Congressman who accused him of using his father's influence to avoid combat in Korea.


Question for Indonesia: Who Will Be No. 2?
LEAD: An assembly created to elect the next President and Vice President of Indonesia opened an 11-day session here today with a subdued ceremony, but amid lively public speculation over who will fill the second-highest position.

Wine Talk
LEAD: A HORIZONTAL tasting has nothing to do with the posture of the tasters.
It is a sampling of many wines from one vintage.
A vertical tasting, on the other hand, is a tasting of one wine from many vintages.

Head of Business Lobby Forms His Own Firm
LEAD: William Lilley 3d, the former CBS executive who has spent the last 18 months in Washington as head of a business lobbying group, announced yesterday that he was forming his own Washington-based concern to provide policy analysis, lobbying and communications services to corporate clients.


Court Upholds Ruling Against Racial Quotas for Starrett City
LEAD: A divided Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn must end its use of ''rigid racial quotas'' even if they were intended to promote integration.


Pillsbury to Keep Burger King, Despite Rumors
LEAD: The Pillsbury Company's stock soared early today in anticipation that the Minneapolis company's new top officer would announce dramatic plans like the sale of the Burger King chain.
But the shares fell back when he said he had no such intentions.

College Basketball; Syracuse Sets Back Villanova by 71-69
LEAD: Rony Seikaly scored on a reverse layup with 1 minute 25 seconds to play tonight as No. 12 Syracuse edged Villanova, 71-69, in a Big East Conference game.


Shultz Ends Mideast Tour Upbeat but Empty-Handed
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz ended his swing through the Middle East today without the general accord he had sought on principles of negotiation but with enough encouragement from the parties to lean toward a return trip at the end of the week.

LEAD: A chunk fell off the Sphinx the other day, and stirred more than just the dust in which it landed.


G.M. to Stop Building Pontiac Fiero
LEAD: Production of the Pontiac Fiero, a car hailed for its innovative design and manufacturing process when it was introduced in 1983, will stop at the end of the current model year, the General Motors Corporation said today.


Witt-Thomas a TV Hit
LEAD: More than 60 million people - the largest Saturday night television audience since the broadcast of ''Roots'' in 1977 - watched Katarina Witt and Debi Thomas duel for the Olympic gold medal in figure skating.


Victory on a Foul
LEAD: Julie Krone, who is involved in a race with Patty Cooksey for most career victories by a woman jockey, picked up her 1,200th triumph Monday night at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N.J., in an unusual fashion.
In the featured eighth race, Krone's horse, Explodom, had a head advantage over Flying Daisey as the horses neared the finish line when the opposing jockey, Armando Marquez, reached out with his left hand and grabbed Explodom's reins from Krone's right hand.

Britain to Sell Its Rover Stake
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C., the country's biggest aircraft manufacturer, will make an exclusive bid for the state-owned car maker Rover Group P.L.C. in an effort to prevent a foreign takeover, the Government announced today.


About Education
LEAD: Prof.
Lee S. Shulman, who may be in the process of revolutionizing testing in America, likes to tell this story.
A man asks his neighbor to return a pot he had lent him some weeks ago.
The neighbor replies angrily: ''In the first place, I never borrowed the pot.
In the second place, it was cracked when I borrowed it.

LEAD: THE largest solicitation of commercial and industrial development proposals in the 22-year history of the New York City Public Development Corporation was announced yesterday by the agency's president, James P. Stuckey.

'Carrie' Churns Toward U.S.
LEAD: It certainly sounds Bardic enough for the Royal Shakespeare Company's imprimatur, from the first-act bloodletting to the finale's mutual murder of mother and daughter.
But, more crassly, is it Broadway?


Washington Talk: Briefing; A View of Capital
LEAD: Playboy magazine's attitude toward women in the nation's capital has been evolving in the last dozen years.
A 1976 issue was billed ''The Girls of Washington.'' Four years later a similar collection was titled ''Women of the U.S.
Government.'' This summer, the magazine plans to display 12 models called the ''Women of Washington.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: I WAS walking on the East Side of Manhattan one afternoon when I saw a woman in slacks and a turtleneck standing outside the front door of a lovely old house.
I immediately crossed the street.
Anyone watching would have thought I was going out of my way to avoid someone I knew and disliked.
The truth was I was going out of my way to avoid someone I didn't know, but worshipped.


Racial Tension at Dartmouth As Teacher and Paper Clash
LEAD: A dispute between a black professor and a right-wing student newspaper has erupted anew, fueling racial tension at Dartmouth College and leaving four students facing disciplinary charges.


Ancient Redwoods Fall to a Wall Street Takeover
LEAD: Thousands of redwood trees are being felled along California's wild northern coast in an environmental drama that is arousing high emotions and demonstrating how decisions on Wall Street can affect people, communities and natural resources far away.


Advertising; ABP Group Sees Growth In the Sun
LEAD: THE ABP Group of New York, Dallas, Montreal and Toronto seems to have all the accouterments of a mega-agency except billings.
The giants bill in the billions of dollars, but ABP's total is around $60 million.


Court Rules In Belgium
LEAD: A Brussels appeals court today approved Societe Generale de Belgique's plan to increase its capital by 40 percent to weaken the stake of the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti, but left it to a higher court to give the final word on the issue.

LEAD: ''Corruption of government officials and law enforcement officers, bribery, trafficker intimidation and violence, and the stark fact that nations are outmanned, outgunned and outspent by narcotics traffickers, continue to undermine global efforts to stop narcotics production and trafficking.''


Determined Bidders for Federated; Canada Rebuff Led Campeau Chief to U.S.
LEAD: It remained unclear yesterday which of the two competing bids for Federated Department Stores Inc. would prevail.
But investors seemed to agree that the newest offer, from R. H. Macy &amp; Company, was no better than the one from the Campeau Corporation.
Federated's stock rose only $1.25, to $67.75, in heavy trading yesterday.

Hamlet In Central America
LEAD: To intervene or not to intervene?
That really isn't the question.
The litany enshrining non-intervention as a principle of Western Hemisphere relations arose from the U.S. dispatch of armed force and gunboat diplomacy, and on that level the taboo is clear enough.


Oil Drops Amid Confusion On Pricing by Exporters
LEAD: Prices of crude oil and byproducts resumed their decline yesterday amid confusing new reports about deep price discounting by some major oil-exporting countries.


American Standard To Sweeten Plan
LEAD: American Standard Inc., the object of a hostile $2.12 billion takeover attempt by the Black &amp; Decker Corporation, said it was sweetening the cash portion of a recapitalization designed to foil the offer.
The company said it was negotiating with unidentified parties about the possible sale of debt securities to increase the cash portion of the recapitalization plan, which would pay shareholders $1.9 billion and give them a stake in the recapitalized company.

LEAD: In a combative opening statement, Evan Mecham's lawyers today began defending the Governor in his impeachment trial here by charging that he was the victim of political persecution.

Cleveland Strike Goes On
LEAD: Classes resumed today for some high school seniors as a teachers' strike entered its seventh day.
The 5,093 members of the Cleveland Teachers Union struck Thursday in a contract dispute with the school board.
The district has nearly 73,000 students.

AGS to Acquire C3
LEAD: AGS Computers Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire C3 Inc., a computer systems integration company based in Herndon, Va., for $15.75 a share, or about $157.5 million.
C3 designs, assembles and maintains computer systems to solve the automation needs of the Federal Government.
AGS, based in Mountainside, N.J., is involved in computer automation of telecommunication and computer systems.


Strike in Panama Halts Most Activity in Capital
LEAD: Normal activity was paralyzed here today in the third day of a general strike called by opponents of this country's de facto ruler, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega.
Scattered outbreaks of violence were reported.

LEAD: REACHING the sixth of its 13 essays on modern American poets, ''Voices and Visions'' this week deals with a man who, in many respects, is the most intriguing of the lot. ''William Carlos Williams,'' produced and written by Jill Janows, can be seen at 10 this evening on Channel 13.

J.P. Steven's Stock Up
LEAD: Shares of J.P Stevens &amp; Company, which is considering a $985.6 million buyout offer from West Point-Pepperell Inc., rose $1.875 a share yesterday, to $56.375, prompting speculation that a higher bid might be made.
West Point-Pepperell, the nation's largest textile and apparel company, on Tuesday offered $56 a share, which topped a sweetened cash-and-stock offer, valued at $55 a share, from Stevens's senior management.


Sports People; Foul Play
LEAD: When two jockeys are thundering toward the finish line in one of those neck-and-neck duels, the will to win can sometimes get so intense that it's all a jockey can do to keep himself from reaching over and yanking on his rival's reins.
For one jockey, it seems, the impulse proved irresistable.
That, in the view of racing officials, was exactly what happened in the eighth race at Garden State Park Monday night when Armando Marquez found himself coming down to the wire with Julie Krone right by his side and threatening to beat him across the line.


Upheaval at Mortgage Insurers
LEAD: The private mortgage insurance business, which for decades has been a virtual money machine, is now running up losses at an alarming rate.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court, ruling that the Voting Rights Act of 1965 applies to election of judges as well as of legislators and executives, has revived a lawsuit aimed at creating a black-majority district for the election of Louisiana Supreme Court justices.

LEAD: The United Nations has drawn up plans to send a small military observer force to Afghanistan next May to monitor a peace agreement that would provide for the withdrawal of Soviet troops, a senior United Nations official said today.

Health; Trip Across Adolescence Is Just as Risky as Ever
LEAD: Despite revolutionary progress in preventing and treating life-threatening infections through immunization and antibiotics, teen-agers today are as likely to get sick and die before reaching their 20's as they were in the 1940's and 1950's.
Only the causes of death and disability have changed dramatically, shifting from traditional medical problems to health effects stemming more from social causes.

Nuclear Plant Release
LEAD: A ''puff'' of tritium escaped from the Department of Energy's Savannah River plant Tuesday, officials said.
They said the release from the plant that makes materials used in the production of nuclear weapons did not pose a hazard to the public.
The release of 20,000 curies of tritium, a radioactive isotope of hydrogen, was described as a puff that lasted less than a minute.

LEAD: One morning last summer, a teen-ager from New York climbed onto a sailboard at Camp Wapanacki, a camp for the blind in Hardwick, Vt.
Although he had never tried it before, he was sailing by afternoon.

This Is the Year to Kill the Wicks Law
LEAD: Over the next decade, New York City plans to spend $16 billion on major capital construction projects.
Count at least $1.6 billion as needless waste.
The reason?
The state Wicks Law, which bars use of a general contractor on public construction jobs.
Common sense cries out for repeal of this weight around the taxpayer's neck.

Tax Cuts in Hong Kong
LEAD: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary, Piers Jacobs, cut taxes on corporate profits and personal income in the 1988-89 budget released today.
Corporate taxes fell to 17 percent from 18 percent in the British colony, and the personal income tax base rate was reduced by one percentage point, to 15.5 percent.


U.S.-Japan Talk On Auto Parts
LEAD: Manufacturers of American auto parts are meeting with executives of 11 Japanese car companies in an effort to whittle away at a large trade deficit between the two countries in the auto parts industry.

The Dance: 'Labor Of Love'
LEAD: THE mood was lighthearted when Gail Donnenfeld and Rocky Bornstein presented their works on Saturday night at the Danspace Project at St.
Mark's Church.
But the two choreographers had more on their minds than simple, spirited fun.


Belgium Cuts Key Rates
LEAD: Belgium's central bank announced cuts today in two key interest rates to reflect the strength of the Belgian franc and international trends.
The bank said it would lower the discount rate to 6.5 percent from 6.75 percent and the Lombard rate to 6.75 percent from 7 percent, effective Thursday.
The discount rate is the interest the central bank charges to member banks.


Plan to Bar CD Piracy Is Called Inadequate
LEAD: A system designed by CBS Records to prevent the recording of compact disks onto digital tape is inadequate, a Government agency has reported after a five-month test.


Piano: Aldo Mancinelli In Recital
LEAD: ALDO MANCINELLI devoted the first half of his piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday evening to Brahms's big F minor sonata, and tackled it whole: One sensed an awareness of the broad scope that informed each contributing episode.
It was an authentic experience of the piece, even though the tone grew rather hard and worked sounding in sustained loud passages.


Paint That Turns to Stone
LEAD: WALLS can be painted to look like stone.
They can also be painted to feel like stone.


Jazz; Randy Weston at Davis Hall
LEAD: THE great jazz pianist Randy Weston opened his concert at Davis Hall Saturday night with a majestic, improvised solo.
Chords peeped out from under rumbling ostinatos.
Thelonious Monk-ish whole-tone flurries and brilliantly colored Ellingtonian note clusters added decoration.
Walking bass lines anchored cascading washes of notes, and Mr.

LEAD: Preston Robert Tisch, who has just retired as Postmaster General, may wind up with an organization that usually works only on Sundays - the New England Patriots.

LEAD: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today that if South Korea and other Asian nations did not end what he called unfair trading practices, they would face retaliation and curbs on their exports.

Pagliarulo Insists On Pride and Heart
LEAD: By the end of last season, as September was turning to October and the Yankees had settled hopelessly into fourth place, Mike Pagliarulo kept playing every day in pain.
He could not fully straighten his right arm nor could he make throws from third base without discomfort.


'Sewer Wars'
LEAD: Some might call it ''sewer wars.'' Last year President Reagan vetoed legislation to provide $2.4 billion a year for building sewage treatment facilities, asserting that it was too much money.
Congress promptly and overwhelmingly overrode the veto.


Rock: Bosho, a Band
LEAD: KUMIKO KIMOTO'S percussion setup - gongs, cymbal, cowbell, tambourine, Roto-tom tunable drum, electronic sound generator and a hubcap - just about summed up the music of Bosho, the six-piece band that performed Monday at Dance Theater Workshop.
Bosho sets in motion Western and Eastern, new-fangled and down-home sounds, layering them into crafty, off-center funk.

LEAD: ADOLESCENCE is marked by battles over power and control.
It is a time of physiological stress as your child copes with what seems like a conquering army of hormones.
It's also a time of emotional stress as he tries to adjust to the new demands made by family and school.
That combination can test the mettle of even the most resilient parents.

New Postmaster General
LEAD: Anthony M. Frank, a San Francisco banker, took office Tuesday as head of the United States Postal Service.
He is the fourth Postmaster General in four years.
Mr.
Frank succeeds Preston R. Tisch, a New York businessman who had held the post since Aug. 6, 1986.
Mr.
Tisch replaced Albert V. Casey, who held the job for seven months.


Navistar Outlook
LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation, the truck manufacturer that returned to profitability in 1987 after a string of losses, said it hopes for a small increase in profits this year despite the rising cost of steel and labor.
Neil Springer, chairman of the Navistar International Transportation Corporation, the Chicago-based company's chief operating unit, said plans were under way to expand its trucking and parts businesses with acquisitions in related industries.

Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: John Kruk, the first baseman for the San Diego Padres, has reached an agreement in principle on a two-year contract.
Kruk, 27 years old, batted .313 in 138 games last season and hit 20 home runs with 91 runs batted in. . . .
Bruce Sutter threw batting practice for five minutes during the Atlanta Braves' workout yesterday, and Manager Chuck Tanner said the right-hander's work was encouraging.


Death Also Came to the Opera in 1897
LEAD: To the Editor:


52 Charged in Poaching Case
LEAD: An investigation has led to the arrest of 52 people suspected of operating a $100 million poaching ring that dealt in tiger, bear, sea lion and rhinoceros parts, state officials announced Tuesday.
Twenty-three other people in Southern California are expected to be charged as a result of a 23-month investigation by the California Department of Fish and Game.


Mansfield Returns
LEAD: Mike Mansfield, currently the longest serving United States ambassador, returned to his post in Tokyo Tuesday after undergoing heart bypass surgery in Washington two months ago.


The World's Only Passenger/Container Ship to Be Berthed in Brooklyn
LEAD: The 19,500-ton M/V Americana arriving in New York Harbor en route to the Red Hook Terminal.
The Ivaran Lines ship, which can carry 108 passengers and 1,120 cargo containers, will be the first since World War II to serve passengers from a Brooklyn terminal. (NYT/Neal Boenzi)


Palestinian Fights Palestinian After Rumor of Collaboration
LEAD: Between impassioned telephone calls to plead a case that might bring a beating or death, the Palestinian lit one cigarette after another in his office here today and said that, yes, he was very nervous.


NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; Costly Homes For Bucktown
LEAD: A CHICAGO builder has turned to an unlikely neighborhood on the Near North Side of the city for a development of higher-priced single-family homes.


Abrams Ends Contract Approval for Indicted Company
LEAD: The New York State Attorney General's office said yesterday that it had withdrawn approval for a $57.6 million highway construction contract in Queens after it learned that a state agency had negotiated confidential provisions with a company under indictment for bid-rigging.


Layoffs Planned By Campbell Soup
LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said that it would lay off 460 workers at a Chicago plant and that it intended to save $10 million by trimming its white-collar work force.
The company said it had begun a hiring freeze and early retirement programs, and a spokesman said additional layoffs might be made.


Jazz: Paul Bley Quartet
LEAD: THE pianist Paul Bley revels in vagueness: at the first set Tuesday at Sweet Basil, leading a quartet, he opened several tunes without a melody; time floated in and out, solo orders were called out in the middle of compositions.
All this caused apprehension, as if the relationship between the audience and the band members mirrored an uncertain relationship between two friends.


Cocoa Prices Fall to Lows; Oil Contracts Are Weaker
LEAD: Cocoa futures prices set new life-of-contract lows yesterday for the fourth straight trading session on fears that the International Cocoa Organization will be unable to control the effects of rising production.
Oil futures prices closed weaker after struggling from a sharp selloff earlier in the day.


Yields Are Down a Bit
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed small declines for the week ended yesterday.


Sandinistas Call for Ouster Of Mediator in Peace Talks
LEAD: The Sandinista Government said tonight that it was ready to hold high-level talks inside Nicaragua next week with leaders of United States-backed contra guerrillas.

LEAD: A portion of United States aid to Jamaica is being blocked because of a property dispute between the Jamaican Government and a Congressman's friend, the Congressman said today.

LEAD: To train for an air strike near the Persian Gulf, the two F-15 Eagle fighters streaked toward the target low to the ground, slipped over a ridge and up a valley, then climbed through clouds into the sun to protect the attack force behind them against hostile planes.

HERS
LEAD: ''I WANT us to be like a family,'' said the creative director interviewing me for a job in advertising.
I began to sweat, and it wasn't just the usual interview anxiety.
The word family does not evoke pleasant memories, reassurance or a sense of security in me.
He continued, ''I like people to think of this company as home.


Sports People; License Revoked
LEAD: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has revoked the license of Steve Adika, a jockeys' agent, for illegally intercepting the simulcast signal that is beamed to offtrack betting parlors.
The board said that Adika intercepted the signal in 1986 and that he has since tried again by offering a bribe to a technician employed in the simulcasting operation.


Frank E. Brown Dies; Archeologist Was 79
LEAD: Frank E. Brown, an archeologist and former director of the American Academy in Rome, died of a stroke Sunday at the Lely Palms Health Care Center in Naples, Fla., where he had lived for the last year.
He was 79 years old.


Candidates Can Land on TV Just by Landing
LEAD: In the frenzied campaign for the multiple primaries and caucuses next Tuesday, Presidential aspirants are engaged in the frequent-flyer version of whistle stop campaigning.
They jet from airport to airport in the hope that their mere presence will get them on the local evening news programs.
It almost always works.

LEAD: Poppe Tyson, a subsidiary of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon &amp; Eckhardt with offices in New York and Union, N.J., has promoted Fergus O'Daly, 44-year-old president and creative director, to chief executive.
The title was formerly held by Ron Vrba, 54, who is chairman.

LEAD: It now appears likely the Senate will begin debating the new treaty eliminating medium and shorter range nuclear weapons without the participation of Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, who played a key role in framing the issues for that debate.


Dollar Stronger on Rumor That U.S. Policy May Shift
LEAD: The dollar strengthened in foreign exchange trading yesterday, especially against the Japanese yen, partly because of a rumor that the Reagan Administration would tolerate a higher value for the dollar.

LEAD: There is one notable bridge personality who ought to be in the Guinness Book of World Records in one category, and has a good claim in another.


U.S. to Let Bristol-Myers Market AIDS Drug
LEAD: The Federal Government has said it intends to give exclusive marketing rights for an experimental AIDS drug to the Bristol-Myers Company.


Higher Sales Buoy Atari's Results
LEAD: The Atari Corporation today reported operating gains for the fourth quarter and all of 1987 as sales increased.
The computer maker was hampered, however, by a write-down related to Atari's October acquisition of the Federated Group, a troubled electronics retailer.

Du Pont Cleanup
LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company will pay $39 million to clean up ditches, lagoons and other groundwater sites contaminated by hazardous waste that seeped from its Chamber Works plant here, a company official said.
The cleanup, part of an administrative consent order with the state Department of Environmental Protection, was described as the largest settlement by one company for one location in the United States.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. The door chime in our house is in the entrance foyer, and I can't hear it when I am working in the basement.
Can I install a second chime that will sound at the same time the upstairs one does?
A.
Yes.
Run a three-conductor cable (or three wires) from the existing chime to the new one so that one wire connects each terminal on the old chime with the matching terminal on the new chime.

Fund Senate Campaigns? No Lowell P. Weicker; Lowell P. Weicker is Republican Senator from Connecticut.
LEAD: For the eighth time, an all-time record, legislation to federally fund Senate campaigns has come to the floor but not to a final vote.
Despite the filibuster, the majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, promises to repeat the exercise.
If he does, constitutional principle, not a selfish desire to line politicians' pockets, will be at stake.

LEAD: SOMEDAY, if Brian Addison Elliott has his way, there will be a television set that walks and responds to the viewer's voice.


Utility Stock Sale
LEAD: The Western Massachusetts Electric Company, a subsidiary of Northeast Utilities, is offering $53.5 million in preferred stock through Salomon Brothers Inc.
The financing is part of a program to help lower the utility's borrowing costs.
The initial annual dividend rate on the preferred stock is 6.375 percent and is effective for 62 days.

LEAD: The Polish Communist Party formally acknowledged today that an anti-Semitic campaign drove thousands of Jews from the country in 1968, but the party did not accept full responsibility for it.

MCA 'Poison Pill'
LEAD: In an apparent effort to block a takeover threat posed by the developer Donald J. Trump, MCA Inc. tightened the trigger on its takeover defense, making it effective if any shareholder acquires 10 percent of its stock.
The original plan, which was adopted last July, would have taken effect when a 20 percent stake was acquired.

Munich Defeats Madrid
LEAD: Bayern Munich beat Real Madrid, 3-2, in the first leg of a European Champion Clubs' Cup last night but allowed goals by Emilio Butrageno and Hugo Sanchez in the final three minutes.
Bayern and Real will meet in Madrid in two weeks in the second leg.
The team with the most total goals will advance to the semifinals.


Trial Set in Killing of 16
LEAD: A man accused of killing 16 people, including 14 members of his own family, is competent to stand trial, a judge has ruled in setting a May 9 trial date.
The man, R. Gene Simmons, 47 years old, surrendered to the police Dec. 28 after a shooting spree left two former co-workers dead and led to the discovery of the bodies of his wife; four daughters; three sons; two spouses of his children; three grandchilden and a child who officials say he fathered by his oldest daughter.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: CHRONIC mildew on walls and ceilings, peeling paint that exposes bare material underneath (not just earlier coats of finish), sweating window panes and crumbling plaster: these problems frequently are signs of indoor condensation.
Most often this condensation - water in household air changing from vapor to liquid -occurs in winter.


German Output Up 2.2%
LEAD: West German industrial production rose 2.2 percent in January from December, the Economics Ministry said today.
The ministry adjusted December's increase to three-tenths of a percent after previously reporting a seasonally adjusted gain of five-tenths of a percent.

Court Adds Hurdle to Suing Localities for Officials' Acts
LEAD: The Supreme Court, splintering in three directions with no majority opinion, today made it harder for victims of unconstitutional actions by local officials to win damages from local governments.


F.A.A. Chief Rules on Exit Closings on Jetliners
LEAD: An effort to close off two of the 10 doors on Boeing 747 jumbo jets operated in the United States was apparently scuttled today by the head of the Federal Aviation Administration.


Davis Jury, in 8th Day, Lacks Verdict
LEAD: The jury in the trial of Larry Davis, who is accused of the execution-style murders of four suspected drug dealers in the South Bronx, concluded its eighth day of deliberations last night without reaching a verdict.


Luring Japanese to Buy Condos in New York
LEAD: An ad in the Japanese magazine The Worldwide, aimed at getting Japanese investors to buy Manhattan condominiums, an undertaking that is gaining acceptance.
