Strawberry Is Fined Again
LEAD: Gary Carter was named co-captain of the Mets today so he could help Keith Hernandez maintain discipline among their teammates.
And he didn't have to wait long for his first challenge: Darryl Strawberry was late for work and was fined by Manager Dave Johnson, who has fined and even benched Strawberry for the same offense in the past.


FINAL DECISION DUE IN SWAGGART CASE
LEAD: National officials of the Assemblies of God, unable to agree with Louisiana leaders of the pentecostal denomination on a punishment for the Rev.
Jimmy Swaggart, have passed the case to an appeals body for the final decision.


Topics of The Times; The President's Line-Item Bluff
LEAD: In his State of the Union address, President Reagan complained about Congressmen who subordinated fiscal policy to politics by inserting extravagant pet projects into the budget - like cranberry and crawfish and wildflower research.
Then he challenged them: ''In 30 days, I will send back to you, as recisions, those items which, if I had the authority to line them out, I would do so.


Concert for Children
LEAD: Rosenshontz, a musical duo comprised of Gary Rosen and Bill Shontz, is to present a special concert for children tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Manhattan Center High School, 116th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.
Youngsters in the audience will be able to participate in a program of original songs that deal with issues dear to children, such as eating vegetables, parting with one's security blanket and refusing to go to sleep.


The Law; Ethics Peril for Lawyer: Seeing a Trial as Drama
LEAD: When Roswell Gilbert pumped two bullets into the brain of his ailing wife of 51 years, Emily, he saw it as an act of mercy.
The prosecutor saw it as calculated murder.
So did the jury.


U.S. Officials Criticize Soviet On Verification Negotiations
LEAD: The United States criticized the Soviet Union today for refusing to engage in detailed talks on verification issues for a treaty to reduce long-range arms.

Touring America by Subway
LEAD: AIRLINES and travel agents are wont to advertise their wondrously inexpensive getaways to the beaches of California and Hawaii, the mountains of Colorado and Montana, or the urban delights of Chicago and New Orleans - but the best bargain tour of the United States can be taken with only a handful of subway tokens and a hearty dose of imagination.


Episcopal Women Seek Bishop Posts
LEAD: Even while the Church of England remains deeply torn over whether to ordain women as priests, its sister Episcopal Church in the United States is moving toward the consecration of women priests as bishops.


Chancellor Green's Good Fight
LEAD: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Richard Green, marched to the stage at Erasmus Hall High School yesterday accompanied by six kindergarten students, members of the high school graduating class of the year 2000.


Disguised Tamil Rebels Kill 15
LEAD: Tamil rebels in Sri Lankan Army uniforms shot to death nine children and six adults Wednesday in an attack on homes of ethnic Sinhalese, a senior military officer said today.


Film: Turner in 'Switching Channels'
LEAD: SOME eccentric inspirations are better than others.
In its own day, the idea of the safety pin sounded crazy as well as dangerous.
There were also people who groaned when Howard Hawks decided to remake ''The Front Page'' with Rosalind Russell as Hildy Johnson.
Not only did Hawks change Hildy from a man into a woman, but he introduced a love-hate sexual relationship between Hildy, the star reporter of Chicago yellow journalism in the 1920's, and Hildy's manic, unscrupulous editor, Walter


Mets' Fragile Pitchers Pass Their First Test
LEAD: The Mets tested two of the biggest question marks on their pitching staff today, and came up with a couple of small exclamation points.


Music: Chamber Orchestra of Europe
LEAD: IN prospect, the program by the Chamber Orchestra of Europe at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening looked unusually appetizing.
The group, formed in 1981, was appearing under the baton of its artistic director, Claudio Abbado, whose appearances in New York are rare enough to insure expectations of quality music making.


Stake in Christie's Bought by Phillips
LEAD: Phillips Son &amp; Neale, a London auction house, said it had acquired a 5 percent stake in the much larger Christie's.
The auction house bought 1.6 million shares from a Kuwaiti investor, the Al Futtooh Investment Company.


Art: The Taut Paintings Of Philip Pearlstein
LEAD: IT may be difficult to like Philip Pearlstein's paintings, with their perpetual rearrangements of inert, expressionless and usually female nudes.
Still, it is also difficult not to respect them.
This mixed response, a dilemma of sorts, has never been clearer than it is at the artist's current exhibition of new paintings at Hirschl &amp; Adler Modern.

LEAD: W. Clement Stone and his wife, Jessie, agreed to sell 1.4 million shares of stock in the Aon Corporation back to the company for $25.95 a share.
The $36.3 million transaction, agreed to Wednesday, was disclosed just days after the Alberto-Culver Company announced it had repurchased 866,802 of its shares from Mr.

Magazine Is Ordered to Pay $9.4 Million for Killer's Ad
LEAD: A jury today ordered Soldier of Fortune magazine to pay $9.4 million in damages to the family of a woman whose husband hired her killer through a classified advertisement in the magazine.


Contra Aid: Ups and Downs in Congress
LEAD: The House rejection of a contra aid plan yesterday continued a fluctuating pattern of Congressional support for such assistance.
The fiscal-year figures below do not include money from other sources - for example, from a contingency fund, from third countries, or from the Iran-contra arms sales.


44 Slain in Sikh-Hindu Violence
LEAD: At least 32 people were killed and 25 wounded when gunmen attacked a village crowd celebrating a Hindu festival in the Punjab Thursday night, the state government said today.
Another 12 people were killed in separate incidents Wednesday night.


Sewall Wright, 98, Who Formed Mathematical Basis for Evolution
LEAD: Sewall Wright, a geneticist who was widely regarded as the foremost American evolutionary theorist of the 20th century, died of complications yesterday after suffering a hip fracture Sunday in Madison, Wis., where he lived.
He was 98 years old.
Dr.
Wright, an avid walker, suffered the injury when he slipped on the ice near his apartment.


AIDS Fight: Public Data Or Secret?
LEAD: When a 26-year-old man died in a respirator fire two weeks ago at New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital, the hospital announced he was an AIDS patient, making public the confidential information that had not even been disclosed to his family.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Congressman's move to withhold some American aid from Jamaica because of a land dispute involving a friend misstated a State Department official's objections to the move.
The official said the Congressman's friend, John W. Rollins, had not sued the Jamaican Government to recover the disputed property; he did not say Mr.


Charles Feinberg, 88, A Whitman Collector
LEAD: Charles E. Feinberg, a book and manuscript collector who specialized in the works of Walt Whitman, died Tuesday of heart failure at Mt.
Sinai Hospital in Miami.
He was 88 years old and maintained residences in Detroit and Florida.

George V. Horton, 76, Country-Music Singer
LEAD: George Vaughn Horton, a country-music songwriter and performer, died Monday of a heart attack at his home in New Port Richey, Fla.
He was 76 years old.

British-Soviet Contract
LEAD: A British engineering contractor, Simon-Carves Ltd., has signed a contract for $:246 million, or $435 million, to build a plant for making nonstrategic computers in the Soviet Union, British diplomats said today.
Each year the plant will be able to turn out 25,000 programmable logic controllers - devices that control conditions like assembly line production.

Panama Runs Into a Cash Crisis, Forcing Banks to Limit Dealings
LEAD: Fears that the United States Government and American banks plan to freeze all payments to the Panamanian Government caused a severe cash shortage here today.
The central bank was unable to meet some obligations, and leading commercial banks were forced to limit withdrawals and other transactions.

LEAD: Marilyn Crispell is to play a piano recital tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (662-2133).
Admission is free.

Spotlighting the Stars Of New York Cabaret
LEAD: ACROSS New York this evening, as stage lights dim on the first night of the first weekend of Cabaret Month, the mood of the city's nightlife should be unusually buoyant.
Because of the recent overturning of a law forbidding clubs without cabaret licenses to have more than three musicians (including a singer) onstage together, many clubs will have more musicians than they could have had a year or even two months ago.

Diet Candy Seeking Name
LEAD: The manufacturer of the diet candy Ayds is seeking a new name for its product because publicity about the deadly disease AIDS is hurting sales, the chairman said today.


Goalie Joins Devils on Decline
LEAD: The Devils were totally dispirited after their 6-1 loss to Washington Wednesday night.
It was their second loss in two nights to the Capitals and the fifth in their last six games, making New Jersey the front-runner to be the first team eliminated from a playoff spot in the Patrick Division.


Setbacks for Artificial Intelligence
LEAD: A major retrenchment is occurring in the artificial intelligence industry, dashing the hopes of many companies that thought they would prosper by providing the technology to make computers ''think.''


Road Runners Race
LEAD: Central Park is to be the site for two races Sunday morning sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club.
At 9:30, a one-quarter mile race for those 2 to 6 years old is to begin at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue.
At 10, a five-mile race for men is to begin at the same location, followed at 10:15 by the start of a five-mile race for women.


ALL U.S. FUNDS NOW HALTED
LEAD: The House of Representatives today unexpectedly defeated a Democratic plan to provide $30.8 million in food, clothing and medical aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.
The vote was 216 to 208.


Bush and Dole Campaign Aides Differ Sharply in Mood and Consistency; Tension Seen in Senator's Staff
LEAD: At a meeting at Senator Bob Dole's Presidental headquarters the other morning, the deputy campaign chairman, Bernard M. Windon, called the staff together and spoke quietly.


TGI Friday Chief Quits To Find His Own Chain
LEAD: J. Michael Jenkins thinks the time is right for acquiring a restaurant chain, and he is leaving his posts as president and chief executive of TGI Friday's Inc. to find one.


Kentucky Reprimanded
LEAD: A National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation of the basketball program at the University of Kentucky, started by a series of newspaper articles, produced no proof of wrongdoing, according to David Berst, the N.C.A.A. director of enforcement.
In the official finding the Committee on Infractions released yesterday, Kentucky was reprimanded for not fully cooperating with the long investigation and was ordered to monitor athletic expenditures and report their results to the N.C.A.A.


Auctions
LEAD: Jack and Belle Linsky's wide-ranging art collection - Old Master paintings, Renaissance bronzes and jewelry, French 18th-century furniture and European porcelain figures -was thought to have been thoroughly documented in their lifetimes.
The couple, who were partners in what Mrs.
Linsky used to describe as ''our stationery business'' - it included Swingline, the manufacturer of staplers that they sold to American Brands for $210 million in 1970 - concentrated on buying period works for more than 40 years.

Mexico Accepts $3.67 Billion In Debt Exchange for Bonds
LEAD: Mexico said today that it had accepted $3.67 billion in bids from foreign banks in its innovative program to swap debt for bonds.
The figure was slightly more than a third of what Mexico was hoping to receive.

LEAD: The dollar was little changed against major currencies yesterday, and trading activity was the lightest in more than a year, according to some dealers.

LEAD: The knifing of a Jewish teen-ager was followed today by a Purim carnival parade in this city of 70,000 Palestinians encircling 40 Jewish families.
The events produced a confrontation of faiths and visions so raw it almost hurt to witness them.

Musica Sacra
LEAD: Musica Sacra, under the direction of Richard Westenberg, is to perform Mozart's ''Coronation'' Mass, Verdi's ''Four Sacred Pieces,'' Giovanni Gabrielli's ''In Ecclesiis'' and motets by Richard Strauss at Avery Fisher Hall at 7:30 tonight.
Soloists in the Mozart and Strauss works are Rebecca Copley, soprano; Catherine Robbin, mezzo-soprano; Jon Humphrey, tenor, and Kevin McMillan, baritone.

Matthews Retires
LEAD: Saying he was not interested in a second-string role, Gary Matthews, the 37-year-old outfielder who in 16 major league seasons compiled a .281 batting average with 234 home runs and 978 runs batted in, announced his retirement as a player yesterday.
Matthews, who picked up the 2,000th hit of his career last Aug.


Lilco Rejects A Bid to Delay Annual Meeting
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company today refused to postpone its annual meeting in May, a postponement that state officials had said was crucial to continue negotiations on avoiding a possible public takeover of the utility.


Korea's Trade Surplus
LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus more than tripled in February from a year earlier on the strength of exports, the Government reported this week.
It said that last month's surplus rose to $524 million from $158 million in the 1987 period.
The surplus for the first two months of this year rose to $810 million from $683 million, it said.

Henryk Szeryng, Violinist, Dies; Player in Romantic Style Was 69
LEAD: Henryk Szeryng, one of the more elegant representatives of a now fading school of Romantic violin playing, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday in Kassel, West Germany.
Mr.
Szeryng was en route to Brussels for a concert celebrating the current NATO conference and for an appearance at an AIDS benefit.


Dr. Beverly Smith, 92; Helped Found Hospital
LEAD: Dr.
Beverly Chew Smith, a general surgeon and a founder of Doctors Hospital, died of a heart ailment Sunday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 92 years old.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1988
LEAD: COMPANIES  Macy is expected to contest the legality of Campeau's latest tender offer for Federated Department Stores.
The Macy strategy apparently will be to contend that the offer represents a new bid, not an amended proposal, and that it violates Federal laws and a Delaware anti-takeover statute.


Expert Analyzes Mark Found on Levin's Neck
LEAD: A mark on Jennifer Levin's neck was left by an object ''identical to or similar to'' the face of Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s wristwatch, an expert on analyzing photographs testified yesterday.


Two Chinese Leaders Are at Odds Over Economy
LEAD: Two senior Chinese leaders are struggling over control of fundamental economic policies, diplomats and other foreign specialists here say.


Two Doctors Charged In Sick-Leave Scheme
LEAD: Two Manhattan doctors were arrested and charged with illegally selling disability certificates to undercover agents of the Transit Authority, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced yesterday.


Brain Graft Seeks to Relieve Huntington Disease Patient
LEAD: Doctors have removed an adrenal gland from a 41-year-old man and grafted it into his brain in an attempt to relieve symptoms of Huntington's disease, a fatal brain disorder.


Electric Voltage Dips As a Fire Breaks Out At a Con Ed Station
LEAD: Electrical voltage dipped throughout New York City and Westchester County yesterday afternoon as a fire of unknown origin heavily damaged a Consolidated Edison transmission station in Yonkers and two power lines there failed.


U.S.-Built Vehicle Sales Surged in Late February
LEAD: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks rose 25 percent in late February from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.


NEW KABUL OFFER IN AFGHAN PARLEY
LEAD: The Communist-backed Kabul Government made a new offer at the Afghanistan peace talks here today, apparently leaving Pakistan's conditions for the makeup of a government after a Soviet withdrawal the major remaining obstacle at the negotiations.


Film: 'And God Created Woman'
LEAD: THERE are few real constants in this world, but surely Roger Vadim's gift for girl-watching looked like one of them.
So it's sad to see Mr.
Vadim's lecherous eye let him down.
Whatever it was that possessed him to remake his 1957 ''And God Created Woman,'' the film that launched Brigitte Bardot, it was not the discovery of a voluptuous and comparably kittenish new star.


Advertising; Taylor Studies Three Agencies
LEAD: W. A. Taylor &amp; Company, which markets alcoholic beverages, has narrowed the field of competitors for its advertising business down to three agencies: Waring &amp; LaRosa, part of the Omnicom Group; Della Femina, Travisano &amp; Partners, part of the WCRS Group, and the William Esty Company, part of Saatchi &amp; Saatchi.


Steven Lubin: A Man of Many Modes and Pianos
LEAD: It is perhaps a little easy, at this advanced point in the progress of the early-instrument movement, to forget the practical difficulties it involves for a keyboard player.
Steven Lubin, best known as a fortepianist, would be game in theory for the idea of playing his Mozart, Beethoven and Chopin on three different period pianos tomorrow night at the 92d Street Y.


College Basketball; Missouri Upsets Oklahoma by 93-90
LEAD: Derrick Chievous had 35 points and 18 rebounds, and Doug Smith broke an 88-88 overtime tie with a slam dunk tonight as Missouri beat fourth-ranked Oklahoma, 93-90, in overtime in a Big Eight Conference game.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds decreased $1.51 billion, to $278.51 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds decreased $1.28 billion, to $81.74 billion.
Assets of the 208 general-purpose funds were up $230.5 million, to $81.67 billion.


New York Tests a Boot Camp for Inmates
LEAD: At precisely 5:30 A.M. today, a bugle blared reveille, and 32 Sixth Platoon men leaped from their bunks.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about a suit by a group of homosexual Catholics against trustees of St.
Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan misidentified the law under which the group, Dignity, contends its rights have been violated.
It is Section 1983 of Title 42 of the United States Code, which was enacted shortly after the Civil War.


Butler Is Seeking Larger Bear Stake
LEAD: A group led by the New York-based Butler Capital Corporation, an investment banking firm, is asking Federal antitrust regulators for permission to increase its holdings in Big Bear Inc. to up to 25 percent from 8.8 percent.
Butler has said previously that it was considering a merger with Big Bear.


Looking Foolish on the P.L.O.
LEAD: Pandering to Israel's supposed interests, Congress ordered the Justice Department to shut down the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission at the United Nations.
This move showed contempt for international law and American ideals of free speech, and Congress now reaps the humiliating rewards.

U.S. Wine Export Spurt
LEAD: Soaring sales to Japan and Britain helped to send total United States wine exports in 1987 to 11.87 million gallons, up 64 percent from the previous year, the Wine Institute, a trade group, has reported.
The dollar's decline was the main cause, the institute said Wednesday.
United States exports totaled $60.8 million in 1987, up from $34.8 million the year before.


Foe Seeks to Revive Suit
LEAD: An attorney for Mr.
Swaggart argued in a state appeals court here today that Mr.
Swagaart and his colleagues had been bound by church rules and the Bible to spread their accusations of adultery against a rival evangelist, Marvin Gorman.


Roll-Call in House Defeating Plan Providing Aid to Contras
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 216 to 208 today by which the House of Representatives defeated a plan to provide $30.8 million in food, clothing and medical aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.
A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the aid package.
A ''no'' vote was a vote against it.
Voting ''yes'' were 203 Democrats and 5 Republicans.

Trial Set in Killing of 16
LEAD: A man accused of killing 16 people, including 14 members of his own family, is competent to stand trial, a judge has ruled in setting a May 9 trial date.
The man, R. Gene Simmons, 47 years old, surrendered to the police Dec. 28 after a shooting spree left two former co-workers dead and led to the discovery of the bodies of his wife; four daughters; three sons; two spouses of his children; three grandchilden and a child who officials say he fathered by his oldest daughter.

Northbound Lanes of Damaged Queens Expressway To Reopen
LEAD: Workers preparing a foundation for shoring under damaged section of the Van Wyck Expressway in Flushing.
The section between Northern Boulevard and Whitestone Expressway was closed Wednesday after three beams supporting southbound viaduct were found to be seriously corroded.
Northbound lanes are expected to reopen by morning rush hour today.

Eugene H. O'Sullivan has joined McCann-Erickson's New York agency as executive vice president, deputy general manager.


Reed Works Magic for Nets
LEAD: It was not easy to get through by phone to the New Jersey Nets' offices yesterday at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
A ''please hold'' greeted most callers to the home of the team with a 14-42 record.


Restaurants
LEAD: RICHARD KRAUSE, a tall, reedy Californian, looks more like a bass player for the Grateful Dead circa 1970 than a leading New York chef.
An alumnus of Spago in Los Angeles, he made his mark here at Batons, which closed last fall, before opening his own place, called Melrose, last October.
After an early shakedown period, both the light salubrious food and the service have improved markedly.

G.E. Shows Lower Profit
LEAD: The General Electric Company, the nation's largest producer of electrical equipment, said in its 1987 annual report released this week that it earned $398 million, or 44 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1987, compared with $730 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier.
Earnings for the quarter had not previously been disclosed.

U2 Wins Top Grammy Prize
LEAD: ''Honest music,'' said Bono Vox of U2, won two top Grammy Awards for the Irish rock band and its album, ''The Joshua Tree.'' At the 30th annual Grammy Awards ceremony, telecast live from Radio City Music Hall Wednesday night after six years of broadcasts from Los Angeles, U2 won album of the year and best rock performance by a duo or group.


Study of AIDS Patients Finds No New Infectious Pathways
LEAD: A study of 2,059 AIDS patients who appeared to have become infected from unknown sources has found no new pathways for the spread of the deadly disease, Federal researchers have reported.

IU Drafts a Plan To Counter Neoax
LEAD: Neoax Inc. said that it had been informed by the IU International Corporation that the IU board was meeting to consider a new recapitalization plan to defeat Neoax's $22-a-share hostile bid.
The plan calls for selling all of its assets other than its environmental services unit for $460 million to a management group led by the Dean Witter Capital Corporation.

Film: From Italy, 'Traffic Jam'
LEAD: ''TRAFFIC JAM,'' Luigi Comencini's 1978 Italian film, begins as if it were going to be a light-hearted, satirical variation on Jean-Luc Godard's apocalyptic classic, ''Weekend.'' Instead it becomes a very heavy, rather literal forecast of the decline and fall of capitalism through gridlock.

LEAD: The Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, is presenting ''An Evening of Villa-Lobos'' at 8 tonight.

The performers include Alfred Heller, pianist; Debra Mitchell, soprano, and Jue Yao, violinist.

CLUE IN THE SPREAD OF AIDS VIRUS SEEN
LEAD: The AIDS virus has been found to infect the lining of the cervix, which may help explain how the disease spreads in sexual activity and childbirth, according to a study made public today.

LEAD: The willingness of the 18 Senate Banking Committee members to agree to a compromise package in approving a landmark banking bill on Wednesday night will go a long way toward securing passage in the full Senate this spring, Senators and Banking Committee aides said today.

LaFontaine to Rest
LEAD: Pat LaFontaine, the leading scorer for the Islanders this season, did not practice yesterday and is listed as doubtful for the team's games tomorrow and Sunday.
LaFontaine, whose streak of 161 consecutive games ended Wednesday night when he sat out the 3-1 loss to the Rangers, has been hampered by a sore right knee that was bruised in a game against the Vancouver Canucks nine days ago.

Sunday at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street.
Offered as part of the Music Before 1800 series, the performance features Margery Daley, a soprano, in the title role.

Peru Sentences Guerrillas
LEAD: Two leftist guerrillas have been sentenced to 25 years in prison for assassinating an admiral who was president of a Peruvian state bank, a court spokesman said today.

25 Trampled in China
LEAD: Twenty-five people were trampled to death in two Chinese cities, and at least 220 others were injured during celebrations Wednesday of the Lantern Festival.
Eighteen people were crushed to death in Xining, capital of Qinghai province, when 100,000 people who turned out to watch a lantern procession panicked, the official New China News Agency said today.


New Big Board Official Versed in Automation
LEAD: Richard A. Grasso, a man instrumental in improving the back office operations of the New York Stock Exchange, was named yesterday as the exchange's next president, replacing Robert J. Birnbaum, who is retiring.
The appointment becomes effective on June 2.

Gretzky's Influence
LEAD: Joey Ferras, a senior center for the Plattsburgh State hockey team in upstate New York, comes from Brantford, Ontario, the hometown of Wayne Gretzky.
With a goal and two assists in a 7-5 loss to Oswego State on Wednesday night, Ferras became college hockey's leading scorer at all levels, running his total to 355 points.


State Report Says Koch Overestimated Revenue
LEAD: The New York State Comptroller, in a twist on the prevailing criticism of the Koch administration's spending plan for fiscal year 1989, said yesterday that the Mayor had overestimated by as much as $125 million the tax revenue New York City will receive next year.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Never the Twain?
LEAD: It looks as if Congress will be out on the town March 16, with Democrats and Republicans heading in different directions.


Robertson Promises Not to Impose His Religious Views on Americans
LEAD: Concerned by skepticism about his commitment to separation of church and state, the former evangelist Pat Robertson said in a statewide 30-minute television address today that he neither desired nor sought to impose his religious views on the people of America.


2 Held in Execution-Style Slaying Of Officer Outside Queens House
LEAD: Two men have been arrested and will be charged in connection with the execution-style killing of a rookie police officer early last Friday, the authorities announced late last night.


New Zealand Deal
LEAD: New Zealand's largest company bought the Government's 70 percent stake in a local oil and gas explorer and distributor for about $528 million, the State-Owned Enterprises Minister, Richard Prebble, announced.
Fletcher Challenge Ltd. will pay the same per-share price for the Government's stake in the Petroleum Corporation of New Zealand as British Gas earlier offered.


Film: 'House on Carroll St.'
LEAD: ''THE HOUSE ON CARROLL STREET'' unfolds in a beautiful, clean city, a place of safe subways and balmy summer breezes, a peaceful, romantic urban landscape bathed in warm golden light.
This place, strange and delightful as it may seem, is in fact New York.
But the city's appearance (which is made spectacularly lovely by Michael Ballhaus's magical cinematography) is deceptive, for the time is 1951.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Bruins 5, Maple Leafs 3: Reed Larson converted a pass from Geoff Courtnall with 2 minutes 15 seconds left to snap a 3-3 tie in Boston.
Larson's goal came 38 seconds after Gary Leeman tied the score for the Maple Leafs, tapping in Tom Fergus's rebound.
Cam Neely scored into an empty net with 6 seconds left.


Seton Hall Gains In Women's Play
LEAD: Seton Hall used a 19-5 spurt early in the second half tonight to overcome a 6-point deficit and defeat Georgetown, 72-63, in the first round of the Big East Conference women's tournament at Pitt.


Art: 3 Shows at Brooklyn Museum
LEAD: DESPITE its relatively low profile among New York City's leading art institutions, the Brooklyn Museum remains conspicuously active.
Three diverse shows have recently been mounted by the ambitious institution, which at the same time is organizing a tremendous expansion.
Starting next Friday, master plans by the five finalists who competed to redesign the museum will be publicly displayed for the first time.


Dismissed Aide Issues Comment
LEAD: Bob Marcum, the athletic director at the University of South Carolina until he was dismissed Tuesday, said he discovered only last week that the school's drug-testing program was ineffective.


Airlines Lift Fares
LEAD: Leading airlines raised fares yesterday for the second time within two weeks, reflecting an unexpected strength in passenger traffic during the usually slow winter season.


West German Freed in Beirut After 5 Weeks
LEAD: A West German engineer who was kidnapped here five weeks ago was freed today.


Group Offers $45 a Share for Koppers
LEAD: In a surprise takeover bid that is expected to escalate quickly, Beazer P.L.C., a British construction company, offered yesterday to pay $1.1 billion in cash for the slightly more than 92 percent of the Koppers Company that it does not already own.


Art: Versailles Palace In Swedish Perspective
LEAD: ''VERSAILLES: The View From Sweden'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is on more than one count a remarkable exhibition.
Made up entirely of drawings from Swedish sources, it looks good, it isn't too big, it is very amusing and it is consistently instructive.
We see great architecture and great gardens as they were set down on paper by the people who designed them, but we also get to read the small print of history.


Topics of The Times; Monumental Indifference
LEAD: For more than a million sunrises, the Egyptian sphinx has guarded the Pharaohs' mysteries with implacable calm.
Nothing has shattered its unblinking meditation; a cannonball fired by Napoleon's army only broke its nose.

With more than 2.1 million shares traded, AFG's shares climbed $4.75, to $37, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Art: Five Sculptures By Richard Deacon
LEAD: RICHARD DEACON'S second solo show at the Marian Goodman Gallery offers New Yorkers the best evidence yet why this 38-year-old Briton is one of the best sculptors around.
The five very different works, all at the same time eminently reasonable and wildly enigmatic, give a clear sense what this artist's seductive and demanding sculpture is about.

He was 89 years old.

Volatile Mix of Empire and Glasnost
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of loosening controls, applauded by the West, creates inevitable complications.
These have never been more apparent than now, in Armenian and Azerbaijani protests.
Moscow's looser grip gives the more than 100 Soviet ethnic groups room to stretch.
But the stretching will not come without pain - for the ethnic groups as well as the Soviet leaders who must fashion a response.

Margaret C. Braun, 74; Served on Staff of U.N.
LEAD: Margaret Cunningham Braun, a member of the United Nations international staff for 28 years, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 74 years old.
In the early 1940's, she was a staff member of the United Nations Information Office, an intergovernmental agency that helped prepare for the founding conference of the United Nations in San Francisco in 1945.

Tolleson's Job Slips Away
LEAD: The mornings begin to blend into one another down here.
Players - from veterans to rookies hoping to make a lasting impression - follow identical routines: they arrive as the sun is still rising, change into their uniforms, read the local newspaper, pour themselves cups of coffee.
Every day at the same time, they gather on the outfield grass to stretch and to work.

LEAD: A 15-year-old defendant on trial here for murder is said to have killed a classmate for a thrill, then showed the corpse to friends who stayed mum about the killing for weeks.


Fairfield Protest Denied
LEAD: The Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference denied a protest by Fairfield University yesterday after its basketball team lost by 63-60 to St.
Peter's in the first round of the conference tournament Wednesday night in Jersey City.


Nicklaus Finds Trade-In Is a Good Deal
LEAD: Although he calls himself an ''old traditionalist,'' Jack Nicklaus broke with his old ways today and played a competitive round of golf using a metal driver.


Wholesale Club Venture by K Mart Is Seen
LEAD: The K Mart Corporation today will announce its entry into the field of wholesale clubs through a joint venture with SHV Holdings, a Dutch company, people close to the big American retail chain said.


Carriers Improve Record
LEAD: On-time peformance by the nation's major airlines improved slightly in January, but 3 of every 10 flights were still at least 15 minutes late, according to the Department of Transportation.


Batus Bid for Farmers Raised to $63 a Share
LEAD: Rebuffed in its first attempt to acquire Farmers Group Inc., Batus Inc. sweetened its tender offer today to $63 a share, or a total of about $4.5 billion, for the nation's seventh-largest insurance holding company.
Batus's original offer was $60 a share.

Former Connecticut Banker Indicted on Insider Charges
LEAD: Two Federal grand juries, one in Boston and the other in New Haven, indicted the former chairman of a Connecticut savings bank today on charges of insider trading, perjury and other offenses in connection with a stock trading investigation of the bank's merger with a Maine savings bank in 1986.


Coping: With a Consumer Problem
LEAD: Robert J. Pearl, a lawyer in Rochester, ordered a tennis racquet from a mail-order company.
The day before he was to play in a tournament, the racquet had not arrived, so Mr.
Pearl bought one at a local store.
When the racquet he had ordered was delivered, he returned it.
But the company refused to send him a refund, insisting that it had fulfilled its obligations.


Israel Curbs Coverage of the West Bank
LEAD: Israel sought for the first time today to close the entire occupied West Bank to journalists, but a military spokesman denied that the move represented new restrictions on coverage.


South Carolina Votes Today In Test of Bush's Momentum
LEAD: Three contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination crisscrossed the state today, striving to pull their campaigns out of the doldrums in time for the South Carolina primary on Saturday and the Republican balloting in 17 other states on Tuesday.


22 on Commuter Plane Die in Crash Near Paris
LEAD: A twin-engine commuter plane flying from eastern France to Paris crashed near the capital this morning while waiting to land, killing all 22 people aboard, aviation authorities said.


2 More Arrests in Officer's Death
LEAD: Two more men were arrested yesterday in the execution-style slaying last week of a rookie New York City police officer.


Southland Sells Reddy Ice Unit
LEAD: The Southland Corporation said it had sold its Reddy Ice subsidiary to the Kaminski-Engles Capital Corporation, an investment firm, for an undisclosed amount of cash.
Reddy Ice is a major producer of fragmentary ice and operates seven plants in Texas, Florida and Nevada.


Woman Hurt in Fall As She Flees a Blaze
LEAD: A woman fell five stories yesterday while trying to escape an apartment fire that the authorities said was set by a man who had argued with her roommate.


Data on Jobless Fail to Relieve Koch's Gloom
LEAD: Despite data showing unemployment in the New York region at its lowest level in almost 18 years, Mayor Koch warned yesterday that the consequences of the stock market plunge in October might yet undermine the city's economy.


3 White Men Charged in Attacks on Blacks
LEAD: Three white men were charged yesterday with beating a black woman who had refused to have sex with them and then randomly attacking other blacks in the Bronx.

2 Seen as Favored For Regents Posts
LEAD: A Staten Island surgeon and a retired executive for the Eastman Kodak Company are likely to be elected to two vacant seats on the state Board of Regents, officials in the State Legislature said yesterday.


Tiny Indiana School A Step Closer to Fame
LEAD: The Bobcats of Oregon-Davis High School in tiny Hamlet, Ind., kept up their winning ways tonight with a 59-54 victory over neighboring North Judson High, moving a step nearer the regional basketball tournament.


No Clowning, Please
LEAD: One day after he walked off the field and called his teammates clowns for playing a practical joke on him, Kirk Gibson, the new millionaire with the Los Angeles Dodgers after nine years in Detroit, returned to the outfield yesterday for an exhibition game against the Minnesota Twins.
Gibson was about to make his debut in Dodger blue Thursday in Vero Beach, Fla., when he discovered that someone had smeared eye black inside his cap and that it had rubbed off on his head.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: With Marvin Powell in retirement after undergoing several knee operations, George Martin of the Giants was selected yesterday to succeed him as president of the National Football League Players Association.
Martin, a defensive end with 13 years of N.F.L. experience and seven years of service as the Giants' player representative, was elected during the second day of a three-day meeting of the union's player representatives in Washington.


Wet Going
LEAD: A pedestrian walking across a rain slicked intersection yesterday in Manhattan.
Sunny skies and seasonable temperatures are expected for today. (The New York Times/Angel Franco)

S.E.C. Backs Banking Bill
LEAD: After winning concessions from Federal banking regulators, the Securities and Exchange Commission has voted unanimously to support Congressional efforts to modify or repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, the law that maintains a barrier between banks and the securities business.


Rhoden Enjoys Spring Debut
LEAD: On any other day, Rick Rhoden would have spent the afternoon boasting about his hitting.
But today, after he pitched for the first time in almost six months and tested his right shoulder, he hardly seemed concerned about Manager Billy Martin's successful experiment batting him second in the lineup.

LEAD: The Upjohn Company said today that it had signed a letter of intent with the Chugai Pharmaceutical Company of Tokyo to form a joint venture that would develop and market drugs.

LEAD: Electric rates for the 820,000 customers of Jersey Central Power and Light Company will rise as high as 2 1/2 percent, the state Board of Public Utilities announced today.


General Services Chief to Quit
LEAD: The head of the General Services Administration, Terence C. Golden, said Thursday that he planned to resign on March 18.

LEAD: The Koch administration dismissed 45 provisional employees of the New York City Emergency Medical Service last night after a one-day job action in which almost half the technicians and paramedics who were scheduled for duty called in sick during two shifts.

NORTHWEST CITED BY F.A.A. ON SAFETY

GUIDEPOST
LEAD:  Mortgage Shopping  As spring approaches, the start of the home-buying season begins.
Just in time, mortgage rates have been dropping.
A fixed-rate 30-year mortgage is lower than last years' high of about 11.25 percent, while an adjustable-rate mortgage is down from about 8.25 percent.
Adjustable rates are attractive to first-time home buyers as well as trade-up buyers because of the initial low rate.

LEAD: Musicality sometimes manifests itself in odd ways.

It is 93-08 209th Street in Queens Village.

Afghan Talks' Mediator Sees Main Issues Settled
LEAD: The mediator in the Afghan peace talks said today that the two sides had removed all significant obstacles to an agreement ending the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan and that country's eight-year-old civil war.


Extension for Reardon
LEAD: Jeff Reardon, the relief pitcher whose 31 saves helped Minnesota to the American League pennant and then victory in the World Series last year, has agreed to a one-year contract extension for 1989 that will pay him $1.15 million, with incentives that could be worth an extra $250,000.
This season he will earn $850,000, the same as in 1987.


About New York; At 76, Alumna Is What's New On Campus
LEAD: One nasty afternoon this week, 30 or 40 students who have been thinking about careers came in from a rain that blew across the city horizontally, shook off their slickers and assembled in an overheated room at New York University to hear the remarks of a 76-year-old businesswoman.
The woman, May Gruber, had, among other achievements, taken a company with $12 million in annual sales in 1963 and more than trebled the gross.

LEAD: Chicago's wealthy MacArthur Foundation is providing $4.5 million to put Alistair Cooke's 13-part ''America'' series and 19 other public television classics on the shelves of 4,000 public libraries across the country next month for use by borrowers.


Dartmouth Ends Week of Rallies In Effort to Curb Campus Racism
LEAD: An open meeting on campus racism today brought to a close a week of anti-racism rallies, marches and forums at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., where a disciplinary hearing is to be held Saturday for four white students accused of harassing a black professor.


IU and Neoax Discuss $670 Million Merger
LEAD: The IU International Corporation, which has sought to elude a takeover by Neoax Inc., said today that it was negotiating with Neoax to be acquired for $670 million.


Insurance Rates Rouse Drivers to Protest Ways to Cut The Premiums
LEAD: Automobile insurance rates are rising sharply across the country, continuing a five-year trend.
In a few states premiums for private passenger cars are increasing so fast that the public is protesting vocally and sometimes dramatically.


A Royal, Though Stormy, Greeting in Pittsburgh
LEAD: Prince Charles after arriving in Pittsburgh.
He toured old steel mill towns and offered encouragement for better times ahead, while British and American planners studied ways to revive industrial wastelands. (NYT/Scott Goldsmith)


Ernest L. Cuneo, 82; Owned News Service
LEAD: Ernest L. Cuneo, lawyer, writer and former owner of the North American Newspaper Alliance, died Tuesday at the National Hospital for Orthopedics and Rehabilitation in Washington after a heart attack.
He was 82 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.


Campeau, May in Deal on Federated
LEAD: The Macy-Campeau tussle for Federated Department Stores Inc. continued yesterday, while one of the rivals took steps to cash in.

LEAD: Robert E. Chambers Jr., right, waiting in a car as the jury viewed the site in Central Park where Jennifer Levin's body was found.

Flaws Found in Shuttle Safety Study
LEAD: The space agency has many groups assigned to assess the safety of launching space shuttles, but its efforts are fragmented and lack objective measures for evaluating the hazards, a National Research Council panel said in a report made public today.


G.M.'s Rebates
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it had added two cars to its buyer incentive program, which has been extended by a month, to March 31.
The Oldsmobile 88 model will carry a sales rebate of $750 and the Ninety-Eight model $1,000.


J. Saunders Redding, 81, Is Dead; Pioneer Black Ivy League Teacher
LEAD: J. Saunders Redding, a historian who is believed to have been the first black to teach at an Ivy League institution, died of heart failure Wednesday at his home in Ithaca, N. Y. He was 81 years old.


Decker Tops Standard's New Offer
LEAD: A billion-dollar seesaw battle for American Standard Inc. continued to escalate yesterday as the Black &amp; Decker Corporation outbid the company's latest proposal to remain independent.


3 Quit a U.S. Panel in Protest
LEAD: Three prominent conservatives have resigned from the Reagan Administration's Panel on Teen Pregnancy Prevention, charging that it is doing more to promote teen-age sex than prevent it.


Swedish Group Is Singular In Ability to Switch Partners
LEAD: Three decades ago, the top-ranked American team was highly flexible.
Its players could change partnerships freely, an advantage when an individual was tired, sick or unavailable.
That flexibility disappeared around the world when more sophisticated bidding methods made their appearance, but there is one country that is an exception.


American Volunteer Is Seized By the Nicaraguan Guerrillas
LEAD: An American volunteer was among a group of people taken captive Tuesday by contras in a northern village, associates of the volunteer said today.


Jury in Chambers Trial Inspects Site of Killing
LEAD: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. went to Central Park yesterday for a cold and muddy tour through the trees just off the East Drive, where Jennifer Levin's body was found.
They stayed about eight minutes before returning to their buses.


Drug Enforcement Role For Military Is Opposed
LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that he would strongly oppose any effort to create an active law-enforcement role for the military in the campaign against drugs.


Wigglesworth Birthday
LEAD: To mark Frank Wigglesworth's 70th birthday, which was Thursday, a program of the composer's music is to be offered at 3 P.M. today at the New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street.
The composer is to be at a reception afterward.
The program includes two new works, ''Autumn Songs'' and a string trio, as well as an earlier trio, ''Lake Music'' for flute, and a choral work, ''Short Mass Without Credo.

Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 5, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


Shallow Thinking on Public Pay
LEAD: Governor Cuomo of New York doesn't believe high state officials deserve high salaries, himself included.
He offers stinging criticism of the salaries paid to a few top executives of public agencies like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Battery Park City Authority and the Urban Development Corporation.


Dollar Slips and Gold Gains As Fears of Inflation Grow
LEAD: The dollar slipped yesterday against most major currencies as a new report on unemployment in the United States indicated that the economy might be stronger than expected.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''It is ridiculous to consider white women as minorities in the same way that blacks and Hispanics and other ethnic groups are minorities.
When I was a kid, water fountains were labeled 'white' and 'colored.' They were not labeled 'white,' 'colored' and 'women.' ''  - Ralph C. Thomas 3d, executive director of the National Association of Minority Contractors.


Rattlesnake Bites Handler
LEAD: A reptile expert who was bitten by his own rattlesnake was in guarded condition today at St.
Joseph's Medical Center here, a hospital spokesman said.
The man, Albert Kilian of Stamford, was taken to the hospital Thursday night after being bitten at his home, officials said.
The Stamford police picked up a special serum at Norwalk Hospital to treat Mr.

Ellery Queen's 'Double Lives'
LEAD: Walking through the exhibition of the Ellery Queen documents that opened to the public last week in the rare book and manuscript hall of Butler Library at Columbia University, a visitor can envision a large part of the history of the modern detective story - from policiers to political thrillers.
The show leaves the strong impression that the American detective story has made as original a contribution to the literary arts as the American musical comedy has made to the


Ashkenazy Cancels Recital
LEAD: Vladimir Ashkenazy's piano recital on Thursday at Carnegie Hall has been canceled and will not be rescheduled.
Mr.
Ashkenazy's management said he is indisposed.
Requests for refunds on tickets will be accepted until April 11.
Refund requests for tickets purchased through Carnegiecharge should be mailed to Carnegiecharge, Carnegie Hall, 881 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y.


Progress at Greek-Turkish Talks
LEAD: The Prime Ministers of Greece and Turkey continued a month-old effort to move toward reconciliation today by agreeing to set up committees to deal with two contentious questions: people declared missing after the fighting in Cyprus in 1974, and military flights in airspace claimed by the other.


In Wilds of Manila, a Hunt for Lost Treasure
LEAD: Looking like a diminutive Indiana Jones in his broad-brimmed hat, Charles McDougald sat at a dimly lit folding table inside an old Spanish dungeon and talked of buried treasure.


Banker May Join Fed Board
LEAD: Frederick Heldring, chairman and chief executive of the Philadelphia National Bank and vice chairman of its parent, the Corestates Financial Corporation, is a leading candidate for a seat on the board of governors of the Federal Reserve, Government officials said today.


Sandinistas Go on the Political Offensive
LEAD: With social tensions increasing in Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government is striking back against growing pressure for another round of political concessions.


Care of Mental Patients Challenged in Lawsuit
LEAD: As an emergency program to relieve overcrowding in New York City psychiatric wards got under way, an advocacy group filed a lawsuit yesterday charging that city hospitals were illegally turning away hundreds of other mentally ill people.


Along the Amazon, Conservation of Fish Could Be Harmful
LEAD: To the Editor:


Spain Curbs Public Smoking; Health Warnings Are Ordered
LEAD: Spain, a country with one of Europe's heaviest concentrations of smokers, today banned smoking in most public places, prohibited tobacco sales to those under 16 years old and ordered the placement of health warnings on cigarette packages and vending machines.


Bonds Fall Sharply on Job Report
LEAD: Bond prices tumbled yesterday after the Labor Department reported an unexpectedly large increase in the nation's employment for February.

LEAD: A South Orange police officer, clinging to the hood of a moving car that was reportedly being stolen, shot and killed the teen-age driver yesterday by firing through the windshield, authorities said.

LEAD: As acquisition candidates go, the Rover Group P.L.C., Britain's largest auto maker, is hardly a prize.

LEAD: When Chip Beck won the Los Angeles Open last Sunday for his first victory in the 10 years he has been on the PGA Tour, Bobby Wadkins became the only golfer to have earned more than $1 million on the Tour without a single victory.

LEAD: Two employees of a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., the oil services company, this week settled civil charges that they illegally purchased stock in the Texas International Company in 1985 while possessing inside information about the discovery of a major oilfield in Egypt by Texas International.

LEAD: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company looked beautiful on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater.

An Injudicious Choice for Judge
LEAD: In its twilight months, the Reagan Administration has nominated for the prestigious U.S.
Court of Appeals on the West Coast a California lawyer named Bernard Siegan, a man distinguished for his extreme conservatism.
Legally speaking, he is so far out that Robert Bork, who was rejected for the Supreme Court for being out of the mainstream, calls some of his ideas ''revolutionary.


Jazz: American Orchestra
LEAD: After two years of struggle, financially and musically, the American Jazz Orchestra began its third season on Thursday evening at Cooper Union with a concert that was its finest realization so far of its intention to make performances of classic jazz a vital, living experience rather than copies of old records.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about Garrison Keillor misidentified the distributor of his radio show, ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' The show, which was produced by Minnesota Public Radio, is distributed by American Public Radio.

LEAD: A doctor was ordered yesterday to pay back $178,000 from a Medicaid fraud in which she filed for bills and prescriptions issued by a former messenger working as a doctor, a prosecutor said.

Cabaret: Amy Coleman in Beatles Songs
LEAD: One measure of the staying power of the Beatles' music is the amazing adaptability of the Lennon and McCartney song catalogue.
In their original versions of songs like ''Yes It Is,'' ''If I Fell,'' ''I'll Be Back'' and ''Run for Your Life,'' to name several of the songs that Amy Coleman covers in her revue of Beatles songs, ''Face to the Wall,'' the Fab Four evoked a winsomely witty romantic ambiance.

Phillips Collection Wins Grant for Renovations
LEAD: The Phillips Collection in Washington is the recipient of a $750,000 challenge grant from the Kresge Foundation of Troy, Mich.
The money is to be used for the renovation of the Phillips Collection annex, which will include additional gallery and storage space and conservation facilities.
The annex is expected to be completed early next year.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  3 Swiss Women Hurt: Heavy snowfall and poor visibility caused crashes yesterday that led to season-ending injuries for Maria Walliser, Vreni Schneider and Beatrice Gafner of Switzerland and forced postponement of a World Cup downhill race in Aspen, Colo.
Walliser, the defending World Cup overall champion; Schneider, the double Olympic gold medalist, and Gafner will miss the rest of the World Cup season with knee injuries, according to a physician for the Swiss team.


Tektronix Plans To Lay Off 1,000
LEAD: Tektronix Inc. said it would lay off about 1,000 employees as part of a restructuring that might result in a third-quarter loss.
Tektronix, which makes electronic instruments and computer graphics equipment, said the layoffs were necessary because expenses have been outpacing revenue growth.
Tektronix said that 300 workers would be laid off today and that the layoffs would be complete by May 28, the end of its fiscal year.


Tribute to Howser
LEAD: Dick Howser's name and likeness became a permanent part of Florida State University's baseball heritage yesterday as the school began a scholarship program and named its baseball complex in Tallahassee in Howser's memory.
The Kansas City Royals, whom Howser guided to a World Series championship in 1985, joined in the festivities as Dick Howser Stadium was officially dedicated in honor of the former major league player and manager who died of brain cancer last June at the age of 50.


BANKS IN PANAMA ORDERED TO CLOSE
LEAD: The Panamanian Government today ordered all banks here to close ''until the supply of dollar bills can be regularized.'' The move was intended to avoid a run on deposits that would force banks into insolvency and touch off a general financial collapse.

LEAD: A Presidential advisory panel today recommended increasing the cost of mailing a first-class letter by 3 cents, to 25 cents.

LEAD: Todd Scott and Scott Cobb, two of the four men arrested in the slaying of a New York City police officer, are convicted felons who have managed to swagger through the criminal justice system like they do the drug-infested streets of southeast Queens, where police sources say they are low-level dealers.


The Republicans Cut Off the Contras
LEAD: The House vote Thursday against all further aid to the Nicaraguan rebels was a mistake.
House Speaker Wright's plan for non-military funds would have kept the contras afloat while supporting the Central American peace talks.
But the Reagan Administration and Republican legislators seemed more interested in gaining a campaign issue against the Democrats than in serious negotiations - or helping the contras.


Baseball by the Boardwalk
LEAD: George Brett couldn't resist it. ''I saw the thing go around a hundred times a day,'' he said. ''I had to go on it.
I'm glad I got it out of the way.
It's scary.
That thing flies.'' Brett, the Kansas City Royals' fearsome first baseman, was talking about the Hurricane, the roller coaster at the amusement park that is the Boardwalk part of Boardwalk and Baseball.


Corrections
LEAD: A heading in the Metro Datelines column on Thursday misstated the year in which two police officers were slain by Thomas Trantino in Lodi, N.J.
The murders occurred on Aug. 26, 1963.

He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan and Edgartown, Mass.

LEAD: Fred Smith, a 6-foot-9-inch senior, snatched the rebound of a teammate's shot and scored a game-winning lay-in with 2 seconds left in overtime yesterday to give Newtown a 56-55 victory over Springfield Gardens in a Public Schools Athletic League quarterfinal playoff game at John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens.


5 Senators to Offer a Contra Aid Plan
LEAD: A bipartisan group of Senators who support aid to the Nicaraguan rebels said today that they would try to fashion their own assistance package by building on elements of the $30.8 million rebel aid plan defeated by the House on Thursday.

LEAD: The Hula Hoop is making a comeback -both among grown-ups whose last hoop was probably chewed up by the family dog a quarter-century ago and among children who are discovering that toys do not have to have microchips to be fun.


Media General Rebuffs Sugarman
LEAD: Media General Inc. rejected a $1.75 billion buyout proposal from the television producer Burt Sugarman.
The company's president, James S. Evans, said the Bryan family, which founded Media General and owns controlling interest, had decided the offer was unacceptable.


Kissinger Urged Ban on TV Reports
LEAD: Henry A. Kissinger has privately urged that Israel bar television cameras and reporters from the occupied territories as part of its effort to put down violent protests.


2 From British Charity Are Sought in Lebanon
LEAD: A British official of a private charity organization and his Syrian assistant are missing in the southern Lebanese port of Sidon and may have been kidnapped, the police said today.

He was 76 years old.

LEAD: The Government said today that 31 people were killed Sunday in nationalist rioting in the southern Soviet city of Sumgait.

LEAD: Brazil and its commercial-bank creditors have agreed on a plan to stretch out repayment of $62 billion of bank debt over 20 years, a Finance Ministry spokesman said today.

NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 5, 1988
LEAD:  International 3-5, 28  Demanding a halt to Soviet aid to the Afghan Government, the United States said it would not stop sending aid to Afghan rebels until Moscow agreed to stop helping the Kabul regime.
The position could become a complication in talks on a withdrawal of Soviet troops.


Some See Bungling on Morgan Bond Plan, But Others Call It a Guide to Future Moves
LEAD: Although many bankers are blaming the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the United States Treasury for bungling a novel plan to cut Mexico's foreign debt, even most critics agree that the move was a bold attempt to help solve the third-world debt crisis that has plagued the world economy for much of this decade.


Small Opera Groups in Labor Dispute
LEAD: A struggle between New York's small opera companies and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians may soon change the face of the city's fringe operatic activity.
Most of the companies have operated for years without union contracts, but several have been unionized over the past three seasons and three more are targets of a current organizing campaign.


Santiago Is Signed
LEAD: A day after Oakland's Mark McGwire, the American League rookie of the year in 1987, signed a one-year contract worth at least $260,000, Benito Santiago, the National League's top rookie, signed a one-year contract worth $175,000.
The San Diego Padres catcher, who hit safely in 34 consecutive games last season, nearly tripled his 1987 salary of $63,500.


The Dance: 'Rock With Me'
LEAD: Mary Bruce Blackburn has created a dance of memorable sweetness and imagination in ''Rock With Me,'' performed on Wednesday in the Morningside Dance Festival's Choreographers Showcase Two at the Horace Mann Theater at Columbia University's Teachers College.
She has, for one thing, set the dance to a very appealing score that includes gospel song by the Whitesburg Baptist pre-school choir, the Spencer Family and Sweet Honey in the Rock.

Prague Seizes 13 Dissidents Before a Catholic Pilgrimage
LEAD: The Communist authorities rounded up human rights advocates on the eve of a Catholic pilgrimage aimed at pressing for greater religious freedom in Czechoslovakia, dissidents said today.

LEAD: DETENTE - a French word once distinctly malodorous in the United States - is breaking out again, and Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are responsible, or at least presiding over the process.
In Western Europe, not all the allies are wholeheartedly enthusiastic by Detente II.


Shingle Siding Repair
LEAD: WINTER winds, coupled with freezing and thawing over several months, can wreak havoc with a home's exterior.
Although early spring is usually too soon to repair shingled roofs (not only do icy surfaces still make such work dangerous, but also the ground may be too soggy to support ladders), you can get a head start on outdoor maintenance by repairing shingle siding.


New York State Income Tax Rates Cut
LEAD: The rates will be lowered over a five-year period, and at the same time larger standard deductions will be phased in, as shown below.
The top marginal rates will apply to most taxpayers; the 1987 threshold is $14,000 for single persons and $23,300 for married couples filing jointly.


For African Island Nation, Foreign Aid Is a Lifeline
LEAD: Anchored in the rich fishing waters of the Gulf of Guinea, the African archipelago of Sao Tome e Principe was shaken in 1981 by food riots.
The new Government could no longer afford to import dried fish.


THE K.G.B. AND ME
LEAD:  I'VE NEVER MET VIKTOR M. CHEBRIKOV, the head of the K.G.B., but after living in Moscow for two and a half years I can't help feeling we're well acquainted.
Every time I see his somber visage in newspapers and on television I think about the dozens of times the K.G.B. has intruded in my life.


HOSPITALS AND NURSING
LEAD: From the point of view of a registered nurse, the article ''A Great Hospital in Crisis'' (by M. A. Farber and Lawrence K. Altman, Jan. 24) was very interesting, especially for what it did not say.
Poor nursing care is cited again and again as a major problem.
However, only one nurse is quoted in your article, and she is a supervisor.

ELITIST DISTINCTIONS
LEAD: In her letter to the editor (Feb. 7), Natania Rosenfeld complains bitterly and cogently about the ''elitism'' of Allan Bloom's views in his book ''The Closing of the American Mind.'' Yet her complaint is exactly what Mr.
Bloom is talking about -the American desire to ''democratize'' art and literature so that ''elitist'' distinctions of quality are banished.

LEAD: The executive committee of the International Baseball Association has approved an application from the Soviet Union to become the association's 65th member.

LEAD: Judye Suttenberg admits she's one of those mothers who bought her children absolutely everything.

Why isn't everyone like that?
She can't understand it.


The Short and Limited Life of Central America's Peace Plan
LEAD: THE presidents of the five main Central American countries have yet to carry out the peace plan they signed seven months ago - and it looks as if they never will.
But even if the treaty dies a slow death, it may manage to have a few lasting effects.

LEAD: WINTER winds, coupled with freezing and thawing over several months, can wreak havoc with a home's exterior.

LEAD:  FAST LANES, by Jayne Anne Phillips. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $5.95.) Unlike the selections in her first collection of short fiction, ''Black Tickets,'' many of these stories of dispossessed drifters are unfocused and even a bit cliched, Jay McInerney said here last year.

The Dance: Sally Gross
LEAD: SALLY GROSS has labored long and persuasively in dance, but she is surprisingly little known among dancegoers.
She is also a choreographer with a sharp sense of visual effect, one who can indicate complex atmospheres and personal histories with the most minimal of brush strokes and the simplest of props.

About Men; The Art of Losing
LEAD: THE SCORE GOES TO 3-0, then to 5-0, then on to 8-0, the ball wildly ricocheting out of the corners of the court and away from my ineffectually flailing swings and tardy bursts of mock speed.
As the score piles up in my friend Bruce's favor, I feel a kind of serene apathy come over me vis-a-vis pursuing this small, thwacked piece of black rub-ber around this claustrophobic arena.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  ASSATA: An Autobiography.
By Assata Shakur. (Lawrence Hill, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $9.95.) Assata Shakur is something of a folk hero to a number of blacks, even those who would not follow a revolutionary to the next block.
She is Assata to them and to her fellow activists of the 1970's, a woman whose worst crime may have been being black and militant.

Hata, a former agriculture minister who had gone to Washington as his Government's point man on this issue.

Wild Tulips Flower Early in the Spring
LEAD: FINISH dormant pruning and spraying.
Check flower borders and young shrubs; push back into the ground, gently, any that have had their roots heaved by frosts.
Indoors transplant annual seedlings that have developed their second pair of true leaves; plant seed of tomatoes, peppers and eggplants indoors.

LEAD: ON FIRST seeing the battered bus, one rescuer said it looked as if it had been filleted.

Six people were killed instantly, one died later, 21 were injured.

The Modern Prepares for the 21st Century
LEAD: The recent move by the Museum of Modern Art in appointing Kirk Varnedoe, age 42, to succeed William Rubin, age 60, as head of its department of painting and sculpture, marks a major generational shift.
With the world's greatest assemblage of 20th-century masterworks and a long roster of illustrious exhibitions to its credit, the department is the museum's biggest, its best funded and its most powerful esthetic presence.


A Voice of Dissent Ruffles Indonesian Politics
LEAD: The decision this week by a small political organization to field its own vice presidential candidate rather than support the nominee of President Suharto created an unexpected crisis for the country's ruling party.


Bloated Budgets Conceal School Basics
LEAD: I HAVE been trying to figure out whether the annual school budget is a sacred cow.
That's why I decided to go to the recent hearing and sit in the auditorium amid the rest of the .002 percent of the town population that attends such stuff.


Shingle Siding Repair
LEAD: WINTER winds, coupled with freezing and thawing over several months, can wreak havoc with a home's exterior.
Although early spring is usually too soon to repair shingled roofs (not only do icy surfaces still make such work dangerous, but also the ground may be too soggy to support ladders), you can get a head start on outdoor maintenance by repairing shingle siding.

Music: Modern Bill by Gerard Schwarz
LEAD: IF there was a conclusion to be drawn from Gerard Schwarz's Music Today program Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, it was that contemporary composers have slowly found their way out of the woods: The earliest work offered, Harrison Birtwistle's ''World Is Discovered'' (1961), was virtually impenetrable, while the latest, Richard Danielpour's ''First Light'' (1988), was instantly accessible.

Body and Mind; The New Marital Therapy
LEAD: HOW LOVE'S SWEET song has changed.
Just a decade ago it was marked by bold discordancies and feisty lyrics: alternate life styles, swinging, open marriage.
All those are gone now, and the new lyrics sound remarkably old: constancy, stability, tradition.

The Editorial Notebook; Walks in the Woods
LEAD: International negotiators, even Soviet and American negotiators, sometimes develop a curious consanguinity, a common impulse to reach agreement even where it runs against their governments' policies.
At times, they explore possibilities for compromise that exceed their instructions, and conspire to sell their joint product to their respective capitals.


The Essence Of Hungary's Cuisine: Paprika
LEAD: PAPRIKA is to the entrees and main dishes of Hungary what whipped cream is to its desserts and pastries: it is theoretically possible to do without, but on the evidence of many a meal in homes and restaurants, the dominant hue of the first and second courses is rosy more often than not, and what follows is likely to be hiding under a billow of white.

CRIME
LEAD: In DOWNRIVER (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95), Loren D. Estleman is back where he belongs, with his tough private eye Amos Walker.
The eighth in this Detroit series, the book bears a slight resemblance to Robert B. Parker's Spenser mysteries: Spenser works with a lethal black man named Hawk, and Walker now has an equivalent of Hawk on his side - a black giant named Richard DeVries, just released after 20 years in prison, and somebody you most definitely do not want to mess around with.

Krone Wins One And Ties Record
LEAD: Julie Krone scored one victory from seven mounts at Aqueduct yesterday to tie Patricia Cooksey for most career victories by a female jockey with 1,203.
Krone, a 24-year-old rider from Michigan, scored aboard Seattle Knight in the fifth race.
She brought Seattle Knight from last place in a field of eight allowance runners to win the six-furlong event by 1 1/4 lengths.

An Influx of New Money Revs Up the Market
LEAD: At least 300,000 people in the United States collect old cars for love or money or both.
And while the number of collectors is increasing by 5 to 10 percent a year, the real growth in the collectible car market is measured in dollars.
This year, participants estimate that up to $500 million will change hands at auctions and private sales.


A Checklist of the Itemized Deductions Now Allowed Taxpayers
LEAD: Limitations are being phased in, so careful taxpayers may want to change the structure of their finances in the coming year to be in the best possible shape for 1988 returns.
MORTGAGE INTEREST  Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible  Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Mortgage interest on only a principal or second home is fully deductible, if the mortgage does not exceed the lower of the home's purchase price and improvement costs (subject to limitations) or its fair market value.

The Oslo Philharmonic Has Come a Long Way
LEAD: Although experiments have shown that orchestras cannot often get along without conductors, it is an open secret that they cannot always get along with them, either.
Some of the tensions are undoubtedly rooted in the same problems that crop up between any group of employees and management, yet the results achieved in performance seem less dependent on personal relations between players and conductor than on artistic rapport combined with mutual respect.

Memories of War
LEAD: To the Editor:


Employing a Little Deductive Reasoning
LEAD: The audit.
The dreaded Internal Revenue Service audit.
This year, more than two million Americans will learn firsthand what the word means, when their tax returns are selected for examination.
While some of these returns will be chosen randomly, the vast majority will have raised some red flag that triggered an audit - failing to report income, for instance, or claiming unusual or outsized deductions.

Timeless Truths of the Dutch Landscape
LEAD: It is not often in first youth that people fall in love with Dutch 17th-century landscape painting.
At 18 or 20, we prefer wilder shores and a more ecstatic mode of expression.
Rare is the young person who would pass up a Provencal landscape by van Gogh or a Fauve harbor scene by Matisse or Derain in favor of rutted flatlands, blasted trees and tumbledown cottages by painters whose names we cannot pronounce, let along remember.

One Man's Treasures Are His Wife's Junk
LEAD: IT was not the first time my wife, quite rightly perhaps, tried to get me to throw my old gym shorts into the trash.
They are tattered, old, ugly, made for a person 35 pounds lighter than myself, and would be rejected from most rag bags.
I, however, refuse to dispose of them, for purely sentimental reasons.

LEAD: About 230,000 West German tourists visited East Germany last year, an increase of 10 percent and the first noticeable increase since 1984, the Bonn Government said today.

LEAD: The table below shows the net present value of after-tax interest and closing costs on a $10,000 loan taken out in 1987.

If You're Thinking of Living in: Branford
LEAD: IN 1644, a fishing and farming community known as Totoket was renamed Branford, after a town in England.
Tightly controlled by a puritanical wing of the Congregational Church, the new town almost collapsed in 1660 when half the population, led by their minister, left in a religious dispute with the more liberal parishioners.

Roughing It in Style in Mexico
LEAD: THIRTY-FIVE miles south of the high-rises of Cancun is a luxury resort made of canvas and sand.
It's a full-service establishment - only your bed is in a tent and your tent, a stone's throw from the Mexican Caribbean, is in a secluded, sandy grove of tropical trees and shrubs.
Operated by an American family, the resort offers maid service, real beds, excellent food and a full bar open all day long, a resident masseuse and hot tub.


The Dreaded Check-Clearing Bottleneck
LEAD: The young couple thought they had it all figured out.
They had sold their co-op and were closing on a Monday.
On the following Friday, they planned to close on their new home.
They asked the buyer of the co-op to furnish a certified check at the first closing, assuming that the funds would then be available for the second.

Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
LEAD: The shameless commercialism of the Games as presented by ABC, was the worst part of the Olympics.
Apparently the Games exist for the coverage; the Games are not covered.
What was once sport is now more about hamburgers and diet soda.
Too few gold medals means lower revenues from sponsors.
Of course this trend can't be allowed to continue.

The Pentagon Needs Less High Tech
LEAD: America spends too much for its military and receives too little for its money.
The military consumes 6.7 percent of gross national product and 32 percent of America's research and development expenditures.
Germany spends 3.1 percent of G.N.P. and employs 6 percent of its R.&amp;D. talent in the service of its defense; Japan spends even less.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  Swiss Takes First: Brigitte Oertli, in the absence of her three injured Swiss teammates, yesterday won the weather-delayed women's World Cup downhill race in Aspen, Colo., and moved into first place in the overall standings.
The Swiss have won all seven downhill races this season.
Oertli, silver medalist in both the downhill and combined at the Winter Olympics, was clocked in 1 minute 22.83 seconds down a course that was icier than on Friday, when the race was stopped.

Tough Treatment For Tax Breaks
LEAD: Everyone is in favor of closing up loopholes in the tax law - a loophole, after all, is something the other guy is wriggling through to avoid taxes.
And the Congressional tax writers did just that in the Tax Reform Act of 1986, tightening deductions and taxing income that was previously exempt.
That was how they kept the law ''revenue neutral'' while lowering marginal tax rates.

Vermont Indians In Rights Battle
LEAD: FOR nine years, the Abenaki Indians of Vermont have been trying to get the state to prosecute them for fishing and hunting without licenses.
Their wish may be granted soon.
So far they have succeeded only in getting summonses three times.
Twice the state, unprepared to argue its case, declined to prosecute.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  SIGHT LINES.
By Arlene Croce. (Knopf, $19.95.) Arlene Croce is the most cogent of dance critics.
Her lucid and nimble style targets the reader who can take a reference to Eddie Murphy in one sentence and ''Giselle'' in the next.
She has been writing for The New Yorker for the past 15 years, and ''Sight Lines'' is her third book of collected reviews.

You Needn't Face It Alone: A Guide to the Tax Guides
LEAD: Taking control of your tax situation involves a lot more than filling out the forms, or gathering up folders of last year's records to drop by the accountant's office.
Actually, financial planning is an ongoing, year-round affair, and for those who spend an hour or two a week monitoring their finances - checking whether their portfolios are meeting expectations and how their household budgets are shaping up - income-tax preparation is a relatively effortless exercise.

LEAD: The Indy-car season doesn't open until April 10 in Phoenix, but the top teams in the series have been testing their 1988 cars almost since the last race of the 1987 season in Miami more than three months ago.
Drivers and team owners say that the lonely, sometimes dangerous work of testing new equipment over the winter is one of the keys to success when the season begins.

Now in his second year as Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, he is struggling to change the culture of an agency that too often, he says, is seen as the enemy of the people, somewhat slipshod, inaccurate and rude.

CLARE BOOTHE LUCE IS REMEMBERED
LEAD: Sylvia Morris makes so much of her intimacy with Clare Boothe Luce that I am surprised she could have missed the grace of Mrs.
Luce's last dinner party.
The evening should have elicited more from Mrs.
Morris than a comment on Mrs.
