A NEW ECONOMICS ON WALL STREET
LEAD: On Wall Street, data-watching was always a favorite sport among economists, but not as much as it is today.
Hand-holding of clients was always important; now, it can dominate an economist's working day.
The principal task used to be the quarterly forecast.
Now, the horizon can be as short as a few days - and sometimes less.


CUTTING CORNERS
LEAD: FOR YEARS, I WAS A ''pe-riphery shopper,'' buying only fresh produce, meat and dairy products that lined market walls.
Occasionally, I navigated up and down the aisles displaying staples and frozen foods, adding imported canned tomatoes, orange juice concentrate and ice cream to my basket.
But I was convinced that just about anything made from scratch was best.


HOSPITALS AND NURSING
LEAD: I have recently moved to New York from Seattle, where I worked for 10 years as a nurse in an intensive-care unit.
In an I.C.U., many things can change rapidly without warning.
Where I come from, the nurse is trained in managing emergencies as they arise.
You know what to do, and can act quickly.
In many of the hospitals I have worked in here, the nurse is not allowed to treat a patient before notifying the physician.

Fresh Research Tells Asthmatics To Stay Active
LEAD: FOR generations, people with asthma have been treated as invalids.
They have been told to avoid exercise because it would induce attacks of their disease.
A vicious circle was set up: the less they exercised, the less exertion it took to bring on an attack of coughing, constricted bronchial passages and difficulty breathing.

Section B playoffs.

Top Female Jockey
LEAD: Julie Krone being doused with champagne by Robbie Davis, another jockey, after she rode Squawter to victory in the ninth race yesterday at Aqueduct.
It was her 1,205th career victory, breaking the record for victories by a woman, which was set by Patricia Cooksey on Saturday night.
Cooksey has undergone knee surgery and is not expected to ride for up to three months.

LEAD: In a savings climate clouded by changes in the Federal tax law and uncertainties about the stock market, the business of Individual Retirement Accounts is shifting gears.
Fewer people are opening accounts, and those who do show a preference for investments that have historically been safe and stable.

LEAD: At least three people and perhaps as many as nine were killed in a daylong series of anti-Chinese protests that shook Lhasa on Saturday, according to reports reaching Beijing today.

Corrections
LEAD: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Feb. 10 gave incorrect quantities for nutrients in some fruits and vegetables.
Oranges contain about 30 micrograms of folacin; bananas, 5 milligrams of niacin and 19 micrograms of folacin.
A 3 1/2-ounce portion of broccoli has 71 micrograms of folacin; a similar portion of turnip greens has 194 micrograms.

LEAD: The body of a man who had been stabbed in the back and strangled with a telephone cord was found yesterday in the bathroom of his Bronx apartment, the police said.
The victim, Clifford Lewis, 34 years old, of 1970 University Avenue in the University Heights section, was found by his mother at 3:20 P.M., said a police spokesman.

Madagascar Frees 245
LEAD: A special court in Madagascar has ordered the release of 245 people held in detention since 1985 in connection with riots by kung-fu enthusiasts the previous year.
Radio Madagascar said the court issued sentences that ranged up to two years in jail, but because the prisoners had been in detention longer than that, the effect was to free them.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing Steiner Retires By Taking a Title: Roswitha Steiner of Austria, in the final event of her nine-year career, captured the last World Cup women's slalom race of the season yesterday and clinched the 1987-88 slalom title.
The 24-year-old Steiner, who retires with eight World Cup race victories and two slalom crowns, outdueled Corinne Schmidhauser of Switzerland in a treacherous competition that saw most of the other favorites fall in the first run.

Bethlehem Steel Bonus
LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said Friday that it would distribute $48 million in cash and stock among 24,000 employees because their wage and benefit concessions helped Bethlehem record its first profitable year since 1981.
By April 15, the workers are to receive cash payments averaging $500.
Also, convertible preference stock worth an estimated $1,500 will be credited to each worker in an employee stock ownership trust.


U.S. TO CUT BACK WORKER SURVEYS
LEAD: Despite protests from Mayor Koch and other officials, the Federal Government plans to reduce the size of its monthly employment survey in New York City, thus sharply limiting its ability to track employment trends among black, Hispanic, teen-age and other workers.


Electoral Integrity vs. Free Speech
LEAD: The startling surge in expenditures by candidates for public office presents a fundamental challenge to the integrity of the electoral process.
Spending increases have been staggering.
Total spending in the 1984 Presidential primaries was $104 million.
The current crop of Presidential contenders spent more than $87 million even before the New Hampshire primary.

Increase in Oil Use Seen
LEAD: Oil consumption in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development countries is expected to grow by 1 percent, or about 300,000 barrels a day, over 1987 levels, the International Energy Agency said.
In its latest monthly report, the agency projected average world consumption, excluding the centrally planned economies, at between 49 and 49.5 million barrels a day in 1988, with non-O.E.C.D.

LEAD: John W. Miller, president of Miller-Rogaska Inc., an importer of crystal, died of heart failure Friday in John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Atlantis, Fla.

Experts Issue Warning About Dengue Fever
LEAD: THE number of cases of dengue fever, a temporarily incapacitating disease spread by mosquitos, is increasing in warm regions of the Caribbean and Latin America, according to United States health specialists, who have called for more vigorous control of the insects throughout the hemisphere.


Pickens's Bid Is Spurned
LEAD: The board of the Homestake Mining Company has unanimously rejected a $1.9 billion takeover offer from Mesa Limited Partnership, the oil and gas company headed by T. Boone Pickens.
The San Francisco-based gold producer said that its financial adviser, the First Boston Corporation, had determined that the offer, for $20 a share, was inadequate.

Cowboys and Japanese
LEAD: Lallation it's called, the difficulty Asians have in pronouncing ''L'' and ''R'' in English.
For years it prompted adolescent jokes about ''flied lice'' and ''I went to U.C.R.A.'' The wisecracks have waned as Japan has given America lessons in quality and industry.
No one is heard to mock the Honda Acula or the Sony Warkman.

LEAD: Jim Abbott, a pitcher who was born without a right hand, was named the 58th winner of the Sullivan Award last night as the nation's top amateur athlete.
Abbott, 20 years old, is from Flint, Mich., and plays for the University of Michigan.
He led Team USA last summer with an 8-1 record and a 1.70 earned run average as it won a silver medal in the Pan American Games.

Steel Production Down
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.971 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 1.5 percent from the previous week's 2.002 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 91.8 percent of capacity for the week, compared with 93.2 percent in the previous week.

Budd to Run
LEAD: Some African nations have threatened to boycott the world cross-country championships if Zola Budd, the South African athlete who became a British subject in 1983, is permitted to run.

LEAD: The bacterium that causes infection in humans scratched by cats has been isolated and grown in the laboratory, researchers at the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in Washington reported in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

The Sun Nears a Period of Intense Activity
LEAD: A STEEP and surprisingly early increase in magnetic disturbances on the Sun in the last few months may herald a cycle of exceptionally intense solar radiation, and astronomers have warned that satellites in low orbits could face premature destruction as a result.

LEAD: Haji Baz Gul, the owner of Arms Store No. 1 in Darra Adam Khel, an hour's drive south of here, said he was not worried about peace breaking out in neighboring Afghanistan.


Philippine Insurgents Kill 9
LEAD: Communist guerrillas ambushed a vehicle near Subic Bay on Sunday, killing three civilians and six Filipino sailors assigned to the United States-run naval base, the military said today.
The sailors - and the civilians, who were hitchhikers - were traveling from Subic to Manila when the rebels attacked near Hermosa, 40 miles west of Manila.

Fireman's Fund Sets Buyback Plan
LEAD: The Fireman's Fund Corporation will purchase 8.5 million of its stock from the American Express Company for $200 million, plus three million shares of American Express stock.
Based on the closing price of American Express's shares on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday of $27.875, the agreement is valued at $283.6 million.


Salvador Ruling Party To Dismiss Candidates
LEAD: Leading officials of the ruling Christian Democratic Party in El Salvador said today that a party member suspected of misuse of American funds would be dropped as a candidate from this month's election.


Bridge: Retirement From the Game Bolsters Expert's Reputation
LEAD: Few players retire from the game and then find that their reputation is growing.
This has happened to Paul Lewis, a New York City bridge expert who temporarily put the game aside in 1985 when he married and moved to Irvington, N.Y.
But since his namesake, Paul Lewis of Las Vegas, has had numerous successes, ''some people,'' he said, ''still think I just moved West.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today significantly expanded the obligations of public companies and their managers to disclose preliminary merger negotiations to the public.


Pirelli Bids To Acquire Firestone
LEAD: Heating up the competition to acquire the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, Pirelli S.p.A., the giant Italian tire maker, announced a $58-a-share, $1.86 billion tender offer yesterday.


Essay Attacks Orders To Protect the Unborn
LEAD: Physicians concerned for the unborn should not turn to the courts to force pregnant women to undergo Caesarean sections, drug abuse treatment or other procedures, two medical researchers argue.


Region in Brain Is Linked to Obsessive Disorder
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have found important new clues to the brain chemistry and anatomy of one of the most serious, puzzling and difficult forms of mental illness, obsessive-compulsive disorder.


Curbing Cremation Fuel Need
LEAD: The depletion of forests in many less developed nations has prompted warnings that shortages of wood for fuel and timber will further impoverish the people and damage the environment.
India is seeking to reduce one source of demand for wood by promoting fuel-efficient cremation, a shift that can help save both forests and money.


Peter Martin, 65, Dies; Founder of a Bookshop
LEAD: Peter Martin, who in 1964 founded the New Yorker Bookshop, an Upper West Side institution that closed for economic reasons in 1982, died of emphysema in San Francisco last Thursday.
He was 65 years old.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Why are rainbows round and often double?
A.
The most common rainbows form when sunlight enters raindrops, according to Dr.
William Gutsch, chairman of the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium.
The drops act like prisms and disperse the sun's light into the familiar spectrum of colors: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo and violet.


Umpire Awaiting Her Call From Majors
LEAD: The umpire at first base this afternoon in the Mets' 5-3 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers was Pam Postema, who said that she didn't particularly want to make history as much as she wanted to make the umpiring staff in the National League.


Coniston Rejection Urged by Gillette
LEAD: The Gillette Company urged its shareholders to reject an attempt by Coniston Partners to oust four company directors at its annual meeting in April.
Colman M. Mockler Jr., Gillette's chairman and chief executive, said that Coniston intended to sell or dismantle Gillette if it succeeded in a hostile takeover.


Moore McCormack Spurns Hostile Bid
LEAD: The board of Moore McCormack Resources Inc. has rejected a $177 milllion hostile bid from Southdown Inc. as ''grossly inadequate.'' The concrete concern, based in Stamford, Conn., said it was investigating several options, including an acquisition of its own, to avoid a takeover.


Girl Mimicking Movie Scene Is Struck and Killed by Train
LEAD: A 15-year-old girl who was acting out a scene from the movie ''Stand By Me'' was struck and killed when she misjudged the speed of an oncoming freight train and stepped into its path, the authorities said today.


Korean Car Exports Up
LEAD: South Korea's three auto makers reported today that their combined exports soared 97.4 percent in February, to 49,879 cars, from 25,270 in the same month last year.
Officials said that the February shipments were mostly passenger cars and that more than 90 percent of them were to the United States and Canada.


Stone Slab in Mexico Reveals Ancient Writing System
LEAD: AN ancient carved stone monument pulled from a river near the Gulf Coast of Veracruz gives evidence of a previously unknown system of hieroglyphics that flourished in the New World by the second century A.D.

LEAD: A political race is shaping up in the House of Representatives that will test the mettle of one of its most visible Democrats and the stomach of the rank and file for the grueling campaigns that are becoming the norm for leadership positions.
It is the contest for chairmanship of the House Democratic


U.S. and British Producers Start Fund for New Plays
LEAD: Two British and two American theater producers - including Jujamcyn Theaters Inc., the smallest of Broadway's three theater-owning groups - have announced the creation of the International Theater Development Fund to develop new work for the London and New York theater as well as for touring-circuit theaters in both countries.


Dallas Selling Water Bonds
LEAD: The City of Dallas is offering about $230 million of water and sewer refunding bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Yields range from 4.75 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 7 percent in 1998 and 7.50 percent in 2003 and 2004.


Nets' Streak Ends After 3 Victories
LEAD: Thurl Bailey and Karl Malone scored 21 points each and Bobby Hansen added 20 as the Utah Jazz won their fifth straight game, defeating the Nets by 105-81 tonight.

LEAD: THIS was not just the customary denial, written on official stationery by the team publicist.
The management of the New Jersey Nets went to more elaborate measures yesterday -holding a news conference at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena - to adamantly deny that it covered up or ignored Orlando Woolridge's drug problem.


Customers Groan as Postal Service Is Cut
LEAD: In the wake of a tightening of postal services, residents and businesses throughout the New York metropolitan region are struggling to adapt to fewer window hours in post office branches and the end of all Sunday mail collection and sorting.


Moog a Bruin
LEAD: Andy Moog, the goalie who was a holdout with the Edmonton Oilers, has been acquired by the Boston Bruins in exchange for Geoff Courtnall, a left wing, Bill Ranford, a goalie, and future considerations.
Harry Sinden, general manager of the Bruins, said that Moog signed a multiyear contract and was expected to be in uniform tonight in Detroit for the game against the Red Wings.

LEAD: For Michel Bergeron, the day was altogether ordinary, which meant his pulse rate was anything but.
There were roster realignments to explain, injury reports to update, trade rumors to deny.
Cigarette in one hand, a cup of coffee in the other, he juggled all the the issues yesterday and prepared to return to his office.

Refund to Lift Morgan's Net
LEAD: J. P. Morgan &amp; Company said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter would be bolstered by $43 million as the result of a Federal income tax refund stemming from the New York City debt crisis in 1976.


Floral Therapy for Flu
LEAD: If the New York Flower Show is any guide, this is the year to learn how to pronounce ''gazebo'' (with a long ''e'').
It is also the year to learn to spell ''ranunculus,'' a kind of upscale buttercup.
And the year to quit cutting back the hollyhocks.
The show, which runs through March 13, is rich in all three.

LEAD: Among the nearly three million Uruguayans the prevailing view is that an accident of birth is the only thing keeping Enrique Iglesias from being their next elected President.

Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Rule on Curb Of Obcenity Book Sales
LEAD: The Supreme Court said today that it would decide whether the First Amendment bars state and Federal governments from using racketeering laws to close down bookstores selling any quantity of sexually explicit materials a judge considers obscene.


NATO's Smiling Summiteers
LEAD: NATO leaders left Brussels happy last week, and not surprisingly.
They heartily endorsed the Euromissile treaty, reaffirmed the U.S. commitment and welcomed efforts at European defense cooperation.
They also avoided details on all the hard questions: conventional arms talks, modernization of battlefield nuclear missiles, strategy and burden-sharing.


False Alarms About AIDS
LEAD: The cover of this week's Newsweek features the rumpled sheets of an empty double bed.
That's the teaser for a rumpled, alarming article: it implies that the AIDS virus can be spread by casual contact, declares the risk of being infected by a blood transfusion to be seven times greater than the best current estimates, and warns that the epidemic among heterosexuals ''will now begin to escalate at a frightening pace.

LEAD: Correcting initial reports on the police killing of three unarmed Irish terrorist suspects in Gibraltar, the British Government announced today that no terrorist bomb had been found at the scene.


Talks on Grain Delayed
LEAD: United States-Soviet trade talks on grain, set to begin on Friday in Vienna, have been delayed, United States officials said today.
The Soviet Union asked that the negotiations be delayed because of logistical difficulties, the officials said.


An Average Reader Finishes This Article In About 2 1/2 Minutes
LEAD: How much time does an average taxpayer spend filling out Form 1040?
The Internal Revenue Service knows, but it does not want to remind the public right on the form.

LEAD: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company and the Toledo Edison Company are offering $877 million of secured lease obligation bonds through a special-purpose financing company called the CTC Mansfield Funding Corporation.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Five Assists for Gretzky: Wayne Gretzky assisted on five consecutive goals, two by Craig Simpson, as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Jets, 6-0, last night at Winnipeg.
Grant Fuhr, the Oiler goaltender, made 21 saves for his fourth shutout of the season and had an assist.
Gretzky started weaving his magic in the second period at the Oilers struck for four goals, including Simpson's 48th and 49th of the season.


MECHAM IS ACCUSED BY POLICE OFFICIAL
LEAD: Arizona's top police official testified at the impeachment trial of Gov.
Evan Mecham today that he realized almost immediately that Mr.
Mecham had committed a crime in ordering him not to cooperate in an investigation of a purported death threat.


Rockwell Pleas Entered
LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation, a former manager and a suspended employee pleaded not guilty today in Federal court here to 24 charges stemming from a reported scheme to double-bill the Government on a navigational satellite system in 1982.
The company also pleaded not guilty to a criminal contempt charge involving reported violations of a 1982 injunction, which prohibited Rockwell from submitting false or fraudulent claims.


College for Deaf Is Shut by Protest Over President
LEAD: Gallaudet University, the nation's only college exclusively for the deaf, was shut down today and classes were suspended indefinitely after hundreds of students, faculty members and alumni blocked entrances to the campus to protest the selection of a president who is not hearing impaired.


Jackson Gets 33 To Spur Knicks
LEAD: Many in the capacity crowd of 19,591 were drawn to Madison Square Garden last night by Michael Jordan, but the fans walked away talking about Mark Jackson.


Democrats Fight Several Wars As Bush Foes Battle to Survive
LEAD: The Democrats fight a multi-front war today for the right to stay in the long march to their national convention, but on the Republican side, Vice President Bush will be trying to bury all his opponents.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page last Wednesday described early sound recordings of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, made with a concealed device in the Oval Office in 1940.


Turkish Avalanche Kills 19
LEAD: An avalanche hit a small village near the Iranian border, killing 19 people and injuring 8 others, the Anatolia news agency said today.


Albany Leader Opposes Cuomo On Scholarships
LEAD: The State Senate majority leader today condemned Governor Cuomo's proposal for Liberty Scholarships for college-bound students from poor families but left open the possibility that some kind of new scholarship program might be approved if Mr.
Cuomo agreed to sweeten existing tuition assistance grants.


200 Bumped by Eastern Air; Irate Man Is Held in Assault
LEAD: A crowd of 200 Eastern Airlines passengers who were bumped from New York-bound flights Sunday angrily confronted ticket agents, and one man was arrested for assaulting police officers, the authorities said.

LEAD: The giant food maker H. J. Heinz Company today reported a 22 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, attributing the improvement to a higher sales volume, acquisitions and the beneficial effects of a cheaper dollar.


Corrections
LEAD: An on article Saturday about voter reaction to the issue positions taken by Presidential candidates misstated the number of registered voters in Southern and border states interviewed in a New York Times/CBS News Poll.
It was 1,724, not 1,666.

LEAD: The man whose attempted murder conviction led to the book and television movie ''Deadly Intentions'' was sentenced to 15 years in prison today on Federal marijuana and weapons charges.

Captive Condor Lays a Fertile Egg
LEAD: The first California condor egg produced by a captive breeding pair is fertile, and a chick should emerge in less than two months, San Diego Wild Animal Park officials said today.

LEAD: American Standard Inc. said that its board would consider the latest unsolicited takeover offer from the Black &amp; Decker Corporation.

LEAD: An American drive to have Cuba cited for violating its citizens' human rights is dominating a meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission for the second year in a row, diplomats say.

Simon said he saw the Vice Presidency as largely a ceremonial post.


2 Workers Held Hostage in Hospital by a Prisoner
LEAD: A prisoner being treated at a Manhattan hospital held two workers hostage early yesterday after ripping out a section of his bed, beating a police officer with it, and then fleeing with the officer's gun, the authorities said.


Low-Cost Amiga
LEAD: THE Amiga 500, as mentioned here last week, is an exciting machine, a home computer with capabilities in graphics and sound that only a few years ago would have cost thousands of dollars more, and in many cases still do.
It comes with 512,000 characters of internal memory, expandable to a million, and a built-in 880,000-character disk drive.

Review/Television; Orbison Is Still Around and Rocking
LEAD: Roy Orbison is not your average rocker.
He was born in Wink, Texas, and he's over 40, well over 40, even older than Mick Jagger.
He made his rockabilly debut on Sun Records in 1956 with ''Ooby Dooby.'' He hit his stride as a Nashville songwriter and performer for Monument Records in the 1960's.
He still wears tinted glasses and an odd helmet of jet-black hair.


Fort Smith Journal; As Things Look Up, the People Look Homeward
LEAD: To the rest of the country, the people of western Arkansas and their cousins just across the Arkansas River in Oklahoma may still seem to be the folk of John Steinbeck stories and Woody Guthrie songs, the so-called Arkies and Okies who fled as dust bowl refugees to the fields and factories of California five decades ago.

By Design; Evolution of Shoulder Pads
LEAD: Shoulder pads have been squaring off shoulders and boosting fashions for at least 10 years.
The fact that the pads, especially the outsize ones, tend to slip and slide around has not diminished their popularity.
Women have just learned to tug and shove them back into place.


Expert Disputes Theory of Levin's Death
LEAD: A forensic expert testified yesterday that Jennifer Levin was killed when her neck was compressed by a chokehold applied from behind, not by a frontal strangulation, The witness, testifying for the defense in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., also said Miss Levin did not appear to have been beaten before her death.


Renaissance Paintings Damaged In Milan
LEAD: About 20 Renaissance paintings, including a masterpiece by Piero della Francesca, were damaged during a malfunction of the heating and humidity systems at the Brera Gallery in Milan, museum officials said today.


Robert E. Link, Educator, 72
LEAD: Robert E. Link, who taught at Brooklyn College for 39 years, died of cancer of the kidney and liver yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.
He was 72 years old and lived in Long Beach, L.I.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Giants acquired Robert Abraham, a linebacker, on waivers from the Houston Oilers yesterday.
Abraham spent last season on injured reserve with hamstring and groin injuries.
A third-round draft choice of the Oilers in 1982 out of North Carolina State, Abraham had been a key part of the Houston defense in each of the four previous seasons.


London Stock Official Quits
LEAD: Sir Nicholas Goodison said today that he would surrender his position as chairman of the London Stock Exchange at the end of the year and not stand for re-election.

Democrats in a Quandary
LEAD: The 2,000 Democrats who recently crowded into a state fairgrounds building for North Carolina's Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner seemed mostly concerned with getting fed.
It wasn't easy since all of them had to stand in one interminable line to be served a dubious piece of fried chicken.


Soviet Verification Proposal
LEAD: Soviet negotiators presented draft proposals at the Geneva arms talks today on how to verify a new treaty reducing long-range arms, Administration officials said.
American officials assailed the Soviet Union last week for failing to present such proposals.
American officials said the Soviet draft proposals did not appear to contain any surprising new suggestions.


Superconductors: Scientists Hail Latest Materials
LEAD: WITH the discovery of a yet another kind of superconductor, a distant cousin of the materials found in the breakthroughs of the last year, research on superconductivity has suddenly passed a new milestone.

LEAD: Brazil's new finance minister, Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega, announced today a shake-up in his top economic team, including a new chief negotiator for this country's foreign debt.


Antibody May Help Pinpoint Blood Clots
LEAD: Doctors are hoping that by injecting a radioactive, genetically engineered antibody into a patient's bloodstream, they can can improve detection of blood clots.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today ruled, by 8 to 0, that Federal bankruptcy law did not allow financially troubled farmers to avoid foreclosure and keep their farms by promising to continue operating them and making payments on their loans.

LEAD: Joel Benjamin of Brooklyn surpassed 74 entrants to win the first prize, $10,000 (Canadian), in the International Open Tournament 1 in Saint John, New Brunswick.
The 23-year-old grandmaster won five games and drew four to achieve his winning 7-2 score in the nine-round Swiss-system event.

LEAD: Demand for stocks involved in acquisitions provided a little spurt yesterday to a mostly lackluster market.

They want to do with women's panties in supermarkets and drug chains what Hanes Hosiery did with L'Eggs pantyhose: sell them where such products have generally never been sold.


Blues Acquire Hull
LEAD: The St.
Louis Blues, approaching the Stanley Cup playoffs with a fear that they lacked scoring power, traded two of their top defensive players yesterday to acquire Brett Hull, a rookie scoring ace from the Calgary Flames.
The Blues gave up Rob Ramage, a defenseman who has been named an All-Star four times, and Rick Wamsley, a goaltender with a 3.40 goals-against average, to obtain Hull and Steve Bozek, a left wing.

He was 42 years old.

It is a job he started out enduring and has come to enjoy.

LEAD: The number of oil and gas rigs working in the United States decreased by five last week, to a total of 978, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today.

A year ago, the rig count was 766, Baker Hughes said.

Sports People; Whalers Get Brodeur
LEAD: In a swap of goaltenders, the Hartford Whalers acquired Richard Brodeur, a 35-year-old veteran of 16 big league pro seasons - 7 in the World Hockey Association and 9 in the N.H.L. - from the Vancouver Canucks.
The Whalers gave up 29-year-old Steve Weeks, who had a 42-33-14 record in four seasons with the Rangers before joining Hartford for the 1984-85 season.

LEAD: China has 20 million surplus workers in its work force of 132 million, the official China Daily said today.

Meanwhile, Back at the Deficit . . .
LEAD: When will the Republican Presidential candidates raise taxes?
Never!
When will the Democratic candidates?
Only ''as a last resort.'' When will Congress?
Certainly not in this election year.
To hear these politicians talk, you'd think the issue was dead in the water.
But it's not.
Fortunately, if the candidates don't dare face it responsibly, others will.

Sports People; Islanders Trade Dineen
LEAD: With the National Hockey League's trading deadline ending yesterday, the three metropolitan area teams were involved in only minor deals in their drives for the playoffs.
In a move to go with younger players, though, the Islanders traded two defensemen with experience who might have helped them.
They sent Gord Dineen to the Minnesota North Stars for a minor league defenseman, Chris Pryor, and they sent Brian Curran to the Toronto Maple Leafs for a sixth-round selection in the 1988 draft.

Shutting the Door on the Poor
LEAD: We have been bombarded with images of the homeless, wrapped in tattered blankets, sitting on steaming grates across from the White House.
This rightly disturbs us.

Budget numbers may not make good television copy, but if we consider only the homeless person and not the reason for his homelessness, we cannot solve the problem.

Corrections
LEAD: A Company News report in Business Day yesterday misstated the total value of Southdown Inc.'s hostile takeover offer for Moore McCormack Resources Inc.
Southdown has offered to pay $31 a share for the 8.8 million Moore McCormack common shares outstanding, $51.77 for each $3.6875 preferred share and $1,174 for each $1,000 face amount of 7 1/4 percent subordinated convertible debentures due 2012.

Savings Bond Sales Rise
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds increased for the sixth consecutive month in February, rising 2 percent, to $658 million, the Government reported today.
The Treasury Department said that sales in February had been $13 million higher than in January and had been 2 percent above the level of a year ago, when sales were $646 million.

3 Ex-Detectives Held in Charity Fraud
LEAD: Three former detectives for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office have been charged with illegally soliciting millions of dollars from businesses through a fraudulent police charity they set up 10 years ago, the Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday.


College Tournaments; West Virginia Falls To Rhode Island
LEAD: Carlton Owens scored 25 points and Kenny Green scored on a dunk with j1 minute 24 seconds remaining to insure Rhode Island's 65-63 victory over West Virginia tonight in an Atlantic 10 semifinal.


Rights Aide Held in Atlanta
LEAD: Hosea Williams, a City Councilman active in the civil rights movement, was charged Sunday with carrying an unlicensed pistol when security officers at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport found a gun in his briefcase.
Mr.
Williams ''said he had been cleaning his car out and put it in his briefcase but forgot to leave it in his house,'' a police sergeant said.


Merrill Official Plans to Quit
LEAD: Robert F. Mancuso, a senior Merrill Lynch &amp; Company executive who founded the firm's leveraged buyout business seven years ago, plans to resign.
Confirming Wall Street rumors of his departure, Mr.
Mancuso said that he intends either to set up his own business to provide financial advice in leveraged buyouts or to join a small firm.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We are on the verge of a meltdown.''  Bryan Jacoboski, an oil analyst.  [ D7:5. ]

LEAD: To the Editor:


Soviet Armenians Mourn Their Dead
LEAD: Tens of thousands of Armenians held a silent march and vigil in the Armenian capital of Yerevan this afternoon in memory of those slain in the recent rampages in the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan, according to Armenians and Westerners who were present.


Women Still Finding Bias in Engineering
LEAD: AS an engineer working in the aerospace industry, LuAnne J. Beckley encountered one prospective employer who wanted her to agree not to have children.
Rockwell International, where she took a job, assigned her to an all-male laboratory with no women's restroom, a problem that was corrected only after she complained to management.


Super Tuesday: The Candidates Speak
LEAD: ''I'm going to be the next President.'' - Vice President Bush


Syntex and P.&amp;G. Set Joint Venture
LEAD: The Syntex Corporation, a pharmaceutical company based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it had agreed in principle to form a 50-50 joint venture company with the Procter &amp; Gamble Company to market nonprescription products to treat pain and inflammation.
Pending approval from the Food and Drug Administration, an over-the-counter formulation of Syntex's Naprosyn, the most widely prescribed anti-inflammatory drug used to treat arthritis in the United

Transfers Begin To Police Unit In Queens Area
LEAD: The Police Department began reassigning narcotics officers yesterday to the new, 118-member Tactical Narcotics Team that will try to rid southeast Queens of its growing drug trade.

Senator Wants Answers
LEAD: Senator Strom Thurmond has asked the White House for a detailed explanation of the procedures followed in selecting a new Under Secretary for International Trade at the Commerce Department.


Who May Cry for Tibet?
LEAD: When Tibetans rose in protest against Chinese repression last fall, Congress condemned China for human rights failures.
Beijing in turn condemned the U.S. for meddling.
Now new protests shake Lhasa just as the Chinese Foreign Minister visits Washington to discuss ever-stronger bilateral relations.

LEAD: The province of Quebec announced today that it would proceed with the $6 billion second construction phase of its huge hydroelectric power project on James Bay, which would be the largest installation of its kind when completed.

Results Plus
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Hawks 143, Suns 113: Dominique Wilkins scored 41 points to lead the Hawks last night.
Wilkins hit a half-court shot at the halftime buzzer, then sank another 3-pointer to open the second half and stake the Hawks to a 78-64 lead.
A season-high point total allowed Atlanta to snap a three-game slump at home.


Review/Concert; In London, a Weekend of Berlioz as Berlioz Heard It
LEAD: The increasingly less aptly named early-music movement broke fresh ground over the weekend, with period-instrument performances by Roger Norrington and his London Classical Players of Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and ''Romeo et Juliette'' at Queen Elizabeth Hall.

Review/Television; 'Inside Soviet Circus,' Dedicated Performers
LEAD: ''Inside the Soviet Circus'' shows a lot of inside but not enough circus.
The National Geographic Special, on Channel 21 at 8 o'clock tonight (and on Channel 13 at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow), doesn't look at Soviet circus life so much as canonize it.
It suggests that clowns, jugglers and aerialists pursue a sacred calling.

Voicing Complaints, Legislators Pick 2 New Regents and Re-elect 3
LEAD: In a four-hour debate punctuated by unusually strong complaints about the state's school system, the Legislature today elected a Staten Island surgeon and a retired Eastman Kodak executive to the Board of Regents.

Review/Television; In Series, Culture Shock For Amish
LEAD: Deciding to go all the way with ''family entertainment'' on Wednesday evenings, NBC is rolling the dice on a new series called ''Aaron's Way,'' which, at 8 P.M., will precede ''Highway to Heaven'' and ''thirtysomething.'' The new show is being given a special two-hour ''preview'' tonight at 8 o'clock.


New Zealand Asks to Delay Cup Racing
LEAD: In a surprise move, Michael Fay, the New Zealand merchant banker, has offered to postpone the America's Cup regatta scheduled for September until 1989 in order to give other challengers an opportunity to race.


Bonds Offered for Prisons And Criminal Justice Center
LEAD: Tax-exempt bonds to finance prisons in New York State and a criminal justice center in Philadelphia were offered yesterday.
Principal and interest payments on both issues were insured, raising their credit ratings to the highest triple-A level.


Ruling Expands Bank's Liability In Employee Discrimination Case
LEAD: A Federal administrative law judge ruled today that a Chicago bank that had been found to have discriminated against female and minority employees might owe millions more in back pay in the case, the biggest of its kind.


Return to the Land of the Gipper
LEAD: Ronald Reagan played football in college.
Then he played a football player in a movie.
In some ways he has been playing the player, if not the game itself, ever since.


Costs of New Submarines Rise
LEAD: An effort to upgrade future Los Angeles-class attack submarines has generated delays at shipyards and contract overruns totaling $1.3 billion, the Navy said today.

Exxon Expects $18 Oil Average
LEAD: Top executives of the Exxon Corporation told Wall Street analysts yesterday that they believed oil prices would average about $18 a barrel for the next few years despite the recent decline.


Michelin Guide's '88 Ratings
LEAD: The 1988 Guide Michelin for France has awarded its highest rating to the Paris restaurant L'Ambroisie, the only restaurant to be added to the three-star category this year.


Noriega Aide Says U.S. Plans Invasion
LEAD: The Government of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega charged today that American military maneuvers now being conducted here violate the Panama Canal treaties and are ''a prelude to a military invasion of Panama.''


About New York; Hunting Clues To Winter's End In Central Park
LEAD: Word raced through the staff meetings in Central Park a couple of days back: snowdrops (galanthus nivalis) had been spotted blooming in the Conservatory Garden.
It wasn't long after that Sarah Price, the curator, discovered a crocus near the women's room.
Glory be!
Could winter's back be broken?
You should live so long.


For Katharine Hepburn, Her Mother's Crusade
LEAD: NEARLY 70 years ago, a determined suffragist known as Mrs.
Thomas Hepburn heard Margaret Sanger speak on the need for birth control; the message changed her life.
Mrs.
Hepburn, the wife of a prominent Connecticut doctor, decided that women needed birth control even more than they needed the vote.


Hope for Black Farmers in New Rules
LEAD: New farm lending rules that become effective next June could slow the long decline in the number of black farmers in the South, according to Federal officials and community leaders.


Arthur N. Seiff, 86; Won Free Press Case
LEAD: Arthur N. Seiff, a trial lawyer, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan while he was working on legal papers.
He was 86 years old.


Sallie Mae Notes
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association offered $500 million of 8.20 percent notes, due in 1993, through various securities dealers.
The Sallie Mae notes, due in five years and two months, were offered at a price of 100 and yield about 37-hundredths of a percentage point more than five-year Treasury notes.


A Super Tuesday in New York
LEAD: At the South Street Seaport yesterday, the name had more to do with the weather than politics.
The high temperature of 55 degrees, combined with bright sunshine, produced some very pleasant lunch hours. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)


Will He Run? Secret Is Kept By Mitterrand
LEAD: On a quiet curving street between the Pont d'Alma and the Eiffel Tower, President Francois Mitterrand's campaign headquarters is ready.
A sign on the brick facade of 7 avenue Franco-Russe says that a school has moved from the four-story building to another address.


Metro Datelines; Look-Alike House Must Get New Plans
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the impoundment of all ''infringing copies'' of architectural plans used by a couple to build an expensive home nearly identical to one on the same street in Scarsdale.


Economic Scene; Faulty U.S. Logic In Cocaine Policy
LEAD: CONGRESS and the Reagan Administration may be confounded by evidence of rising cocaine production and smuggling.
But it comes as no surprise to the handful of economists who study the markets for illicit drugs that the Federal war on cocaine is being lost.
They contend that relative simple economic analysis shows that the war is being fought on the wrong fronts with the wrong weapons.


Tandon Sells Disk Drive Unit
LEAD: The Tandon Corporation said it had sold the disk drive business on which the company was founded to the Western Digital Corporation for $49 million in cash and other considerations.
Western Digital, of Irvine, Calif., a leading maker of computer storage, communications, video controller and logic-processing units, will also assume about $28 million in Tandon liabilities.


ARCO-Tricentrol
LEAD: ARCO said it was starting a tender offer for all American depositary receipts of Tricentrol P.L.C. at $7.10 each.
The company said the offer was not conditioned on the receipt of any minimum number of A.D.R.'s, each of which represents two Tricentrol ordinary shares.
ARCO said the offer was part of its previously announced plan to acquire all shares of Tricentrol, a small British oil company.


3-Way Muddle; Primary Vote Leaves Many Questions But No Clear Leader for Democrats
LEAD: Among the Democrats this year, there is a palpable hunger for an ''electable'' candidate.
The party has captured the White House only once in the last 20 years, and now it is presented with what looks like a rich opportunity, with the conclusion of the Reagan era.
So a big question after


Correction
LEAD: The ''60-Minute Gourmet'' column in The Living Section on Feb. 24 omitted an instruction for an ingredient in sauerkraut with pork chops.
The ingredient, apple cubes, should be added in step 6. along with the wine, bay leaf and thyme.

Education; From Shakespeare to Hansberry to Cafeteria Post
LEAD: The waxed floor of Room 108L glistens from the morning light.
Vacant student desks are marshaled like a platoon set for a parade.
Chris Ask is already at his desk going through trial runs with the tape recorder and phonograph that will be vital to the day's lessons.


Suit Charges Bias in Foster-Care Rules for Aliens
LEAD: New York City and the Legal Aid Society sued the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday, contending that alien children who are in foster care have little chance to become legal residents of the United States.


U.S. and Japan Talks Fail
LEAD: Discussions between the United States and Japan over participation by American companies in Japanese construction projects ended in failure today.

The Editorial Notebook; Stanford Enriches Its 'Core'
LEAD: Who controls a university's curriculum and what should a required ''core'' curriculum contain?
These questions continue to roil Stanford University.
A faculty-student task force recommends broadening a required program on Western civilization.
It wants to incorporate material on the contributions of women and minority members, and thus has ignited far-flung controversy.

Sports People; Marino Steady Patient
LEAD: One day after being released from Pembroke Pines General Hospital in Florida after tests for a stomach disorder he suffered last Saturday, Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins headed for California and another knee operation yesterday.
Dr.
Richard Steadman is to perform arthroscopic surgery in Lake Tahoe, on Marino's left knee, the quarterback's fourth such operation in five years.

LEAD: A grand jury has indicted a 35-year-old man on 1,148 counts of rape, sodomy and other charges involving the sexual abuse of his two step-daughters over a three-year period, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

China Indicates Support for Arms Embargo on Iran
LEAD: The Chinese Foreign Minister told President Reagan today that China would support a United Nations arms embargo on Iran if the resolution wins the backing of an ''overwhelming majority'' of the Security Council.

Sports of The Times; Whose Fans Lead in the Lout Rankings?
LEAD: IT has always been a matter of perverse civic pride that the absolute best and the absolute worst sports fans resided in New York.
Sometimes they even resided in the same building, like hockey fans who levitated the Rangers into the Stanley Cup semifinals of 1986, while a few cretins chanted ''Get a Porsche'' at the Philadelphia goalies, referring to Pelle


Guemes Island Journal; Will Seaweed Farming Mean Paradise Lost or Kept?
LEAD: Mention sushi in this pocket of paradise and you'll probably be run off the island.
The raw fish, a much-maligned food of the stylish moderns, is wrapped in seaweed, which the Japanese called nori.
Now plans are under way to make Guemes Island the nori capital of the Western Hemisphere by establishing a 700-acre seaweed farm here, Farming, in this part of the world, has clearly changed: salmon are raised in pens and seaweed is grown in underwater nets suspended from floats in saltwater ranches, dried and then processed into thin sheets of edible wrapping.

OIL MINISTERS SEEK MEETINGS TO AVERT COLLAPSE IN PRICES
LEAD: A sharp drop in crude oil prices in recent weeks has prompted oil ministers around the world to call for emergency meetings aimed at preventing a recurrence of the 1986 price collapse.


Bridge: Two Players at Same Table Had a Reason to Bid Eight
LEAD: Something patently illegal was seriously debated early in this century: Can players bid eight if they choose?


Boston
LEAD: IN this city, the name Legal has been associated for years with fresh and basically unadorned seafood.
So it came as no small surprise to Boston restaurant patrons when the Legal Sea Foods restaurant chain announced last December that it would introduce exotic Chinese preparations to its already extensive menu.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: Anna Quindlen is on vacation.
Her column is moving to The Home Section, where it will appear starting March 24.


Corning Glass to Buy International Clinical
LEAD: Corning Glass Works, whose products range from Steuben crystal to dental ceramic, said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire International Clinical Laboratories Inc. for $26 a share, or about $260 million.


Cuomo Says G.O.P. Seeks To Overspend on Programs
LEAD: Saying that Republicans in the State Senate ''have always been the big spenders,'' Governor Cuomo charged today that Senate Republicans were pressing for almost $2 billion worth of programs the state cannot afford.


Floridians Find It Easy to Get Permits to Carry Hidden Guns
LEAD: Only three people who have applied for permits to carry concealed weapons under a new Florida gun law have been turned down because of previous crimes.
But officials say many convictions do not appear in the records because of loopholes.

In France, A Fondness For Homey Classics
LEAD: BENEATH the lofty toques of most haute cuisine chefs in France is a humble bistro cook, or so it seemed on a recent trip through Paris and Burgundy, with stops at 20 or so restaurants.
Everywhere, chefs and restaurateurs were talking about a rekindled interest in ingenuous home cooking, rhapsodizing over boeuf bourguignonne and coq au vin with a fervor once reserved for the latest nouvelle cuisine flourish.


Tourism Up in O.E.C.D.
LEAD: Tourism flourished in major industrial countries last year, tentatively topping the record set in 1985, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.
Real tourist trade earnings (allowing for inflation and exchange rate fluctuations) climbed 6 percent in the 24-nation O.E.C.D., compared with the 1986 rise of three-tenths of 1 percent.


Sales by Sequa
LEAD: The Sequa Corporation, formerly the Sun Chemical Corporation, said it would withdraw from third-party insurance operations and had agreed to sell its Chromalloy American Insurance Group Inc. to Resolute Holdings Inc. for undisclosed terms.
Additionally, the company said it planned to dispose of all of its land transportation businesses, which include the American Transit Corporation and Hausman Bus Sales Inc., as well as its Woolley Tool petroleum services business.


Sports People; Wieland Hits Tape
LEAD: Bob Wieland, who lost both legs during the Vietnam War, crossed the finish line yesterday morning and completed the Los Angeles Marathon, which he started last Saturday.
Wieland covered the 26-mile-385-yard course in about 74 1/2 hours, using his powerful arms to push himself along.
He bettered his 1987 time by 18 hours.

Rangers Win After 3 Early Goals
LEAD: The last 15 minutes of the third period were filled with fights and fouls, bad goals and regrettable mistakes.
For the Rangers, none of those 15 minutes were elegant at all.
Luckily, not a one of them mattered in the least.

2d U.S. Appeals Court Hears Japanese Internment Lawsuit
LEAD: A second Federal appeals court here heard arguments today in the case of 120,000 Japanese-Americans who were held in prison camps in World War II.

Manila Accused of Rights Abuses
LEAD: Amnesty International today accused the Philippine Government and Government-backed forces of carrying out unlawful killings, including mutilations and a beheading, in the name of preventing an insurgency.


Chevron in Talks On Soviet Venture
LEAD: The Chevron Corporation is talking with the Soviet Union about creating a joint venture in the petroleum business, a Chevron spokesman said.
Chevron officials have repeatedly visited the Soviet Union in recent months to discuss business opportunities.
On Friday, Nikolai Lemayev, the Soviet Minister of Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Industries, had discussions with Chevron officials in San


Martin Herzer Is Dead; Stage Manager Was 45
LEAD: Martin Herzer, a production stage manager who worked on many of the most successful Broadway shows of the last decade, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 45 years old.

Tibet Unrest: Fears Return; Display of Tolerance Fails to Win Hearts
LEAD: The details emerging about the violent anti-Chinese demonstrations Saturday in Tibet leave little doubt that Beijing's attempt to court Tibetans through a display of greater tolerance has won neither their loyalty nor acceptance of the Chinese presence.


Abram Hails Israeli 'Restraint'
LEAD: The head of a delegation of American Jews that returned over the weekend from Israel said yesterday that Israel was ''trying to handle a difficult situation with care and circumspection'' in its occupied territories and blamed ''Arab intransigence'' for the deadlock in peace talks.

Real Estate; City in Jersey Adds Space For Industry
LEAD: GLEAMING new office towers and attractive new shops on George Street, New Brunswick's main commercial thoroughfare, are the most visible signs of rebirth in that central New Jersey city, which in the last five years has regained its economic footing after years of decline.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Ameron Inc., Monterey Park, Calif., a maker of construction products, basic steel products and protective coatings and liners, said it had repurchased 911,400 common shares, or about 18.6 percent, from Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd. for $36 a share, a total of $32.8 million.


Whirlpool Pursues Deal With Roper
LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation indicated that it would try to complete its acquisition of the Roper Corporation despite the existence of a higher bid by the General Electric Company.
The company issued a statement saying that it ''remains firmly committed to effecting the agreed upon transaction'' with Roper.


Illegal Arms Deal Trial Opens in District Court
LEAD: The lawyer for a New York arms dealer asserted yesterday that his client, acting on behalf of American intelligence officials, had tried in 1982 and 1983 to purchase two Soviet tanks from Polish generals.

PEN/Faulkner Group Lists Award Nominees
LEAD: The nominees for the eighth annual PEN/Faulkner Award for the best American fiction of 1987 were announced yesterday.


60-MINUET GOURMET
LEAD: RECENTLY I took a casual inventory of the various foods that have been prepared for this column to determine the one most commonly used.
It turned out to be, of course, chicken breasts, which, for a variety of reasons, are a great choice for cooking in less than an hour.


Appeals Court Backs G.M. on X-Car Safety
LEAD: Three Federal appellate judges today upheld a lower court's finding that there was no evidence that the General Motors Corporation knowingly sold 1.1 million 1980 X-cars with brake defects.


Review/Opera; First 'Cosi' of Metropolitan Season
LEAD: The ragged edges of stage business and musical ensemble in ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera Monday evening will probably smooth themselves out in later performances.
It may be, too, that the singers will find their way to a feeling, thinking exploration of Mozart's six characters and the funny, sad, searing, bewildering situation they get themselves into.

Review/Oratorio
LEAD: How ironic that Alessandro Stradella, one of music history's more rakish figures, should have composed a magnificent oratorio on the folly of injudicious lust barely a year before he was assassinated in consequence of an adulterous liaison.


Blacks, Years After Selma, Share in Jackson's Victory
LEAD: Twenty-three years ago this week, demonstrators marching for the right of black people to vote were turned back at the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., by policemen with dogs and cattle prods.


Australia Loan to China
LEAD: Australia has agreed to lend China 200 million Australian dollars, or about $145 million, in low-interest funds for trade-related projects, an Australian Government minister said today.
Industry Minister John Button said that terms for the three-year loan had not been set but that the rate would be well below commercial levels.

Bridge: Contract May Be a Puzzle, Even With 4 Hands Visible
LEAD: One of the principal challenges of bridge is to find the best contract for you and your partner without being able to see the other hands.
The challenge would be trivial if you could see all 52 cards.
True or false?

LEAD: With no dominant or polarizing personality on the political scene - no Roosevelt or Eisenhower, no Nixon or Reagan -we should not be asking ourselves ''Who is winning?'' so much as ''What is winning?'' To help us see what direction America is taking, let us use the prism of the losers.

INSIDE
LEAD:  A New Capital for Japan?


Big Arbitrager Remains in Jail
LEAD: John A. Mulheren, the major arbitrager who is accused of threatening Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted insider trader, remained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center last night, awaiting an appeals court hearing this morning on whether he can be transferred to the private Carrier Foundation, a clinic in Belle Mead, N.J., as desired by his family.


Review/Music; Sinfonova, Bostonians Who Play With Elan
LEAD: Musical groups with distinct personalities aren't that common today, but the Sinfonova Chamber Orchestra - which came from Boston for a Carnegie Hall concert Sunday night - does seem to have its own voice.
The real speaker is apparently the group's conductor, Aram Gharabekian, who worships at the altars of forward melodic movement and beautiful sound.


Tidy City Is Paramount For Jakarta's Governor
LEAD: The new Governor of the city of Jakarta, a national capital territory that is a little (but only a little) like the District of Columbia, has spent most of his first six months in office getting the bad news.


S.E.C., in Filing, Challenges New York Takeover Law
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission submitted a friend-of-the-court brief in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday arguing that New York State's anti-takeover law is unconstitutional.


Jock Semple, Marathon Official
LEAD: John Duncan (Jock) Semple, who was involved wih the Boston Marathon for six decades but will always be remembered for chasing down a woman who entered illegally in 1967, died today.
He was 84 years old.

After Super Tuesday; Hart to Meet Reporters; May Be Quitting Race
LEAD: Gary Hart canceled travel plans today and scheduled a news conference for Friday morning, when he may abandon his race for the Democratic Presidential nomination a second time.


Armed Against Birds, Bomber Set for Duty
LEAD: The first B-1B bomber to be strengthened against damage by birds was cleared for flight training today, allowing the Air Force to fly a low-altitude training mission for the first time in more than five months.


Japanese to Buy U.S. Grain Hauler
LEAD: C.Itoh &amp; Company and the National Federation of Agriculture Cooperative Associations will join forces to buy the Consolidated Grain and Barge Company, an American grain transporter based in St.
Louis, C. Itoh officials said.
They said they expect to sign an agreement to buy Consolidated Grain and Barge, which has 30 elevators and 650 barges along the Mississippi River, late next month.


Benjamin Borsody, 87, An Innovator in Radio
LEAD: Benjamin Frank Borsody, a construction engineer and innovator in radio systems design, died Sunday at the Kensington Manor Nursing Home in Sarasota, Fla., after a series of strokes.
He was 87 years old and lived in Sarasota.


Government Gives Private Sector A Chance to Run Medicare Plans
LEAD: Thousands of retired clothing workers will participate in an experimental program in which their union's welfare fund will manage the retirees' health care using Medicare funds.


Architecture Director Named at the Modern
LEAD: Stuart Wrede, an architect with wide experience as a teacher and museum curator, has been named director of the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, the museum announced yesterday.


Phoenix Journal; Her Life's Work (Not So Oddly) Is Matching Shoes With Feet
LEAD: Jeanne Sallman's ranch house here is stuffed with boxes of shoes - anything from a skinhead's black leather stomping fantasy to a disco dancer's Day-Glo chartreuse pump.


Safe-Sex Version of a Pornographic Film
LEAD: When Elisa Florez was studying political science at Georgetown University in 1984 she did not know what AIDS was.


Supporter of LaRouche Wins Democratic Post in Houston
LEAD: Local Democratic leaders here spent the day trying to explain how a supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the extremist politician, was elected Tuesday as chairman of the Harris County Democratic Party.

Malaysian Politician Freed
LEAD: A regional court today freed a leading opposition politician who had been imprisoned without trial since Oct. 27.
The politician, Karpal Singh, was released in Ipoh, 120 miles north of Kuala Lumpur, after he won a lawsuit charging wrongful arrest.
Mr.
Karpal is a member of Parliament and the Vice President of the opposition Democratic Action Party.

Pile, an interior designer and teacher at Pratt Institute, has written a book that is a refreshing anomaly in design textbooks.
It is informative without being dull, and would be as suitable on a coffee table as on a designer's bookshelf.

Review/Violin; Bach to Sibelius to Faure
LEAD: If Joshua Bell develops into the art-ist his best work suggested at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening, he will satisfy some wants that are mostly given short shrift in today's violin playing.
In the first half of the recital, he distinguished himself mostly by being tasteful and expert.
He did not employ a thick, hectic vibrato; he did not saw at the allegros in his Mozart (K.


7 Die in Arizona Road Crash
LEAD: A man driving a motor home hit a tractor-trailer rig Monday, causing a four-vehicle crash and fire that killed him, his wife and their four grandchildren, officials said.
Also killed was a woman driving a pilot truck behind the tractor-trailer on the narrow, twisting section of U.S. 93 near this remote community in western Arizona, the authorities said.


Wachtler Asks for 17 Criminal Court Judges
LEAD: The state's Chief Judge said today that drug arrests in New York City had increased so rapidly - by 65 percent over two years - that its courts were on the verge of crisis and needed 17 more judges.

Mobil Plans to Sell Additional Assets
LEAD: The Mobil Corporation said it expects to get another $500 million from asset sales in 1988 in addition to the $1.5 billion in cash it will receive from its deal to sell the Montgomery Ward retailing business.
Mobil's president, Richard Tucker, told securities analysts that the additional $500 million would come from the sale of ''dribs and drabs'' in the company.


Reward for Carlesimo
LEAD: P. J. Carlesimo, Seton Hall's head basketball coach, received a new five-year contract yesterday after guiding the Pirates to their best season in 32 years.
The signing ended months of speculation on whether Carlesimo would be back.
He compiled a 54-92 mark in his previous five seasons at Seton Hall and may have saved his job with this season's 20-11 record and an 8-8 Big East mark.

Home Improvement
LEAD: MUCH ordinary furniture made during this century, and even some fine furniture, is fastened with dowels: cylindrical wooden pegs that function like nails or screws but are held in place by glue.
When installed expertly, dowels create a joint tat is usually stronger and longer lasting than one with metal fasteners.

An American Ritual Sold by the Foot
LEAD: REAL linoleum, made from linseed oil, wood dust, cork and resins, has not been manufactured in the United States for over 10 years.
But some distributors import linoleum from Europe in styles from purely durable to high-tech chic.
American manufacturers are keeping up by making new vinyl tiles and sheets with brick, floral and marbleized motifs that recall the old look.

LEAD: The Swedish forestry company Stora Kopparbergs Bergslags A.B. will merge with Swedish Match A.B. in a deal valued at $983 million for Swedish Match's owners.

Cuba Economy Shrank in 1987
LEAD: Cuba's economy shrank 3.5 percent in 1987 after expanding an average 7.2 percent a year during the 1981-85 period, according to a confidential report by the central bank.
It grew 1.4 percent in 1986.
The decline of Cuba's gross social product (the Communist equivalent of gross national product) confirmed that 1987 was a very difficult year for the Cuban economy.

LEAD: The Jets traded Barry Bennett, the 32-year-old defensive lineman, to the Los Angeles Raiders yesterday for an undisclosed draft choice.

Hers

In 20 years, we had all come a long way.

Hungary, Suzuki Discuss Venture
LEAD: Hungary is holding talks with the Suzuki Motor Company and other Japanese companies to set up its first car assembly plant in a joint venture worth 10 billion forints, or about $210 million, the Hungarian press agency said.
The assembly of 50,000 Suzuki Alto mini-cars annually could begin in two years, the press agency said.

Personal Health
LEAD: When sexual intercourse causes pain instead of pleasure, the effects on the partners and the relationship can be devastating.
The partner who is in pain is likely to avoid sexual activity, and the other partner is likely to feel guilty and reluctant to inflict pain by attempting intercourse.
Both partners may end up frustrated and resentful as well as confused when an activity purported to bring joy to so many turns out to be so discomforting for them.

An Old Pro
LEAD: Seventy-year-old Joe Redington, the second-oldest musher in the field, is leading the Iditarod sled-dog race, a grueling 1,150-mile course from Anchorage to Nome, Alaska.
He dashed out of the checkpoint at McGrath yesterday saying, ''I feel like an old fox being chased by 50 young hounds.'' Redington left the town on the Kuskokwim River after staying just over four hours to feed and rest his 14 dogs.

Migration to America 33,000 Years Ago Hinted
LEAD: Radiocarbon dating of charcoal found with ancient stone tools in southern Chile has bolstered the argument of some experts that humans lived in the Americas 33,000 years ago, much earlier than is generally accepted, anthropologists reported yesterday.


Nothing Is Easy for Rangers' Patrick
LEAD: James Patrick might have guessed it wasn't going to be as easy as it looked.
The New Jersey goal was empty, the path to it clear, the chances for the Ranger defenseman's second goal of the night apparently excellent.
Patrick, who never put the puck in the net, would eventually be credited with the goal anyway, thereby providing the Rangers with their final score in a 7-4 pounding of the Devils at Madison Square Garden


RKO to Acquire Video Retailer
LEAD: RKO Warner Theaters Video Inc. agreed to buy the Super Video Inc. home-video outlet business from the General Cinema Corporation in a deal that RKO said would make it the largest video retailer in the country.
Terms were not disclosed.
Super Video operates more than 370 video rental and sales outlets in supermarket chains in the United States, while RKO Warner Theaters Video has 20 video ''superstores'' in New York and New Jersey.


Black &amp; Decker Shuns Bid Talks
LEAD: The Black &amp; Decker Corporation said it would not take part in talks about a cease-fire in its $2 billion hostile takeover attack on American Standard Inc.
On Tuesday American Standard proposed an agreement under which it would provide Black &amp; Decker with non-public information.
But Black &amp; Decker said the arrangement would have prohibited additional action to pursue its $73-a-share bid for the New York-based plumbing and air-conditioning maker.


Peremptory Challenges By Defense Are Upheld
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that judges cannot bar defense lawyers from excluding potential jurors on the basis of race, sex, religion or national origin.

LEAD: Eight of the Southern and border states allow voters to cast ballots in either party's primary, regardless of their party registration.
The states are Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Mississippi, Missouri, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia.

LEAD: The landmark status of nearly 30 Broadway auditoriums is at stake today as a tempestuous fight between the Koch administration and the major theater owners goes to the Board of Estimate, with a chance that many recent designations might be altered.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1988
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL  OPEC is studying a plan to reduce oil output by 5 percent, several officials of the organization said.
The proposal is intended to address the slide in oil prices, which have recently fallen to $13 to $14 a barrel, from OPEC's official price of $18.
Non-OPEC oil producers met in London.

Atlantic Air Traffic Gain
LEAD: More than 25.8 million passengers flew across the North Atlantic in 1987, a 21.7 percent rise from the previous year, the International Air Transport Association said today.
David Kyd, a spokesman for the Geneva-based association, said that the number of North Atlantic passengers in 1986 totaled only 21.1 million as Americans stayed away from Europe because of the dollar's weakness, fear of terrorism and concern about the fallout from the Chernobyl accident.

Super Tuesday Primaries: The Results
LEAD: The table below gives results of the primary elections for President held Tuesday in 16 states.
The columns indicate the vote for each candidate, his percentage of the total, the delegates won, and the percentage of the total delegates.
Where total delegates in a state do not add to 100 percent, the preference of one or more delegates has not been determined.

5% Output Cut Studied By OPEC
LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is studying a plan to reduce its oil output about 5 percent, equivalent to 850,000 barrels a day for all its members with the exception of Iraq, several OPEC officials said today.


Expert Advice
LEAD: According to Postmaster J. Robert Tracey of Morristown, N.J., a higher-than-normal number of postal carriers slipped and fell on ice this winter.
The solution?
Enter Randy Velischek, defenseman for the Devils.
Velischek will speak at the Morristown post office from 8 A.M. to 10 A.M. on Tuesday to tell carriers how to avoid trips, slips and falls on ice.

LEAD: To the Editor:


A Steam Engine From China
LEAD: A tourist rail line based here is going to the Far East to find a new steam locomotive.
The Valley Railroad plans to spend about $300,000 on a new locomotive from China, where 70 percent of the locomotives are run by steam because of that country's scarcity of oil and surfeit of coal.
It is cheaper to go there for the engine than to have one custom-built in the United States or rebuild an old one, railroad officials said.


Savings Unit Loan Pledge
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board issued a long-expected resolution today to reassure uneasy Wall Street securities firms that have lent funds to the Financial Corporation of America's ailing savings unit, the American Savings and Loan Association.


Yields Post Small Drop
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were down slightly for the week ended yesterday.

French Trade Deficit
LEAD: The French current account balance of payments swung back into a deficit in 1987 after achieving its first surplus for seven years in 1986, the Finance Ministry said today.
The current account, which measures not only trade in goods and services but also such invisible items as bank transfers, fell to a deficit of 27.2 billion francs, or about $4.9 billion, in 1987 from a surplus of 20.2 billion francs the previous year.


Police Charge 5 at Princeton in Drinking Spree
LEAD: Five Princeton University students were charged today with serving alcohol to minors during campus parties that resulted in 36 people being taken to the hospital for drinking too much.

Forstmann Little
LEAD: Forstmann Little &amp; Company, the investment firm that specializes in buyouts, announced that some of its affiliates plan to divest themselves of four units with the help of Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, the investment banking firm.
The units, which have total annual sales of $500 million, are American Electric of Memphis, a unit of FL Industries; Reznor, of Mercer, Pa., another FL division; Janitrol Aero, a division of the FL Aerospace Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio, and the Management Services Corporation of Oklahoma City, a unit of Lear Siegler Holdings.

Investors Remain on the Sidelines
LEAD: Bond traders and investors remained on the sidelines yesterday, resulting in the third consecutive day of listless activity with no substantial change in interest rates.


I.M.F. Loan to Sri Lanka
LEAD: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $343 million loan to help with economic reform in Sri Lanka.
The I.M.F. said that, of the total, $194 million would be available over the next three years, of which $61 million could be drawn immediately.


Mathematics Expert May Soon Resolve A 350-Year Problem
LEAD: One of the most notorious unsolved problems of mathematics, a 350-year-old conjecture known as Fermat's Last Theorem, may be close to succumbing to a new line of attack, mathematicians said yesterday.

LEAD: The crumbling remnants of the solid Democratic South were dealt another blow in Tuesday's primaries, when hundreds of thousands more people voted in Republican primaries than had ever done so before.


Talking Deals; Signs of Revival For Junk Bonds
LEAD: WHEN the stock market crashed in October, many on Wall Street expected takeover activity to stall, largely because junk bonds, those speculative high-yield securities that backed many deals, became too costly to issue.
Fearful of a recession, investors demanded, and got, a higher return for accepting the securities' greater risk.

The Editorial Notebook; The New Jesse Jackson
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson, who came out of Super Tuesday a certifiably mainstream candidate, really is different this year.
Four years ago, such a showing would likely have provoked him to an indignant denunciation of the disparity between his popular vote and the delegates he earned.
This year, Mr.
Jackson reacted with almost introspective humility.

Feeling Safe
LEAD: ''Semper Paratus - Always Ready'' is the motto of the United States Coast Guard.
And so, there they were, 28 active duty Guardsmen and 13 reservists, protecting the Kansas coast of the Missouri River ''against any possible threat of terrorism,'' according to the service's Reservist issue for March.

LEAD: P. J. CARLESIMO believes in ''we.'' He believes in it so much that ''we'' were named Big East coach of the year yesterday, ''we'' received a five-year extension worth as much as $1 million from Seton Hall University on Wednesday, and ''we'' have a chance against Georgetown this afternoon.

Several top aides urged him to concede the state, and thus almost certainly the Republican Presidential nomination, to Vice President Bush.

Trio in Debut at Y
LEAD: The Fisk Karr Lewis Trio - a new ensemble featuring Eliot Fisk, guitarist; Gary Karr, double bassist, and Harmon Lewis, harpsichordist - is to make its New York debut tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
The Baroque program features solo and ensemble works by Quantz, Torelli, Soler, Telemann, Bach and Rameau.

This time, Mr.
Lowe has the more interesting job of playing Tim Whalan, whose good looks, good manners and racing record make him very much in demand, especially among those Hamptons residents who know about his other, less obvious talents.

LEAD: Costa Rican Ambassador Guido Fernandez, regarded in some quarters as one of the most effective ambassadors in Washington for his efforts to promote the President Oscar Arias Sanchez's Central American peace plan, left the United States Thursday to become Costa Rica's Minister of Information.
But a small cloud hangs over his departture.


Mrs. Reagan Has Skin Patch Scraped From Her Upper Lip
LEAD: A dermatologist removed a small patch of skin from Nancy Reagan's upper lip and tests show it to be noncancerous, her spokeswoman said today.


New York Panel to Urge Broader Role for Teachers
LEAD: A task force appointed by the State Education Commissioner is expected to recommend that schools throughout New York be restructured to give teachers a greater decision-making role in areas ranging from textbook selection to hiring practices.


Review/Theater; Danner and Quinn In a New 'Streetcar'
LEAD: ''We've had this date with each other from the beginning,'' says Stanley Kowalski to his sister-in-law, Blanche DuBois, just before he sweeps her away to bed in ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' That line -wholly in character for Stanley and yet a classic expression of tragedy's inexorable pull - sets off what is still among the most shocking acts of human destruction the American stage has known.


Soviet Reports 9 Died in Hijacking of Jet by Family
LEAD: A woman led at least three of her seven sons - jazz musicians who hid weapons in their instrument cases - in the hijacking of a Soviet airliner Wednesday in which nine people were killed, official accounts said today, The mother and sons were among 11 members of the same family who boarded the flight in the Siberian city of Irkutsk, apparently hoping they could force the crew to take them to London instead of Leningrad, the plane's final destination, according to the accounts.

Hans A. Panofsky, 70, Scientist
LEAD: Hans A. Panofsky, an atmospheric scientist who taught at Pennsylvania State University for 30 years and who was credited with several advances in the study of meteorology, died of a cerebral hemorrhage after a heart attack on Feb. 28 in San Diego, where he lived.
He was 70 years old.


McGuigan to Return
LEAD: Barry McGuigan of Northern Ireland won the world featherweight championship from Eusebio Pedroza on June 8, 1985.
He defended it twice, then lost a controversial decision to Stevie Cruz in Las Vegas, Nev., on June 23, 1986.
He has not fought since.
McGuigan, 27 years old, plans to make his comeback April 20 in London as a superfeatherweight against one of three opponents - Francisco Tomas Cruz of Brazil, Gerome Porras of Puerto Rico, or Tommie Cordova of the United States.


Big East Tournament; Parity May Emerge as Champion
LEAD: Many reasonable observers think that this year's Big East Conference tournament is anyone's tournament, that any of six teams could wind up in Sunday's championship game.
Pitt is the regular-season champion, Syracuse is right on the Panthers' heels, Seton Hall is on a roll, and Georgetown is ever Georgetown.


Schedule for the New Directors Series
LEAD: The New Directors/New Films series opens tonight at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.
All films will be shown at the museum's Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters I and II.
Single tickets are $5, except for screenings of ''Little Dorrit,'' which cost $10.
A series ticket is $90.
Additional showings may be scheduled for some sold-out films.

Who's Living Up to the Arias Plan?
LEAD: Nicaragua has gone further in complying with the Arias peace plan than Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador.
However tardily and grudgingly, the Sandinistas are negotiating directly with their sworn enemies, the contras.
There's more diversity of published and spoken opinion in Managua than in those other three ostensibly democratic countries.

He was 30 years old.

The Cost of Sales Calls In Europe Is Surveyed
LEAD: McGraw-Hill is always doing research on how much average sales calls cost in hopes that publishing that figure will lead manufacturers to use advertising in McGraw-Hill publications to augment such calls.


Waldheim Apologizes for War Crimes by Austrians
LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim publicly apologized today on behalf of his country for Nazi crimes committed by Austrians.
