A Correction
LEAD: Because of an error by the authors, the ''first major United States bank to actually charge off some third world debt from its books'' was mis-identified in an article March 3 by Robin Broad and John Cavanagh.
The proper institution is the First Na-tional Bank of Boston.


New Meese Link to Pipeline Payment Is Reported
LEAD: A $150,000 payment from Bruce Rappaport, a Swiss businessman, to his American lawyer for work on an Iraqi pipeline project was deposited into a stock trading account that made investments for several people, including Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, according to people familiar with the transaction.

Where Two Can Dine for Under $50
LEAD: DINNER for two in the average New York restaurant has broken the three-digit barrier, and with a little imagination when it comes to wine, the damages could easily surpass $150.
Add to that expense drinks before dinner, miscellaneous service tips, the coat check fees, cab fare, maybe a baby sitter and a trip to the dry cleaner afterward to get that chocolate stain out of your new silk tie, and you may resort to looting the Christmas


The Icy Nightmare of '88
LEAD: The Weather Bureau forecast fresh-to-brisk winds and fair weather for the Northeast on March 11, 1888, followed by rain.
Rain it did, in torrents.
Then shortly past midnight the rain turned to snow, with fierce winds, and it snowed for most of three days.
Unheralded, it was a storm to make history - the

LEAD: To the Editor:


Manufacturers Hanover Sees No Dividend Cut
LEAD: Long the target of rumors that it would be forced to cut its dividend, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation yesterday laid out the reasons it believes that move would be unnecessary.


Restaurants
LEAD: JOHN CLANCY no longer owns John Clancy's restaurant.
His former chef, Sam Rubin, does - although Mr.
Rubin is no longer chef.
That job is handled by a capable young woman named Melissa Lord.
If this is getting confusing, don't worry, the important news is that seven-year-old John Clancy's, the handsome all-seafood restaurant in Greenwich


U.S.F.L. Loses Appeal
LEAD: A Federal appeals court in New York yesterday upheld a 1986 verdict that effectively ended the existence of the United States Football League.

Ear Retrieved and Restored
LEAD: Doctors have reattached a 2-year-old boy's ear after retrieving it from the stomach of one of three pit bulls that mauled him.
The boy, Chris Graham, was attacked by the dogs at his grandparents' farm on Tuesday, officials said.


Recital Is Canceled
LEAD: The joint recital by the violinist Shlomo Mintz and the pianist Yefim Bronfman that was scheduled for Sunday at 3 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall has been canceled.
Mr.
Mintz has the flu.
The concert will not be rescheduled.
Refunds are available by mail or in person at the Fisher Hall box office.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Feb. 24 about the Equitable Gas Company misstated the size of its advertising budget for 1988.
It is $750,000, a company spokesman said.


Amid Avowals of Love, Bursts of Hate
LEAD:  To Dwell in Peace: An Autobiography  By Daniel Berrigan. 356 pages.
Harper &amp; Row. $19.95.


Wedtech Jury Chosen; Arguments Due Today
LEAD: Twelve jurors and six alternates were chosen yesterday in the trial of Representative Mario Biaggi and six other men charged with racketeering in the Wedtech Corporation case.
Opening arguments are scheduled for 10:30 this morning.

Joint Agency Idea Attacked
LEAD: The new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission reiterated her position today that the agency should remain independent from the Securities and Exchange Commission.
She also urged better coordination between the two regulatory agencies.


Writers' Talks Halted
LEAD: Scriptwriters and producers meeting under the guidance of a Federal mediator broke off talks Thursday on ending a four-day strike, the executive director of the Writers Guild of America-East reported.
The official, Mona Mangan, was at the talks with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers in Los Angeles.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: LEGEND has it that Marco Polo packed his saddle bags with pasta from China in the 13th century and carried it back to Italy, where it became a national dish.
Be that true or not - I find it difficult to believe that he didn't polish it off en route - pasta of all sorts has never ceased to be popular in China.


TV Weekend; 'Bacall on Bogart,' Profile of the Ultimate Tough Guy
LEAD: Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall met each other in 1944.
He was in his mid-40's; she was 19.
The star and the starlet had been signed to make ''To Have and Have Not,'' the first of their four movies together.
They were married in 1945.
He died in 1957.


Top Catholic Rivals in Final
LEAD: When Tolentine and Molloy met in the semifinal round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association playoffs last year, the 6,000-seat Alumni Hall at St.
John's was sold out.
When they met this season, Molloy's 1,100-seat gym was filled.
The same will probably be true at 8 P.M. tomorrow, when they will meet in the C.H.S.A.A.


At The Bar
LEAD: Complaints about incompetent lawyers and frivolous litigation are perennial.
But they reached a peak in the early 1980's, with the nation's top lawyer, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, leading the assault.
Indeed, along with his attacks on advertising by lawyers and his scuffles with television photographers, Chief Justice


Rivals Switch Emphasis to Electability
LEAD: With the great battle for the South behind them and Illinois's rich cache of delegates in front of them, the remaining candidates for President today began looking toward the general election in November and at who had the best chance of winning then.


Presidio Oil Makes Hostile Sabine Bid
LEAD: The Presidio Oil Company, an oil and gas concern based in Englewood, Colo., began a hostile tender offer of $20 a share, or $256 million, for the Sabine Corporation.
Presidio also plans a proxy contest to gain control of the board of the Dallas oil and gas exploration and production concern, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Head of Harvard Says No to Teacher's Tenure
LEAD: Derek Bok, president of Harvard University, refused today to grant tenure to an assistant law professor associated with an ideology challenging the traditional view of the law.


Bonfire in Bronx!!! Wolfe Catches Flak!!!
LEAD: He held on for dear life, as if a tornado were going to rise up at any moment and blow them out of the proper groove and -back to the Bronx! - ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' Tom Wolfe (1987)


Boy, 15, Is Convicted of Murder for Thrill
LEAD: A 15-year-old boy who beat a classmate to death with a baseball bat because he wanted to know what it was like to kill someone was convicted of murder today and sentenced to life in prison.


McDonnell and Lockheed Talk
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had held exploratory subcontracting talks with the Lockheed Corporation and several other companies on producing its new commercial aircraft line.


Shultz, Seeing Arab 'Time Bomb,' Urges Israelis to Rethink Borders
LEAD: Pressing his campaign for Arab-Israeli peace talks, Secretary of State George P. Shultz today urged Israel to rethink its concept of defense and to address the ''ticking demographic time bomb'' of an Arab population under occupation.


Panel told Cleanup of Weapon Plants May Cost $100 Billion
LEAD: Cleaning up the Energy Department's nuclear weapons production plants may cost as much as $100 billion and will pose a major challenge for the Federal Government, a House panel was told today.


Girl Called 5th Victim Of Hammer Attacker
LEAD: A 15-year-old Bronx girl who was hit on the head last week by a man wielding a blunt object, possibly a hammer, is considered the fifth victim of the same attacker, the police said yesterday.


Hamilton Grange, Once Moved, Still Handsome
LEAD: To the Editor:


Gwynn May Need Surgery
LEAD: Tony Gwynn, the Padres outfielder who batted .370 and won his second National League batting title last season, will return to San Diego so that doctors can examine his injured left index finger.
He will probably undergo surgery Friday, and, according to the team trainer, Dick Den, he will be sidelined from four to six weeks.


Dallas Pastor Warned His Wife
LEAD: A former minister left two telephone messages for his wife the night she was choked nearly to death, describing his whereabouts in detail and warning her to lock the garage door, according to tape recordings released today Walker Railey, who was senior pastor of the United Methodist Church of Dallas at the time of the attack, told the police he found his wife, Margaret, unconscious on the floor of the garage at their home April 22.


Debentures From Masco Industries
LEAD: Masco Industries is offering $300 million in 10 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 1995 at 99.358, to yield 10.13 percent, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.
The size of the issue was increased from $250 million.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 420 money market mutual funds increased $1.41 billion, to $280.06 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $423.7 million, to $82.17 billion.
Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were down $306.5 million, to $81.5 billion.

Forstmann Drops Plan for AFG Bid
LEAD: After reviewing confidential financial information, Forstmann Little &amp; Company said it was dropping its plan to submit a competing tender offer for AFG Industries, which earlier this month accepted a $940 million buyout bid from its chairman.
A spokesman for Forstmann Little declined to elaborate.

U.N. to Study Rights in Cuba; U.S. Sees Diplomatic Victor
LEAD: The Reagan Administration claimed a diplomatic victory tonight after the United Nations Human Rights Commission unanimously agreed to accept an invitation from Havana to investigate human rights in Cuba.


Age No Object
LEAD: Matt Dunigan's first day in his new career as a player in the Montreal Expos' farm system raised an old question in West Palm Beach, Fla.
The question concerned the age of Dunigan, a former Edmonton Eskimos quarterback who abandoned the Canadian Football League and signed a minor league contract as an outfielder with the Expos on Wednesday.


Largest Initial Offering Set By Massachusetts Financial
LEAD: The Massachusetts Financial Services Company, the Boston-based investment advisory firm, has arranged to sell $2 billion worth of stock in a new bond fund that would be the largest initial public offering of shares ever arranged.


This Drive Carried As If It Had Wings
LEAD: A sea gull took off with a couple of golf balls today during the first round of the Honda Classic, causing Brad Faxon to wonder if nature's creatures just don't like him.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Lilco Accused of Lying


Crude Oil Rises Above $16 On Talk of OPEC Restraint
LEAD: Prices of crude oil jumped above $16 a barrel yesterday in domestic trading amid conjecture that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might cut production to halt the recent slide in prices.


Federal-City Effort Attacks Violent Brooklyn Drug Ring
LEAD: One of the largest and most violent drug rings operating in Brooklyn has been smashed with the arrest of the group's leader and five major associates, Federal and city law-enforcement officials said yesterday.
Another associate is being sought.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 11, 1988
LEAD:  Companies


The Wake-Up Alarm
LEAD: At last, the danger of AIDS to heterosexuals in the United States has exploded into public debate.


Iraq Offers Cease-Fire in 'War of the Cities'
LEAD: As missile attacks continued in the Persian Gulf war, Iraq offered today to halt the 11-day-old ''war of the cities'' with Iran Friday as long as Iraq fires the last shot.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article on Wednesday from Managua, Nicaragua, reported the abandonment of efforts to convene talks this week between the Sandinista Government and its guerrilla opponents.
The Government dropped the plan after the contras said they would not attend, and each side accused the other of bad faith.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Let us not give rise to the impression that we had nothing to do with this.
Obviously there is no collective guilt.
Nevertheless, as head of state of the Republic of Austria, I wish to apologize for Nazi crimes committed by Austrians.''  - President Kurt Waldheim.  [ A3:3. ]


Connecticut Gains in Tourney
LEAD: A year ago, Connecticut's Cliff Robinson and Phil Gamble were home in Storrs, watching their teammates lose, 61-59, to Boston College in the elimination game of the Big East Conference tournament.


Defense Rests In Chambers Case
LEAD: The defense rested yesterday in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., and court officials said the case would probably go to the jury next week.


INDONESIAN LEADER SEEKS TO BAR VOTE
LEAD: President Suharto, who was elected to a fifth five-year term in office Thursday, has asked that a vote for Vice President be canceled.


Colt to Go Private for $660 Million
LEAD: Colt Industries said yesterday that its directors had approved a $660 million buyout led by senior management and a Morgan Stanley &amp; Company investor group.


Farmers Rejects Batus Proposal
LEAD: Farmers Group Inc. said that it had rejected as inadequate Batus Inc.'s unsolicited offer of $63 a share, or $4.35 billion, and that the company had held exploratory talks with an unspecified third party about a leveraged buyout.

Robert S. Liebert, 58, Psychiatrist
LEAD: Dr.
Robert S. Liebert, a psychiatrist and author, died Wednesday at New York Hospital.
He was 58 years old and lived and practiced in Manhattan.


A Test of Change Explodes in Soviet
LEAD: Two years ago Igor Muradyan, a young economist living in Yerevan, joined a small group of Armenian intellectuals for what they took to be an exercise in democracy.

Review/Film; 'Off Limits,' a Thriller
LEAD: The story is nothing out of the ordinary: two tough-talking, super-macho detectives are put on the trail of a serial killer, a sadomasochist who has been murdering prostitutes and is sure to do it again.
But the setting raises the ante, since it is the turbulent, troubled Saigon of 1968 in which ''Off Limits'' unfolds.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Chrysler Corp. said it would consider resuming vehicle production in Europe if its new trans-Atlantic marketing drive leads to several years of rising sales.
Chrysler expects to be selling cars and Jeeps in Europe at the rate of 25,000 a year by the end of 1988.


Corrections
LEAD: An article from Moscow on Wednesday about a new Soviet income tax misstated the number of employees in Soviet cooperatives.


Trouble for Skier
LEAD: Bill Johnson, the 1984 Olympic gold medalist in downhill skiing who has struggled to recover from knee and back surgery this season, has been temporarily suspended from the United States Ski Team for races in Beaver Creek, Colo., this weekend.
The action could result in Johnson's being dropped from the team because he must pick up points in the remaining races this season to maintain his B-team ranking.


Old Soldier Mobilizes A Gray-Haired Army
LEAD: Old soldiers never die, they just fade away, the refrain goes, but not according to Richard G. Stilwell, the retired Army general.


Chrysler Financial To Offer Notes
LEAD: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, the financing subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, will offer $500 million in medium-term notes, probably this week, and plans additional debt issues in Europe soon.


Advertising; Nostalgia Highlights Sugar Drive
LEAD: THE suppliers of the nation's refined sugar, which have been hit by both changing industrial and consumer uses, are going to try to win back consumers with an adroit use of nostalgia.

Former Chief of Staff Testifies for Mecham
LEAD: Gov.
Evan Mecham's last chief of staff testified today that he would not have responded as the Governor did to reports that another Mecham aide had threatened a grand jury witness.


SOVIET WON'T END AFGHAN ARMS AID
LEAD: A senior Soviet official declared today that Moscow would not cease arming the Kabul Government as part of an agreement for an Afghan cease-fire.
The Reagan Administration has demanded an arms cutoff as part of any peace settlement.


Cardigan Bay Dies at 31
LEAD: Cardigan Bay, a pacer from New Zealand who in 1968 became the first horse in harness racing history to win $1 million in purses, died peacefully in his sleep at the age of 31 last Friday on Puketutu Island off Auckland, New Zealand.

Review: New Directors/New Films; 'Who Killed Vincent Chin?': Answer Is Complex
LEAD: On a hot summer night in 1982, Vincent Chin, a young, thoroughly assimilated Chinese-American, was having a night out with his pals (white), celebrating the last days of his bachelorhood at a Detroit topless bar called the Fancy Pants.
In the course of the evening, Mr.
Chin got into a scuffle with another customer, Ron Ebens, an unemployed auto worker.


Study Sees Bias in New York Teacher Exams
LEAD: The tests New York City uses to license public school teachers are discriminatory, and the city should rely instead on a state-mandated test already in use, a Columbia Law School panel has recommended.

LEAD: *

Skitch Henderson

Tickets, at $30, $27.50, $22.50, $20 and $14, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

LEAD: Three white men were arraigned yesterday on attempted murder charges in random attacks on blacks in the Bronx that the police said followed a black prostitute's rejection of their offers.

Corrections
LEAD: A report in Business Day on Wednesday about the Tandon Corporation misstated the revenues of its disk drive unit.
For the nine months ended in September, the unit had sales of $90 million.
The report also inaccurately described Tandon's personal computer business.
The company has been making personal computers since 1984.


Our Towns; Where Students Make the Grade And $25 a Week
LEAD: Last Friday after third-period remedial math class, the teacher, Lynn Prestia, handed out paychecks to three of her Red Bank High students.
To earn the money, they had attended class for five straight days, were on time, did the homework and brought their supplies.
Travis Patton had two perfect weeks.


Dartmouth Punishes Four as Harassers of Professor
LEAD: Four students at Dartmouth College charged by the school with harassing a black music professor have been given penalties ranging from probation to suspension, the college announced today.

A Cappella Choir
LEAD: The King's Singers, an a cappella choir of seven male voices based at King's College, Cambridge, is to sing works from around the world, Sunday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall.
The program includes ''Scenes in America Deserta'' by the British composer John McCabe; a setting of the Lamentations of Jeremiah by the 17th-century Mexican composer Juan Gutierrez de Padilla; Dvorak's settings of Lithuanian folk songs, and two groups of American works -folk-song settings, and choral versions of works by Paul Simon.

CBS Is Said to Be Replacing Its Political Coverage Chief
LEAD: Richard M. Cohen, a CBS News producer whose maverick actions sometimes provoked the ire of CBS management, has been told that he will be replaced as head of the network's political coverage.


Layoffs at Case IH
LEAD: Tenneco Inc.'s Case IH subsidiary said it planned to cut employment worldwide during 1988 by about 3,000 workers, or 10 percent.
The agricultural and construction equipment producer said the reductions, affecting all areas of the company, would take place in the next few months. ''Employment will be reduced through hourly and salaried layoffs, retirements, attrition, termination of temporary employees, a hiring freeze and improved manufacturing and staff productivity,'' Case said.


Charles Escapes Injury; Avalanche Kills Friend
LEAD: Prince Charles escaped injury today when an avalanche struck while he was skiing.
A close friend was killed and another skier was injured.


Reliance Seeking Rest of Days Inns
LEAD: Reliance Capital Group L.P., which with the publicly traded Reliance Group Holdings Inc. owns 49 percent of the Days Inns Corporation, said it wanted to buy the rest of the hotel chain for $9 a share in cash.
The new offer, which values the company at $182.3 million, revises one made in November that would have paid $7.75 a share in cash and $2.25 a share in preferred stock.


Japanese Surplus in Trade With U.S. Shrinks by 14.4%
LEAD: Japan's unadjusted trade surplus with the United States shrank 14.4 percent in February as imports from the United States reached record levels, the Finance Ministry said today.


Wang Expects Smaller Profits
LEAD: Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that it expected third-quarter earnings and revenues to fall, and its stock dropped sharply as analysts lowered their earnings estimates for the maker of minicomputers and office work stations.


Lorimar Overture By Davis
LEAD: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation, which is already in preliminary discussions about a possible merger with Warner Communications Inc., said yesterday that Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, had asked for a meeting to discuss a possible sale of the company for $17 a share in cash.

BELL COPTER AND ARMY SETTLE CASE
LEAD: The Army and Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. have settled a four-year dispute over accusations that the Army was fraudulently overcharged for helicopter spare parts.
The Army said today that Bell had agreed to pay the Government about $88 million.


U.S. Bonds Fall a Bit in Light Day
LEAD: Treasury bond prices fell modestly yesterday, in reaction to higher prices for oil and gold.


Norway's Statoil in Red
LEAD: Norway's state oil company, Statoil, today reported a record loss of $300 million for 1987, in contrast to 1986's profit of $180 million.
The loss was caused by cost overruns in the expansion of the Mongstad refinery.


EASTERN HITS SNAG IN SALE OF SHUTTLE
LEAD: A Federal district judge held Eastern Air Lines Inc. in contempt today for taking steps to sell its Eastern Air Shuttle to its parent company, the Texas Air Corporation.

He has agreed to keep it open until April 1.

New-Fashioned Films From Novice Directors
LEAD: THE artist David Hockney peers down at a 17th-century Chinese scroll unrolled before him, depicting the emperor's voyage on the Grand Canal.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption in The Home Section on March 3 about tapestries misidentified the site where a weaving in the ''Microchip'' series by Joyce Crain is displayed.
It is at the Lafarge Corporation in Reston, Va.
Another tapestry in the series is at Automatic Data Processing in Dayton, N.J.


Armani an Anchor in a Time of Fashion Flux
LEAD: Giorgio Armani provided a soothing, reassuring conclusion to the fall and winter fashion openings here.
In showings Wednesday night and tonight, each for 500 people in the theater of his headquarters on the Via Borgonuovo, he showed short hemlines and gently shaped clothes.
His sure hand dissipated some of the confusion about the new fashion scene.


Hofstra Ensemble
LEAD: The American Chamber Ensemble, a resident performing group at Hofstra University, is to present a program of music by Long Island composers at CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street, Sunday at 3 P.M.
The ensemble, joined by Stanley Drucker, the principal clarinetist of the New York Philharmonic, will give the New York premiere of Elie Siegmeister's ''Prelude, Blues and Finale'' for two clarinets and piano.

Jazz Musicians Honor Max Gordon, Impresario And Father Figure
LEAD: As Bobby Short pounded out ''Happy Birthday'' on the small platform stage of the Village Vanguard early Thursday evening, some 200 guests joined voices to celebrate the 85th birthday, two days early, of the veteran jazz impresario Max Gordon.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 12, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


American Brands
LEAD: American Brands Inc. of Old Greenwich, Conn., said it had decided to dispose of three additional subsidiaries of its recently acquired E-II Holdings Inc.: the Culligan International Company, the Samsonite Corporation and most of the Samsonite Furniture Company.
American Brands said it would retain the Vogel Peterson division of Samsonite Furniture.


28 THEATERS ARE APPROVED AS LANDMARKS
LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate, in a major victory for preservationists and the Koch administration, unanimously approved landmark status early yesterday for 28 Broadway theaters that have been home to some of the greatest moments in American stage history.


Milt Jackson and Trio
LEAD: Milt Jackson, a vibraphonist, is appearing with a trio led by Monty Alexander on piano tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592).
Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. with a 1:30 A.M. show tonight; there is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $10 charge at the bar.


More People Seek 'a Pill for Every Ill'
LEAD: Every day before she sets off to work, Roberta Berk, a 48-year-old commodities broker, takes one aspirin, 500 milligrams of vitamin C, 1,000 milligrams of calcium, an antihistamine tablet and powdered fiber in water.


A Challenge to Suharto Ends in 'Consensus'
LEAD: President Suharto's nominee for Vice President was elected by acclamation today after the reluctant, last-minute withdrawal of the only other contender.


Output Cut At OPEC Less Likely
LEAD: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seem to have abandoned a proposal to reduce production by about 5 percent because of fears that any sacrifices in output would simply turn a larger share of the market over to non-OPEC oil producers.


Pope Continues the Theology of Egalitarianism
LEAD: To the Editor:


As Tickets Pile Up, 500,000 Scoff
LEAD: Half a million New Yorkers routinely ignore summonses for minor offenses each year - from illegal parking to littering -despite aggressive campaigns by city agencies to find them and make it easier to pay fines, city officials say.


Suzanne Lee Bricker Bride Of William Joseph Sullivan
LEAD: Suzanne Lee Bricker and William Joseph Sullivan were married yesterday at St.
Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev.
William D. Roberts.


Apres Ski
LEAD: After the United States Ski Team failed to win a medal and placed no higher than ninth at the Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, it came as no surprise when Harald Schoenhaar, the team's Alpine director, announced yesterday in Vail, Colo., that he had given his resignation to the board of directors.


McFARLANE ADMITS WITHHOLDING DATA ON AID TO CONTRAS
LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, pleaded guilty today to four misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress and agreed to serve as a prosecution witness in the criminal investigation of the Iran-contra affair.


Let the Candidates Speak Up About Space
LEAD: To the Editor:

U.S. Withholds a Canal Payment In New Steps to Oust Panamanian
LEAD: President Reagan imposed new economic sanctions on Panama today, saying the United States would not conduct ''business as usual'' until Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military ruler, relinquished power and left the country.


Morris E. Kaufman, 50, a Mortgage Banker
LEAD: Morris Enouch Kaufman, co-founder and chairman of American Mortgage Banking Ltd., died of heart failure March 5 at his home in Floral Park, Queens.
He was 50 years old.


Revenue Gain Doubted In Bush's Tax Proposal
LEAD: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office cast doubt today as to whether cutting the capital gains tax - one of Vice President Bush's important campaign promises - would raise Government revenues.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Theaters as Landmarks


Iran and Iraq Call a Halt to Missile Strikes on Cities
LEAD: After 12 days and hundreds of casualties, Iran and Iraq stopped missile attacks on each other's cities this afternoon.
But each side threatened to resume the strikes if the other broke the unofficial truce.


Lisbon Journal; In Old Section of City, A Ghetto With a View
LEAD: The Alfama district is Lisbon's slum by the sea, along the banks of the Tagus River where it widens to enter the Atlantic.


Beirut Weekly Says Captors Plan to Free Marine Hostage
LEAD: The weekly Beirut magazine Al Shiraa said today that the captors of an American Marine officer have promised to free him but have set no date.


Blizzard on Northern Plains Halts Travel and Endangers Livestock
LEAD: A blizzard struck the northern Plains with deep snow driven by winds of up to 60 miles an hour yesterday, endangering newborn calves and stranding travelers along hundreds of miles of blocked highways in Colorado, Nebraska, Wyoming and the Dakotas.


Crude Oil's Rise Continues; Precious Metal Prices Fall
LEAD: The price of crude oil futures inched higher yesterday and remained above the psychologically important $16-a-barrel level for the second consecutive day.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract was up 29 cents, at $16.29 a barrel.


J.P. MEI, 76, CHINATOWN LEADER
LEAD: Joseph P. C. Mei, a former president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Society, died of a heart attack on March 3 at his home in Chinatown.
He was 76 years old.


ANSWERS TO QUIZ
LEAD: Questions appear on page 18.


Biaggi Accused of Greed By Wedtech Prosecutor
LEAD: Representative Mario Biaggi was accused by a Government prosecutor yesterday of demanding millions of dollars in bribes for helping a South Bronx company win military contracts.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Amerifirst Federal Savings and Loan Association, Miami, said it had received inquiries about a merger.


Petra T. Shattuck, 46, Lawyer and Professor
LEAD: Petra Tolle Shattuck, a lawyer who specialized in the legal status of American Indians and who taught civil liberties and American constitutional law at the City University of New York, died Wednesday after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage a week ago.
She was 46 years old.


Cup Offer Runs Aground
LEAD: The board of directors of the San Diego Yacht Club, defender of the America's Cup, said today that it would be willing to negotiate on a New Zealand challenger's compromise offer calling for a 1989 multinational regatta in waters off San Diego.
But Michael Fay, who made the proposal, later refused to meet with the defenders.


Review/Theater; IN REVIVAL OF 'NIGHT MUSIC,' AN IDEALIZED OLD WORLD
LEAD: Every element of ''A Little Night Music,'' from the waltz tempos of Stephen Sondheim's thrilling score to the graceful pirouettes of Hugh Wheeler's dialogue, is infused with a delicate three-quarter-time pulse.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about the Guide Michelin gave an incorrect address for the Traveller's Bookstore.
It is at 22 West 52d Street in Manhattan.


Santa Fe Special Dividend
LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today that it would immediately begin to distribute the remaining $5-a-share debt portion of its $30 special dividend after a Delaware court denied the Henley Group's motion for a preliminary injunction to halt the distribution.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article yesterday about recommendations of a New York State education task force misidentified a co-chairman.
He is Dr.
Edward J. Mortola, current Chancellor of Pace University.


Speaker Seeking To Trim Power Of School Board
LEAD: The Speaker of the New York State Assembly said yesterday that he would push legislation to reduce the power of members of the New York City Board of Education by stripping them of their salaries and perquisites.


U.A.W. and Chrysler Agree to Early Talks
LEAD: The United Automobile Workers has agreed to early contract talks with Chrysler Corporation, the union's president, Owen F. Bieber, says.


Jersey Man Pleads Not Guilty In Hit-Run That Killed Child
LEAD: A New Jersey man pleaded not guilty yesterday to murder and assault charges in connection with a hit-and-run incident in Harlem that killed a 9-year-old girl and critically injured two other children.


Seattle Bids To Make Old Rails New Trails
LEAD: When the Burlington Northern Railroad confirmed last month that it had sold parts of this city's popular bicycling and jogging trail to a wealthy real estate developer, some critics said it was as if the Space Needle had gone condo.


Big East; PIRATES TURN BACK HOYAS AND MOVE INTO SEMIFINALS
LEAD: There has been jubilation at Seton Hall over the last few days: the basketball coach signed a new contract on Wednesday, and won the Big East coach-of-the-year award on Thursday.
But Seton Hall players knew yesterday that it would take more than momentum and optimism to beat Georgetown in the Big East tournament.


P.L.O. Told to Shut Mission in 10 Days
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization must shut its observer mission to the United Nations within 10 days or the United States would take action in Federal court to close it.


This Article Is About a Snow Job
LEAD: It was the mildest winter in 17 years.
New Yorkers had faith in the March 11, 1888, forecast that ''slightly warmer weather would be followed by rain.''


World Health Group Plans Survey To Help Understand AIDS Spread
LEAD: People in dozens of countries will be asked how they make love, how often and with whom in a World Health Organization survey intended to help understand and curb the spread of AIDS, an official has said.


Profit Condemned
LEAD: To the Editor:


2 Tiny Bullet Wounds Found
LEAD: An undertaker found two bullet wounds in the body of a 58-year-man thought by authorities to have died a natural death on March 9 in his Greenwich Village apartment.
The death of John Hunter of 52 Carmine Street was ruled a homicide yesterday by the New York City Medical Examiner after X-rays confirmed that there were very small bullet wounds to the scalp and groin, said a police spokesman, Sgt.


The Gore Foreign Policy 'Difference': Generally Less Liberal Than Rivals
LEAD: In his bid for the Presidency, Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee has relied on a strategy that emphasizes the conservative side of his record to set himself apart from the rest of the Democratic field and to support his contention that he has the best chance of being elected.


New Howard Beach Trial Will Have Two Juries
LEAD: The judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case ruled yesterday that the seven remaining defendants will have a single trial with two juries.


Miss Dempsey Weds B. J. Charendoff
LEAD: Pamela Lawrence Dempsey, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Bruce Jay Charendoff, an associate at the Hartford law firm of Shipman &amp; Goodwin, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in Manhattan.
The Rev.
Henry Fehren, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Harold Swiss officiated.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Ben Feliciano, a jockey at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore, was fined $300 yesterday after Zeus Belle, a filly he was riding, was blinded in the right eye on Monday.
Feliciano's whip broke the plastic cup of the horse's blinkers, damaging the horse's eye with splinters.
Zeus Belle, who finished third, will probably continue racing whether or not she undergoes surgery to save the eye.


Steve Mills, Comedian In Vaudeville Days, 92
LEAD: Steve Mills, one of the last of the vaudeville comedians who worked with the Shubert organization in the 1930's and 1940's, died Wednesday at his home.
He was 92 years old.


Time Up for Pound Note
LEAD: The British Treasury withdrew the pound banknote from service today, nearly 200 years after introducing it to conserve gold.
Pound coins, introduced in 1983, will replace the notes, which were first printed in 1797.
The notes will no longer be accepted as legal tender in shops but can still be exchanged at banks.


Promises by Texaco's Creditors
LEAD: Texaco's creditors sought to induce management to settle the company's dispute with the Pennzoil Company by offering top executives protection from lawsuits by shareholders.


Bassist and Dancers
LEAD: Reggie Workman, a bassist, will lead a quintet and the Maya Milenovic dancers will perform at 8 P.M. tonight at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street (662-2133).
Admission is free.


Producer Price Index Dipped in February As Retail Sales Rose
LEAD: In a pair of largely reassuring reports on the economy, the Government said today that prices at the producer level declined in February while retail sales continued to show scarcely any adverse effect from last fall's stock market plunge.


Lupu and Philharmonic
LEAD: Radu Lupu will be the soloist with the New York Philharmonic in the Beethoven Third Piano Concerto at 8 P.M. tonight.
The performance, which will be conducted by Klaus Tennstedt, will include Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 (''Eroica'').
Tickets are $35 to $7.50.
Information: 580-8700.


COPING: With an Aging Pet
LEAD: The dog that frisked its way through so many years of your life is not eager to play anymore.
And the cat seems to spend more time than ever sleeping.


Pitt Finishes Well
LEAD: To a certain extent, the Big East tournament is like starting over for Pitt.
Three months have been condensed into one long weekend in New York, a game of roulette, really, in which the Panthers are trying to reaffirm that they are the class of the conference.
The regular-season championship they won last Sunday in


Lilco Takes Write-Down
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company, as expected, said today that it would take a $1.35 billion write-down related to its investments in three nuclear plants.
Lilco also announced that its earnings in 1987 fell by 14.8 percent, to $269.9 million, or $1.72 a share, from $316.7 million, or $2.13 a share, the year before.


Review/Television; Michael Jackson Profile on Cable Shows His Star Quality as a Child
LEAD: Michael Jackson may have lost out on the top laurels at the recent Grammy Awards, but he still was the indisputable star of the show.
Glancing over my shoulder during his sensational ''Man in the Mirror'' production number, I caught the members of Ireland's U2 group, which did win several top awards, watching the stage with unabashed respect and admiration.

U.N.L.V. Is Surprised By Cal-Irvine
LEAD:  Pacific Coast


Utah Rejects Textbook Ban
LEAD: The Utah Textbook Commission has rejected an Indian request that grade schools remove a book containing stories by Washington Irving and John Smith that depict Indians as blood-thirsty savages.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article yesterday about Brooklyn co-op owners whose building is threatened with seizure by the Federal Government in the Hyfin Credit Union scandal incompletely identified a mortgage lender.
It is the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburg.


Queens Slaying Parallels Death Of Officer, 22
LEAD: Jury selection began yesterday in Queens in the murder case of a Jamaica man who, according to court records, drove up to a man in a parked car, got out and shot him in the head three times.


Gunmen in Sri Lanka Kill 17 in Bus Attack
LEAD: Masked gunmen attacked a bus in Sri Lanka today, killing at least 17 passengers, mostly ethnic Tamils, the police said.


Righetti Still Not on Track
LEAD: Every spring, it's the same old thing: one bad game follows another, and Dave Righetti can neither explain his troubles nor find an answer to them.


CORRECTION
LEAD: A headline in Weekend yesterday in the Sounds Around Town column misstated the location for performances by John Wallowitch and Bertram Ross.
They are at Danny's Skylight Room, 346 West 46th Street.


MECHAM TRIAL TOLD OF GODLY GUIDANCE
LEAD: Gov.
Evan Mecham believed he was ''divinely guided'' in making executive decisions, one of his closest aides testified Friday at the Governor's impeachment trial.


Cocaine Traces Are Found In Pilot Who Died in Crash
LEAD: Evidence of cocaine use was found in the body of an airline captain who was among nine people killed in the crash of a commuter airliner near Durango, Colo., on Jan. l9, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Harvard Is Upset: Clarkson upset first-seeded Harvard, 6-4, in a ECAC Hockey tournament semifinal last night after St.
Lawrence defeated Vermont, 4-2, at Boston Garden.


Bridge; Player With 2-Suiter Made Rare Retreat to No-Trump
LEAD: Two or three times in a bridge lifetime a player can expect to pick up a complete two-suiter, with seven cards in one suit and six in another.
In this rare situation he usually finds himself fighting his opponents and his partner for the right to be the declarer with one of his suits as trump.


Reagan Is Optimistic on Trade Bill
LEAD: President Reagan, who has persistently threatened to veto a comprehensive trade bill that is approaching final passage in Congress, said today that the lawmakers had thrown ''overboard many objectionable provisions.''


Tables Curtailed
LEAD: Futures and options tables reflect trading only up to 1 P.M. because of a power failure.
Settlement prices unavailable.


Book on the AIDS Quilt
LEAD: On May 11, Pocket Books will publish ''The Quilt: Stories from the Names Project,'' with a foreword by Elizabeth Taylor, national chairman of the American Foundation for AIDS Research.
The Names Project Quilt - the national AIDS memorial, which weighs about 3 1/2 tons and is the size of two football fields - contains more than 3,000 individual panels, each depicting the name of someone who has died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.


Redmen Suffer Late Collapse
LEAD: St.
John's seemed on the verge of righting all the wrongs of its season last night.


Koppers Sues Beazer, Shearson
LEAD: The Koppers Company filed a lawsuit in United States District Court here charging Beazer P.L.C. and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. with violations of Federal securities laws in their proposed takeover of Koppers.
The group led by Beazer, a British construction concern, and including Shearson as both adviser and participant, made a tender offer for


Ortega Says Congress Hurt the Contras
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra says he thinks contra leaders will come to the negotiating table this month in ''a position of weakness'' because of the recent Congressional vote cutting off aid to their movement.


Jersey Commission Proposes Major Shift in Tax Burden
LEAD: A commission on state taxes and spending approved recommendations today to help cut property taxes while easing the burden on lower-income families by raising taxes on those earning more than $50,000 a year.


Beecham Drug: Positive Tests
LEAD: A study of Enimase, a drug made by Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain to treat heart disease has shown positive results, the medical journal Lancet reported yesterday.
But analysts said that sales of tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, the genetically engineered drug made by Genentech Inc. for the treatment of heart attacks, are unlikely to be affected before 1990.


Merrill K. Riddick, 93; Politician and Aviator
LEAD: Merrill K. Riddick, who campaigned for President three times as the candidate of the Puritan Ethic and Epic, Magnetohydrodynamics and Prohibition Party, died here Wednesday of cancer.
He was 93 years old.


Syracuse Wins
LEAD: In Jim O'Brien's estimation, Boston College did not have many options.
The Eagles could have attempted to fly with Syracuse, and the game would have probably been over at halftime.
So with apologies, O'Brien chose to have his team hold the basketball yesterday for as long as the rules allowed, hoping to frustrate the


New York's Bridges Are Falling Down
LEAD: New York City is a clump of islands joined to mainland America only at the Bronx.
The 76 bridges that lace it together, and the 2,000-plus that span rail lines and roadways, are lifelines.
Yet New Yorkers take these vital links for granted.
Almost all the bridges are victims of deferred maintenance.


U.S. REBUTS RUMORS OF POISON DUMPING
LEAD: No evidence has been found to substantiate suspicions that hazardous chemicals might have been dumped into the Ohio River under the cover of a huge oil spill in January, an environmental official said Thursday.


State Raises Drinking Age
LEAD: Wyoming today became the last state to raise its minimum drinking age to 21.
Gov.
Mike Sullivan signed into law a bill raising the age from 19 effective July 1.
The bill had stalled for years in the state Legislature over what its opponents called Federal blackmail.
Wyoming stood to lose $8.2 million in Federal highway funds immediately if the increase were not in place by July and the Government would have continued to withhold funds until the state adopted the increase.





CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in the Business People column on Monday about Donna Frame Tuttle, the nominee for Deputy Secretary of Commerce, misstated her college graduation year.


S.E.C. Is Said to Broaden Its Sterling Drug Inquiry
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broadened its investigation of suspected insider trading in the securities of Sterling Drug Inc., issuing nearly two dozen subpoenas to arbitragers who bought the securities while the merger was being planned or negotiated, a number of Wall Street professionals said yesterday.


Review/Dance; 3 Choreographers Show Off Modern Dance From Japan
LEAD: Modern dance would appear to be alive but not too well in Japan, to judge by a program presented on Tuesday evening at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of the Asia Society.
The three dances on the program, produced by the Contemporary Dance Association of Japan and presented by Asia Society, did suggest that there is some very good dance training to be had in Japan and that the Butoh style is not the only kind of modern dance in Japan these days.


'Allah Will Call,' Afghan Refugees Say
LEAD: In a dozen mud hut camps along both sides of the road between this nondescript market town and the even smaller village of Thal, 40 miles nearer the Afghan border, 150,000 refugees are waiting.


Drug Found to Reduce Pain In Circumcision of Newborns
LEAD: A local anesthetic provides a safe and effective way to reduce the distress of circumcision of infant boys, a new study has shown.


David F. Cavers Dies; Legal Scholar Was 85
LEAD: David F. Cavers, retired Fessenden Professor of Law at the Harvard Law School, died of prostate cancer at his home in Cambridge, Mass., on March 4.
He was 85 years old.
Professor Cavers taught at the law school from 1946 until 1969 and was its first associate dean.
He was a specialist in the field of conflicts of law, the process of resolving conflicts between the laws of different jurisdictions.


Review/Concert; A Modern Recasting of Old Japan's Rituals By Kodo, the Percussion and Dance Group
LEAD: Music demands muscle - one fact it's impossible to forget during a concert by Kodo, the 10-man, two-woman Japanese percussion-and-dance group that's appearing through Sunday at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.
Traditional rituals recast as theater and contemporary thoughts about ancient instruments both figure in Kodo's performance, which includes ancient and modern compositions.


Review/Opera; Janacek Rarity, 'House of the Dead,' in Paris
LEAD: Leos Janacek's operas have been performed less frequently in Paris than in most major Western cities, but when the Paris Opera set about rectifying that omission, it did so in flamboyant style.
Instead of producing just one opera, there were two, and they were presented within the context of a two-month


LAROUCHE TRIAL DELAYED AS JUDGE ORDERS SEARCH OF FEDERAL RECORDS
LEAD: The judge in the fraud trial of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. today delayed a resumption of testimony pending searches of Government records for any evidence suggesting infiltration of the political extremist's organizations by Federal agents.


Murray Rimmer, Hospital Administrator, 54
LEAD: Murray Rimmer, administrator of Gracie Square Hospital, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at New York Hospital.
He was 54 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


ECONOMIC DATA BUOY BOND PRICES
LEAD: Bond prices rose yesterday, buoyed by new indications of modest economic growth and continued low inflation.
But bond dealers cautioned that most of the day's gains reflected purchases by those who had previously sold Treasury issues short rather than buying by retail investors.


Official Predicts Lower Limit on Drug in Pork
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration will lower the permissible level of a widely used animal drug in American pork because the drug has been found to cause cancer in mice, an official at the agency says.


U.S. to Close P.L.O. Mission
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said the Palestine Liberation Organization must shut its observer mission to the United Nations within 10 days or the United States would take action in Federal court to close it.
Page 4.


Europe's Loss No Gain for Detroit
LEAD: The weak dollar that has caused the price of luxury European cars to soar and their sales to plunge in the United States would seem to create a golden opportunity for domestic car makers.
But for reasons ranging from lack of production capacity to unpopular models, they seem unable to expand their share of the potentially lucrative market for cars that go for $20,000 and up.


The Blizzard That Spawned 100 Years of Memories
LEAD: One hundred years ago this weekend, New York City's most dramatic snowstorm, the Blizzard of '88, burst upon a New York that had been basking in a warming sun that seemed to be a curtain raiser for the spring that would be official 10 days later.
The blizzard began as rain that turned into snow late Sunday, March 11.


'Shalom '88'
LEAD: Israel's 40th anniversary will be celebrated at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, this weekend with a program of contemporary Israeli music and dance called ''Shalom '88.'' A company of 40 young Israeli performers - including such stars as Boaz Sharabi, Yaffa Yarkoni and Amalia Izhak - will provide a sampler of Israel's many ethnic cultures.

LEAD: Dale Murphy stepped into the batter's box for the Braves as a new pitcher was brought in, and just as Murphy was taking his practice cuts and getting all loose and warm and comfy, he heard the announcement:


Impressive Neck
LEAD: Mike Tyson, the world heavyweight champion, and Tony Tubbs, the man who will challenge for his title later this month, passed their physical examinations yesterday and were declared fit for the bout March 21 at the Tokyo Dome.
They took their exams at the Jikei Medical College Hospital, where the champion's neck was measured at 20.1 inches against 17.3 inches for Tubbs.


Toni Bodini, Restaurateur, Is Married to Jean Goutal
LEAD: Toni Allen Bodini and Jean Goutal, partners in the Tapis Rouge restaurant in New York, were married Wednesday at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
Irwin Hamilton Kramer, by the Rev.
David Cockcroft, a Presbyterian minister.


Gooden Relaxes And Is Impressive
LEAD: Dwight Gooden buzzed four vintage innings against the Atlanta Braves today in his second start of the spring, and said later that part of the credit should go to Sandy Koufax.


Koch Proposals to Convert 2 Buildings to Shelters Are Rejected
LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate yesterday rejected plans to convert two vacant commercial buildings into homeless shelters, a major setback to a Koch administration plan to provide housing for the homeless.


For Soviet Emigres, Family Visits Still Difficult
LEAD: To the Editor:


In Cash Squeeze, Panamanians Switch to Barter
LEAD: It was payday today at the Acsesa automobile repair shop here, but instead of receiving checks or cash, the 90 mechanics and drivers stood in line as a fellow employee doled out payment in food.


JAIL TERMS SET FOR FRAUD ON TAX SHELTERS
LEAD: Charles A. Atkins, who was convicted in what the Government has called the largest case of tax-shelter fraud ever brought to court, was sentenced yesterday to two years in jail, followed by four years of community service.
Two co-defendants received lesser sentences.


A Correction
LEAD: The photograph used to illustrate yesterday's editorial on the Blizzard of 1888 was misidentified.
It was supplied to The Times 30 years ago by a photo archive as having been taken in the famous blizzard.
It turns out to be a poor reproduction of Alfred Stieglitz's ''Winter - Fifth Avenue,'' taken in 1892.


JACKSON EDGES OUT DUKAKIS IN ALASKA
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson won nearly 35 percent of the delegates selected at Alaska Democratic Party precinct caucuses, narrowly edging out Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, who took 31 percent, party officials announced today.


Guidepost
LEAD:  Staying Dry  Spring showers bring out raincoats and umbrellas.
But which ones will keep you driest?
While raindrops roll off water-repellent fabric in a light rain, the material won't prevent a soaking in a downpour.
Water-repellent material is better at keeping raindrops out of the fibers.


Federated Delays 'Poison Pill' Plan
LEAD: Federated Department Stores said that its board had postponed putting into effect the rights plan attached to Federated's common shares until next Friday or later.
The shareholder rights plan, sometimes referred to as a ''poison pill,'' would allow shareholders to buy new Federated shares at a 50 percent discount if another company acquired 30 percent of the company.


Paine Webber Is Censured
LEAD: Paine Webber Inc. was censured today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for defrauding its customers on coupons of the brokerage's ''stripped'' Treasury bonds between January 1984 and July 1985.
A source close to the investigation put the amount of the fraud at $200,000.


Flxible Bus Fiasco
LEAD: To the Editor:


CORRECTION
LEAD: A picture caption in Business Day last Saturday with an article about the Rover Group inaccurately described the Range-Rover, a four-wheel-drive, four-door vehicle intended for highway and off-the-road driving.
It is sold worldwide, not just in the United States.


Dollar Off in Light Trading; Gold Has Modest Decline
LEAD: The dollar declined in quiet trading yesterday as the foreign-exchange markets began to mark time until the United States trade figures for January are released on Thursday.


Jack Bennett, 86, Dies; Government Economist
LEAD: Andrew Jackson Bennett, an economist who advised the United States military government in Germany after World War II, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C.
He was 86 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

G.S.A. Is Extending Phone Contract Bids
LEAD: The General Services Administration said yesterday that it would extend the deadline for submitting bids for contracts to build the Government's new telecommunications system to allow the U S Sprint Communications Corporation more time to prepare its bid.


Amid Despair, She Tries to Bring Hope
LEAD: For 31 years, Margit Homs has been braiding the hair of other people's children, helping them with their homework, teaching them to tie their shoes.


New York Area Retail Sales Dip
LEAD: A number of leading retailers had an average decline in sales of 1.6 percent in the New York metropolitan area in February, compared with the same month of 1987.
The retailers' stores in New York City, however, had an average gain of 2.5 percent.


Arab Stresses P.L.O. Role
LEAD: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has rejected Secretary of State George P. Shultz's approach to an international conference on the Middle East and insisted that the P.L.O. must be fully represented at any such talks.


Three Men on An Eagle
LEAD: From time to time when the Romans couldn't decide which of three leaders they wanted to rule they simply fudged the whole problem by putting all three in office.


Swaggarts Appeal for Funds
LEAD: The Jimmy Swaggart Ministries will begin a nationally televised appeal for money on Saturday in which the evangelist's family pleads that ''everything could be finished'' unless contributions pick up.


Convictions of 4 Are Upheld In New Bedford Rape Case
LEAD: The Massachusetts Supreme Court, in a decision Thursday, upheld the convictions of four men who raped a woman on a barroom table in New Bedford in 1983, rejecting defense arguments about the fairness of the 1984 trial in Bristol Superior Court.


About New York; Where Is Romeo In This World Of Hip-Hop?
LEAD: A couple of fellows from the Royal Shakespeare Company have been in town for a fortnight trying to show students from 45 schools that the Bard was user friendly, not impenetrable.
All this week the two gentlemen of London have focused on Verona, the setting of ''The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet,'' and ninth graders who cast a less than enthusiastic eye on the work at the outset have come away thinking it didn't hurt so much after all.

LEAD: An associate of Irwin Schiff, the enigmatic millionaire businessman who was slain last summer, was a ''cooperating Federal informant'' when he was arrested by the Manhattan District Attorney's office Thursday, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn said yesterday.

LEAD: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned tonight after his Government split apart over a decision to resume the construction of a nuclear power plant.
It was the third time that Mr.
Goria had quit since taking office almost eight months ago, but this time his departure seemed final.

Mauch Is Ailing
LEAD: Manager Gene Mauch of the California Angels has left the team's spring training camp in Mesa, Ariz., for unspecified health reasons, the team announced yesterday.
He is scheduled to undergo an examination Monday in Palm Springs, Calif.
The Angels hold the latter part of their spring training in Palm Springs, and Mauch owns a home in nearby Rancho Mirage.


Shortage of Memory Chips Has Industry Scrambling
LEAD: A severe shortage of computer memory chips is hurting the sales of computers and placing new strains on the semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan, an agreement that some executives blame for the shortage.

Demonstrations by the Deaf Bring A Resignation but Not Yet a Truce
LEAD: The new president of Gallaudet University, the nation's only college for the deaf, resigned early today in response to protests by students and faculty because she was not deaf.


Albany Faces Up to Campaign Reform
LEAD: The New York State Assembly's approval of a campaign finance reform bill leaves State Senate Republicans with no place to hide.
For years, they have quietly killed similar bills in the adjournment rush.
Not this year.


Review/Film; THE 'PEACE RUN,' A PUNGENT LOOK AT POLAND
LEAD: ''The Great Race'' is a metaphor for Poland in the 1950's - and possibly in 1988, too.
Feliks Falk's screenplay centers on a ''Peace Run'' by model factory workers, high-producing farmers and zealous activists, thoroughly manipulated by Communist Party bureaucrats.
The director, Jerzy Domaradzki, does not spare the satire.


Before the Blooms, a Little Shopping
LEAD: It's still a bit early to go outdoors and begin planting, although by this time of year the urge is there.
It's not too soon, however, to do some shopping.
Browsing in gardening catalogues and centers will turn up new products to help with spring cleanup and get plants off to a healthy start, even potted ones on a city windowsill.

A Promenade In Monte Carlo
LEAD: IN MONTE CARLO, THERE'S THE OLD, THE NEW and the newly old.
The newly old buildings are the newest, as seen in the still-unfinished Metropole Hotel, which is being rebuilt in the style of the Belle Epoque, with pillars, marble floors and ''riotous over-decoration,'' as one Monacan lovingly described it.

LEAD: The Via di Santa Sabina runs for only a few hundred yards across Rome's Aventine Hill, but it is one of those magic places where this city reminds visitors that there are more than 2,000 years of history here -all intertwined.
It is a green, normally quiet spot where that thought can be allowed to spur fantasy.

LEAD: THE official beginning of spring is a week away.
But the markets have begun to display their springtime finery.
Appetites whetted by the arrival of spring insist on asparagus.
Bunches of asparagus have made their appearance with prices at less than $2 a pound.
Artichokes and herbs also have irresistible seasonal appeal.

In Montreal, A New Electricity Is in the Air
LEAD: Dance-theater is a term used lately to cover a multitude of sins, and it is one that has particular appeal to the burgeoning experimental dance scene in Montreal.
In the late 1970's, West German choreographers called their work dance-theater -Pina Bausch made the label famous - and it became applicable thereafter to Japan's Butoh dance and to work, such as Maguy Marin's, that grew out of the French dance explosion.

John D. Twiname, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.


Covering Panel Edges
LEAD: MANUFACTURED wood paneling, particularly plywood and particle board, has revolutionized carpentry and woodworking.
However, one drawback is inherent in working with these materials, and that is covering their edges.
This is necessary both for a finished appearance and to protect the wood from moisture.

Artists of the High Plains
LEAD: Hard by the Indian hunting grounds, religious sites and battlefields of Montana and northern Wyoming, the traveler can find rich collections of the arts and artifacts of the area.
The region holds a number of museums where fragments of American Indian history and culture have been preserved.
But few collections are as successful - or as elclectic - as those of the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyo.

Tibetans Press Demands for Freedom From China
LEAD: Tibetan women burning a Chinese flag yesterday in New Delhi, as they vowed to return to their homeland.
Some 150 refugees took part in the demonstration, the latest to commemorate the 29th anniversary of an unsuccessful uprising against Chinese rule in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa. (AP)

LEAD: Romare Bearden, a painter who artistically manipulated pieces of photographs and colored paper and became the nation's foremost collagist, died Saturday after suffering a stroke in New York Hospital.
He was 75 years old and lived in lower Manhattan and St.
Martin.

Ben Yehuda Street
LEAD: THE LAST TIME I WAS IN JERUSALEM, white-hot midsummer, a poet friend suggested that I meet her at a cafe on Ben Yehuda Street.
I was astonished.
There are a few leafy garden spots to which visitors tend to be taken again and again by their eager hosts - I usually pretend, out of politeness, that I haven't been to any of them yet, so that my current hosts can surprise me.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I am trying to repair a loose door lock.
The bolts holding the inside plate and the body of the lock in place need tightening, but I can't get at them because there is a decorative plate or cover over this.
This plate is not held on by screws, and I can't figure how to remove it.
How do I get this cover plate off?

LEAD: I am flattered that you considered my life's story worthy of attention (''Dr. Krim's Crusade,'' by George Johnson, Feb. 14).
However, I worry about a conclusion to which the article may have led readers, namely that interferon research has been a disappointment to me and to others in the field.

It is in Columbus, Ohio.

Bombing in Colombia
LEAD: Bombs exploded outside the opposition newspaper El Colombiano Thursday night, killing a man in the street and slightly wounding 10 others.
The newspaper's director, Juan Gomez Martinez, is a candidate for mayor of Medellin, the country's second biggest city, in municipal elections next Sunday.
Five months ago, he was the target of a kidnapping attempt by drug traffickers fighting possible extradition to the United States for trial on drug charges.

LEAD: Dave Anderson's open letter to John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League (''Hockey the Way It Oughta Be,'' The New York Times, Feb. 26), focuses on a need of long standing: attention to the utter lack of management and guts in the N.H.L. to keep a premier sport from losing its tradition, its skills and its wonder to those who watch.

POSTING: Choir School Site; Offices by Macklowe
LEAD: On one of the most built-up streets in Manhattan, Sheldon Werdiger, the project manager for 125 West 55th Street, speaks of creating a park feeling.
Though the 23-story office building being developed there by the Harry Macklowe Real Estate Company has two of New York's tallest new buildings as neighbors, it is near a mid-block public plaza and will yield to small plazas of its own on both 55th and 56th Streets.

FACTS WITHIN FRAMES
LEAD: GARRY WINOGRAND NEVER CARED for moderation.
For him, to be a photographer was to see pictures everywhere, in everything.
It was normal for him to shoot several rolls of film before lunch, or during lunch, every day.
And he wasn't just behind in developing and editing his work, as all photographers are.

Westchester Life
LEAD: A Pennysaver by another name would attract more readers.
So reasoned Stephen A. Traube, the 45-year-old president of The New Pennysaver Group Inc. in Elmsford, when he changed the name of 13 of his community Pennysavers to Westchester Life and began adding local news and syndicated editorial features to the weekly giveaway.

LEAD: KEA'S ARK, the controversial hand-built vessel that stood in the parking lot of a Baptist church here and was envisioned as a land-based ark and urban museum, is slowly being dismantled.

PALESTINIANS QUIT THE POLICE FORCE IN OCCUPIED AREAS
LEAD: Palestinians working for the Israeli police in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip were resigning from their jobs tonight amid predictions that the entire 1,000-member Palestinian force would quit by Sunday.
Police officials said almost 500 had already resigned in a dramatic protest that began Friday.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.

LEAD: I attended Dartmouth during the heyday of these young conservatives' efforts on The Dartmouth Review.
The editors of The Review wrote malicious and self-serving journalism.
The newspaper, which had no association with the college, represented the viewpoints of some old, conservative alumni and a small minority (10 percent) of students.

Tracking Balmier Rates in the Rockies
LEAD: AT ski areas throughout the West, the arrival of spring brings sun, shorter lift lines, a boisterous mood in the apres-ski lounge and, in most cases, discounted hotel and lift rates.
Spring skiing can stretch into the summer at a few resorts, with slopes staying open into June.
At others, mid-April signals the end of the season.

'Blood Knot,' About Apartheid
LEAD: IT'S a rare day when problems arising from South Africa's policy of apartheid fail to make news.
But even the most detailed report cannot examine the emotional, soul-searing effects of apartheid on the people living the headlines.
Communicating the secrets of the human heart is the job of literature and the arts, and the South African playwright Athol Fugard's drama ''The Blood Knot'' is a case in point.

Dethrone the Emperors of Trash
LEAD: Big plastic bags of trash line New York's downtown sidewalks every day, waiting for commercial carters.
Meanwhile, scavengers tear them open looking for returnable bottles.
Garbage-combers scatter scraps.
Rats dart out, scratching for food.
Here is the domain of the Emperors of Trash.


Why Auto Rebates Don't Really Help
LEAD: FOR several years now, American automobile manufacturers have been using sales incentive and rebate programs to increase the sales of selected models.
The effect of these programs is so large that total consumer spending is substantially affected when the incentive programs end.

Supertitles: The Eyes Have It
LEAD: Religion used to be the topic that well-bred people did not bring up in polite company.
Now it is supertitles.
The rapid spread of captioned opera and the surprisingly enthusiastic acceptance of the device, on this continent and in Europe, has served to inflame both advocates and opponents.
When it appeared that supertitling might be a fad, jeered today and gone tomorrow, the rhetoric remained fairly rational.

LEAD: Thirty United States senators wrote to Secretary of State Shultz to support his Middle East peace plan and to criticize Prime Minister Shamir for rejecting the heart of the plan - land for peace.

LEAD: JAMES LLAMAS, a New York City resident, has been spending his weekends lately looking for land upstate.
The venture is partly personal and partly for profit.
He and his fiancee are seeking a parcel they can divide and sell, using the proceeds to finance the building of a vacation home on the portion that they would keep.

LEAD: CONVERTING an old barn into a home has been a fond fantasy, and for some people a realized dream, for decades.
In Connecticut, where so many farms have been plowed under to make way for housing developments and shopping centers, barns are scarce, and, of course, they aren't being built any more.
Or are they?


The Piazza della Signoria
LEAD: To trave, as we did, from Venice direct to Florence is to experience the Time Machine at its most devastating.
Venice, still recognizably the city of Canaletto and Guardi, is the world's largest pedestrian precinct; Florence is a gigantic toyshop with malignant, destructive boys in little vehicles tearing up and down the aisles, bent on raising havoc.

LEAD: When 7-year-old Ronald DeSillers Jr. of Miami died last April in Pittsburgh while awaiting a fourth liver transplant, he had received about a half million dollars from sympathizers around the country, including President Reagan.

How do I get this cover plate off?

LEAD: To the Editor: Although I hate to disagree with a professional filmmaker, I must take exception to Mel London's remarks (Letters on Travel, Jan. 24) regarding lead pouches to protect film from airport X-rays.

Russia's Old and Rival Capitals
LEAD: WITH JUST FOUR WORDS - ''LOVED LENINGRAD, hated Moscow'' - first-time visitors to the Soviet Union have been summing up their feelings ever since Intourist hung up its shingle.
The twofold reaction is visceral, irrepressible and virtually universal.
In Leningrad, visitors feel bouyant, alert and subtly flattered.

Practical Traveler; Getting to the Airport
LEAD: WHEN friends came home from Greece, they had made no plans for getting out of Kennedy International Airport and traveling home to the suburbs in Bergen County, N.J.

About Men; The 7-Month Itch
LEAD: AS A RULE OF thumb, a man has as many barbers in his lifetime as he has affairs.
This includes one-cut visits as well as liaisons that go on for years.
The similarities between the two relationships extend to the sensitive courtship, or tryout, period, the growing intimacy and fear of intimacy, the meetings that result in complete satisfaction and those that disappoint a little or a lot, and ultimately - and perhaps inevitably - the guilt at the end.

Artichokes and herbs also have irresistible seasonal appeal.

The Impropriety of Hugging a Mike
LEAD: When you watch pop singers in a nightclub or on television, you usually see them hugging and kissing the microphone.
Such passionate gestures toward the hardware are meant to underline the performer's capacity for emotional abandon, but they are not likely to produce good sound.
In fact, the hand-held mike subjected to these dramatic antics is usually supplemented by another microphone, known as the body mike, sequestered in the singer's clothes to yield an acceptable sound balance - and the output of nearby stage microphones is also blended in.

LEAD: The engagement of Robin Isabel Riley to John Christopher Ahrens, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Donald Charles Ahrens of Toledo, Ohio, has been announced by the mother of the future bride, Isabel Cooper Riley of Manhasset, L.I.
A May 14 wedding is planned.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I am trying to repair a loose door lock.
The bolts holding the inside plate and the body of the lock in place need tightening, but I can't get at them because there is a decorative plate or cover over this.
This plate is not held on by screws, and I can't figure how to remove it.
How do I get this cover plate off?

LEAD: More than a month after the first cars and motorcycles roared out of the Sahara to complete the 10th Paris-to-Dakar rally, the dust has yet to settle on the world's longest and toughest motor race.


OPEC's Plan Runs Into a Snag
LEAD: OPEC apparently dropped plans to cut oil production.
Officials said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had studied a plan to reduce oil output by 5 percent in hopes of raising sagging prices.
But it reportedly abandoned the proposal because of fears that any cuts in output would be made up by non-OPEC producers.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: THE World Wrestling Federation, saying it was ''shocked and appalled,'' has suspended David Sammartino for an incident with a ringside fan following a match in Watertown, N.Y., last week.
The federation said that Sammartino, son of Bruno Sammartino, assaulted Martin Gallagher, a 200-pound construction worker who heckled him after David lost his match at Watertown High School Wednesday.


Harbor Views at an Amiable Inn
LEAD: NEAR the reception desk of Danfords Inn in Port Jefferson is a picture of George Washington.
Under it, in a spidery 18th-century hand, is the message, ''I never slept here.'' George wouldn't lie.
In spite of its Colonial look, Danfords Inn is a 1980's creation.

Appetites whetted by the arrival of spring insist on asparagus.
Bunches of asparagus have made their appearance with prices at less than $2 a pound.
Artichokes and herbs also have irresistible seasonal appeal.

Will Lower Unemployment Fuel Inflation?
LEAD: Unemployment has fallen to 5.6 percent, the lowest rate in 8 1/2 years.
Will increased tightness in the labor market push up inflation?
The Phillips curve - an economic relationship which shows that inflation grows as unemployment shrinks, and vice versa - would suggest the answer is yes.
But most economists say the curve is not an accurate guide.

LEAD: ''Gone the way of the Hula-Hoop'' has become a vivid way of saying ''passe.'' Now the phrase itself may be that.
Hula-Hoop sales topped two million last year and will exceed that this year.
Hula-Hoops are back.

How Currents Of Art, Revolution And Culture Took Russia's Jews On Fateful Paths
LEAD: The scene is a room in Odessa.
Five literary men face the camera - all seated, all formally attired in the fashion of 1913.
The two on the far left and the far right are unfamiliar names today, but the trio in the middle remain celebrated figures wherever modern Jewish culture is studied.
In the very center sits Simon Dubnow, the foremost Jewish historian of his era.

Why Fast Food Has Slowed Down
LEAD: BURGER, chicken or pizza?
Eat at the restaurant or take it home?
Drive to get it, or have it delivered?
Decisions, decisions.
They may be insignificant for consumers, but they are make-or-break ones for the nearly 130,000 fast-food outlets that dot the country.
The recent top-management shakeup at the Pillsbury Company put the spotlight on troubles at its Burger King subsidiary, but if misery likes company, then Burger King must be a happy place: For all the purveyors of fast food, with the exception of giant McDonald's Corporation and tiny White Castle Systems

South Africa Bans New Anti-Apartheid Group

ENERGY AT ESTEE LAUDER
LEAD: In her Jan. 17 letter to the editor, in response to Lisa Belkin's article ''The Makeover at Estee Lauder,'' (Nov. 29), Phyllis Kraemer really did miss the point.
Age is not the question.
Vitality is.
At Estee Lauder, we are trying to inject a bit more energy and vitality into our approach.
We have never targeted our marketing to a specific age group - at either end of the spectrum - nor do we plan to at this time.


THE WEDDING
LEAD: As a road representative for a large manufacturer of wedding gowns, I am in the bridal business.
Norma Kamali, Mary McFadden, Carolina Herrera and Oscar de la Renta are all fine designers, but they are nothing more than part-timers in the bridal business.
The mainstays in this business are the bridal-wear designers whose gowns cost between $500 and $600.

LEAD: I wish to take exception to the notion that Reagan political appointees have been exhibiting a disdain for Government service (''Reagan's Disappearing Bureaucrats,'' by Phillip Longman, Feb. 14).


Sentence in Pentagon Fraud
LEAD: A former high-ranking official at the Defense Personnel Support Center here was sentenced Thursday to 10 years in prison for taking bribes in the awarding of clothing contracts.
Frank Coccia, 55 years old, who supervised the award of $1.3 million in contracts a year when he was head of the Clothing and Textile Directorate, had pleaded guilty to taking part from 1976 to 1986 in a kickback scheme that involved at least 9 companies and 15 people.

LEAD: ARMY Brigadier General Myrna Hennrich Williamson is the services' senior female officer, outside the nurse corps whose officers traditionally are women.
Commissioned in 1960, General Williamson has served as a company commander, commander of a military police training battalion, brigade commander and commanding general of the Third Reserve Officer Training Corps Region, with headquarters at Fort Riley, Kan.

LEAD: MANUFACTURED wood paneling, particularly plywood and particle board, has revolutionized carpentry and woodworking.
However, one drawback is inherent in working with these materials, and that is covering their edges.
This is necessary both for a finished appearance and to protect the wood from moisture.

POSTING: 700 Jersey Acres; New Frontier
LEAD: The empty tract on which the 150 to 200 homes of Deerfield will be built is outside the most established residential areas of New Jersey but centered among them.
Bergen County is off to the north, Cherry Hill is well to the south, Princeton University is west and Asbury Park is east.
The site, once farms and woodlands, is at the intersection of Middlesex, Mercer and Monmouth Counties and Monroe and Millstone townships.

New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow. $19.95.


WHAT'S DOING IN: BRUSSELS
LEAD: Brussels seems to affect different people in different ways.
Emily Bronte and Baudelaire hated it, Victor Hugo and Cocteau adored it, Lord Byron was impressed by the parks.
Marx and Engels read the tentative chapters of the ''Communist Manifesto'' to Brussels workingmen, Verlaine shot Rimbaud after a lovers' spat in the narrow street that runs by the Hotel Amigo, Emily's sister Charlotte wrote her last novel, ''Villette,'' with Brussels as the setting.

Italy Enacts Seat-Belt Law
LEAD: Parliament has approved a law requiring the installation and wearing of seat belts, bringing Italy into line with the rest of Western Europe.
