South Africa's Economy Faces an Unsteady Future
LEAD: ALONG the undulating highway that leads southwest from this city, a traveler passes through countryside made lush by summer rains.
It is a place of farms and fruit stalls, but on the hillsides back from the road stand the sentinels of a harsher world - the towers of concrete and steel atop South Africa's richest gold field.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Phantom Tours  Question:Having seen ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' and currently planning a trip to Paris, I wonder whether it is possible to take backstage tours of the Paris Opera House. - W. H. B., New York, N.Y.
Answer:Backstage tours are available twice a month, but arranging one with an English-speaking guide requires making an appointment a month in advance.

PERSPECTIVES: Recycling; Putting Vacant Buildings Into Service
LEAD: OVER a period of at least 10 years, New Yorkers have grown accustomed to hearing that the inventory of city-owned tax-foreclosed buildings is increasing.

A Maze of Boulevards and Byways
LEAD: ROAD MAPS ARE DESIGNED to take your from point A, to point B, but mazes are designed to get you lost.
Consider the above, as round as the world, and as full of distractions.
Get out your pencil and start at the top - you may choose your own entrance - and find your way back to the adjacent exit.

HOME FROM AFGHANISTAN
LEAD: As a Vietnam veteran, I particularly related to Bill Keller's article ''Home From Afghanistan'' (Feb. 14).
I saw the faces of the men in my platoon in paratrooper Aleksandr Simonov's face.
He says, ''. . . every night, I dream of my fellow soldiers.'' I do the same thing, even after so many years.

2 Arrested in 21 Robberies
LEAD: The arrest of two men is believed to have solved 21 bank robberies committed in the area in the last two months, the police say.
Coincidentally, the two were arrested Thursday, although the police say the two carried out the robberies individually.
Mark MacAdoo, 22 years old, was arrested in connection with 10 robberies in which the bandit escaped on a motorcycle with a total of about $6,000, the police said.


OH MY CRACKING PISTONS!
LEAD: Funny, isn't it, that only dumb people who get smart are news.
People who were smart all along are not news.


LUBOVITCH SETS HIS OWN TEMPO
LEAD: Dressed in black, always dressed in black to make himself less visible, Lar Lubovitch is obsessed with focusing the stage lights during a rehearsal of his new dance, ''Musette.'' The choreographer knows exactly what he wants: no abrasive edges around the spots, but a smooth transition from the hot patch on center stage where his dancers stand basking to a dim gray area on the sidelines.


Explosion Halts Train Service
LEAD: An electrical transformer seven stories beneath Grand Central Terminal exploded at 11:56 A.M. yesterday, cutting off power to Metro-North and Amtrak lines and suspending passenger service in both directions for more than an hour, according to New York City Fire Department and Metro-North officials.


TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: In the Right Place at the Right Time; THE THING FROM THE BRINY DEEP
LEAD: Travel serendipity?
Because I grew up among life scientists, my most vivid images of the unexpected tend to be biological.
But which to choose?
Should it be the toucans glimpsed while up to my knees in mud beside Lake Catamaco in Mexico?
The fire ants I sat down on by mistake in the Galapagos?
Or the popular hole in a wooden wall in the rudimentary zoo of Kabul, Afghanistan, on the other side of which was a single elephant eye, looking back out?

Covering Panel Edges
LEAD: MANUFACTURED wood paneling, particularly plywood and particle board, has revolutionized carpentry and woodworking.
However, one drawback is inherent in working with these materials, and that is covering their edges.
This is necessary both for a finished appearance and to protect the wood from moisture.

Designer With an Affinity for the Past
LEAD: The first academy award for costume design was given, in 1948, to Dorothy Jeakins for ''Joan of Arc.'' If years are locomotives, then 1948 is 40 stations down a twisted track, a world that only exists in memory and old snapshots.

A CORRECTION
LEAD: The Streetscapes article on Feb. 21 incorrectly stated that the building at 503 Fifth Avenue had been emptied of tenants and not since relet.

Correction
LEAD: The Pop View column in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday incorrectly described the uses of proceeds from Michael Jackson's ''Man in the Mirror'' recording.
A spokesman for Mr.
Jackson says that indeed a part of the royalties from the 7-inch and 12-inch singles of ''Man in the Mirror'' will be donated to charity, benefiting Camp Ronald McDonald for Good Times, a camp for children with cancer.

Street Fashion; Preppy Look With a Downtown Twist
LEAD: A LOT of young men about town have been cleaning up their act lately, shying away from the black-leather rock-and-roller look so popular in the last fashion millennium (about a month ago on regulation calendars) in favor of tweedy checks and plaids.
Subdued silk ties, striped shirts, comfy cardigan sweaters, baggy trousers and slicked-down hairdos are getting their share of attention, too.

Colorado's Late Skiers Get a Touch of the Sun
LEAD: APRIL in Colorado is indeed the cruelest month, dumping snow on lilacs at altitudes as low as 5,000 feet, sometimes burying the entire bush higher up.
This seeming endlessness of high-country winter is hard on would-be gardeners and tennis players, but not so hard on skiers, who may still enjoy the lingering snow, as well as April's longer days and higher temperatures.

Food; The Farmers' Banquet
LEAD: SOMETIMES I AM SURPRISED THAT the French have cookbooks at all.
For even though the written word is sacrosanct in France, all one has to do is walk out the door and, inevitably, the subject of food comes up.
Before you know it, you're jotting down recipes for the cheesemonger's favorite potato gratin, the hairdresser's grandmother's version of creme caramel, the dry cleaner's apple tart and the farmer's wife's cheesecake.

Exploring Twin Cities By Canal Boat
LEAD: WE had to board Paradise before 6 P.M., but we just could not find it.
Paradise is the name of the new tourist boat that runs overnight between Suzhou and Hangzhou along the Grand Canal.
Paradise is also the name that Chinese give to the twin cities of Suzhou and Hangzhou, linked in an ancient Chinese saying that Marco Polo elaborated on when he told the West of the fabulous cities of the East: ''In heaven, paradise; on earth, Suzhou and Hangzhou.

Jail Overcrowding Tests the Ingenuity of City and State
LEAD: LAST month's uprising in New York City's Rikers Island jail complex, in which 550 inmates seized control of 12 dormitories for three and a half hours, sounded yet another warning about the dangers of jail and prison crowding.

FROM THE CAULDRON OF LITERATURE: AN EXILE'S JOURNAL
LEAD: Witold Gombrowicz was born into a family of Polish gentry in 1904.
He completed his law studies in Warsaw and studied philosophy and economics in Paris, but abandoned a legal career when he made his literary debut with a collection of short stories, ''Memoir From Adolescence,'' in 1933. ''Ferdydurke,'' a novel, and ''Yvonne, Princess of Burgundy,'' a play, followed in 1938.

The River of Grass Seen From a Tram
LEAD: EVEN on one of those raw, blustery days that bedevil the winter visitor to Florida, there are no vacant seats on the tram tour that explores the Everglades at Shark Valley.
Thirty miles west of Miami, along the well-traveled Tamiami Trail, Shark Valley is the most accessible of the three entrances to Everglades National Park, the one closest to south Florida's booming resort communities.

THE WORLD: Occupied Territories; Uprising by the Palestinians Is Not a Made-for-TV Movie
LEAD: THE 4,000 residents of this tiny Arab village in the West Bank mountains say they have held some 20 demonstrations since the Palestinian uprisings began last Dec. 9.
The village's Israeli-appointed leaders have all resigned and its youth have broken apart one of the ancient stone terraces on the hillside sloping down from Mazraa Sharqiya in order to build a series of roadblocks at the entrance to the town.

Patricia O'Connor to Wed
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
George J. O'Connor of Carmel, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Mary O'Connor, to Dr.
Greenfield Sluder, a son of Dr. and Mrs.
John C. Sluder of Armonk, N.Y.
The future bride is an assistant professor of biological sciences at Wellesley College.
Dr.
Sluder is a staff scientist at the Worcester (Mass.) Foundation for Experimental Biology.


Au Printemps, Au Marche
LEAD: WEEKS BEFORE WINTER OFFICIALLY submits to spring, the signs are there.
From Brittany's port of Erquy to the bustling riverside quays of Lyons, from Nice's sun-kissed Cours Saleya to the sunrise tuna auction in St.-Jean-de-Luz, one's senses are alerted to the change of season.
Already, plump melons from Cavailon, tiny peas from Barbentane, strawberries from just north of Marseilles, peaches from Salon-de-Provence, cherries from Ceret, have begun to trickle into market stalls.

LEAD:  Boxing  Whitaker Loses Title Bid: Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico retained his World Boxing Council lightweight title yesterday in Paris with a controversial split decision over Pernell Whitaker of the United States.
Whitaker, who won a gold medal at the 1984 Olympics, appeared to have an easy time from the start and was peppering the champion with right jabs throughout the fight.

LEAD: IT IS infinitely simpler to commission a work of art than it is to remove one after it has been installed, the Federal Government is learning.

LEAD: Bernard Rudofsky, the provocative architect and social commentator whose books and museum exhibitions influenced not only his profession but fashion, interior design, urban planning and food, died of cancer yesterday at New York University Hospital.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Vegetables and Pasta: Seductive, Simple
LEAD: THE official beginning of spring is a week away.
But the markets have begun to display their springtime finery.
Appetites whetted by the arrival of spring insist on asparagus.
Bunches of asparagus have made their appearance with prices at less than $2 a pound.
Artichokes and herbs also have irresistible seasonal appeal.

Cezanne's Sketchbooks: Secrets and Surprises
LEAD: The quietest exhibition of the current season to date in the New York museums may well turn out to be the most important one.
It is ''Paul Cezanne: the Basel Sketchbooks,'' and it can be seen through June 5 at the Museum of Modern Art.
The 114 drawings in the show are from the hand of one of the greatest artists who ever lived, and they range in date from his student days to the final phase of his career.


A Furnished Time Machine
LEAD: SUMMER may be fine for visiting drafty British country houses and walking the length and breadth of their gardens.
But during the perennial spring drizzle, one seeks the cozier atmosphere of drawing rooms in town.
Also, in only visiting stately aristocratic homes, one neglects the equally rich heritage of the frequently more stylish rooms of merchants' houses.

It is routine procedure for an inmate marched down from death row to see a lawyer or a member of the press and Mr.
Darden, 54 years old, knows the routine well.

Heavy Metal
LEAD: IT IS THE LARGEST ATRIUM IN Washington.
Its Corinthian columns, 75 feet high, 8 feet in diameter, are the world's biggest.
The Pension Building in Judiciary Square was erected between 1882 and 1887 with a dual purpose - to house the offices of the Federal Government's pension bureau and to serve as a setting for large gatherings.

THIRD-COMMANDMENT BLUES
LEAD: Mr.
Bush is indeed off the hook, but not because he used the adjectival form of the expression, as Mr.
Safire indicated.
Mr.
Bush is off the hook because he was never on it.
The Third Commandment, many believe, has nothing to do with minor swearing; it refers, rather, to lying under oath - to perjury, not profanity.

TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING
LEAD: May I clarify my position on man's ''minimal daily requirement'' for exercise (Body and Mind: ''Too Much of a Good Thing,'' by Morton Hunt, Feb. 7)?
I agree with the American College of Sports Medicine recommendation of 20-30 minutes of aerobic exercise three times a week, which was mentioned in your article.


Totalitarianism, Indoors and Out
Since ''The Case of Herman the Stoker'' makes some effort to penetrate the mind of its subject, a lot of it is about firewood.
Leszek Wosiewicz's short film includes the information that birch logs are good for keeping bad thoughts away and for making a person ready to work.
Maple, on the other hand, produces a more dynamic state of mind.
A man named Herman, who presumably contributed these observations (which are presented by two unseen narrators), learned to make fires when he worked at a mental institution.
Later, once the patients were liquidated, it became a school for German officers during the days of the Third Reich.
Herman was so sensitive to the nuances of firewood, and so adroit at making fires to suit particular personalities, that he came to hold a privileged position within the ranks of the regime; he eventually rose to the honor of building fires for the Fuhrer himself.
Hitler was a maple man.

Leicester Square
LEAD: Every big town has, or should have, its place to meet - the place that everyone knows and that is accepted as the hub of focus of the city.
In New York it's Times Square, or possible Rockefeller Center.
In San Francisco, Union Square.
In Florence, the Piazza della Signoria; in Venice, the Campanile in the Piazza San Marco.

Nuclear Plant Shuts Down
LEAD: The Millstone 1 nuclear power plant shut down automatically at 5:45 A.M. today when a water feed pump lost power, a Northeast Utilities spokesman, Anthony Nericcio, said.
The plant will be put back into service when the cause of the power interruption is determined and any problems corrected, he said.

Review/Piano; Chopin, Bartok And Beethoven In Chen Recital
LEAD: Hung-Kuan Chen made it clear in the first few bars of his piano recital Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y that he would play his Beethoven with unusual concentration and command of rhythm.
The E flat sonata, (Op. 27 No. 1), was very impressive for security at top speed in the finale and for evenly weighted, thoughtful chording in the slow movements.

Curbing the Sexploitation Industry
LEAD: I can't even count the times in the last three years, since I began to express my concern about violence and sexuality in rock music, that I have been called a prude, a censor, a music hater, even a book burner.

I'm not advocating censorship but rather a candid and vigorous debate about the dangers posed for our children by what I call the ''exploitation industry.

Review/Music; Cabaret Singers Recall The Style of Cole Porter
LEAD: The packed and ecstatic 12-hour Cole Porter celebration at Symphony Space on Saturday held a little bit of pleasure for almost everybody.
Mr.
Porter, who moved pop songs to a more sophisticated musical and emotional level, was represented by a flock of cabaret singers, Porter experts reminiscing, celluloid memories (by which Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers made an appearance), Bobby Short and an orchestra playing original scores from Porter's early Broadway plays.

LEAD: The club record for golf bags shipped by the Boston Red Sox on one trip is 14, set last season on the road to New York and Baltimore.

They said the move would take the pressure off a Federal judge who is scheduled to hear arguments today on issues in the complex takeover struggle.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Saturday about Rob-ert D. McFarlanes's plea of guilty ot four misdemeanor counts of with-holding information about the Nicaraguan rebels from Congress characterized his plea incorrectly in one paragraph and a later passage.
The charges to which Mr.
McFarlane, a former national security adviser, pleaded guilty said that he had withheld material information, but they did not charge that he made false statements.

Bookstore Behemoths Trade Quips
LEAD: With nearly 2,000 stores in their two chains, Waldenbooks and B. Dalton are the undisputed behemoths of books.
While each chain has undoubtedly felt the hot breath of the other on its neck, outwardly, at least, they have generally treated each other with studied indifference.
Recently, however, their competition has taken on a dimension that is anything but bookish, causing amusement among publishers.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Capitals 3, Bruins 0: Steve Leach and Greg Adams scored first-period goals and Pete Peeters stopped 42 shots last night as Washington won in Boston.
It was the third time in five games that the Bruins were shut out.
Peeters, a former Bruin who leads the league in goals-against average, made several outstanding saves in posting his second shutout of the season.

LEAD: Stalwarts of American business have agreed to a Soviet request to give marketing pointers to Soviet managers of newly restructured ministries, foreign-trade organizations and state enterprises, American officials reported today.

Louis Cardinals.

Lucie on the Atlantic Coast.

LEAD: When truck drivers leave their diesel engines idling to keep the engines and fuel warm or to heat or cool the cab, they can be shortening the life of the truck engine by 6 to 12 months, according to a study by Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois.

The Ides of Marx
LEAD: Old joke in Eastern Europe: Q. What is the difference, comrade, between Communism and capitalism?
A.
Under capitalism, man exploits man.
Under Communism, the situation is reversed.
As if to illustrate, Mikhail Gorbachev now promises a radical new reform to the toiling Soviet masses: the progressive income tax.

Tax Watch; State Amnesties: Results Mixed
LEAD: WASHINGTON


Steel Output Falls 0.2%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.967 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of two-tenths of a percent from the previous week's 1.971 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production was 91.6 percent of capacity, compared with 91.8 percent in the previous week.

Corrections
LEAD: A drawing with the Fitness column of SportsMonday this week depicted the Pelvic Tilt incorrectly.
The excercise is done this way: Lying on the back, bend the knees, with feet flat on the floor and hands at sides.
Press the small of the back against the floor.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Do people who have been blind since birth dream in images as seeing people do?
A.
Researchers generally agree that people born blind are entirely lacking in visual imagery in their dreams.

LEAD: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee since 1973, yesterday announced his intention to retire from Congress in January after 40 years.


Sedgwick Group Picks Outsider as Likely Heir
LEAD: David Rowland has been named group chief executive of the Sedgwick Group P.L.C., Britain's largest independent insurance broker, effective immediately.

Treaty On Ozone Is Backed In Senate
LEAD: The Senate voted unanimously today to approve ratification of a historic international agreement to limit global use of chemicals that are believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield.
The vote was 83 to 0.
With today's vote, which had been expected, the United States became the first major user and producer of chlorofluorocarbons to approve an international agreement that would first freeze and then roll back their consumption and production.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Clyde Drexler of the Portland Trail Blazers was named the N.B.A. player of the week for the period ending Sunday.
He averaged 28.7 points, 6.6 rebounds, 5.8 assists and 3 steals as the Blazers won all three of their games and extended their winning streak to eight games. . . .
Coach Jimmy Johnson of the University of Miami, who led the Hurricanes to the national collegiate football championship last season, has agreed to a two-year contract extension through the 1992 season.


Yankee Rookie Shows Promise
LEAD: The home run that Jay Buhner hit against the Expos Sunday afternoon in West Palm Beach seemed to carry into the clouds.
It finally settled over the fence in center field, well beyond the 400-foot marker and well past the shrubs that border the chain-link fence.
It was the kind of home run that big-league ballplayers glow about in the clubhouse when their work is done.


U.S. Davis Cup Team
LEAD: Andre Agassi and Jay Berger, newcomers to Davis Cup competition, will join Ken Flach and Robert Seguso on the United States team that will play Peru in Lima, April 8-10, in the quarterfinal round of the American Zone competition.

LEAD: Two homestate politicians, Senator Paul Simon and the Rev.

Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, for the ethnic and racial loyalties of Illinois Democrats in the final hours before Tuesday's Presidential primary.

LEAD: The Knicks' halftime statistics looked like a mess last night.
Mark Jackson was shooting 1 for 8 from the field, Patrick Ewing was 2 for 10 and the Knicks as a team were shooting 33 percent.
As they left the floor trailing, 56-41, the Madison Square Garden crowd, which has become accustomed to seeing them win at home, booed them loudly.

The Deficit: Still No. 1 Problem
LEAD: President Reagan's budget, issued several weeks ago, projected a steadily declining Federal deficit, one that would fall to a mere $39 billion by 1993 even with no further spending cuts or tax increases.
In effect, he is saying that the deficit problem has been solved, that we do not need a tax increase, that all we need now is the patience to let the medicine work.

Ambitious Project Will Buy Land To Preserve the Connecticut River

Review/Television; 2 Series Put the Less Prominent in Prime Time
LEAD: Hispanic people and the elderly, not among the more overexposed groups on prime-time television, are suddenly popping up in two weekly series making their debuts on CBS this evening. ''Trial and Error,'' at 8 o'clock, is about two Mexican-American roommates in Los Angeles. ''Coming of Age,'' at 9, offers a former airline pilot and his wife, still only 60ish, who decide to move to a retirement community in Arizona.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on March 4 from Hebron, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, incorrectly described the aftermath of riots there in 1929.
Although dozens of Jews were killed or wounded in the riots, a Jewish community remained in Hebron until 1936, when further unrest prompted the British authorities to evacuate Jews from the city.

Ply-Gem Sets Pact
LEAD: Ply-Gem Industries has agreed to acquire Wolverine Technologies Inc. for $60.8 million.
Ply-Gem, a New York-based maker of home improvement products, will pay $18.50 a share for the almost 3.3 million shares of common stock in Wolverine, which manufactures vinyl siding and windows.
Ply-Gem, had revenues of $313 million in 1987, while Wolverine reported revenues of $111 million.


Dow Advances 15.09 Amid Light Trading
LEAD: Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday in a late rally amid the lightest trading since Dec. 29.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was only 131.9 million shares, down from 200 million on Friday.


Our Towns; Meals on Wheels And a Side Order Of Devotion
LEAD: When Mabel Gates and Hilton Wilson are delivering for Meals on Wheels, they're not kidding around. ''We're very fast,'' said Mrs.
Gates. ''We get here early, we leave early, and we're good deliverers.''


Panama Canal's Fragile Prospects
LEAD: Since 1914, the Panama Canal has been one of the main arteries of international trade, providing cheap and efficient service to shippers.
But basic questions have emerged about the canal's role in the future, quite apart from the political crisis that has rocked Panama since last June.


Regan Criticizes Cuomo's Budget As Overly Rosy
LEAD: The New York State Comptroller said today that Governor Cuomo's proposed state budget was based on an overly optimistic economic forecast and could result in a shortfall of up to $800 million.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Desert Partners
LEAD: A partnership led by the Texas oilmen Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown is soliciting proxies to elect six nominees to the USG Corporation's 15-member board.
Desert Partners L.P. is seeking to gain control of the nation's largest gypsum producer.
USG's directors will be elected at the Chicago-based company's annual meeting on May 11.


Suspicion Stalls Japanese Project
LEAD: For more than two years Japan has tried to launch an ambitious and expensive program in which American, European and Japanese scientists would pool their knowledge to explore the deepest secrets of biological science.


Cement Maker Rejects Offer
LEAD: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. today rejected a $308.3 million tender offer by a rival cement maker, Southdown Inc., and said it was talking with unidentified third parties about a possible leveraged buyout.


Studies Document Allergies Both Dangerous and Rare
LEAD: Deer can make hunters sneeze, cockroaches often prompt asthmatics to wheeze and exercise can send joggers into shock, according to researchers who study little-known but potentially deadly allergies.


Bonds Mark Time on a Quiet Day
LEAD: Bond prices were little changed in dull, trackless trading yesterday.


Rig Count Off in Week
LEAD: The number of oil and gas rigs exploring for oil in the United States fell by 32 last week, to 946, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today.
A year ago, the number stood at 761.


Savings and Loan Shut
LEAD: Federal regulators closed the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Paducah, Ky., today and transferred its insured deposits to the Security Trust Federal Savings and Loan Association in Oak Ridge, Tenn.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it closed First Federal because it was insolvent and had liabilities of $167.9 million and assets of $130 million.


ENTIRE GAZA STRIP PUT UNDER CURFEW
LEAD: The Israeli authorities imposed a nightly curfew on the entire Gaza Strip tonight after the resignation of hundreds of Palestinian policemen there.


New Drug Dissolves Heart Clots, Saving Lives
LEAD: A NEW drug has joined the ranks of clot-dissolving substances that can save the lives of many heart attack patients.
In a British study, patients taking the drug Eminase after a heart attack were only about half as likely to die than patients who received a placebo, an inert substance.
The findings were reported this week in the journal

LEAD: The New Directors/New Films festival is presenting a number of unconventional documentaries, but none as alarming and significantly lunatic as ''The Emperor's Naked Army Marches On,'' conceived by Shohei Imamura (''Vengeance Is Mine'') and directed by Kazuo Hara as his first feature.

LEAD: Last week, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was scheduled to testify before the House Judiciary Committee about his department's budget for the coming year.
Then the panel canceled the session, saying it conflicted with a heavy load of Presidential primaries.


Erased Files Get New Life
LEAD: YOU think you're saving that important file, but you accidentally erase it instead.
If you haven't done this yet, you will.
Woe, despair and anguish follow.
Life loses its meaning, birds cease to sing, flowers wilt and children and pets seek hiding places.

The Chinese movie, directed by Chen Kaige and on view tonight at 6 o'clock and tomorrow at 8:30 P.M.

LEAD: The Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, which is to be the largest museum of contemporary art in the world when completed, yesterday won passage in the Massachusetts Legislature of a $35 million appropriations bill.

LEAD: R. H. Macy &amp; Company yesterday increased the cash front end of its takeover offer for Federated Department Stores Inc. by $200 million, to $77.35 a share, from $74.50 for 80 percent of Federated's stock.

LEAD: Two months after a Presidential task force issued recommendations on how to prevent another stock market crash, the White House is planning to form another group to draft its final, official position, White House aides said today.

LEAD: Tom Trebelhorn, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, officially announced today that Paul Molitor and Jim Gantner would switch positions.

LEAD: The flight of senior investment bankers from large Wall Street firms continued yesterday with the resignation of Henry Lentz Jr. from Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.


Good Ways and Bad to Fight Drugs
LEAD: T.N.T. and the death penalty: those are New York's reactions to the drug-related murder of a young police officer.
T.N.T., short for a new police offensive, makes sense as long as it receives sustained official support.
But the death penalty campaign perpetrates a fraud.
Both responses apply in any city bedeviled by drugs.

The Endless Brawley Case
LEAD: The case of Tawana Brawley has become a festering social wound.
Without the alleged victim's cooperation, it may never be healed, but it can at least be treated, with an assiduous grand jury investigation.
The public is entitled to justice, too, and to official closure of a case that has won national attention and continues to torment race relations.

LEAD: Arthur Francis Sampson, who led the General Services Administration for three years in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, died Sunday.
He was 61 years old and lived in Falls Chuurch, Va.

Police Informant Receives Award
LEAD: An anonymous informant in a black hood received $10,000 in cash yesterday from Copshot, a private group that offers rewards for providing information leading to the arrest and conviction of someone who shoots a New York City police officer.
With the informant were Chief of Detectives Robert Colangelo, center, and Phil Caruso, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

LEAD: Dock workers at Panama's three major commercial ports went on strike today after the cash-starved Government of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega failed to pay them, and the police fired tear gas at hundreds of teachers who had gathered at the Ministry of Education to demand wages due them.

U.S. Starting Seizures Of Citizens' Passports
LEAD: The United States on Tuesday will begin to seize the passports of Americans re-entering the country with illicit drugs despite warnings by legal experts that the action would pose constitutional problems.


Pharmacy Concern And National Data
LEAD: Medco Containment Services Inc., a mail-order pharmacy company based in Elmwood Park, N.J., said it had agreed to acquire the National Data Corporation, a financial services company based in Atlanta.
Medco will issue 26.9 million new shares, to be exchanged at a 2.3-for-1 ratio, for the 11.7 million outstanding shares of National Data.

LEAD: Robert B. Semple Jr., editor of the Op-Ed page at The New York Times for the last six years, has been appointed associate editorial page editor, effective June 1.
The appointment was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, who supervises both pages.


Judge Can Hear a Suit in Spite of Her Husband's Indictment
LEAD: A New York State judge whose husband was indicted after an investigation initiated by lawyers for New York City can preside over a negligence case in which the city is a defendant, the Appellate Division has ruled.

LEAD: A Federal court jury today found Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, who is serving a life sentence for trying to assassinate President Ford in 1975, guilty of escape.

LEAD: An American-made F-16 jet crashed into a mountain today in northern Norway during an eight-nation NATO exercise, killing the Norwegian pilot, according to the Allied Press Information Center.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.H.L.
Tie Ends Canadiens' Winning Streak: A power-play goal by Chris Chelios, a defenseman, early in the third period allowed Montreal to salvage a 2-2 tie at Bloomington, Minn., with the North Stars.
Montreal entered with a 10-game winning streak, longest in the league this season.
Minnesota, with the worst record in the league, earned its third point in two games after losing its previous seven games.

Charter Medical Price is Increased
LEAD: The Charter Medical Corporation said that the price of a buyout offer by the WAF Acquisition Corporation had been increased.
The price is now $30.25 in cash and $7 in principal amount of junior subordinated debentures due in the year 2000 for each share of Charter's class A and class B stocks.
WAF's original offer had been for $28 in cash and $5 in debentures.


Film Company Set By United Artists
LEAD: United Artists Communications Inc., which operates movie theaters and a cable television company, has formed Corsair Pictures, a New York based company. ''Corsair will finance modestly budgeted, independently made films,'' said Frank Perry, who will head the company.


Scientists to Seek 'Shadow Bands' During a Total Eclipse of the Sun
LEAD: AS a total eclipse of the sun sweeps across the Pacific Ocean Saturday, astronomers aboard two cruise ships will try to record images of ''shadow bands,'' a phenomenon that has often been reported during eclipses but never photographed.


Bush Bests Democrats in Polls
LEAD: Vice President Bush holds big leads over the Rev.
Jesse Jackson or Albert Gore Jr. but only a narrow edge over Michael S. Dukakis in possible general election matchups, according to polls conducted for Time and Newsweek magazines.

Reagan to Seek New Contra Aid Vote This Week
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he will seek a vote this week on a new contra aid package and expressed irritation with intelligence assessments that the Nicaraguan rebels are within weeks of extinction as a result of a congressional cutoff of American assistance.


Baseball Can't Settle on Rules
LEAD: With the start of the baseball season three weeks away, the proposed rule changes involving balks and the strike zone remain in limbo.
In the latest move in negotiations between the rules committee and the Players Association, the association has asked the committee to reconsider its rejection of the union's proposal that the new rules be implemented on a one-year trial basis.

LEAD: Paul McDonald Fye, who led the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution nearly 20 years, died Friday at his home in Falmouth, Mass.
He was 75 years old.

Bulgarian Free Zones
LEAD: Bulgaria has established two duty-free zones to ''encourage economic cooperation'' between Bulgarian and foreign companies, the state-run press agency reported today.
It said the zones had been set up in Rousse and Vidin to offer areas where ''economic activities can be carried out'' without duties or taxes.


Effort Disclosed to Improve Armor on Tank
LEAD: The Army disclosed today that under a classified program to improve the armor of its main battle tank, the M-1A1 Abrams, it was starting to build the tank with depleted uranium in the armor plating.

LEAD: One of the great pleasures in the world of sport is the feeling in the pit of a batter's stomach at the moment he hits a high, hard one exactly right.
There is a similar visceral echo when a golf swing really clicks, and tennis players experience it when they connect with perfect ground strokes, sending shock waves of satisfaction through their bodies.

LEAD: President Reagan pleaded with critics on Capitol Hill today to support an increase in funds for his proposed missile shield based in space.

LEAD: Iran and Iraq shot missiles at each other's cities yesterday, ending a truce that began Friday.
The photo above, released by the Iranian News Agency, is said to show rescuers searching for survivors of a missile attack on Teheran.
Iraq claimed its missile attacks were a reprisal for Iran's shelling of border towns Friday night.

LEAD: The 63d running of the traditional Hastings International Tournament in England was won by Nigel Short.
The 22-year-old British grandmaster scored 9-5 to top one of the strongest fields ever assembled for this event.

General Signal To Buy GCA
LEAD: The General Signal Corporation has agreed to acquire the GCA Corporation, the troubled manufacturer of equipment used to make semiconductors, for between $75 million and $80 million.
General Signal, a big electronics concern, said it would pay off GCA's debts and swap a fraction of its shares for each of GCA's nearly 9.5 million outstanding common shares.

LEAD: An article on the Health page last Thursday about macular degeneration, an eye disease, incorrectly described the dosage in an experimental study.

Panama Troops Storm a Hospital To Quell Pay Protest by Workers
LEAD: Panamanian military units attacked the country's largest hospital today after doctors, nurses and other medical workers who had not been paid took to the streets demanding their paychecks and the overthrow of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega.
At least 23 workers were hit by birdshot or otherwise wounded in the three-hour skirmish, which ended when heavily armed military forces stormed the hospital.

LEAD: In a move that stunned the banking world, John R. Torell 3d resigned yesterday as president of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
The 48-year-old executive has been with the banking company for 27 years and was widely assumed to be the heir apparent to John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and chief executive.

Apple Price Cuts
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said that the suggested retail price of its entry-level Macintosh Plus personal computer has been reduced to $1,799 from $2,199, effective immediately.
Apple also reduced prices on three hard disk drives: the HD 20 SC is reduced to $1,099 from $1,299; the HD 40SC to $1,699 from $1,999, and the HD 80SC to $2,799 from $3,199.

Wepner Sentenced
LEAD: Chuck Wepner, who once fought for the heavyweight title, was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison after admitting to cocaine charges.

In Furnace's Hulk, Lessons on Courage
LEAD: SINCE the birth of my children I've become a coward.
In my youth, I walked out boldly into the night without the baggage of a chicken.
I went to raise my voice to the moon and sniff the air and look into people's houses.
I didn't bother about mortal peril.
I could go skiing by myself at night in the woods, without imagining that my carcass would be discovered months later, a few bleached ribs sticking up through the spring ooze, and the headline in the local paper: ''NO ONE HEARD HER CALL.

From Screen to Solid 3-D Model In a Matter of Minutes
LEAD: A GRADUATE student at the University of Texas has invented a device that builds three-dimensional models of objects only minutes after they have been designed on a screen using computer graphics.
The inventor, Carl R. Deckard, likens the device to a three-dimensional laser printer that is capable of producing a solid object rather than a two-dimensional representation of the object.

Merc Official Re-elected
LEAD: Zoltan (Lou) Guttman was re-elected vice chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange last night, defeating John Tafaro, a former member of the Merc's board, 283-272.
Mr.
Guttman will serve another two-year term.
William Bradt is the chairman of the New York Merc.
Exchange members also chose five new members for the Merc's board.

LEAD: A Navy paymaster was found beaten and strangled today aboard the destroyer U.S.S.
John Hancock and $120,000 was stolen from the ship's safe, a naval spokesman said.
The officer's body was found stuffed into a sea locker in another part of the ship, said Chief Petty Officer Art Riccio.
Officials identified the victim as Lieut.

They were freshmen on the Fairleigh Dickinson basketball team then, preparing to face Michigan, the second-ranked team in the country, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.


Chairman Rodino Retires, With Grace
LEAD: For one who has enjoyed the power and privileges that Congressional seniority bring, leaving Capitol Hill for good isn't easy.
So it was understandable that Representative Peter Rodino of New Jersey, who has spent more than half his 78 years in the House, might have had second thoughts about retiring after his current term.


FLORIDA EXECUTES CELEBRATED KILLER
LEAD: Willie Jasper Darden, who maintained his innocence through 14 years on death row and became the focus of an international debate over capital punishment, was executed today in Florida's electric chair.


New York Government: For Sale?
LEAD: This week's hearings of the State Commission on Government Integrity dramatically erase all doubts about New York's need for campaign finance reform.
The bald testimony of campaign donors who depend on favorable government action creates the clear impression that New York's officialdom is for sale.


Societe Generale
LEAD: Societe Generale de Belgique, the giant Belgian conglomerate at the center of a takeover battle, said it would hold an extraordinary meeting of its shareholders on April 14.
The gathering promises a showdown between the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti and a rival alliance of French and Belgian companies unless the two camps can settle a two-month battle for control of Societe Generale de Belgique before then.


France's Cozy Election
LEAD: Some French are complaining again at the ''Americanization'' of their campaign for president.
They mean a focus on personality, with nothing much clear-cut in the way of programs or issues.


Teachers of the Gifted Fight Accusations of Elitism
LEAD: In classes for the gifted, there are many shades of brightness.


Koch Criticizes City's Legislators In Fight for More State School Aid
LEAD: Renewing the war that began two months ago with a battle over pension increases, Mayor Koch and New York City lawmakers traded accusations today over who is to blame for the problems of the city's school system.


General Mills' Profits Rise
LEAD: General Mills Inc. said today that its earnings jumped 25.5 percent in the third quarter, primarily because of growth in its consumer foods division.


Hoyt Ammidon, Retired Chairman Of United States Trust, Dies at 78
LEAD: Hoyt Ammidon, retired chairman of the United States Trust Company and a leader in civic, cultural and philanthropic organizations, died of cancer Sunday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital.
He was 78 years old and lived in Glen Head, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla.


Quaker State Seeks To Sell Restaurants
LEAD: The Quaker State Corporation is trying to sell its 100 Arctic Circle restaurants in nine Western states, a company spokesman said.


Market Place; Analysts Favor Bar Code Stocks
LEAD: STOCKS related to bar code reading equipment - one of technology's niche industries - have sharply recovered from their low prices in the October market debacle.
These companies continue to benefit from broadening applications and from forecasts of higher profits.


8 Charged in Philadelphia Jail Inquiry
LEAD: A prison guard and a cook were charged today with taking money to help a prisoner escape and six other guards were accused of viciously beating a second inmate.


Ralph Dubin, Artist, 69
LEAD: Ralph Dubin, an artist whose work evolved from social realist figuration into one more heavily influenced by abstract forms, died of a heart attack on March 9 at his home in Manhattan.
He was 69 years old.


Why They're Pleading to Get Into P.S. 87
LEAD: In the principal's office at Public School 87, parents seeking to enroll their children hovered, anxious to please.


A Winner Loses
LEAD: A fugitive arrested after he was recognized on the television game show ''Super Password'' pleaded guilty Monday to collecting $100,000 on a life insurance policy by falsely contending his wife had been killed.
The 36-year-old fugitive, Kerry Dee Ketchem, appearing under a pseudonym on ''Super Password,'' was identified by a viewer and was arrested as he tried to pick up a record $58,600 in winnings.


Bridge
LEAD: In the 1930's, 40's and 50's, college campuses provided constant bridge activity.
In a few cases dedicated enthusiasts found that their passion for the game inhibited graduation.


Corrections
LEAD: A report yesterday in the Science Watch column of Science Times about the military use of a small space station misidentified the industry newsletter that first reported the development.
It was Space Station News, based in Washington.

LEAD: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper.

Economic Scene; A Demand-Side Cocaine Policy
LEAD: ECONOMISTS who analyze the illegal drug markets offer a skeptical perspective on Washington's strategy for stopping cocaine.
They acknowledge that the current $700 million interdiction effort has increased risks for smugglers.
But as Peter Reuter of the Rand Corporation argues, the quantity of powder seized is a poor measure of how successful the program is.

About New York; A Matchmaker For Stories And Storytellers
LEAD: On the 19th floor of an old office building in midtown Manhattan a woman mans a telephone the livelong day.
At times, people ring her up and tell her the most astonishingly intimate stories, laying bare their lives in the hope that a book will come out of it, or a movie or at least an article.
The woman, Dorothy Beach, runs Dial-A-Writer (212-398-1934).


British Utility and U.S. Bank Find Good Investor Demand
LEAD: Two corporate issues totaling $550 million were offered yesterday through Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company at prices slightly higher than had been expected because of strong investor demand.


Gap Narrows In U.S. Trade
LEAD: The Government's broadest measure of the United States' trade performance, the current account deficit, shrank significantly, to $38.99 billion, in the last three months of 1987, the Commerce Department said today.


About Education
LEAD: Critics of public education have clamored for a return to ''the basics.'' In recent years, many schools have responded but without uniform success.
A new study says that students may be reading more but understanding it less.


Stock Buyback At Cleveland
LEAD: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., a mining and oil drilling concern, announced a restructuring yesterday, including the repurchase of $170 million of common and preferred stock.


Dow Falls by 2.66 in Lackluster Trading
LEAD: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday as both blue chips and secondaries continued to meander in lackluster trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.66 points, to 2,047.41, but advances led declines by 789 to 718.

LEAD: One of the hallmarks of the current economic recovery, now in its sixth year, has been the creation of 10 million jobs.

LEAD: Last year, while 28,000 homeless people were placed each night in municipal shelters and welfare hotels, there were 72,000 empty apartments in New York City, according to a city-sponsored study released last week.

LEAD: TIMOTHY NUGENT likes almost everything about being a student at the New England Culinary Institute: the classes, the hands-on cooking experience, the teachers.
But what he doesn't like - what sends a shudder through his slight frame and prompts words like ''nasty'' and ''vile'' - is the traditional chef's uniform that is required in the institute's kitchens.


Obstacles in Jackson Path: Arithmetic and Attitudes
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson managed 7 percent of the white vote in today's Illinois primary, according to The New York Times/CBS News Poll of voters who had just cast their ballots, and took his anticipated 90 percent of the black vote.
But, as Mr.
Jackson conceded tonight, that was not enough to win the statewide popularity contest here, or enough to give him anything approaching a majority of the 173 Democratic convention delegates chosen in today's voting.

LEAD: A state task force today suggested amending the New York Constitution to allow voters to register and vote on election day.


Review/Theater; 'Fences' and 'Les Mis': After a Year's Run, Changes and Constants
LEAD: For the brave theatergoer contemplating a visit to a Broadway hit that has run a season or longer, only two matters can be taken more or less for granted: ticket prices will have inched upward since opening night, and some, if not all, of the original cast that thrilled critics and Tony Award voters will have fled.

Poll Finds Arts Attendance Has Declined
LEAD: Attendance at concerts and other performing-arts events, as well as participation in most arts activities, has declined in this country since 1984 as leisure time has dwindled and the use of video-cassette recorders has rapidly expanded, according to a poll released yesterday by Louis Harris and Associates.

LEAD: The Rev.
John Capers Fletcher, a retired Episcopal priest who ministered to the deaf for 47 years, died of a heart attack March 3 at Alexandria, Va., Hospital.
He was 87 years old and lived in Alexandria.

LEAD: House Democratic leaders told President Reagan today that they were not prepared to vote this week on a new aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels.
They also made it clear that any package considered later would have to resemble a Democratic plan that the House rejected this month.

LEAD: A tender offer for bonds issued by the troubled First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc. failed yesterday to attract the number of securities needed to proceed with a complex $1.47 billion plan to rescue the banking company.

Duty on Court for Robinson
LEAD: An old field house has a certain smell to it, a sweet mustiness that settles in over the years and becomes as fixed as the collapsible wooden bleachers, the yellowed varnish on the floor and the small concesson stand that offers little more than pop and popcorn.

The answer is yes.

LEAD: Singapore will not cut the tax that employers pay for hiring foreign workers, despite demands by some members of Parliament to do so, Labor Minister Lee Yock Suan said today.

Review/Television; Family Life in a Welfare Hotel on 'The Equalizer'
LEAD: The plight of the homeless is not the most popular subject on prime-time entertainment.
Television normally prefers uplifting and inspirational situations.
One of the few television movies to cope with the homeless featured a feistily cute Lucille Ball as a bag lady.
Among the weekly series, the subject has been broached at least occasionally on ''Beauty and the Beast,'' which describes itself as a ''contemporary fable.


Women and Cooking
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Littlepage Dismissed
LEAD: After three seasons in which his teams won 23 games and lost 63, Craig Littlepage was dismissed yesterday as basketball coach at Rutgers.
Littlepage, who is 36 years old, moved to Rutgers in 1985 from Penn, his alma mater. ''We appreciate the special effort and commitment that Craig Littlepage has put into the Rutgers basketball program,'' said Fred Gruninger, the athletic director.


Doctors Urge Campaign Against AIDS Quackery
LEAD: Acknowledging a growing sense of urgency, top Federal health officials sought today to enroll health care professionals and educators in a stepped-up drive against medical fraud at a time when fear of AIDS is providing a rising number of prospective victims.


Review/Theater; 'Juan Darien,' a Tragic Story Told Without Talk
LEAD: In the distance on the deep St.
Clement's stage, there is a tiny church, and, as we watch, the church windows crumble and the building itself seems to disintegrate.
Suddenly, lush foliage descends until the stage becomes a jungle.
Strange serpentine creatures slither through the vines and leaves.
Lizards fly, accompanied by frenzied night sounds.

LEAD: Cuisine of the kind rarely found outside France's best restaurants will be on its way to the stars if three enterprising Frenchmen have their way: they plan to package fine food for space flights, long expeditions on Earth or just family outings.

Life in the 30's
LEAD: Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

In Britain, Tax Overhaul and a Feud
LEAD: Britain's annual Budget Day, always a time of suspense in the House of Commons, arrived today with an extra fillip of drama because of a feud between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her strong-willed Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson.


Meachem Clinging To His 'Future'
LEAD: The dream still has hold of Bobby Meacham.
It won't let go, not now, perhaps not ever.
In his mind's eye, Meacham can still see himself playing shortstop at Yankee Stadium, picking up every ground ball, making every throw, perfectly.
The picture doesn't seem to fade.
Eventually, it may disappear.
Meacham's hope - to be the Yankees' everyday shortstop - has already begun to slip away.

LEAD: First Nationwide Bank and the J. E. Robert Companies said they planned a new business of managing troubled savings institutions.

It means that the church recognizes the wealth within its own ranks, that it is a church of many significant minorities.

Mauch Has Bronchitis
LEAD: Manager Gene Mauch, who left California Angels training camp abruptly last week to undergo medical tests, has been diagnosed as suffering from a case of mild bronchitis, the club announced yesterday.
Mauch, 62 years old, was released from St.
Joseph's Hospital in Orange, Calif.

Jules Rasinski, the club physician, conducted the tests and prescribed medication for Mauch, who returned to his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

Review/Concert; Borodin Quartet at Tully
LEAD: The Borodin Quartet is one of the Soviet Union's pre-eminent chamber groups, and one of the world's more durable ones.
Founded in 1945, it boasts its original violist and cellist, and it hasn't had a personnel change since 1976.
It is an ensemble that plays with an appealing sweetness, and moves with a seemingly unshakeable unity of purpose.

LEAD: Greece will open its first embassy at the Vatican, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

Pope John Paul II met with Patriarch Dimitrios I in December.

''Vincent,'' Paul Cox's study of van Gogh's life and work, matches the intense surface of those self-portraits but contains little of their underlying power.

Mr.
Vorenberg, who lived in Cambridge, was president of Gilchrist's, one of Boston's oldest department stores.
His father, Felix Vorenberg, headed the store for many years.

LEAD: President Reagan, in an unusual appeal, urged South Africa today to grant clemency to six blacks convicted of complicity in a 1984 mob killing.

Donors Tell New York Panel Of Disguising Political Funds
LEAD: Contributors and solicitors for campaign funds in New York State yesterday painted a graphic and unusually detailed portrait of the tricks of the fund-raising trade that pay for the election of public officials.
They told a state integrity panel about officials begging for contributions, donors disguising their contributions and state aides soliciting campaign funds from people doing business with or regulated by the state.

LEAD: Charles Blitzer, head of the National Humanities Center in North Carolina for the last five years, was named today as director of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, one of the nation's top scholarly positions.

Mr.

He replaces James Caples Jr., who resigned.

LEAD: President Amin Gemayel has said Western powers are welcome to come and rescue any of their citizens held hostage in Lebanon.

LEAD: Bond prices continued to drift aimlessly in very light trading yesterday as market participants were forced to scramble to drum up business.

Study Shows Significant Decline in Ozone Layer
LEAD: Federal scientists reported today that atmospheric ozone over the Northern Hemisphere had declined significantly over the last two decades.

Corrections
LEAD: An article and a chart in some editions on March 5 about rates of unemployment and employment in New York State and New Jersey gave inconsistent figures for January and February.
The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics provides two kinds of figures: those adjusted for seasonal variations (shown in the chart), and those not adjusted for seasonal variations (cited in the article).

A Vanishing Way of Life: The Large American Family
LEAD: If there were a list of socially endangered species, large families would be among those at the top.
Only about 2 percent of American families with children under the age of 18 have five or more children at home, according to a 1986 census report.
In 1960, the figure was 8 percent.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-13, D26-27  An Iran-contra indictment accused John M. Poindexter, Oliver L. North and two other men of illegally providing the Nicaraguan rebels with profits from the sale of American weapons to Iran.

Review/Music; Javanese Puppetry and Song
LEAD: The World Music Institute, which presents concerts of everything from third-world exotica to jazz and blues, sponsored a four-hour performance of Javanese shadow puppet theater on Saturday evening at Washington Square Church.
For the occasion, the dhalang - puppetmaster, narrator and director - was Sumarsam, a master not only of his puppet arsenal, but also of conveying his art to listeners for whom its conventions are alien.


U.S. Weighs Rebellion's Effect on Noriega's Grip on Power
LEAD: Senior Administration officials said today that the coup attempt against Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega demonstrated deepening division within the Panamanian military, his principal base of support.
But the officials said they were uncertain whether the failed rebellion would weaken General Noriega's hold on power.


U.N. Asks Iran and Iraq To End 'War of Cities'
LEAD: The Security Council issued an informal statement today calling on Iran and Iraq to end the 16-day-old ''war of the cities.''


OPEC Decides Not to Meet on Prices
LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that it would not hold any extraordinary meetings to deal with the recent fall of oil prices, which has taken the average price to between $13 and $14 a barrel in the last few weeks.
Several oil producers outside OPEC, however, continued to meet in


ATOM LOBBY GAINS VICTORY IN SENATE
LEAD: In a victory for the nuclear lobby, the Senate today voted against imposing accountability for accidents on the contractors who operate the Government's nuclear research and weapons program.


Tennis Notebook; Davis Cup Coach Looks Down the Road
LEAD: Perhaps we can call this the Davis Cup version of ''Star Trek: The Next Generation.'' Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe may still have some good days left, and Ivan Lendl will eventually become a citizen of the United States, but Tom Gorman, the Davis Cup coach, was looking toward the future when he named Andre Agassi and Jay Berger to the team that will play in Peru


Pencil Promotion Scratched
LEAD: When the Allegan County Sheriff's Department submitted a $930 bill for 5,000 pencils bearing the sheriff's name, the county commissioners drew the line.
The pencils were to be distributed to students to promote the department's Youth Services Bureau, Sheriff Robert Schra said in explaining why he had submitted the bill as a school-safety expense.


Linoleum as Weapon
LEAD: To The Home Section:


Washington Talk: Briefing; Potted Plants Galore
LEAD: If the legal profession gave out Academy Awards, Brendan V. Sullivan, the lawyer who represented Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North at the Iran-contra hearings last summer, would certainly have received at least a nomination for his dramatic declaration, ''I am not a potted plant.''


Marilyn R. Menge, Lawyer, 31
LEAD: Marilyn R. Menge, vice president of the New York State Women's Bar Association, died of ovarian cancer Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center in Manhattan.
She was 31 years old and lived in Albany.


Big Baseball Pay Loss Noted
LEAD: Baseball players lost between $70 million and $90 million in salaries during 1986 and 1987 because of collusion by owners, according to a study commissioned by the Major League Baseball Players Association.


Koppers Turns Down Bid From Beazer and Shearson
LEAD: The Koppers Company yesterday rejected a $1.27 billion takeover bid from Beazer P.L.C. and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., saying the $45-a-share offer was inadequate.


New York Shifts a Primary
LEAD: Governor Cuomo signed legislation today that will allow New York's state primary elections to be held this year on Thursday, Sept. 15.
The state primary, not to be confused with New York's April 19 Presidential primary, had been scheduled for Tuesday, Sept. 13, but that is the Jewish holiday of Rosh ha-Shanah.


Frozen Food Unit For United Biscuit
LEAD: United Biscuits Holdings P.L.C., a leading cookie maker, which owns the Keebler Company of Elmhurst, Ill., agreed to buy a big British frozen foods business from Hanson TrustP.L.C. for $:335 million, or about $620 million.
Hanson, a conglomerate with holdings in Britain and the United States, bought the frozen foods company, Ross Young's, in 1986 when it took over Imperial Group P.L


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: SPRING thaws and rains often bring leaky basements with them.
Unfortunately, in early spring the ground may be too hard from freezing or too muddy to let you fix basement leaks the best way: by repairing the exterior of the foundation walls or by regrading the land near the house.
But several measures can be taken to remedy most problems so well that no further repairs will be necessary.


F.D.I.C. Faces a Texas-Size Drain
LEAD: The banking problems in the depressed Southwest have become so acute, banking experts say, that they could create the largest one-year drain in history on the Government agency that insures deposits at the nation's banks.


Garcia Accepted Bribes, Wedtech Judge Is Told
LEAD: Former executives of the Wedtech Corporation bribed Representative Robert Garcia, a prosecutor has told the judge in the Federal racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi.


Robins Merger Is Approved
LEAD: A Federal judge today approved the A. H. Robins Company's merger pact with the American Home Products Corporation after the companies agreed to put $100 million toward quick settlement of some Dalkon Shield claims.


Taiwan Gangster Convicted of Killing Writer
LEAD: A Taiwanese gangster who said he had killed a Chinese-American journalist on orders from Taiwan's Government was convicted of murder today.


Health; Personal Health
LEAD: Early this year, the National Cancer Institute canceled plans for a 10-year, $130 million study among 32,000 women to determine if the risk of breast cancer could be greatly reduced if women cut in half the amount of fat they eat.
With one in 10 women destined to get the disease, the possibility that a relatively simple dietary change could save lives initially seemed worth investigating.


Beach Resort Imports Sand
LEAD: A Texas beach will soon change color, from brown to white, with the help of Florida sand.
For years, people have complained about Galveston's murky water and brown, narrow beaches, said Ralph McPheeters, administrator of a development called Palm Beach at Moody Gardens. ''We can't do anything about the water, but we sure can do something about the sand,'' he said Tuesday.


K Mart's New Unit
LEAD: The K Mart Corporation, the big discount retailer, said it was forming a new business to sell office supplies and furniture, and business equipment in warehouse-type stores.
The venture marks K Mart's entry into the field.
The stores will compete with traditional office-supply houses and catalogue distributors in an industry that generates revenues of $108 billion a year.

LEAD: Pakistan suggested today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, could play a role in unblocking the Afghan peace talks when the two officials meet in Washington next week.

A Muted Trumpet
LEAD: ''In our adversary system of justice, any person haled into court who is too poor to hire a lawyer cannot be assured a fair trial unless counsel is provided for him. . . .
The right of one charged with crime to counsel may not be deemed fundamental and essential to fair trials in some countries, but it is in ours.


A South Korean Resigns His Opposition Post
LEAD: Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's best-known opposition leader, resigned today as president of his party in a last-minute bid to unite the nation's bitterly divided opposition before legislative elections next month.

Police Chief's Yard Yields a Body and a Puzzle
LEAD: A body unearthed in the police chief's front yard after three days of digging has been identified as that of his wife's former husband, who disappeared nine years ago.


Suspects Arraigned in Police Officer Slaying
LEAD: Philip Copeland, far right, 22 years old, appearing in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday to be arraigned in the execution-style slaying of Edward Byrne, a rookie New York City police officer, Feb. 26.
The three others charged were Todd Scott, 19, Scott Cobb, 24, and David McClary, 22.
The defendants pleaded not guilty in separate and brief court appearances before Justice Allen Beldock.


Citibank to Phase Out Policy Against Liberal Arts Majors
LEAD: Citibank said today that it would abandon a policy that denied credit cards to some liberal arts majors after students at the University of California at Berkeley demanded the bank's representatives be barred from campus because of the policy.


Drawn-Out Legal Battle Is Predicted in Iran Trial
LEAD: The 23-count indictment today against four defendants in the Iran-contra affair aims some of the standard weapons in the arsenal of Federal prosecutors at high-level officials who say they were lawfully carrying out President Reagan's national security policies.


First Interstate
LEAD: First Interstate Bancorp is offering $100 million of 8.65 percent subordinated notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.85, to yield 8.687 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The five-year notes, which are noncallable for the first three years, are priced to yield about 87-hundredths of a percentage more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.


Yields Move A Bit Lower
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly lower for the week ended yesterday, continuing a downward pattern in recent weeks.


Racial Remark Creates a Furor; Ouster Is Sought
LEAD: A high-ranking official in the Education Department has become the focus of controversy after a newspaper quoted him as saying that the student bodies of black colleges may ''contain a high level of thieves.''


Review/Jazz; Some Elders Offer 'Salute to Dick Hyman'
LEAD: The eight musicians who played for a ''Salute to Dick Hyman'' at last Thursday's ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert at the Loeb Auditorium of New York University brought an unusual amount of warmth and affection to this 14th salute to a living jazz musician that has been organized by the impresario Jack Kleinsinger over the past 15 years.


Washington Talk: The Supreme Court; Anti-Abortion Aid Stirs Church-State Questions
LEAD: Posing as a frightened and pregnant teen-ager, a 24-year-old banker walked into the Pregnancy Distress Center in Columbus, Ohio, six weeks ago and asked for advice.
She was leaning toward having an abortion, she said, but first she wanted to make sure she understood her other options.

The Wearing of the Black
LEAD: What should be a day of joy for the Irish, of all nationalities, turns instead into a day of mourning for the victims of yesterday's attack in a Belfast graveyard.
The mourning extends to lost hopes of reconciliation in Northern Ireland: wake follows wake, coffin follows coffin, tears follow tears, in a cycle that defeats reason and obliterates decency on both sides - Northern Ireland's Protestant majority and the

LEAD: Under attack at the polls, in criminal court and in the State Senate, Evan Mecham took the stand here today to defend himself in the first impeachment trial of a governor in almost 60 years.


Army Tuition Aid Drying Up Under Budget Cuts
LEAD: Army bases around the country are running out of tuition assistance funds for soldiers because of a $30 million cut in the Army's education budget, according to college groups.

LEAD: Two years ago, Mayor W. Wilson Goode won widespread applause when he broke an unpopular 20-day strike by a union so powerful, in the view of many Philadelphians, that it actually ran the city sanitation department - and none too well, at that.

Tax Returns Aren't Speed Trials
LEAD: The Reagan Administration deserves heaps of credit for its war on red tape.
The Office of Management and Budget estimates it has sliced away 560 million hours that people used to spend filling out Federal forms each year.
But stopwatch efficiency can go too far.
Now the tape-cutters want every Federal tax form to carry an estimate of how long the ''average taxpayer'' should spend filling it out.


Ohio State Wins in N.I.T.
LEAD: Perry Carter scored 25 points and had 10 rebounds last night as Ohio State defeated Old Dominion, 86-73, in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

LEAD: Barbara Conrad, a mezzo-soprano who has sung with the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera, made her formal recital debut Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall, offering a program that explored some unusual corners of the art-song tradition.

HERS
LEAD: ON April 15, 1964, a fat envelope from Mount Holyoke College arrived at my house telling me that I had been admitted to the class of '68.
I was in heaven.
I had wanted to attend a Seven Sisters school since I was 13 years old.


Review/Music; Reggae by Sugar Minott
LEAD: Sugar Minott, the Jamaican singer, blew into S.O.B.'s last Thursday like a three-day hurricane.
Leading his tough working band, one of those rare groups that sounds like its members play together regularly, are paid well and like each other, Mr.
Minott tore the place up.


Westchester Begins Playland Inquiry
LEAD: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke ordered an inquiry into the operations of the county-owned Playland Amusement Park today amid charges of ''mismanagement and improprieties'' touching his administration.

C. B. King, 64, Is Dead; Rights Lawyer in South
LEAD: C. B. King, a lawyer from Albany, Ga., who was prominent in the Southern civil rights struggles in the early 1960's, died of prostate cancer Tuesday while traveling in California.
He was 64 years old.


Commuters, Arise
LEAD: To the Editor:


Colombia Convoy Ambushed
LEAD: Eight soldiers and a civilian were killed and 13 people were wounded on Tuesday during an ambush by left-wing guerrillas in the northern part of the country, a spokesman for the military said today.
In the Atlantic province of Cordoba, Alfonso Cujavanta, the regional leader of the leftist Patrotic Union, became the first newly elected official to be assassinated.


Sports People; Funds for School Meet
LEAD: The national scholastic indoor track and field championships, whose existence was threatened earlier this month by insufficient funding, has received a flood of last-minute contributions to the Metropolitan Athletics Congress.
The M.A.C., the organizer and developer of the meet, has generated more than $3 million in college scholarships since its inception in 1984.


A Senate Leader, Indicted, Perseveres
LEAD: Six months after he was indicted on charges of using public funds to finance partisan election campaigns, the State Senate's Democratic leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, speaks in two distinct voices.


NORTH, POINDEXTER AND 2 OTHERS INDICTED ON IRAN-CONTRA FRAUD AND THEFT CHARGES
LEAD: Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North, Rear Adm.
John M. Poindexter and two other key participants in the Iran-contra affair were indicted today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States by illegally providing the Nicaraguan rebels with profits from the sale of American weapons to Iran.


Correction Officers Complain Rikers Riot Was Mishandled
LEAD: The head of the correction officers' union charged yesterday that a riot on Rikers Island last month that extensively damaged the jail was mishandled by the Correction Department.


Review/Film; 'Bell Diamond,' Beyond the Mines
LEAD: Jon Jost's ''Bell Diamond'' is about the seven-year marriage of Jeff, a Vietnam veteran, and Cathy, who live in Butte, Mont., in a house that is enviably full of waste space and seems to have been furnished with knickknacks won at a carnival.


Review/Saxophone; Steve Lacy, A Jazz Expatriate
LEAD: Steve Lacy, the expatriate soprano saxophonist who lives in Paris, usually plays with American jazz musicians when he visits New York.
But through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, he is working with his longtime Paris-based sextet.
Its music is as eccentric and cluttered as a much-used messy desk - or, perhaps, an imaginary Cubist collage of sheet music, saxophone mouthpieces, a book of poetry, toys, cabaret ticket stubs and stamps from North


Bush vs. Dole: Behind the Turnaround
LEAD: History is written by the victors, and that is true even of political campaigns not yet concluded.
In retrospect, the winning side's decisions invariably appear brilliant, and losers almost always look foolish.


'Cosi' Mystery at Met
LEAD: Hei-Kyung Hong, a young South Korean soprano who is quickly becoming one of the most sought-after singers on the operatic scene, was pulled out of the opening-night cast of ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera last week, in an incident that has set the corridors buzzing with gossip about prima-donna jealousy.


Tennstedt Cancels Concerts
LEAD: The conductor Klaus Tennstedt has canceled his remaining series of performances with the New York Philharmonic because of an injury to his arm in a fall, the orchestra has announced.
Felix Kruglikov will conduct in his place.
The performances are tonight, tomorrow and Saturday at 8, and Tuesday at 7:30.


Worries Over Computer as a Grant-Making Tool
LEAD: A proposal by the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts that would emphasize greater use of computerized data in determining grants to nonprofit arts groups has provoked concern among arts administrators around the country.


On at Least One Thing, the Democratic Candidates Can Agree: It's Wide Open Now
LEAD: The Democratic Presidential race, clouded before the Illinois primary Tuesday, looked even murkier today as the candidates moved their campaigns into Kansas, Michigan, Wisconsin and other states that vote in the next month.


3 Killed by Grenades at Belfast Funeral
LEAD: Three people were killed and dozens wounded today as an assailant threw grenades into a screaming crowd at a funeral and then fled across the graveyard from enraged mourners.


Industrial Production Rises 0.2%
LEAD: The nation's industrial production edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in February as reductions in output at auto factories and coal mines offset gains in other areas.


Koch, Seeing Error, Puts Ex-Rights Chief on Women's Panel
LEAD: Mayor Koch, conceding that he mishandled the resignation of Dr.
Marcella Maxwell as head of the New York City Human Rights Commission, has named her to head his Commission on the Status of Women - the same job she held before taking over the rights panel four years ago.


First Republicbank in Bailout Talks
LEAD: Officers of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation met with executives of the First Republicbank Corporation today to prepare a temporary bailout intended to stanch a growing run on the bank company's deposits, officials close to the talks said.


Ortega Denies That His Troops Crossed Into Honduras
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today rejected Reagan Administration charges that Nicaraguan forces are fighting inside Honduras, and he invited foreign observers to visit the border area to verify his statement.

LEAD: Jacques Tiffeau, the French-born fashion designer who rose to the top on Seventh Avenue in the 1960's, died of lung cancer on Feb. 29 in Paris.
He was 59 years old.

LEAD: Morton Thiokol Inc. has been fined $31,700 for six violations of state health and safety rules after an investigation of a fire that destroyed an MX missile assembly building and killed five workers, officials said today.

Chemical's Name
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation wants to change its name to the Chemical Banking Corporation at the April 26 shareholders meeting, a bank spokesman said. ''We want to change the name to reflect our geographic diversification following our merger with Texas Commerce Bancshares and the planned merger in January 1989 with Horizon Bancorp in New Jersey,'' he said.


New York Assembly Stiffens Rules On Legislative Employees' Hours
LEAD: In a move that he said would ''enhance the accountability'' of the State Assembly, the Speaker, Mel Miller, announced today that Assembly employees must now record the hours they spend each week working on legislative business.


U.S. Gives Japan Deadline In Dispute on Construction
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today set a two-week deadline for Japan to resolve the conflict over opening its construction market to American companies, a White House official reported.
If Japan fails to offer a ''satisfactory solution'' to the dispute, the official said, it will face American retaliation.


Review/Rock; Marti Jones's Soulful Voice
LEAD: Marti Jones's show at the Bottom Line on Friday was full of lost possibilities.
She's a startlingly immediate singer; her voice, windowpane clear, can take the most trivial ''I . . . you'' (love/hate, see/didn't see) songwriting conceit and charge it with the sort of larger meaning that can spring from a small, tactile description.


A 'Virus' Gives Business a Chill
LEAD: For the first time in the United States, a computer program that can secretly spread from computer to computer and potentially destroy stored data has compromised a major commercial personal computer software product.


Review/Television; Putting Marianne Moore in Perspective
LEAD: Marianne Moore (1887-1972) is probably remembered by too many people as the slightly eccentric old poet who lived in Brooklyn, dressed dramatically, loved baseball and visited the ''Today'' show to be interviewed by Joe Garagiola.
Tonight's edition of ''Voices and Visions'' on Channel 13 - shunted to midnight because of pledge-week festivities -does indeed touch on those aspects of the woman John Ashbery once called ''the Mary Poppins of poetry.


Israel Cuts Phone Lines to Arabs; 4 More Are Slain
LEAD: Israel severed international telephone links to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today in what the authorities described as a new effort to put pressure on the organization of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.


Panama Turmoil Helps Lift Prices of Energy Contracts
LEAD: The prices of energy futures contracts rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, responding to a drop in oil inventories and to turmoil in Central America.


Contra Bases Called Target Of Managua
LEAD: The Nicaraguan attack along the Honduran border appears primarily aimed at rebel supply bases in Honduras that support anti-Government operations in northern Nicaragua, according to United States military officials.

LEAD: The mood was enthusiastic this week at the enormous McCormk k Place exhibition halls here, as more than 1,200 suppliers of home improvement products for the amateur displayed their wares to about 36,000 store buyers at the National Home Center Show.
