Publication Is Advanced On Donald Regan Book
LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich said this week that it had advanced from September to May the publication date of ''For the Record: From Wall Street to Washington'' by Donald T. Regan, former White House chief of staff.


Ward Orders Some College For Top Ranks
LEAD: The New York City Police Commissioner announced yesterday that members of the force seeking promotion to the rank of sergeant, lieutenant or captain would have to complete two to four years of college.


Market Place; Pension Funds May Sell Stocks
LEAD: AS the first quarter winds down, money managers are spending some of their cash to ''dress up'' clients' portfolios.
Fearful of losing pension fund accounts, these managers want to show more stocks in their portfolios during this rising market.


Takeover Law In Ohio Upheld
LEAD: A Federal judge rejected a claim by an Italian tire maker that Ohio's anti-takeover law is unconsitutional.


Military in Panama Is Accused of Abuses
LEAD: Panama's security forces tortured, beat and arrested people who peacefully protested the rule of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, killing one man who shouted ''Down with Noriega!'' in public, Amnesty International said today.


Linoleum Nostalgia
LEAD: To The Home Section:


Gentle, Slow-Moving Car That Goes Moo
LEAD: MOVE over, Detroit. Delaware's own


Orrin Frink, Mathematician, 86
LEAD: Orrin Frink, a mathematician who taught for 41 years at Pennsylvania State University and was chairman of the university's mathematics department from 1949 to 1960, died March 4 at his home in Kennebunkport, Me.
He was 86 years old.


Gertrude Hill, Training Director, 58
LEAD: Gertrude Hill, director of training for the New York City Department for the Aging, died of a heart attack Saturday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan.
She was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 17, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


Housing, the Koch-LeFrak Way
LEAD: A quarter-century ago, New York City acquired a splendid housing site on Grand Street on the Lower East Side.
Ever since, its fate has been buffeted by arguments about which race and what income group might live there, and by changes in housing laws - and the site has remained untouched.
Finally, Mayor Koch has persuaded Samuel LeFrak, the builder, to produce housing there.


Chevron, Koreans In Joint Venture
LEAD: Chevron U.S.A.
Inc., the domestic operating company of the Chevron Corporation, said it had agreed to conduct a joint-venture oil exploration and development program with the Lucky-Goldstar International Corporation of Seoul, South Korea.
Lucky-Goldstar will make an initial investment of about $20 million in the venture, which will begin drilling immediately at 10 onshore and offshore well sites in California, Oklahoma, Texas and the Gulf of


E.P.A. Rejects Doing a Cancer Study of Herbicide
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency says it will not conduct a special study of a widely used herbicide suspected of causing cancer among farmers because other research has not confirmed the suspicion.


Advertising; Denny's New Owner Dismisses Foote, Cone
LEAD: TW Services Inc., the new owner of the Denny's restaurant chain, has dismissed Foote, Cone &amp; Belding, Los Angeles, from the account after a 10-year relationship, and also let go Western International Media, which had been doing the media buying.


Review/Dance; Phoebe Neville
LEAD: Phoebe Neville presented two types of dances Sunday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.
There were fine examples of the exquisitely crafted pieces for small casts for which she is best known.
But there was also an ensemble work for all 11 members of the Phoebe Neville Dance Company.


Housing Starts and Permits Are Up
LEAD: Builders broke ground for new homes at an annual rate of 1,494,000 in February, an 8.9 percent increase that followed two straight declines, the Commerce Department reported today.


Maurice Linder Dies; Insurance Agent, 93
LEAD: Maurice Linder, an insurance agent for 45 years and the oldest living member of the industry's ''Million Dollar Round Table,'' died of heart failure Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla.
He was 93 years old and lived in Palm Beach.


Dollar Strengthens Slightly; Gold Edges Lower in U.S.
LEAD: The dollar strengthened slightly against most major currencies yesterday, but traders remained cautious in advance of today's release of new trade data.


Wickes Negotiates Hosiery Unit Sale
LEAD: The Wickes Companies said it was negotiating to sell the Kayser-Roth Hosiery Group to members of the unit's management and the Narragansett Capital Corporation of Providence, R.I.
The hosiery unit, based in Greensboro, N.C., is one of the world's leading manufacturers of men's and women's hosiery, including such brands as No Nonsense, Liz Claiborne, Calvin Klein, Burlington and Supp-Hose.


Waldheim Was No Mere Clerk or Bystander
LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Jan. 22 about negotiations to sell The New York Post described the newspaper's longevity claim incorrectly.
The Post was founded in 1801 and considers itself the oldest newspaper in the United States published continuously as a daily.
The Hartford Courant, which began as a weekly in 1764, considers itself the oldest continuously published newspaper.


N.F.L. Extends Instant Replay
LEAD: Instant replay will remain another year to tantalize and taunt National Football League fans.


Women's N.C.A.A.; St. John's Advances With 83-70 Victory
LEAD: In their first trip along the route of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament, the St.
John's Express eliminated Fairfield, 83-70, last night at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.


Review/Film; A Pious Hasid in the Hell of Pigalle
LEAD: The notion must have seemed like a laugh riot: take a pure and pious Hasid and plop him onto the streets of Pigalle in the company of drug pushers, hookers and transvestites.
Well, we've all seen worse; the problem here is that the heavy hand of Gerard Oury, who directed and collaborated on the script for ''Levy and Goliath,'' knocks over credibility some time before Levy knocks over


Lag Cited in Small-Business Growth
LEAD: Unlike the rest of the nation, where most new jobs have been created by small businesses, New York City's small employers have made ''a steep cutback'' in the rate of expansion, according to a government study released yesterday.


Democrats Complain They Weren't Told
LEAD: Democrats in Congress said tonight that they had not been told of the decision to send United States troops to Honduras and had learned of it only when they were asked about it by reporters at a Democratic fund-raising event.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. In cold weather the glass and the aluminum frames of our skylights sweat so much that moisture accumulates and runs down off the low end.
This water is damaging the drywall.
Is there a cure?
A.
Apparently the skylights do not have double-pane insulating glass, and the aluminum frames do not have thermal barriers.


Tandy to Buy Grid Systems
LEAD: The Tandy Corporation said today that it would acquire the closely held Grid Systems Corporation, a manufacturer of laptop personal computers based in Fremont, Calif.


Surprise: Yankee Pitching Is Thriving
LEAD: If pitching was a concern when the Yankees opened their training camp four weeks ago, it is less so today.
Rick Rhoden, who will be their starting pitcher on opening day, threw six innings today against the Texas Rangers without allowing a run and extended the staff's string of scoreless innings to 21.


Aide Accuses Top Doctor of Plagiarism
LEAD: Sharply conflicting testimony in a Federal trial yesterday focused on the accusation that a prominent physician had plagiarized a medical article written by a junior colleague.


Chicago Journal; In Bits and Pieces, This Is Their Vietnam
LEAD: Joe Hertel used to keep Vietnam in his basement, hidden away in boxes and footlockers filled with old photographs and other war souvenirs.
Sometimes he would show the ragged collection to other veterans, and it would bring back memories both sweet and sad.


CARLUCCI CONFERS WITH SOVIET AIDE
LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci met for 10 hours today with the Soviet Defense Minister, Gen.
Dmitri T. Yazov.
American officials said the talks produced no specific agreements but opened the way for an expanded military discussion between the superpowers.

Income Up 8% At May Stores
LEAD: The May Department Stores Company, one of the nation's largest retailers, said it had an 8 percent rise in net income in the fourth quarter, to $230 million, or $1.52 a share, from $213 million, or $1.38 a share, in the period a year earlier.
Revenues held steady at $3.37 billion.
For the fiscal year ended


Scripps to Sell Stock to Public
LEAD: The E. W. Scripps Company, the privately held parent corporation of the Scripps Howard Media Group, said this week that it plans to sell some of its limited-voting common stock to the public.


Judge Backs Settlement In State Farm Bias Case
LEAD: A Federal judge has approved a settlement of a sex discrimination suit brought against the State Farm Insurance Company, which will now have to pay as much as $420,000 apiece to women who were denied jobs as insurance agents in California.

Lawrence Turcic, 38, Met Museum Curator
LEAD: Lawrence Turcic, assistant curator in the drawings department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York.
He was 38 years old.

Duo Recital at Weill
LEAD: The cellist Anner Bylsma and the fortepianist Malcolm Bilson, two highly regarded performers on authentic instruments, will play a duo recital tonight at 8 at Weill Recital Hall, in Carnegie Hall.
Each of the players will be featured in solo works - Mr.
Bylsma in a Bach sonata, Mr.
Bilson in a sonata by Schubert - and they will collaborate on two Beethoven Sonatas for Piano and Cello (Op.


Review/Film; 'Beatrice,' Medieval Tale by Tavernier
LEAD: Bertrand Tavernier lays on plenty of medieval lifestyle in ''Beatrice,'' possibly in an effort to distract us from its Gothic plot, compliments of Krafft-Ebing.
The de Cortemare castle seems to have been decorated by the same firm that did the Majestic Theater - cold stone relieved by a swatch or two of material.


Treasury Bonds and Notes Regain Ground
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose yesterday, recouping virtually all the losses sustained in the previous trading session.


Review/Film; 'Stars and Bars,' U.S. As Land of the Odd
LEAD: Toward the middle of ''Stars and Bars,'' Henderson Dores (Daniel Day-Lewis), a New York art-auction-house representative, arrives in Atlanta to register at one of those multi-story theme parks that are now the fashion in hotels in this country.
The room clerk, smiling, gives Henderson his key and says, ''Follow the path through the atrium, then take the scenic elevator to the 35th floor.


Cruise Ship Plans Refunds
LEAD: Passengers of the fire-crippled cruise ship Scandinavian Star, under tow to Cancun on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula today, will receive refunds and tickets for another Mexican cruise, a company spokeswoman said.
Jill DeChello of the Miami-based SeaEscape Ltd., which runs the Star, said the passengers would be reimbursed their fares, which range from $179 to $499 fares, and get a free cruise.


Senate Delays Override Effort
LEAD: The Senate today scheduled for Tuesday a vote on President Reagan's veto of a civil rights bill.


Boogie-Woogie Band
LEAD: Sammy Price, a pianist, will lead a boogie-woogie band tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260).
Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., along with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.


Bilzerian Looks At SSMC Sale
LEAD: The Florida corporate raider Paul A. Bilzerian, who took over the Singer Company earlier this year, said today that he might seek a buyer for SSMC Inc., the sewing machine company spun off from Singer two years ago.

Count Basie Orchestra
LEAD: The Count Basie Orchestra will play music for dancing, presented by the New York Swing Society, on Sunday at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090).
Doors open at 7 P.M.; tickets are $25.


Editor Joins Revlon Unit
LEAD: Andrea Robinson, beauty editor of Vogue magazine for eight years, has resigned to become president of Ultima II, a division of Revlon Inc.
Ultima II markets cosmetics treatment products and fragrances.
Ms.
Robinson will report to Robert A. Neilson, chairman and president of Revlon's fashion and designer group.


HOUSE PANEL BACKS $1 TRILLION BUDGET
LEAD: The House Budget Committee today approved a $1.1 trillion Federal budget for the fiscal year 1989 that generally follows the budget accord reached with President Reagan but raised some of his domestic spending proposals while reducing others.


Interest in Koppers
LEAD: The Koppers Company, the building products concern that has rejected a $1.27 billion bid from Beazer P.L.C. of Britain, said others were interested in buying all or part of it.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Koppers said it had held no talks with the third parties, but might do so.


Oil Surges in Late Trading On Reports OPEC Will Act
LEAD: Prices of oil futures moved sharply higher in late trading yesterday, largely in response to reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would take steps next week to bolster prices.

The Risk of the Recalcitrant Surrogate Mother; Brecht and Solomon
LEAD: To the Editor:


TWO U.S. SENATORS ENDORSE DUKAKIS
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis came to Washington today to pick up the endorsements of two Senators and to court some others, signifying a new phase of the race for the Democratic nomination marked by intense competition for the backing of party leaders.


Japanese Riding Hawaii's Real Estate Boom
LEAD: Real estate brokers here tell stories about Genshiro Kawamoto, a 55-year-old Tokyo billionaire who in recent months has cruised Honolulu's better residential neighborhoods in a black limousine.
Every so often he pointed to a house he wanted to buy.


At the Border, Nicaraguan Says Raid Is Over
LEAD: Sandinista troops have called off a major military offensive along the northern border with Honduras after overrunning a series of contra guerrilla bases, according to local commanders.

Managers' Group Bids for Air Wis
LEAD: A company led by senior managers of Air Wis Services Inc. said it had offered to acquire the airline holding company for about $103.6 million in cash and bonds.
The company's subsidiary, Air Wisconsin Inc., is the nation's largest regional air carrier, flying under the name United Express and providing feeder traffic from East Coast cities for connections to United


Tuna Importers Told To Cut Dolphin Deaths
LEAD: A Federal agency today ordered foreign nations that export tuna to the United States to reduce the number of dolphins killed in fishing.


Review/Theater; 'Great Hunger,' a Dearth of Words
LEAD: ''The Great Hunger,'' Tom MacIntyre's adaptation of Patrick Kavanagh's poem, has been controversial both in Ireland and on its world tour - for a reason that is self-evident.
The play seems to contradict the founding principles of the Abbey Theater as a home for the eloquence of such writers as Yeats, Synge and O'Casey.


Lilco Inquiry By Giuliani Is Reported
LEAD: Two Suffolk County officials said today that United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani has for the last four months been investigating criminal allegations that the Long Island Lighting Company has repeatedly lied to regulatory commissions and filed false documents with the panels.


Soviet Pledges Independent Pullout From Afghanistan
LEAD: A Soviet spokesman said today that the Soviet Union would withdraw its troops from Afghanistan independently, even if negotiators in Geneva fail to agree on conditions for ending the war.

Asset Sales Sought For Media General
LEAD: Burt Sugarman, the chairman of Barris Industries and Giant Group Ltd., disclosed today that he had held talks with several Media General Inc. shareholders in an attempt to find potential purchasers of the assets of the communications concern based in Richmond.


2 Azerbaijani Officials Dismissed Over Rioting
LEAD: The Communist Party chief of the Azerbaijani city of Sumgait, where at least 32 people were killed in attacks against Armenians last month, has been dismissed for ''major shortcomings'' in his work, officials said today.

Tucson Open seeking to exempt Mary Bea Porter from qualifying for next week's Standard Register Turquoise Classic in Phoenix, an L.P.G.A. spokeswoman said.

Top Basketball Honors
LEAD: Danny Manning of Kansas and sue Wicks of Rutgers were named the winners of the Naismith Trophy Yesterday as the top college basketball players of the year.


I.R.A. Man Buried, in Peaceful Rites
LEAD: A fresh grave was dug this morning at Milltown Cemetery, and another Irish Republican Army insurgent was interred, this time in peace.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 18, 1988
LEAD: COMPANIES  Federal regulators will provide $1 billion in cash to First Republicbank's subsidiary banks in an effort to stop a huge outflow of deposits and a widespread loss of confidence in Texas's largest banking company.
The F.D.I.C. said it would guarantee all deposits, of any amount, in the company's 73 banking subsidiaries.


Candidates Clash Over Troops Move
LEAD: Four Democratic Presidential contenders clashed long-distance with a Republican candidate yesterday over the dispatching of United States troops to Central America.

Pillsbury's Pizza Unit To Be Sold
LEAD: Seeking to fend off a possible takeover, the Pillsbury Company announced several restructuring moves late today, including plans to sell its Godfather's Pizza chain.


Ms. Magazine Is Changing Hands Again
LEAD: Ms. magazine, which has been more successful as a philosophical statement than as a commercial venture, is changing hands for the second time in six months.
A group of executives is negotiating to buy Ms. and another publication, Sassy, from the Australian publishing concern that purchased Ms. in September.


Study Warns of Inadequate Housing
LEAD: The number of Americans who cannot afford adequate housing has risen sharply in the 1980's, a Harvard University study released today concluded.


The Law; At the Bar
LEAD: Like millions of people in his generation, Isaac Shapiro can vividly recall that moment on Dec. 8, 1941, when he heard Pearl Harbor had been bombed.
He was a 10-year-old on his way to school, and clusters of apprehensive men clogged the streets of his hometown. ''The war with America has started,'' one told him.


LaRouche Lawyers Introduce Three Kissinger-F.B.I. Letters
LEAD: Lawyers for Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. introduced today three letters between Henry A. Kissinger and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and said they were evidence of a Government effort to harass Mr.
LaRouche.


Ruder Sees Disagreement on Market Curbs
LEAD: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today that talks between the exchanges and regulators have yet to produce sufficient agreement on new measures -including coordinated trading halts, price limits and other ''circuit breakers'' - to prevent another collapse of the stock market.

Ruling Is Issued Against Shaving Convict's Beard
LEAD: New York State prison authorities were barred yesterday from shaving the beard of an Orthodox Jewish inmate by a state judge in Brooklyn.


Bork Signs to Write Book on American Law
LEAD: Robert H. Bork, whose nomination to the Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate last fall, has signed with the Free Press, a division of Macmillan, to write a book tentatively titled ''Dissenting Opinion.'' Publication is planned for the spring of 1989.


Lectures in Gaelic
LEAD: An afternoon of Irish language and song is planned tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the American Irish Historical Society, 991 Fifth Avenue, at 80th Street.
Two lectures, given in Gaelic, will cover the topics ''The Short Story'' and ''An Analysis of Irish Government Attempts to Develop an International Financial Services Center in Dublin''; English translations will be available.


Review/Music; Giordano's 'Chenier' In Concert
LEAD: Giordano's ''Andrea Chenier'' is not likely to return anytime soon to its status as a beloved potboiler in the standard repertory.
The plausible candidates for its leading roles are just too few, and verismo opera does not thrive in unidiomatic performances.
But it is not a good idea to give up hope; just a few years ago, it seemed as though there were not one single international-class soprano who was vocally and temperamentally right for Maddalena de Coigny, and now there is at least one, as Aprile Millo showed in a Carnegie Hall concert performance on


Di Giorgio Stake
LEAD: An investment group led by the Belzberg family of Canada holds a 6 percent stake in the Di Giorgio Corporation and said it might seek control of the San Francisco-based manufacturer and distributor of food products.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Fril Trading Inc., a West Indies investment concern controlled by the Belzbergs, said it had purchased its stake at an average price of $20.91 a share.


New Security Is Proposed
LEAD: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it was asking the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve trading in a new product called Cash Index Participation contracts.
The exchange said the so-called C.I.P.'s would allow investors to buy or sell an index of stocks in the same way they trade individual shares of stock.


Rushing to React in Honduras
LEAD: If Nicaragua were intent on occupying Honduran territory, that might justify President Reagan's dispatch of 3,200 U.S. troops to support an aggrieved ally.
Yesterday's truculent declarations from President Daniel Ortega suggest, again, that Managua knows how to snatch defeat from the jaws of political victory.


Review/Art; David Salle and Rafael Ferrer: In Mainstream and Out
LEAD: David Salle's paintings (at the Mary Boone/Michael Werner Gallery) are still naughty, sly, cool.
They are less busy, less layered with images.
Everything seems slow, displaced, almost under water.
Objects and women appear to be waiting, preparing, making themselves available.
The sources of the appropriated, vaguely familiar images are more obscure.


Topeka Journal; A Club Where Egos Are Kept Small
LEAD: No one knows exactly why the founders formed the Saturday Night Literary Club, one of Topeka's most venerable organizations.
For the last century the Literary Club's members have met to hear, politely, one member read an original essay, then to criticize it and its author, sometimes politely.

LEAD:  Hearty Peasant Fare


Campeau Bid Ruling By S.E.C.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission advised a Federal district judge yesterday that the Campeau Corporation's revised tender offer for Federated Department Stores Inc. need not be delayed because it is an amended bid rather than a new one.

Southdown Sues
LEAD: Southdown Inc., the Houston cement maker that has offered $420 million for Moore McCormack ResourcesInc. of Stamford, Conn., said it had sued Moore McCormack's directors over an anti-takeover provision and a possible recapitalization.
Earlier this week, Moore McCormack, which also produces cement, said it was considering a financial restructuring or recapitalization that could mean paying a substantial cash dividend to its shareholders to maximize the value of its stock and avoid being acquired by Southdown.


U.S. Says Saudis Are Buying Missiles From China
LEAD: Saudi Arabia is buying Chinese-made intermediate-range missiles, capable of hitting targets across much of the Middle East, the State Department said today.
The missiles are similar to ones in the arsenal of Iran.

LEAD: Two very different made-for-television productions are being offered this Sunday, both at 9 P.M.
NBC is presenting still another revival of ''Inherit the Wind,'' the sturdy warhorse that's trotted out every few years to give actors of a certain age a chance to show off.
This time the stars are Jason Robards and Kirk Douglas.

LEAD: ''The Milagro Beanfield War,'' Robert Redford's first film as a director since ''Ordinary People,'' is a populist fable set in some beautiful New Mexican landscapes about one stubborn Chicano's battle against an uncaring system.
It's as full of good intentions as a campaign to get out the vote.


New York Gets Its Irish Up (Again)
LEAD: Bagpipes skirled, marchers stepped smartly and politicians did what they do best as the Irish and the Irish-for-a-day celebrated St.
Patrick's Day.
Mayor Koch, in an Irish sweater, chatted with John Cardinal O'Connor as, for the 227th time, a grand parade marked the city's annual enchantment with the patron saint of a foreign land.

He was 81 years old.

And it even seems to work. c The 11,000-square-foot courtroom and chambers in a former public high school auditorium were planned as a great leap forward from the 19th-century model to state-of-the-art courtroom design and trial management, with computer data bases and instant retrieval of information, laser disk document storage and electronic rep

LEAD: Puerto Rico's voters will decide Sunday whether the Democratic Party will stay in the control of statehood advocates or be turned over to those who want the island to remain a United States commonwealth.

Gino is a hard-working medical student, and his education is being paid for by Nicky, who is proud of being able to provide for his slightly younger brother.

LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 82.4 percent of capacity in February, the third consecutive month at that level, the Federal Reserve reported today.

The Deaf Are Heard
LEAD: At first, nobody listened.
Students at Gallaudet University, the nation's only college for the deaf, said the new president should be someone hearing-impaired.
The trustees passed over two deaf finalists and picked Elisabeth Ann Zinser, an educator of unquestioned ability who, in the students' eyes, was doubly handicapped: her hearing is fine and she doesn't know sign language.


A Spirited Lacroix and the Serious Japanese
LEAD: Christian Lacroix, the designer who made couture clothes sizzle, has shown he can make relatively subdued styles as well as fanciful, exhuberant ones.
Both types were represented in his first extensive ready-to-wear collection.
It was presented in a courtyard tent at the Louvre late Wednesday afternoon, the first day of the fall and winter fashion openings.


British Cut Interest Rates To Halt Advance by Pound
LEAD: The British Government cut interest rates today to halt the surge in the value of the pound, yielding to warnings from British companies and some Government officials that the currency's continuing advance was threatening to dent the nation's exports.


Raucous Pop Songs To an International Beat
LEAD: THERE'S a great moment in the middle of ''Paid in Full,'' a slinky rap piece by Eric B. and Rakim, remixed and tarted up for dance clubs: Out of left field comes a woman's wailing voice, obviously Middle Eastern in its gentle, hilly melismas.
But her voice fits in perfectly, suggesting different cultures colliding and yet having fun.


Plane With 137 Aboard Crashes In Mountainous Part of Colombia
LEAD: A Colombian Avianca airliner with 137 people on board crashed today minutes after taking off on a domestic flight from the northeastern town of Cucuta near the Venezuelan border, the airline reported.
Officials said there was no immediate sign of survivors but at least one report said there were survivors.

LEAD: Silvia Luz Arana de Gills, a 29-year-old Argentine whose husband and two children are American citizens, will arrive in New York in six weeks.


Okinawan Folk Music
LEAD: Yukito Ara, a performer on the Okinawan shamisen, a variant form of the Japanese lute, will play a concert of folk music from Okinawa at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art,Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, Manhattan, on Sunday at 2 P.M.
Tickets are $10.
Information: (212) 206-1050.

LEAD: In the spirit of glasnost, many Americans welcome the idea of open relations with the Soviet Union - if the Russians match their words with deeds, according to a survey of 76,000 people in five cities.

LEAD: Fordham tonight continued what has become a wrenching basketball tradition.

LEAD: Coaches Ben Braun of Eastern Michigan and Steve Newton of Murray State are happy to be in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional, although they are quick to add that they don't plan to be doormats for their high-powered opponents in the first round Friday.

LEAD: When it met the other day, the Federal Election Commission did not act like the deliberative panel it is supposed to be.

Magee was one of five players in the field of 114 to birdie the 18th hole.
Bay Hill's 18th, a 456-yard par-4 slightly uphill with the green tucked against water on the right, is one of the 10 most difficult holes on the PGA Tour.

LEAD: For a movie that starts with voyeurism, advances to acute acne and concludes with a bout of necrophilia, ''Love Is a Dog From Hell'' is a remarkably innocent romance.
Dominique Deruddere, a 31-year-old Belgian director, found the idea for his first full-length feature in the stories of Charles Bukowski, an American writer with an underground reputation who did the screenplay for ''Barfly.


Pipeline Used for Alaskan Oil Shut by Blackout in Panama
LEAD: The 80-mile pipeline that carries Alaskan oil across Panama for shipment to Gulf Coast refineries in the United States was closed for a second day yesterday because a strike by utility workers caused a widespread electricity blackout.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration's decision to send more than 3,000 troops to Honduras is so far largely a symbolic gesture of support for Honduras after a Sandinista attack on contra bases along the border, according to diplomats in the region.


Haydn Opera
LEAD: The Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, near 122d Street and Broadway, Manhattan, will present a Haydn opera, ''La Fedelta Premiata'' (''Virtue Rewarded''), in an English translation by Marcie Stapp, tonight at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M.
The production is the American premiere of the work, and is directed by Lou Galtero, with choreography by Francis Patrelle.

LEAD: Hoping to protect a key selling point of its Macintosh, Apple Computer Inc. filed a copyright-infringement suit against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company.

Economic Scene; The Merger Rise: How Beneficial?
LEAD: CORPORATE America is becoming the acquisitive society par excellence, with everybody trying to acquire everybody else.
The current merger wave, briefly slowed by the shock of the stock market plunge on Oct. 19, is again climbing to record heights.
In just the first two months of this year, deals totaling nearly $50 billion were consummated - one-third more than in the corresponding period last year and double the value of deals in the first two months of 1986.

French 'Field of Honor'

The film will be shown in the New Directors/New Films festival at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 6 and on Sunday at 3:30 P.M.

British Jobless Rate Dips
LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 9.1 percent in February from 9.2 percent in January, the Government said today.
The figure stood at 11 percent in February 1987, the Department of Employment said.

LEAD: The nation's deficit in foreign trade widened slightly in January, to $12.4 billion, a $200 million increase over December's total.

Review/Art; The Hypnotic Canvases Of Robert Moskowitz
LEAD: ROBERT MOSKOWITZ works and reworks a narrow repertory of images, inventing through mysterious scenes of icebergs, howling dogs, crosses and skyscrapers a world in which distinctions blur between past and present, solid and ephemeral.
There is a hypnotic quality to these large-scale paintings and pastels, and they call forth elusive, subconscious emotions.


Toll of 2 Cancers Is Up Among Elderly
LEAD: A new study has found surprisingly sharp increases over 15 years in deaths from two uncommon types of cancer in elderly white Americans.
They are brain cancer and multiple myeloma, a marrow cancer that can painfully destroy bone.


Thiokol Says Workers Killed In Blaze Had Ignored Rules
LEAD: Morton Thiokol officials said today that five employees killed in a fire while fueling an MX missile motor had ignored company rules and entered the building during a phase of the operation that should have been handled by remote control.

LEAD: The four-day visit to Washington by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel ended today with the Reagan Administration's Middle East peace initiative on the brink of failure.

N.F.L. Takes Over Indebted Patriots
LEAD: The National Football League today virtually took the New England Patriots away from the Sullivan family.


Study Finds Dioxin Caused No Increase In Defects at Birth
LEAD: An accident in 1976 in Italy that exposed the largest population ever to the chemical byproduct dioxin caused no increase in birth defects, scientists have reported.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation yesterday increased its offer for the Roper Corporation to $50 a share, topping a $45-a-share bid from the General Electric Company.


Review/Film; 'D.O.A.,' Racing Death
LEAD: ''You just gave up, Dex,'' his estranged wife tells him. ''I just quit,'' Dex tells his new girlfriend.
And in case she didn't get it the first time, he explains it to her later: ''I've been dead for four years now.
I forgot to appreciate life.''


Gore Stumps in Kansas for Tomorrow's Caucuses
LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. greeting a worker outside the Boeing military airplanes plant yesterday in Wichita.


Brazil Pays Some Interest
LEAD: Brazil paid $118 million in interest on outstanding loans from commercial banks worldwide, Brazil's central bank said yesterday.
It issued a statement jointly with William Rhodes, a Citibank vice president who is chairman of the 14-member bank advisory committee.


Clark Is Sidelined for 3 Weeks
LEAD: Jack Clark had not hit a home run for the Yankees, so when he finally did against the Baltimore Orioles today, his teammates thought that maybe his slowest-motion trot round the bases was his normal home-run gait.


Review/Dance; Ariel Herrera, Who Falls Upward
LEAD: Ariel S. Herrera stood out last year in a showcase series for new choreographers, and ''Fish on Friday,'' the 40-minute work he presented Wednesday night, confirms that he is a young talent to be followed.


Corruption Witness Admits He Obstructed Justice
LEAD: A witness in municipal corruption cases pleaded guilty yesterday to obstructing justice by withholding information about a collection company for New York City's Parking Violations Bureau.


Poland Gets U.S. Envoy
LEAD: The United States Ambassador, John Davis, formally presented his credentials in Warsaw today, five years after Washington scaled down its diplomatic presence in Poland to protest the imposition of martial law.
The post had been vacant since the United States called back Ambassador Francis Meehan in 1983, two years after martial law was imposed to suppress the Solidarity union movement.


Voluntary Hospitals To Add Beds to Ease Crisis in New York
LEAD: Private hospitals have agreed to provide most of the 412 beds being added to relieve overcrowding in New York City hospitals, according to a plan issued yesterday by the State Health Commissioner, Dr.
David Axelrod.


Dannie Richmond, 56, Drummer With Mingus
LEAD: Dannie Richmond, a drummer whose long association with Charles Mingus made him one of the leading percussionists in modern jazz, died Wednesday in Harlem of a heart attack.
He was 56 years old.


Review/Film; A Look at High School In 'O.C. and Stiggs'
LEAD: ''O.
C. and Stiggs,'' made by Robert Altman in 1984, deals with what may be one of the director's least favorite subjects: all-American boys.
Mr.
Altman's utter lack of sympathy for this film's two schoolboy protagonists (the screenplay is based on material from National Lampoon magazine) is unmistakable, and it's also liberating, so his satirical side is given unusually free rein.


Letter Says Prosecutor Is Blackmailing Judge
LEAD: A Colombian accused of smuggling 3.3 tons of cocaine into the United States has presented a letter in court alleging that the chief prosecutor in his Federal trial is blackmailing the judge.

Scientists Fear for an Ancient Egyptian Boat
LEAD: A 4,600-year-old wooden boat of the Pharaoh Cheops appears to be in good condition, scientists said today.
But they wondered how much longer it would survive the inhospitable conditions of the pit at the base of the Great Pyramid at Giza, where it was found.

Sports People; Cubs-Rangers Trade
LEAD: The Chicago Cubs traded 27-year-old Ray Hayward, a left-handed pitcher with an 8-5 record and a 3.10 earned run average with Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League last season, to the Texas Rangers for two players who spent last year with Oklahoma City of the American Association.
They are Dave Meier, 28, an outfielder, who hit .320 with 18 home runs and 86 runs batted in, and Greg Tabor, an infielder, who hit .303 with 8 home runs and 66 r.b.i.


Review/Film; Poitier in 'Little Nikita'
LEAD: Richard Benjamin's strategy in directing ''Little Nikita'' seems to have been to paper over the holes in the plot with routine moves from spy shows past, in hopes of making the improbable passable.
Sidney Poitier, an F.B.I. agent again, gets onto a couple of K.G.B. ''sleepers'' named Richard and Elizabeth Grant, a very American couple in the southern California town of Fountain Grove, who have been waiting 20 years for the call to action from Moscow.


Canadian and U.S. Dollars Advance as Pound Softens
LEAD: The dollar soared against most major currencies yesterday, but the Canadian dollar traded at a four-year high against the American dollar.


Nigerian Currency Falls
LEAD: The naira, the Nigerian currency, slid today to its lowest level in nine months: 4.32 to the United States dollar, bankers said.
The level marked a 1.5 percent depreciation since the last foreign exchange auction two weeks ago, when the naira was set at 4.25 to the dollar.
The currency has fallen steadily since the beginning of the year, when it stood at just over 4 to the dollar, dealers said.

LEAD: The new owners of the Winston Network Inc., the country's largest out-of-home media company, have changed its name to AMNI, derived from the American Out-of-Home Media Network.
It has also had several promotions announced by Craig P. Heard, its president.
They include four executive vice presidents: Berton Miller, Angelo Schifano, Donald Allman and Robert G.

Queens Murder Suspect Is Sentenced to Prison
LEAD: One of two men who investigators suspect ordered the slaying of a rookie New York City police officer was sentenced yesterday to three and a half to seven years in a separate gun possession case.

LEAD: The Israeli Army tried to break compliance with a Palestinian strike and bulldozed an olive grove today as part of its newest measures to curb a 14-week-old revolt in the occupied territories.

LEAD: A former lawyer for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told a Wedtech executive that in 1983 Mr.

Venture Capital Funds
LEAD: A group of venture capital firms will have an average of $44.8 million to invest this year, up 11 percent from last year, according to a study released on Wednesday.
Grant Thornton, the accounting and management consulting firm that conducted the survey, noted that 93 percent of the 183 venture capital firms that responded said they expected to receive more requests for funds from young companies this year.

Manuel Antonio Noriega.
It also began a shake-up of the military high command, The curbs were imposed after strikes by utility workers cut off electricity and water and blocked roads.

LEAD: An editorial yesterday said incorrectly that there were no criminal prosecutions of Ulster policemen who killed six suspects in 1982.

LEAD:  Decorative Arts Rare, offbeat decorative arts produced over the last century - an 1880's lavishly gilded chair by Antonio Gaudi, a glowing 1920's glass platter by Frederick Carder and several 1930's geometric-patterned Kodak cameras by Walter Dorwin Teague -will be auctioned tomorrow at Sotheby's and next Saturday at


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 421 money market mutual funds decreased $492.9 million, to $279.53 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds decreased $2.06 billion, to $80.11 billion.
Assets of the 210 general purpose funds were up $541.7 million, to $82.02 billion.


Review/Film; Math Teacher to Root For in 'Stand and Deliver'
LEAD: Even those used to watching Edward James Olmos regularly in his ''Miami Vice'' role will have a tough time recognizing him at first in ''Stand and Deliver,'' since Mr.
Olmos has transformed himself so completely.
His hair has been thinned and pasted unflatteringly across his pate; he looks heavier, wears glasses and has none of the complexion-improving makeup used for his television role.


Hanoi Seeks Talks With Beijing
LEAD: After a flare-up of hostilities this week in the South China Sea, Vietnam appealed to China today to negotiate an end to naval attacks around a contested offshore island chain ''and all other matters of border disputes.''


Mario On Mario
LEAD: Picking a Democratic nominee from the convention galleries, putting aside the candidates who went through the primaries, would be a terrible mistake.
It would be the best way to give the election away to the Republicans.
If people like Mario Cuomo wanted to be President, they should have run in the primaries.


Review/Film; Mastroianni in 'Mattia'
LEAD: Marcello Mastroianni has never had any trouble convincing us that he can charm any woman who catches his eye, and any audience along with her.
He's doing it again in ''The Two Lives of Mattia Pascal,'' a movie made for European television that opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room.

LEAD: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, was barred today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee from appearing at a closed briefing for members on the fighting along the Honduran border.

LEAD: United States veterans are cheating the Government of tens of millions of dollars each year by lying about their incomes and thus collecting excessive benefits, a Congressional report says.

LEAD: Bob Dole probably missed his chance for the Republican Presidential nomination when he could not follow up his Iowa victory with one in New Hampshire.
Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts may look back upon Illinois as the state in which his hopes suffered a similar setback.


HUMANLIKE DEFECT IS CREATED IN MICE BY USING FAULTY GENE
LEAD: Scientists say they have created the equivalent of an inherited human disease in laboratory mice by giving mouse embryos deliberately defective genes.

LEAD: Ken Lofton, a reserve guard for Arizona, plays only 16 minutes a game, but has nearly twice as many steals as any other Wildcat.

LEAD: At 10 public schools in New York City, many educational decisions - including setting entrance requirements, shaping the curriculum and choosing the principal -are worked out with a branch of the City University.

LEAD: Texas raced to a United States Open, American and N.C.A.A. record in the 200-yard freestyle relay, and by the end of tonight's event the Lady Longhorns were all but assured of winning their fifth swimming and diving championship.

LEAD: Almost $8 million in crisp new $100 dollar bills that disappeared six weeks ago on a flight from New York City to Buenos Aires was recovered yesterday from a small group of Brazilian thieves who apparently took it in the belief that they were stealing music cassettes.

LEAD: The Rutgers University fraternity under investigation after the death of a pledge who drank himself to death will be closed for at least a year, officials said.

LEAD: A Brooklyn landlord who was sentenced to live 15 days in the neglected apartment building he owns in the Crown Heights section, has corrected 81 percent of the housing code violations that prompted the sentence, the city said yesterday.

Increase Voted in Insurance for Nuclear Accident
LEAD: The Senate approved by voice vote today a bill that would increase from $700 million to more than $7 billion the pool of insurance available for swift disbursement to victims of a major nuclear accident.


North Quits Marines, Suggesting Subpoenas for 'Highest' Officials
LEAD: Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North announced today that he had submitted his resignation to the Marine Corps because he might require ''testimony and records from the highest-ranking officials of our Government'' for his legal defense in the Iran-contra affair.


A Puzzle at Border: Why the Pullback?
LEAD: Nicaraguan troops appear to be beginning to withdraw from Honduras even though they probably could have won an even more significant victory if they had destroyed contra positions inside Honduras, senior American officials said today.


Luther Swygert, 83, U.S. Appeals Judge In Celebrated Cases
LEAD: Luther M. Swygert, a senior Federal appeals judge who handed down important decisions on issues ranging from labor relations to civil rights, died Wednesday at the Whitehall Convalescent Home in Chicago.
He was 83 years old and lived in Chicago and Dune Acres, Ind.

CORRECTION
LEAD: The Executive Changes column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the owner of Schenley Industries of Dallas.
The company was sold in October and is now a subsidiary of the United Distillers Group.


AIDS Virus Seen Unlikely to Cause Mental Illness
LEAD: An international conference of medical experts announced today that it had found no evidence that people infected with the AIDS virus were likely to suffer mental disturbances before suffering from the disease itself.

MECHAM ADVISERS PESSIMISTIC
LEAD: Gov.
Evan Mecham acknowledged today that his senior political advisers say there is little chance he can avoid conviction in the first gubernatorial impeachment trial since 1929.


Coping: With Storing Winter Clothes
LEAD: The ritual of storing winter wear is about to begin and, as uninspiring as the job may be, the time and trouble can pay off, experts say.
Cleaning and covering cold-weather clothes, storing them in cool, dry places and protecting them from household pests will extend their life.
Neglect will show up as holes, stains, fading, mildew and misshapen garments.

John's has been eliminated, the Redmen find it difficult and sad to realize that Shelton Jones has completed his college career.

'Family Values' and Good Intentions
LEAD: Governors are suddenly turning to help constituents who cannot even vote: disadvantaged children.
In Congress, Republicans and Democrats alike now flock to introduce legislation that would expand child care and early education programs.
And on the primary trail, ''family values'' have become a staple of campaign oratory.

Dollar Ends Mixed in U.S.; Gold Prices Mostly Higher
LEAD: The dollar turned mixed in domestic dealings yesterday after rising overseas, as uneasiness set in over the coming close of Japan's fiscal year and the long-term prospects for the United States economy.


Israeli Soldiers Kill Another Arab
LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian today and wounded dozens as a wave of protests continued.


6 Top Ad Agency Officers Secede
LEAD: Angered by their loss of autonomy, six top executives yesterday walked out of the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein advertising agency, a subsidiary of the WPP Group, to set up their own shop.


Salant Will Buy Clothing Company
LEAD: Manhattan Industries agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Salant Corporation, another New York clothing company, for $100 million.
Manhattan agreed to the merger after Salant raised its bid to $18.50 a share of common stock.
Its initial, unsolicited offer, on Feb. 2, was $16 a share.


Exemption for Golfer
LEAD: A golfer who failed to qualify for a tournament after interrupting her round to revive a child who fell into a swimming pool will be allowed to enter the tournament, the Ladies Professional Golf Association announced yesterday.


Review/Music; POULENC ORGAN CONCERTO ON THE CARNEGIE PORTABLE
LEAD: Poulenc's Concerto for Organ, Strings and Timpani is a wonderful piece, but it depends a lot on flavor and atmosphere.
Carnegie Hall is the wrong place: no organ.
Portable substitutes sound and look wrong.
The conductor Erich Leinsdorf is not a specialist in flavor.
And the hall's rather hard acoustics do not lend warmth to a lean string tone such as the Philadelphia Orchestra employed there Tuesday night with Michael Stairs as soloist.


Air Canada-Airbus
LEAD: Air Canada is near agreement with Europe's Airbus Industrie to buy 34 short-haul A320 airliners and take options on 20 more in a contract worth more than 10 billion francs, or about $1.75 billion, the newspaper Le Monde said.
A spokeswoman for the European consortium declined to confirm the report, but said Airbus was in talks with Air Canada as well as with other airlines.


Ex-Puerto Rican Police Agent Guilty in Slaying of 2 Radicals
LEAD: A former police intelligence agent was found guilty early today in the murders of two young advocates of Puerto Rican independence almost 10 years ago and a former police colonel was acquitted.


Despairing Indians Looking to Tradition To Combat Suicides
LEAD: Following the ghost of his younger brother, 25-year-old William Wainanwit drank himself into a stupor one day last month and then went out behind the family trailer and hanged himself.


Southdown Sues
LEAD: Southdown Inc., the Houston cement maker that has offered $420 million for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. of Stamford, Conn., said it had sued Moore McCormack's directors over an anti-takeover provision and a possible recapitalization.
Earlier this week, Moore McCormack, which also produces cement, said it was considering a financial restructuring or recapitalization that could mean paying a substantial cash dividend to its shareholders to maximize the value of its stock and avoid being acquired by Southdown.

One was the thousand-year anniversary of the City of Dublin, the other their own 25th anniversary year as a group.

Review/Music; From Finland, Conductor With Youthful Verve
LEAD: There are those who feel that young conductors should be apprenticed in obscure European opera houses, neither seen nor heard until they are old enough to sidestep qualms about maturity.
Esa-Pekka Salonen, a Finnish conductor who is not yet 30 years old, has been making some flashy recordings for CBS these last few years, and while one might argue that he does not always reach the depths of the broad late-Romantic works that attract him, his interpretations are usually thoughtfully conceived and persuasively executed.

Review/Jazz; A Sunny Murray Lesson In Free-Style Drumming
LEAD: Sunny Murray, who emancipated jazz drumming from the beat in the 1960's, showed the discipline that free drumming takes when he brought a quintet to the Knitting Factory on Wednesday.
Mr.
Murray rarely chooses to play a steady beat or a repeated lick, but his rumbles and accents, his thumps and flourishes, carried the music forward unswervingly.

LEAD: Most Americans see stress as a torturous byproduct of life in a high-speed society.

Guidepost
LEAD:  Battling Bugs  The approach of warm weather brings out insects, especially in kitchens.
Even if your home is bug-free, insects may hitch a ride with the groceries.
You can fight them with sprays, powders, traps, even ultrasound machines.
But before you shop, check your shelves: you may have the products you need, and you may see what's attracting the insects.

Defect Is Linked to Heart Attack and Stroke

Golden Nugget Wins $29 Million Judgment
LEAD: The developer of the financially pressed Dunes Casino Hotel project has been ordered to pay $29 million to Golden Nugget Inc. for failing to pay for a parking lot.


ANSWERS TO QUIZ
LEAD: Questions appear on page 12.


Divestment Plan Is Rejected
LEAD: University of Colorado regents voted Thursday not to divest a $300,000 investment in a company doing business in South Africa.
Pauline Coker, a spokeswoman for the university, said its only investment in a company doing business with South Africa is slightly more than $300,000 in Caterpillar Inc. bonds that mature in 1992.


Schools in Key Games
LEAD: St.
Nicholas of Tolentine, which beat Archbishop Molloy, 70-65, for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association city championship last Saturday, could have three more key games before closing its season.

Decker Raises Standard Bid
LEAD: Unwilling to abandon its effort to acquire American Standard Inc., the Black &amp; Decker Corporation today raised its bid to $77 a share, or about $2.5 billion, from $73 a share, or $2.3 billion.


Quake Has Little Punch
LEAD: The earthquake that shook Tokyo early yesterday may have rocked skyscrapers, spilled coffee onto tabletops and knocked books off shelves, but it had little effect on Mike Tyson and Tony Tubbs.


For Firestone Workers, Some Soothing Words
LEAD: One day after agreeing to buy the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for $2.6 billion, top executives of the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan came here to soothe the fears of workers and to underscore that they were interested in operating the American tire maker as an independent unit.


Barry Honored
LEAD: Last night, the Golden State Warriors retired Rick Barry's jersey number, 24.
He retired eight years ago, after playing for the Warriors in 8 of his 14 professional seasons, including 1967, when he led the National Basketball Association in scoring, and 1975, when he helped the Warriors win the league championship.


Plant Dismisses 4 Workers
LEAD: Four employees at the Peach Bottom nuclear plant were dismissed and seven others suspended with intent to dismiss Thursday because of drug involvement, the Philadelphia Electric Company said.
The plant, in south-central Pennsylvania about 90 miles west of Philadelphia, has been closed for the past year under order of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission because control room operators were sleeping on the job.

LEAD: Doctors inserted a tiny filter into one of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s major veins to intercept any additional blood clots similar to one that lodged in a lung last week, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Center said today.

Federated's 'Poison Pill' Is Upheld
LEAD: In a severe setback to its effort to acquire Federated Department Stores Inc., the Campeau Corporation lost a key court decision yesterday, and R. H. Macy &amp; Company now has the upper hand in the takeover fight.


Hilton Ruiz, Pianist
LEAD: Hilton Ruiz, a pianist, will play a solo concert at 8 o'clock tonight at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street (662-2133).
Admission is free.


Sagan Is Charged in Paris
LEAD: Francoise Sagan, who became famous at 18 for her novel ''Bonjour Tristesse,'' was indicted today for using and transporting cocaine in Lyons.
Miss Sagan, a friend of President Francois Mitterrand, said the charge was politically motivated.
The writer, 52 years old and the author of 19 novels and a few film scripts, was among 30 people charged.


Review/Dance; Plisetskaya, 62, Makes It Look Easy
LEAD: With the arrival of Maya Plisetskaya, ''Making Music Together,'' Boston's Soviet-American festival, turns a historic introduction to contemporary Soviet music and dance into a family affair.


PHILLIES RELEASE COWLEY
LEAD: The Phillies temporarily released Joe Cowley, delaying the comeback attempt of a pitcher who less than two years ago threw a no-hitter.
Manager Lee Elia said Cowley had been given his unconditional release.

LEAD: A Wappingers Falls, N.Y., youth who is a key figure in the Tawana Brawley case has been arrested on a gun possession charge in Poughkeepsie and faces another charge in a shootout last week, the Poughkeepsie police said yesterday.


A War Within the Sri Lankan War
LEAD: A brutal struggle for demographics is under way in eastern Sri Lanka, where ethnic Tamil guerrillas are slaughtering Sinhalese villagers and the Sri Lankan Army is sending the villagers back, sometimes against their wills, when they flee.


For Visitors on the Wing
LEAD: Robins are back and they will soon be joined by blackbirds, towhees, warblers and thrushes.
Each day through May birds will arrive.
Those already here are mating and will soon start to build nests and raise young.
All this because spring will arrive tomorrow at 4:39 A.M.

LEAD: Vernia Brown, who was 19 years old, is listed in the police homicide report as ''innocent bystander.''

LEAD: Cadet Sherri Langston at a rehearsal yesterday for her bas mitzvah last night in the Jewish chapel.
The 22-year-old junior had no formal religious training until she studied Judaism at the academy.
Her sister graduated from West Point last year and is stationed in West Germany. (The New York Times/Willaim E.

LEAD: In less than an hour, Caroline McLean, a freshman at South Bronx High School, found a job, her first, as a cashier at a fast-food restaurant in midtown Manhattan.
By Easter, she said, after earning enough to buy some new clothes, she will quit.

LEAD: The Writers Guild of America announced the winners of its 40th annual awards for ''outstanding achievements in writing'' for movies, television and radio during 1987.

Gains for Nicaragua: A Victory or a New Problem?
LEAD: Nicaraguan troops appear to have won an important military victory by expelling contra guerrillas from some isolated Nicaraguan territory along the Honduran border.
But their military victory may prove to be something of a political problem because it may kindle new sympathy for the contras in Congress.

A TOUCH OF SHAKESPEARE WITH A ROCK SCORE
LEAD: At first sight, on the dim stage, she might be a reincarnation of Anna Pavlova as the Dragonfly.
She is then revealed as a funky ballerina-queen bee.
Finally, she is Shakespeare's Titania, tenderly stroking the head of one of the reclining Bottoms who form the circle in which she sits.

The Eyes of March
LEAD: A broom handle hovers over a base-runner's head.
The broom handle is held by Dave Bristol, a Philadelphia Phillies' coach, and the runner at first base, Milt Thompson, must stay crouched, as though the sky has just been lowered, else he bump his noggin.
This is a spring-training lesson in base-running maneuvers.

Sleep Aid: Little Bumps in the Night
LEAD: For years, hospital patients have slept on foam mattress pads designed to relieve pressure on the body and prevent bedsores.
Now these polyurethane cushions, made of convoluted foam about two inches thick, are becoming popular with consumers seeking more restful sleep at home.


Jersey Rates Its Workfare Experiment a Limited Success
LEAD: Six months into its trial, the state's program to train welfare recipients and start them working is struggling with the limits and delays of the welfare system.


The Right Call on Instant Replays
LEAD: National Football League team owners are a conservative bunch.
So it was revolutionary when, two years ago, they made instant replays part of the game, a last-resort corrective for erroneous calls.
This week, happily, a majority of owners rebuffed a challenge to this welcome innovation.

LEAD: A brilliant performance by Kelly Hrudey in goal inspired the Islanders to recover from a three-goal deficit and gain a 3-3 tie tonight against the Washington Capitals.

LEAD: Bill Walsh has signed a two-year contract to remain as coach of the San Francisco 49ers, but he will yield the position of team president to the owner, Edward J. DeBartolo Jr.

LEAD: In a suprise announcement, Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company said today that one of its top merchandisers, Joseph H. Batogowski, 48 years old, was resigning to pursue ''outside business interests.'' Mr.
Batogowski, a 22-year veteran of the nation's largest retailer, could not be reached for comment.

4.4% Growth in Britain
LEAD: Consumer spending helped Britain's gross domestic product grow by 4.4 percent last year, according to Government figures released today.
Consumer spending grew by slightly more than 5 percent in 1987 compared with 6 percent in 1986, the figures showed.
Officials said Britain's economy had not been so buoyant since gross domestic product grew 7.25 percent in 1973.


A Macho Australian Arrives on Her Cycle
LEAD: It is easy to find soft-headed movies that pretend to be about women's roles in society, and much harder to come across a film as good as ''Shame,'' a tough-minded Australian action story with a smart, sensitive, unsettling macho heroine.
In the film's first minutes a black-clothed motorcyclist rides into a small town, takes off a helmet to reveal long, strawberry blonde curls and walks into a grimy bar asking for a room and a mechanic to fix her bike.

Eastern Air Penalty Planned
LEAD: The legal problems of Eastern Air Lines and its parent, the Texas Air Corporation, mounted yesterday when a Federal judge said that he would penalize Eastern on Monday for its attempts to transfer its shuttle operation to a newly formed subsidiary of Texas Air.


A CHINESE SCROLL'S MARVELS, UNFOLDED BY AN ARTIST
LEAD: Dressed in the crisp, bright colors of his own paintings as he explores the mysteries of a 70-foot-long Chinese scroll, David Hockney effortlessly connects the past and the present, revealing himself to be a splendid art teacher in the process.
In ''A Day on the Grand Canal With the Emperor of China (or Surface Is Illusion but So Is Depth),'' he delivers an extremely clear and articulate analysis of the manner in which the 17th-century scroll has been painted.


Edward Villella Is Back for a Visit
LEAD: Edward Villella is a happy man.
The former New York City Ballet star, now living with his family in Florida, has returned to New York with the Miami City Ballet, which he directs.
The company, which presented its first performance in October, makes its New York debut tonight at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

AIDS TEXT REJECTED IN NEW YORK
LEAD: An easy-to-understand book about the threat of AIDS, intended for high school and junior high school students, has been rejected as a classroom text by the New York City Board of Education even though the book is based on a film the board commissioned and distributes to schools.


U.S. Aids Financial Corp. Unit
LEAD: In an emergency move, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it would guarantee against loss all the depositors and general creditors of the American Savings and Loan Association.

Manuel Antonio Noriega.
He said, ''I have been informed by the Department of Justice that they support the position that this man should ultimately be extradited.

STROKES IN WOMEN LINKED TO SMOKING
LEAD: Women who smoke half a pack of cigarettes a day are twice as likely to have a stroke as women who have never smoked and those who smoke two packs a day have six times as likely, researchers say.


26 Clubs for Rugby Event
LEAD: Twenty-six rugby clubs will converge, regardless of the weather, on Downing Stadium at Randalls Island today to compete in the first Big Apple Rugby Challenge.
The all-amateur tournament features entrants from local colleges and high schools, and an exhibition for players over 45 years old.


Kaiser Steel Plans A Reorganization
LEAD: Thirteen months after seeking protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, the Kaiser Steel Corporation, once the nation's ninth-largest steelmaker, said it had filed a reorganization plan.

De Benedetti Is Selling Buitoni Pasta to Nestle
LEAD: Carlo de Benedetti agreed today to sell his Buitoni pasta company to Nestle S.A. of Switzerland for $1.27 billion.


Review/Music; GIUSEPPE SINOPOLI URBANIZES BRUCKNER
LEAD: Giuseppe Sinopoli gave us a clever Bruckner Eighth Symphony at Carnegie Hall Thursday night.
Using the Philharmonia Orchestra of London, the Italian conductor has put Bruckner on a diet, the broad cushioning string sound we know so well compressed into slender, sharply penetrating shapes.

Clark Hasn't Lost Sense of Humor
LEAD: Jack Clark figures that he should take advantage of his status as the player who has endured the widest assortment of disabling injuries in recent seasons.


OF A CERTAIN AGE
LEAD: THE MERE MENTION OF A WOMAN'S AGE once sent shudders rippling through polite society.
The same was true in cosmetics advertising, with copywriters delicately discussing youthfulness instead.
Today, as more women boast of their advancing years, cosmetics companies are tackling the subject with vigor and enthusiasm.


Albert York Abides in His World With Grand Aloofness
LEAD: Albert York is a strange case.
This reclusive painter of deliberate, dreamlike landscapes, still lifes and portraits was born in Detroit in 1928.
He went to art school in Canada and Michigan.
He moved to New York City in the early 1960's and studied briefly with Raphael Soyer.
He has lived for more than 20 years on the east end of Long Island, where he has witnessed more than his share of development and change.


Food Inspection Results
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 29 food establishments cited for violating the health code.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD: TALES OF GOLD.
By Lewis H. Carlson and John J. Fogarty. (Contemporary Books, $25.) This book by Lewis H. Carlson, a professor of humanities at Western Michigan University, and John J. Fogarty, an associate professor of English at Ferris State College in Michigan, is an oral history of the last 15 Summer Olympic Games.


Koch Expands School-Aid Bid
LEAD: Mayor Koch asked about 150 local politicians and education officials yesterday to help him lobby the State Legislature for increased aid for New York City's public schools.


CREDIT WHERE IT'S DUE: LILCO TO THE RESCUE
LEAD: Everyone dumps on Lilco.
Once in a while, someone should tell the other side of the story.


Old and New Collide on the Waterfront
LEAD: ON THE southern edge of Claremont Channel, a grim slip on Jersey City's well-worn waterfront, a rattling conveyor belt carries the squashed remains of old automobiles up to a hopper.


Portobello Art Festival
LEAD: NOTTING HILL is one of the liveliest of London's small villages.


Hockey; MERRIMACK SAVED BY 7 STRAIGHT GOALS
LEAD: Merrimack produced a memorable comeback tonight against Northeastern by scoring seven straight goals to defeat the Huskies, 7-3, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.


6 People File to Oppose Mecham for Governor
LEAD: Six candidates had filed petitions to oppose Gov.
Evan Mecham in a recall election May 17 as the petition deadline passed Friday.


Modern Nursing Is a Task, Not a Calling
LEAD: AS a nurse in the same geriatric ward for a few years, I've periodically been restless for a change but never acted upon my wish for it.
A few weeks ago, I finally requested to switch from days to the night shift.
After waiting with mixed feelings, I was notified to start on nights the day after my vacation was through.


Practical Traveler; Flying Business Class
LEAD: ECONOMY-CLASS travelers confess to being tortured by curiosity about what is happening on the other side of that curtain near the front that the flight attendants draw so decisively after takeoff.
In moments when I have been on the other side, I have secretly hoped to spy out the truth.
I never learned much except that carving beef on a little trolley looks like back-breaking work.


Ceramics: Expression Through Color
LEAD: COLOR is said to be the most complex, yet the most exciting, aspect of design.
In painting, color is both fact and illusion.


KANSAS CAUCUSES WON BY DUKAKIS
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts won the Kansas Democratic caucuses today as the Rev.
Jesse Jackson used strong showings in the state's larger counties to finish second.
Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee was third.

East Regional; High-Volume Coaching Spurs Owls and Hoyas
LEAD: As is the case with many coaches, there are similarities in the way John Chaney of Temple and John Thompson of Georgetown go about their jobs, blending the roles of surrogate parent and drill instructor.
Thompson jokingly talked today about how he called the Hoya players just about every nasty thing he could think of during the course of the regular season, reaching a point where the players thought they were probably the worst and dumbest team ever to play for him.


He Gave Elegance to Manhattan's Skyline
LEAD: The death last month of the builder and architect Irwin S. Chanin did not have any immediate impact on the shape of the city -Chanin was, after all, 96 years old, and had not put up a new building in years, even though he did manage the remarkable feat of going to his office almost daily until a couple of months ago.


As Sales Drop, Builders of Boats Turn to Artworks
LEAD: New England boat builders are diversifying, making sculptures and ornaments for buildings as well as custom-made yachts, to compensate for a flagging market.

Joseph spends 10 hours a day consulting the green screen of his Quotron, the blue monitor of his IBM XT and the green display of his Bond Brain.


THE FIRES OF SPRING
LEAD: JULY MAY MARK THE official beginning of barbecuing season, but those with a passion for grilled foods gladly overlook such formalities.
In deep winter, these people can be found scraping the snow from their grills; in spring, they huddle under umbrellas as they cook.

LEAD: Twenty years after the Kerner Commission chastised the press for reporting the news ''with white men's eyes and a white perspective,'' a panel of black journalists said last week that newspapers and broadcasters had failed to recruit enough blacks into the nation's newsrooms.

Peaceful Coexistence in the Office
LEAD: WE asked 10 computer users familiar with the Macintosh and the I.B.M.
PC's, PS/2's and compatibles to take the standard desert island test. ''If you were stranded and could have only one computer, which would it be?'' The findings of this unscientific survey, which has a margin of error of 100 percent, reveal more about the users who inhabit the different computer universes than about the merits of the two categories of machines.

Rhode Island Bounces Syracuse, 97-94
LEAD: The Running Rams of Rhode Island came into their first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in a decade believing they could run with anybody.
After a desperation 3-pointer by Earl Duncan, the Syracuse guard, bounced off the rim at the buzzer today, the East Regional's 11th-seeded team had proven it did indeed belong among the nation's elite.

GUERRILLAS IN SALVADOR STEP UP PRE-ELECTION TERRORISM
LEAD: Stepping up their violent effort to stop national elections here on Sunday, Marxist guerrillas have killed one mayor and kidnapped two others in recent days, burned a mayor's office, exploded several bombs and burned cars, trucks and buses to paralyze road traffic.

And Now Military Talks
LEAD: The meeting between Soviet and American defense ministers here produced ''no breakthrough,'' as Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci said.
Still, it was a remarkable first, not spring but a sign of changing climate that can gradually lead to a dramatically different sense of the superpower confrontation.


A Honeymoon Revisited, With Children
LEAD: I FIRST visited the south of France in 1961.
That is more than half my life ago, and I have returned often since.
Like so many others, I find myself moved by that landscape - compelled by its long history, dazzled by its light.
Some travelers are drawn to mountains, while some prefer valleys instead; for each pilgrim to the desert there is one who dreams of forests; for each lover of the lakefront there is one who wants the river.

''We help people to try to find a way to afford what's out there.''

In Mexico, a Fight for the Mantle of Revolution
LEAD: Mobilized by Mexico's governing party, tens of thousands of workers, peasants and civil servants gathered in front of the National Palace here Friday to hear President Miguel de la Madrid honor the memory of President Lazaro Cardenas, who, 50 years earlier, ordered the takeover of foreign oil companies.


The Ruthless Young Crack Gangsters
LEAD: THEY are a new breed of criminal in New York City: young members of crack-peddling gangs who murder on a whim.
And though police officials say they are confident the gangs can be uprooted by methods that have worked before, other law-enforcement experts and social scientists are less optimistic.


What Hath Norrington Wrought?
LEAD: Classical music-lovers should be amply familiar by this time with the name of Roger Norrington, the English specialist in the period performance of 19th-century music.
Mr.
Norrington's Beethoven symphony recordings have been almost universally admired, and his recent Berlioz weekend in London's Queen Elizabeth Hall, capped by ''authentic'' accounts of the ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and ''Romeo et Juliette,'' were almost more revelatory than his Beethoven.


POSTINGS: By the Sea; Hotel and Town Houses
LEAD: In a one-time resort now being transformed into a bedroom community, Henry V. Vaccaro is hedging his bets.
Along with the first hotel to be built in Ocean Grove, N.J, in 50 years, Mr.
Vaccaro plans 14 town-house condominiums.
The combination resort-and-conference hotel will have 168 rooms and Victorian architecture.


FATHERS AND SONS ON THE WATERFRONT
LEAD: Your article about the decline of the shipping industry noted that the local economy had undergone rapid change, but it failed to emphasize the benefits that change has brought.
During the last 40 years, maritime industry has withdrawn from the Hudson waterfront, leaving much of it in a state of devastation.


Questions and Answers On Presidential Primary
LEAD: CONNECTICUT will hold its Presidential preference primary March 29.
At stake in the voting will be 35 Republican delegates and 52 Democratic delegates to the parties' national conventions this summer.
Seven other at-large Democratic delegates - party and elected officials - will be chosen later.
As the primary nears, there are questions about who may vote and how to register.


Iraq Attacks Iran Oil Terminal
LEAD: Waves of Iraqi planes pounded Iran's biggest oil terminal today, leaving at least two tankers ablaze in the northern Persian Gulf.
Iran said it shot down three Iraqi planes.


Next Week Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

And so the Philadelphia Dance Theater's presentation of five Humphrey dances, on Thursday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, was very welcome.

Housewives and Prom Queens, 25 Years Later
LEAD: I find my history in novels - and only after the passage of time.
The feminist novel, which flourished in the 1960's and 70's, held more than met the eye of the reader (and writer in some cases) at the time.
Concealed within these tales are the seeds of many conflicts that bedevil the womens' movement, and women, today, though even if we had been prescient enough to recognize them then, the issues would have remained stubborn, defiant and perhaps insoluble.

Breuker is an eclectic, and like such fellow pastiche artists as the composers Carla Bley and Henry

Burt R. Meyers of White Plains and West Yarmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dara Lynn Meyers, to Evan M. Kingsley, a son of Rabbi and Mrs.
Ralph P. Kingsley of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Lenox, Mass.
An October wedding is planned.

Cologne
LEAD: To the Editor: As a repeat visitor to Cologne, I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Cologne'' by John Dornberg (Travel, Jan. 31) and learned about a few more places to visit.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:  L. RON HUBBARD: Messiah or Madman?
By Bent Corydon and L. Ron Hubbard Jr. (Lyle Stuart, $20.) The Church of Scientology is a bizarre cult, and its founder and leader, L. Ron Hubbard, was a ''cosmic outlaw,'' in the words of L. Ron Hubbard Jr.
There is little of the son in this book but a good deal of Bent Corydon, who headed one of the Scientology ''missions'' in California during the 1970's until Hubbard decided to take over these lucrative franchises, leaving their well-rewarded leaders bewildered and broke.

Military's Use of German Cars Is Questioned
LEAD: A House subcommittee has asked Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci to explain reports that American military personnel in West Germany use some German-made cars and buses, contending that doing so ''undermines the American automotive industry.''


Fresh, No-Frills Dining in Danbury
LEAD: DINNER at the New England Food Company in Danbury can be a rare gustatory experience, comparable to dining at the home of an exceptionally gifted cook who uses only the best fresh ingredients.


Review/Opera; NEW 'HOFFMANN' CAST
LEAD: There were five newcomers Wednesday night in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Contes d'Hoffmann'' cast, but the most striking was a familiar face: Placido Domingo in the title role.
Hoffmann surely counts among the celebrated tenor's best parts.
It suits his voice admirably, and he invests the acting with all his considerable intelligence.

This Newcomer Is Disposable
LEAD: I was on my way to the Houston FotoFest, just about to board the shuttle bus to my hotel, when I ran into my friend Elaine.
Instead of the Leica M4 she usually wears, she was sporting the latest compact-VHS video camcorder.
She had just begun recording her own documentary of the outskirts of Houston when my nose appeared in her finder.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration, wary of a possible political backlash on Capitol Hill, has rejected a proposal to use American helicopters to transport Honduran troops to the battle zone where Sandinista forces have been fighting rebels, a senior Administration official said today.

Hotels Act to Meet Keener Competition
LEAD: ROOMS, the stock in trade of the hotel industry, have to be sold every day - a feat that becomes increasingly difficult when the supply is increased and the demand reduced.
There is concern now that the county's hotel market has too many rooms and too few customers.


Saving a Study to Save the Sound
LEAD: MEMBERS of Congress, trying to keep a cleanup study of Long Island Sound moving at full speed, have begun fighting a Reagan Administration proposal to cut the Federal estuary program by $2.5 million in 1989.


Costa Rica
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding ''Costa Rica's Quiet Beaches and Lush Land'' (Travel, Jan. 24), I would like to suggest that anyone going to Costa Rica should consider a three-day raft trip on the Picuare River, which flows through lush, virgin jungle.
Visitors can expect to see dazzling, electric-blue Morpho butterflies, scarlet macaws and the exotic nests of the oropendula.
