LEAD: MEMBERS of the New Jersey Supreme Court are to be congratulated for the depth and comprehensive nature of their judgment in the Baby M case.

THE WORLD: The French Election; Mitterrand Is Counting on A Continued Rift on Right
LEAD: It is seven long and presumably uncertain weeks before the next president of France will be elected.
The politician with a commanding lead in the opinion polls, President Francois Mitterrand, has not yet formally declared that he will run for a second term of office.
Yet the focus of political discussion in France is not about the campaign but about who will govern with whom after the


A Filtered Portrait of Lincoln Comes to the Small Screen
LEAD: On April 4, 1865 - 123 years ago, almost to the day - Abraham Lincoln visited Richmond, for the only time.
The very morning after the Confederate capital fell to his Union forces, Lincoln walked, unannounced, into the heart of the city.
To his surprise the newly freed black population turned out to greet him with ''wild, indescribable, ecstatic joy,'' in the words of one contemporary journalist.

LEAD: LILI ELSIS slumped on her cellar stairs and put her head in her hands. ''We just moved all this in last Thursday,'' she said with a sigh.

TAKING A BITE OUT OF THE BIGGEST STATE
LEAD: At first glance, Alaska seems a bit overwhelming as a vacation site.
The 49th state is a fifth the size of the continental United States, and one of its 5,000 glaciers is larger than Rhode Island.
But Alaska can be toured on a cruise ship or by rail, plane and ferry.

Minority Caucus Backs Plan for Desegregation
LEAD: THE Black and Hispanic Caucus of the General Assembly has endorsed a proposal for voluntary school desegregation.
The group said the plan was far preferable to a court order mandating integration.

LEAD: BARBARA MUSIC has been a designer of textiles, theater costumes and bridal and evening dresses.
But her latest career is trimming bridal and evening shoes with all manner of laces, beads, buckles and fabric flowers.


GRUMMAN'S PROBLEM: CREDIBILITY
LEAD: ''Turbulent Times Ahead for Grumman''  [ Feb. 14 ]  does not address Grumman's most serious problem, lack of credibility.
In an era where it is recognized that advanced electronic systems form the backbone of aerospace systems, Grumman has failed to demonstrate the capability to manage the development of systems and software.

Sophocles With a Chorus Of Gospel
LEAD: When ''The Gospel at Colonus'' had its first performance at P.S. 122 on the Lower East Side in 1980, it was a half-hour show with one actor, five singers, two songs by Bob Telson and just the beginnings of writer-director Lee Breuer's central idea: that the essential nature of Greek tragedy could be revealed to modern audiences by presenting Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus'' in the form of a black Pentecostal church service.


Stepping Back In Time in The Caribbean
LEAD: WHEN word got around the island of Nevis not long ago that construction of a new golf course was being contemplated, the response from most Nevisians and long-time foreign residents was predictable: why build something we already have?
That the existing course has only one hole - making it the only one-hole course in the West Indies and perhaps anywhere, for that matter - was irrelevant to most residents, who felt that one hole was quite enough.


Europeans Agree to Work on U.S. Space Project
LEAD: The European Space Agency has agreed, after two years of negotiations, to take part in the United States space station project and provide a laboratory module to be permanently attached to the earth-orbiting station.

How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
LEAD: What Darryl Strawberry did in January of this year was no different from what Lee Mazzilli and Wally Backman did in July of last year, or from what Keith Hernandez did in September of 1984.
When Strawberry's teammates tell the media that he quit, it's to motivate him; when Strawberry says that his teammates were unmotivated, he's mouthing off, creating distractions.

Once again their mission is unclear.
Once again professional military people are troubled.

PETER J. CALLAHAN  Newark, Del.

Samson, Gorilla, Dies at 30
LEAD: Samson, a 30-year-old western lowland gorilla believed the oldest breeding male gorilla in captivity, has died at the Brookfield Zoo.
The 400-pound gorilla suffered a stroke and died Thursday, said a zoo spokeswoman, Linda Elbert.

BEYOND INSULIN
LEAD: INSULIN INJECTIONS, SCIENTISTS HAVE LONG known, are merely a way to manage diabetes - not cure it.
Diabetics no longer die of comas induced by excessive blood sugar.
But they do die, before their time, of a range of complications directly related to the hour-to-hour fluctuations of blood sugar, or glucose, that persist even with insulin therapy.

More Dollars Equal Less Message
LEAD: I HAVE been an advertising writer for 27 years.
I've written ads for everything from automobiles and airlines to ham and cheese.
For many of those years, I've written commercials that helped put people in public office.
I've stopped, as have a number of my colleagues, even though poltical advertising is a very profitable part of our business.

Mouse in the Castle? Off With Its Head!
LEAD: ONCE upon a time in the kingdom of Nassau County, there lived a King and Queen (anyone who owned a home in this kingdom was considered a King and Queen).
Anyway, one evening this particular royal couple went to bed.
All the lights were out and the castle was very, very quiet.
The couple were about to fall asleep when suddenly they heard a noise coming from another part of their domain.

Riches Abound in 'The Woods'
LEAD: While immersed last week in the magnificent original cast recording of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's fairy-tale musical, ''Into the Woods'' (RCA Victor 6796-2RC; all three formats), I was reminded of how crucial a cast album can be to the future reputation of a show.
If the score is first rate and the performances finely tuned, no matter what a show's short-term commercial fate, its cast album will keep the music circulating and win for it future champions who may never have seen it produced.

THE CONTINUING PASSION FOR PEARLS
LEAD: PEARLS HAVE ALWAYS fueled a panoply of emotions.
They have been lusted after and fondled in the names of both propriety and passion.
Royalty has always been bedecked with ropes of them, fathers indulge their daughters with them and career women, finding them a luxury within reason, treat themselves to a modest strand or two.

Pacino has offered a performance that is a far cry from the conventionally heroic and patrician Mark Antony of Shakespearean tradition.

For Devotees of Dumplings
LEAD: THE Long Island Seafood Dumpling House in the Merrick Mall Plaza is a restaurant in transition.
When first visited, it had a sign outside that said East West Cafe, and so did the menu.
The staff answered the phone with ''Good evening, East West Cafe.'' Since December, the restaurant has been operated by the Queens Dumpling House of Rego Park.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD: SOVIET SUCCESSION STRUGGLES: Kremlinology and the Russian Question From Lenin to Gorbachev.
By Anthony D'Agostino. (Allen &amp; Unwin, $45.) One school of thought sees all signs of struggle in the Kremlin as playacting, a device to gull the West into giving aid and comfort to the comparatively ''good'' Soviet leader who is at odds with supposedly ''bad'' domestic foes.

Review/Concert; Fischer-Dieskau Returns to New York Stage
LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, who had not sung in America since 1980, returned to Carnegie Hall Friday night to sing Mahler's ''Kindertotenlieder'' with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London.
It was easy for him to renew his bond of communication with this public.
Oboe and horn played their brief opening lament; the baritone entered with a quiet reflection that the sun would rise again as though no sorrow had befallen in the night, and instantly we were all in the world of Mahler and Ruckert (the poet) and their close examination of grief.


Peugeot Alive and Going Global
LEAD: WHEN Jacques Calvet, chairman of the Peugeot automobile group, joined the company in 1982, it was in shambles.
It lost $300 million that year, its market share in Europe was plummeting and many analysts said bankruptcy was just around the corner.


Chores for the Season
LEAD: BEGIN cleanup of the lawn; rake off winter's debris, old leaves, twigs and dead grass; add to a compost pile or fill plastic bags for dumping; apply lime if the lawn was not limed in recent years; if no fertilizer was applied late last fall, now is the time; follow rates provided on bags for both lime and fertilizer and use a calibrated spreader to make applications accurate.

LEAD: A crowd of 6,021 gathered at the Rutgers Athletic Center today to bid farewell to Sue Wicks, the Lady Knights' superstar who was playing the final home game of a career unmatched by any player, male or female, in school history.

Addiction Is a Family Problem, Too
LEAD: One woman used to call in sick for her husband when he was too drunk to get up in the morning.

LEAD: If he shows up late, he gets fined.
If he is quoted bad-mouthing teammates, he is given the chance to clear the air, face to face.
And if he plays good baseball, he remains in the lineup.
NICK HANSLOWE  Liverpool, N.Y.

Why, then, does Mr.
Raines say that Charles's education was ''a noble . . . experiment that backfired''?
Judging from its results, it succeeded very well.

Oddities From Old Kitchens
LEAD: Tools and utensils that kept houses humming a century ago have been dusted off and placed on view at the New-York Historical Society, in an exhibition called ''Bellows, Bobbins and Butter Churns: Keeping House in 19th-Century America.'' Most of the 190 or so items, on exhibit through Oct. 2, were used by women in their daily chores - cooking, spinning, sewing, laundering and keeping their houses heated, lighted and free of pests.

LEAD: I guess I loved Cher the most the night she showed up at the Academy Awards looking like a tarantula.

Just Because It's True, Is It Art?
LEAD: In 1982, 18 students from a high school in East Los Angeles took the Advanced Placement exam in calculus and passed.
They received college credit for their high school work.
The next year, 31 students from the same school passed, and the number has climbed steadily ever since.
Eighty-seven students passed the test in 1987.

Pampered Look at the Wild
LEAD: ''MOOSE!'' The cry from one excited passenger sets 59 other heads aswivel, and those of us across the aisle jump out of our plush seats and lean over fellow riders to catch a glimpse of a barn-size cow and her calf grazing by the edge of a grove of birch trees.
Outside the wide, curved glass windows we see unbroken wilderness; inside, we enjoy unalloyed luxury.

A Big Texas Bank Gets Federal Aid
LEAD: Texas's biggest banking company got an emergency $1 billion loan from Federal regulators.
First Republicbank of Dallas sought the aid in an effort to restore depositor confidence.
The company, with $32.2 billion in assets, has seen some $2 billion in withdrawals this year amid concern about its financial condition.


2 BRITISH SOLDIERS KILLED AT I.R.A. RITES
LEAD: There was more macabre violence at an Irish Republican Army funeral today as two armed British soldiers in civilian clothes drove their car into a crowd of panicked mourners and were, in turn, seized, beaten and finally shot to death.


Barcelona
LEAD: To the Editor: In response to a letter (Travel, Feb. 7), Paul Delaney said he did not recommend the Hotel Colon in Barcelona because, among other things, the linens were not changed every day.
I've never understood this complaint, which I've heard many times from travelers.
How many of us at home have our bed linens changed daily?


Value of EKG for Students Debated
LEAD: MARY JANE PANULLO said that ever since her son, Cary, was given an electrocardiogram last year as part of his high school pre-football physical, she has rested easier.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 24 with an article about Antigua, Guatemala, misstated the market days for the town of Chichicastenango.
They are Thursday and Sunday.
A brief accompanying report described Antigua's bus services incorrectly.
The Greyhound company does not operate in Guatemala.


The Only Way to Go
LEAD: EXPERTS and administrators around the world have long been troubled by the problem of procedural penalties for such matters as tardy arrival and slow play.
It seems unfair, say some, for a major knockout team match to be decided by circumstances other than actual play.
The counter-argument focuses on the difficulty of discouraging misdemeanors without imposing penalties with teeth.

LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, is to arrive in Washington on Sunday in search of a compromise that would ease the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

Covert Whispers to Workers and Customers
LEAD: THE fact that subliminal messages have gone public does not mean covert messages have become extinct.
In department stores there may be the subliminal sound of jail doors slamming or police sirens wailing to deter shoplifters.
The music piped into a factory may be cautioning workers to be safe.

Correction
LEAD: A caption on page 22 of The Times Magazine today, under the heading ''Russia Enters the Race,'' misstates part of the Soviet Union's plan to explore Phobos, one of Mars's two moons.
Both Soviet craft are to engage in laser-aided analysis of the moon and send hoppers to its surface; the tasks are not allocated to one craft apiece.

Cassettes
LEAD: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on the pleasure of listening to cassettes while driving (Practical Traveler, Feb. 7) neglected mentioning an affordable reference guide to thousands of available titles. ''Words on Tape'' at $29.95 lists over 15,000 titles from 435 cassette publishers.
Titles are listed by author, title and subject.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: NO CEILING BUT HEAVEN.
By Mykal Mayfield Banta. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) This is a first novel both violent and overwhelmingly sad. ''No Ceiling but Heaven'' is the strife-filled tale of the Midwestern Harden family, as narrated by the mentally retarded Johnny.
The Hardens' difficulties center mostly on Bobby, Johnny's twin brother, who is angry and destructive, a borderline psychopath.

Corrections
LEAD: An article last Sunday about fast food restaurants misstated the time period for Kentucky Fried Chicken's financial turnaround.
The company was financially sound by 1980, and in good shape when Pepsico bought it in 1986.
No cash infusions were needed.

STYLISH INVESTMENTS
LEAD: In hard times, men traditionally dress up to look affluent and successful.
During the Great Depression, for example, many families put a good portion of their clothing budget into the breadwinner's suit.
Although we're a long way from the 1930's, it appears that the diminishing prosperity of recent times has caused many young men to abandon casual clothes for a more conservative style.

An elderly person stares at me, and I wonder how he got in the house.

Or did we leave the back door open last night?
He does resemble me, though.
I know what you are saying, little mirror on the wall.

How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
LEAD: Trade him to the Dodgers for Kirk Gibson, straight up.
Think of it.
Darryl goes back to his hometown under the nurturing wing of Tommy Lasorda.
If Darryl starts to open his big mouth at the wrong times, Tommy will stuff it full of good home-cooked pasta.
Gibson comes to a contending team under the watchful eye of veteran players.

Where the Frontier Spirit Lives On
LEAD: ON Dec. 5, 1905, a man bundled in furs against the 60-degree-below temperature stepped off a sled on the frozen Yukon River, walked into the town of Eagle and asked where he could send a telegram.
The message he sent (over a telegraph line constructed five years before to send military communiques) announced the discovery of the Northwest Passage; it was signed ''Roald Amundsen.


A NEW LENNON MYSTERY TOUR
LEAD: When John Lennon was assassinated on Dec. 8, 1980, it seemed that a particularly vivid chapter in the history of popular music had come to an abrupt end.
Of course, in the most literal sense, it had: Lennon's ''approved'' creative works - his contributions to the Beatles catalogue, his post-Beatles solo disks, the handful of songs he wrote for other performers, his two books of humorous poetry and short stories, and a number of artworks, films and video productions - would have to stand as a definitive and finite record of the material he considered ready for release.

TIMOTHY MUSKAT  Ithaca, N.Y.

SURE TIPS FOR SHIRTS
LEAD: Jay Gatsby, Fitzgerald's fictional dandy, was the ultimate shirt connoisseur.
He had only to ring up his personal buyer, and a cornucopia of elegant linens, silks and flannels would arrive.
Most American men, however, buy their dress shirts the way they buy supermarket chicken - with a hasty examination of the parts visible through the plastic wrap and an assumption that what's hidden will be fine.

Help From the 'Hidden Persuaders'

The movie was ''Picnic.'' And at a New Jersey drive-in theater, according to legend, an invisible message flashed across the silver screen every 32 seconds: ''Eat popcorn.

'Home' to Africa
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding Steven Barboza's article ''Going 'Home' to Africa'' (Travel, Feb. 21): His reference to Goree Island evokes a haunting, devastating experience.
We -my husband and I - were there 10 or 11 years ago when visiting our daughter, then a Peace Corps volunteer in Senegal.
The the slave house, the inscriptions on the walls, that flat rock from which the enslaved took their last step out of Africa are all indelibly incised in my memory.

A River Route To Budapest
LEAD: FOR much of its length between West Germany's Black Forest and the Black Sea, the Danube is a waterway for sturdy freight barges.
The swift flow of the river, one of the world's fastest commercial waterways, deters leisurely boating.
Dams and locks help control flow and aid navigation on a river that is shallow, quirky and full of character and vitality.

DESTINATION: MARS
LEAD: MARS TUGS AT THE HUMAN IMAGINATION like no other planet.
With a force mightier than gravity, it attracts the eye to its shimmering red presence in a clear night sky.
The mind vaults to thoughts of what might have been (if Mars were a little closer to the Sun) and of what could be (if humans were one day to plant colonies there).

PORTUGUESE SINCE HENRY THE NAVIGATOR
LEAD: THE dot that represents Madeira on world maps lies roughly at the level of Casablanca in the Atlantic Ocean, a half-inch or so off Morocco.
Close inspection transforms the dot into a sunny, colorful little volcanic archipelago 340 miles from the African coast, composed of one main island called Madeira, high and green, another small sandier one, Porto Santo, which serves mainly as a beach resort, and several uninhabited bits of rock, the Desertas, which float attractively on Madeira's horizon and offer tourists on day cruises a chance to explore, and the more distant Selvagens.

LEAD: My professional life has been severely disordered by a call to jury duty in Nassau County.
Though recognizing my responsibility as a citizen to serve, and beyond that being intrigued in anticipation of a new experience, I was and am worried: as a clinical social worker in agency and private practice, my extended absence would mean that depressed, anxious, sometimes abused or otherwise disturbed clients would go unserved.

LEAD: ''Rashomon - it's more than just a movie.
The word has come into the language now.'' Fay Kanin, the co-author, with her husband, Michael, of a 1959 adaptation of Akira Kurosawa's film, was remarking how deep a note the movie has struck here.
The very name, she said, now means any conflicting versions of the same reality.

Corrections
LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on Feb. 14 about frequent flier programs misstated Pan American World Airways' policy on the types of flights taken before March 31 that would qualify a passenger for triple mileage credits on later flights this year.
Shuttle flights are considered qualifying.


LONG ISLAND GUIDE
LEAD:  3-D ART  As contemporary as it may seem, the concept of 3-D images is actually quite ancient.
It all began when for the first time an artist tried to simulate the appearance of depth on a flat surface.
With ''Seeing Is Believing: The History of 3-D in Art and Popular Culture,'' the Heckscher Museum in Huntington is exploring this cross between artistic endeavor, scientific technology and popular culture.

The Editorial Notebook; The Brawley Case of 1753
LEAD: On Jan. 1, 1753, an 18-year-old Londoner named Elizabeth Canning celebrated the New Year at the home of her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs.
Colley.
At 9 that night she left for the home of the Lyon family, where she was a housemaid.
The Colleys accompanied her.
When they left Elizabeth, she had less than a mile to go.

Army Sets Radon Testing
LEAD: The Army has announced it will test buildings on its bases for the presence of the natural radioactive gas radon. ''The first structures to be tested will be day care centers, hospitals, schools and living areas,'' the Army said in a statement Friday.
Radon, a natural product of decaying uranium in soil, may increase the risk of lung cancer, medical researchers say.

Livestock Killed On Road
LEAD: A herd of beefalo, which are part-bison and part-cattle, roamed onto the Florida Turnpike early today, causing five accidents.
Seven beefalo were killed, the police said, and one motorist was slightly injured.
Sgt.
Alvis Chinn of the Florida Highway Patrol said 75 to 100 animals from a 400-head herd broke through a hole in a fence along the Florida Turnpike Extension in northwest Dade County.

Review/Theater; 'M. Butterfly,' a Story Of a Strange Love, Conflict and Betrayal
It didn't require genius for David Henry Hwang to see that there were the makings of a compelling play in the 1986 newspaper story that prompted him to write ''M.
Butterfly.'' Here was the incredible true-life tale of a career French foreign service officer brought to ruin - conviction for espionage - by a bizarre 20-year affair with a Beijing Opera diva.
Not only had the French diplomat failed to recognize that his lover was a spy; he'd also failed to figure out that ''she'' was a he in drag. ''It was dark, and she was very modest,'' says Gallimard (John Lithgow), Mr.
Hwang's fictionalized protagonist, by half-joking way of explanation.
When we meet him in the prison cell where he reviews his life, Gallimard has become, according to own understatement, ''the patron saint of the socially inept.''

Air Canada-Airbus Deal
LEAD: Air Canada is near agreement with Europe's Airbus Industrie to buy 34 short-haul A320 airliners and take options on 20 more in a contract worth more than 10 billion francs, or about $1.75 billion, the newspaper Le Monde said Friday.

Falklands Ferry Planned
LEAD: A group of Falklands fishing companies plans to open the first ferry service between the South Atlantic archipelago and the South American mainland since the war between Britain and Argentina in 1982.
A spokesman for the consortium, which has raised $1.8 million to buy a suitable vessel, said today that it would operate a passenger and cargo service between the Falklands and Montevideo, Uruguay, and Punta Arenas, Chile.

LEAD: Two weeks before the start of another season, his eighth in the major leagues, Mookie Wilson is in the same place he said last July he didn't want to be: still with the Mets, still platooning in center field with Lenny Dykstra.
The difference is, last season he openly talked about wanting to be traded and this spring he talks about it only when asked.

The chain has been using newspapers since it started a quarter-century ago.

LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.99 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of 1.2 percent from the previous week's 1.97 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 92.7 percent of capacity for the week, compared with 91.6 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: Eric Gregg and some other National League umpires will have a new look this season.

Overweight umpires became the source of jokes at last year's World Series.

F.A.A. to Add Flight Coordinator To Improve Air Safety at Chicago
LEAD: Seeking to halt errors by air traffic controllers that have caused a disturbing number of near-collisions at O'Hare International Airport, Chicago, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it would assign another full-time air traffic coordinator to the airport tower.


Woman Struck by 4 Vehicles
LEAD: A woman crossing a street here Sunday was struck by four vehicles and killed, the police said.
The woman, Janell Bankhead, 25 years old, was first hit by a van as she walked across a street about 12:30 A.M.
She tried to get up, but a pickup truck heading in the opposite direction struck her.
She was then hit by two other vans.


Dollar Off in Quiet Trading; Gold Up $5.45 in New York
LEAD: The dollar fell against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar in quiet trading yesterday, mirroring a selloff in both the stock and bond markets.

Judge John H. Pratt of the Federal District Court in Washington, who earlier this month had found Eastern in contempt of an injunction he issued last year against the sale or transfer of its assets, said he would fine Eastern $10,000 a day starting April 5 if it continued to violate his order.

Goodrich Order
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has ruled that the B. F. Goodrich Company's acquisition of the Diamond Shamrock Plastics Corporation in 1981 breached antitrust rules and ordered Goodrich to sell a chemical plant in La Porte, Tex.
The plant manufactures vinyl chloride monomer, which is used to produce such plastic goods as irrigation pipes and phonograph records.


Ford-South Korea
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company will begin exporting its Lincoln Continental and Mercury Sable models to South Korea this spring, the company said.
A Ford spokeswoman, Pam Kueber, said the initial volumes would be small, in part because South Korea's import duties would raise the cars' retail prices to about three times those in America, which are about about $28,000 for the Continental and $15,000 for the Sable.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Troops in Slow Motion
LEAD: The 82d Airborne Division has a reputation for its ability to be dispatched anywhere in the world within hours.
It took less than 10 hours for two battalions, flown from Pope Air Force Base, N.C., to arrive in Honduras last week.

Sale By McGraw-Hill
LEAD: A Dutch publisher, Verenigd Bezit VNU said today that its subsidiary, VNU Business Publications Inc. had purchased a McGraw-Hill Inc. magazine, Electronics, for an undisclosed sum.
Electronics, aimed at management in the electronics industry, employs 35 people and has a circulation of 135,000.
VNU said the magazine was a better fit in its organization than in McGraw-Hill's.

2d Honda Plant in U.S.
LEAD: Honda broke ground on Sunday for a second United States auto assembly plant.
The plant is scheduled to open in August 1989, company officials said.
The $380 million factory will employ 1,800 workers and have the capacity to proaduce 150,000 cars a year.
Honda began manufacturing in the United States in 1979 at its motorcycle plant in Marysville, 35 miles northwest of Columbus.

LEAD: Ciriaco de Mita, a balding, voluble man who likes to play cards with his cronies after lunch, is poised to become the most powerful politician in Italy, but he is not very happy about the prospect.


Judge Bars Shifting of Air Shuttle
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Eastern Air Lines Inc. to abandon its plans to sell or transfer its shuttle to its parent, the Texas Air Corporation.


Bid Made for Kansas City Southern
LEAD: An investor group led by a New York real estate developer today offered $60 a share to acquire Kansas City Southern Industries, the railroad, data-processing and financial-services concern.

LEAD: *
American Express Bank Ltd. is issuing 100 million Swiss francs of 4 1/2 percent Eurobonds with a maturity of seven years at a price of 100 3/4, through its Trade Development Bank unit.


Navy Said to Be Concerned By Sub Data Going to Canada
LEAD: The United States Navy remains concerned about the prospective transfer of nuclear-submarine technology to Canada, William L. Ball 3d, the nominee for secretary of the Nay, said today at his confirmation hearing.


Performers' Unions Strike The Makers of Commercials
LEAD: The actors and announcers who make commercials went on strike nationwide today after contract talks were deadlocked over cable television residuals and cost-of-living adjustments.


Sports of The Times; Joey Meyer's 582-Foot Homer
LEAD: DURING the 1953 season, Mickey Mantle hit a home run that sailed over the center-field stands at Griffith Stadium in Washington.
As soon as the ball disappeared, Arthur (Red) Patterson hurried out of the press box.
Upon his return, but without any scientific evidence, the Yankees' public-relations director announced that the ball had soared 565 feet.

Argentine Is Accused in U.S. Of a Key Role in 'Dirty War'
LEAD: A former Argentine general was described at an extradition hearing here today as ''the essential linchpin'' in transmitting orders for the torture and disappearance of thousands of Argentine civilians under military rule.


'The Sun' Is Removed From Met's Staircase
LEAD: The Metropolitan Museum has taken down ''The Sun,'' a hanging sculpture by Richard Lippold that was installed for a week's trial over its Great Staircase. ''We are in the process of mulling it over,'' a Met spokesman said. ''At some point in the next several weeks we will decide what to do with it.


Uncovered Short Sales Up Sharply on Exchanges
LEAD: Both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange yesterday reported sharp increases in their '' short interest' ' for the month ended last Tuesday, March 15.


Bogus Threats Suspected in Indian Case
LEAD: The United States Attorney for New Jersey asked a judge yesterday in Newark for a rehearing of extradition proceedings against two Indians accused of being terrorists, saying that the prosecutor he assigned to the case appeared to have fabricated death threats against herself.


Hospital Shortages Hurt Patient Care in New York
LEAD: New York's health-care system is suffering extraordinary shortages of beds, workers and money that are curtailing access to treatment and jeopardizing the quality of patient care, according to medical experts.


A Genial Fischer-Dieskau Reflects on Life and Lieder
LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's song recital at Carnegie Hall tonight will be his first in America since 1980.
His long absence only serves to make him seem even more a living legend; he has been singing professionally for 41 years and has been world-famous for most of them.
His art and style have virtually defined lieder singing (even when they provide a model to be reacted against) for a whole generation of singers.


Robert Brustein Wins Drama Criticism Award
LEAD: Robert Brustein, theater critic for The New Republic, has won the 1987 George Jean Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism.
Mr.
Brustein, who also is artistic director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and professor of English at Harvard University, won the award in 1962 and is the first person to receive it twice.


Gil Evans, a Key Jazz Composer And Orchestrator, Is Dead at 75
LEAD: Gil Evans, one of America's great jazz composers and arrangers, died of peritonitis Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where he had gone to recover from prostate surgery.
He was 75 years old.


U.S. Discounts Noriega's Offer to Quit
LEAD: With President Reagan calling again for the ouster of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama, Administration officials today dismissed General Noriega's offer to resign by 1989, calling it a ploy.

Officials Call Border Dispute An Obstacle in Afghan Talks
LEAD: A border dispute between Afghanistan and Pakistan has emerged as a new obstacle to a treaty ending the Afghan civil war and allowing the withdrawal of Soviet troops, according to officials close to the negotiations.


Food: True and False
LEAD: To The Living Section:


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: IN French terminology, a dish with tomatoes, garlic, olive oil, peppers, olives and saffron is considered to come from the Mediterranean regional tradition.
Such dishes are gaining in popularity, and chicken is one of the easiest and most appropriate foods to cook in Mediterranean style.


Review/Theater; Some Romans and Countrymen Conspire Anew to Murder Caesar
LEAD: The worst thing that ever happened to ''Julius Caesar'' was its adoption by teachers nationwide as the ninth-grade student's ideal introduction to Shakespeare.
In countless classrooms, ''Julius Caesar'' became the play that was Good for You - a sodden launching pad for earnest discussions about the perils of democracy, despotism, mob rule and .


Pravda Writer Disavows Article on Armenia
LEAD: An Armenian correspondent for Pravda has disavowed an article published over his signature, an article that dashed Armenian hopes for a favorable resolution of territorial demands.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man was sentenced to three to nine years in prison yesterday for a 1986 automobile crash that killed a couple on the Interborough Parkway.

LEAD: The Israel Chamber Orchestra is a finely polished ensemble with a lovely string sound and winds that play firmly and precisely.
Like most orchestras, it has its strengths and weaknesses in matters of repertory, and its director, Yoav Talmi, let us see some of each in a Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie


Bike Riding Is In, Winter Is Out
LEAD: Charlie Colon riding his bike around the Unisphere in Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens as the temperature reached 43 degrees yesterday.
Today's temperature is expected to climb to 52. (NYT/Barton Silverman)


Democrats Abroad Pick Dukakis in London Vote
LEAD: In this lonely outpost of the American political campaign, a band of Democrats trickled into a polling place in the shadow of Westminster Abbey today and helped pick Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis as their choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination.


Review/Film; Interchangeable Families In Hi-Tech Black Comedy
LEAD: Video cameras and monitors watch over the characters in Atom Egoyan's ''Family Viewing'' with the patience and passivity of vultures, but without the enthusiasm.
The advent of this modern technology seems to have drained all vitality out of the participants in Mr.
Egoyan's very peculiar black comedy, and it's their listlessness that makes them so funny and sad.


Head of E.P.A. Bars Nazi Data In Study on Gas
LEAD: The chief of the Environmental Protection Agency, alerted by a letter of protest from agency scientists, has barred from an E.P.A. report on a toxic gas any data that the Nazis acquired in experiments on concentration camp prisoners.


Oil Declines On Silence By OPEC
LEAD: The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries called off a news conference today, and his action pushed oil prices down.
He had been expected to announce measures to bolster prices.


Art Historian Goes on Trial In Theft of Documents
LEAD: Charles Merrill Mount, a scholar and art historian who is charged with transporting documents stolen from the Library of Congress and National Archives, went on trial today, denying the allegations but predicting he would be convicted.

The head of the contra delegation, Adolfo Colero, said that progress had been made.

LEAD: John T. De Palma , former chairman of Republic National Bank of New York in the mid-1970's, died Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
He was 76 years old and lived in Cranford, N.J.

And on March 13, when the Tar Heels lost the title game of the Atlantic Coast Conference Tournament for the third time in four years, that talk surfaced again.

Metro Datelines; Democrat Is Winner In Suffolk Recount
LEAD: Democrat Robert Sweeney defeated Republican James Caples by 43 votes in the race for the state Assembly seat in the 11th District in Suffolk County, the Board of Elections announced yesterday after a recount of the vote.


Securities 'Fingerprinted' to Halt Fraud
LEAD: SINCE the famous paper crunch of the late 1960's, the securities industry has been searching for new ways to guard against counterfeiting of stocks and bonds.
Placing special codes that a computer reads on the certificates has caused problems because computers read only the codes and cannot distinguish between bona fide certificates and good imitations.

LEAD: Keith P. Fischer, the former president of a number of agencies, has added still another agency to the list.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man was sentenced to three to nine years in prison yesterday for a 1986 automobile crash that killed a Bronx couple on the Interborough Parkway.


EATING WELL
LEAD: ALTHOUGH it's not absolutely necessary to have special kitchen equipment to turn typical American meals into healthful ones, some appliances can make the job easier.
Since one of the most frequently heard complaints is that nutritionally sound food takes too long to prepare, anything to make the job more efficient is a plus.


Banned in Annapolis
LEAD: James H. Webb Jr., who angrily quit last month as Secretary of the Navy, is still a popular man on campus at the Naval Academy in Annapolis.
Seven years ago Mr.
Webb, a 1968 graduate of the Academy, wrote a fictional novel, ''Sense of Honor,'' based on his experiences at Annapolis as a midshipman.


First Boston Is Penalized
LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that its market surveillance committee had censured and fined the First Boston Corporation and one of its managing directors for trade-reporting violations.

LEAD: *
American General Corp., Houston, a provider of financial services, named Joe D. Heusi president and chief executive of Maryland Casualty Co., Baltimore, its principal property-liability insurance company.


Proposal for a Food Cut Assailed
LEAD: Members of a Senate committee today criticized the Agriculture Department for a proposed budget cut that would eliminate financing for the distribution of surplus food to the poor.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Hunter College announced yesterday that Jeff Bieder resigned as basketball coach after four seasons in which his teams had a record of 58-52, including a 17-12 mark this season.
Bieder has taken a job as basketball coach at Long Island City High School. . . .
Bobby Dodd, the former Georgia Tech football coach, has been released from an Atlanta hospital after undergoing chemotherapy.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL  CHICAGO (NL) - Placed Mike Mason, pitcher, on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.
PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Traded Jeff Stone and Keith Hughes, outfielders, and Rick Schu, infielder, to the Baltimore Orioles for Mike Young, outfielder, and a minor-league player to be named later.

LEAD: ''There's no change,'' Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis protested as he pledged his support for tough new trade legislation.


Japan Fines Toshiba Unit for Sales to Soviet
LEAD: A Japanese court today found the Toshiba Machine Company guilty of selling militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, but it imposed a light fine on the company and gave suspended prison terms to two former executives.


Mexico's Foreign Aid Plan
LEAD: Mexico today announced a 10-point financial aid program for Central America, including an innovative debt-relief plan, aimed at helping the war-torn countries rebuild their economies.


Campeau Raises Its Offer Again
LEAD: Seeking a knockout blow in its battle to win Federated Department Stores, the Campeau Corporation made higher offers to both Federated's shareholders and board yesterday.


Southland Borrows From a Licensee
LEAD: The Southland Corporation said today that it was raising $320 million for its recent leveraged buyout through a loan from its convenience-store licensee in Japan.


Gooden, Police File Suits
LEAD: Charging in legal documents that the city had inadequately trained the police officers who he said punched and taunted him, Dwight Gooden of the Mets is suing the city of Tampa and three officers who arrested him after a scuffle Dec. 13, 1986.


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 23, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


THE PRESIDENTIAL PEN, THE CONGRESSIONAL ERASER
LEAD: President Reagan likes to warn Congress that his ''veto pen'' is ready whenever Congress is considering legislation he opposes, but the record shows that he has vetoed far fewer bills than some of his predecessors did.
Following are the top Presidents for vetoes cast and those overridden by Congress, which requires a two-thirds vote by each house.


Lethargic Bonds Ignore Reports
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were virtually unchanged yesterday as traders shrugged off several items of economic news that on other days might have started a rally.


Business Technology; Advances; Silicon Chips Are Promising A New Era for Computers
LEAD: COMPUTER memory technology is advancing so rapidly that some engineers believe that in the next decade silicon chips will begin to replace magnetic disks as the main way of storing information in computers.


6th Next Wave Festival To Open With Epic Play
LEAD: The Brooklyn Academy of Music announced yesterday that its sixth annual Next Wave Festival would open on Oct. 19 with ''The Warrior Ant,'' an epic work, conceived as a Japanese Bunraku play, by Lee Breuer and Bob Telson.
The play traces the life of a mythical warrior ant, using Afro-Caribbean songs, dance and puppetry.


Record Regained
LEAD: Janet Evans being congratulated yesterday after setting the 800-meter freestyle world record in Orlando, Fla.
Page A24. (AP)


INSIDE
LEAD:  F.B.I. Harassment Charged


Review/Television; 'The City Never Sleeps'
LEAD: The night has a thousand eyes, but thank heavens most are friendly.
In ''The City Never Sleeps,'' nighttime in New York is inviting.
The WNBC-TV film, on Channel 4 at 7:30 tonight, says darkness brings an eccentric congeniality to the streets.
Even if that's not all it brings, the film is amusing.


Mayor's Nominee Voted To the Landmarks Panel
LEAD: Mayor Koch's nominee from Staten Island to the Landmarks Preservation Commission was approved by the City Council yesterday, ending a 14-month battle by Anthony M. Tung to hold on to the post.


Fire in Bronx Kills 2 People In Crack Den
LEAD: A fire in a Bronx crack den killed two people early yesterday and injured five others, including two people described as squatters who jumped from the roof.
The authorities said that the fire in the city-owned building had been set and classified the deaths as homicides.


FOOD NOTES
LEAD:  Kosher Competition The traditional thick, sweet wine for Passover has considerable competition.
Dozens of dry white and red kosher wines are available, including Champagnes, Chiantis, Beaujolais, Bordeaux whites and reds, and California cabernet sauvignons.


Defense of College Plan Ordered
LEAD: A State Supreme Court Justice, acting on a petition from the police patrolmen's union, has ordered the Koch Administration to defend a new policy that would require candidates for police sergeant to complete 64 units of college credit.


Nets Sink 76ers; Knicks Routed; Mavericks 124, Knicks 105
LEAD: Roy Tarpley set a club record with 24 rebounds and scored a career-high 29 points tonight, leading the Dallas Mavericks to a 124-105 victory over the Knicks.


Sacred and Secular In Easter Celebrations; Lamb Dishes Of Old World Affirm Tradition
LEAD: LAMB has not been high in favor in this country in recent years, and mutton, its adult counterpart, is almost entirely unknown in modern butcher shops.
Once a feature of Colonial banquets, a boned leg of mutton slowly spit-roasted before a bank of embers is something few of us will have the good fortune to taste.


ISRAEL SAYS ARABS UNDER DETENTION NOW NUMBER 3,000
LEAD: Israel said today that it was detaining 3,000 Palestinians in connection with the protests in the occupied territories, including 700 arrested in the last week alone.


A Tender Lamb Dish For a Passover Seder
LEAD: LAMB has been a traditional springtime food in the Middle East since Biblical times.
It is appropriate to serve lamb for Passover, but rules govern the preparation, and are subject to various interpretations.


The Message of a Vigilante Killing
LEAD: Mayor Koch rightly denounces the gang that pursued, beat and fatally injured an alleged thief in East Harlem.
But city and community leaders dare not ignore the frustration behind the crime.


NEW DOUBTS RAISED ON AGENT ORANGE
LEAD: A new Air Force report has raised questions about some conclusions of an often-cited 1984 Government study that was supposed to be ''reassuring'' for Vietnam veterans exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange.


Taipei Halts Work on Secret Plant To Make Nuclear Bomb Ingredient
LEAD: Under pressure from the United States, Taiwan has stopped work on a secret installation that could have been used to obtain plutonium, a main ingredient in nuclear weapons, according to Administration officials.

LEAD: The Black &amp; Decker Corporation yesterday called off its takeover bid for American Standard Inc., in return for a $25 million payment from Kelso &amp; Company, which last week agreed to buy Standard for $2.5 billion.

Texaco Clears Hurdles As Court Hears Plan
LEAD: As a Federal bankruptcy judge began final hearings today on the reorganization plan of Texaco Inc., the company said two potential obstacles to ending its yearlong bankruptcy had been removed.


John A. Maurer, 83, A Holder of 60 Patents
LEAD: John A. Maurer, an inventor who developed 16- and 8-millimeter sound recording and reproduction systems, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J.
He was 83 years old and lived in Somerset, N.J.


Real Estate; Architectural Double Role In Manhattan
LEAD: EVEN among the high-rise structures now going up in the west midtown section of Manhattan, the 55-story residential structure nearing completion on Eighth Avenue at 57th Street is a standout.

LEAD: Phil Stinnie matched his career high with 34 points and Virginia Commonwealth eliminated the defending champion, Southern Mississippi, from the National Invitation Tournament with a 93-89 victory tonight.


Education; What Parents Should Ask Before Prepaying College Tuition
LEAD: Tuition prepayment programs allow parents to pay a flat fee now that will cover the future cost of college at a given school when their child is ready to enroll.
The programs guarantee that the child's education will be paid for, regardless of tuition increases in the intervening years.  *
Is there a maximum annual amount that can be contributed?


Nets Sink 76ers; Knicks Routed; Nets 102, 76ers 90
LEAD: Roy Hinson did not miss a shot from the field for the Nets, and Charles Barkley missed the entire second half for Philadelphia tonight as the Nets came away with a 102-90 victory at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.


2 Medals for Baker
LEAD: President Reagan presented a new Presidential Medal of Freedom to the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., on Monday after the original was lost in a break-in at the Baker home in northwest Washington.
Mr.
Baker ''is probably the only person who has received two Medals of Freedom,'' a White House spokesman said.

LEAD:  Ruben Blades's 'Truth'


Stop &amp; Shop Workers Agree to End Strike
LEAD: A settlement was reached early today ending a one-day strike by thousands of Stop &amp; Shop supermarket workers in Connecticut and in western Massachusetts, a company spokeswoman said.


Soviet-Bloc Energy Sales
LEAD: The Soviet bloc's exports of energy to the West grew last year, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.
Gas deliveries rose 5.4 percent, oil 3.7 percent and coal 1.3 percent.
The bloc's biggest customer, West Germany, took 22 percent of the total.


For Hockey Players, Call of the Kitchen
LEAD: Hockey players, who spend half their season on the road and often have several days of free time between games, eat in restaurants almost as much as they play on the ice.
It's no wonder that so many have entered the restaurant business as a sideline to their profession.


U.S. Files Suit Against P.L.O. to Shut U.N. Mission
LEAD: The United States filed a lawsuit in Federal court in Manhattan today in an attempt to force the Palestine Liberation Organization to shut its observer mission to the United Nations.

LEAD: DeAndra Anrig was flying a kite when it suddenly started to fly her, her parents say.

Fain Arrested
LEAD: Ferris Fain, the American League batting champion in 1951 and 1952, is being held without bail in Placerville, Calif., after deputies raided his home last Thursday and arrested him when they found more than 400 marijuana plants, according to Lieut.
Howard Wilson of the El Dorado County Sheriff's office.

LEAD: The price tag for four years of college will approach $80,000 at some of the nation's campuses next September, about the cost of a modest house in many parts of the country.

Postal Rates Are Going Up; Mailing a Letter to Cost 25/
LEAD: With a pledge of better service, the Postal Service said today that it would institute higher postage rates, including a 25-cent charge for first-class letters, beginning April 3.


Woman Asserts F.B.I. Tried To Force a Lie About Agent
LEAD: A Pennsylvania woman has accused the Federal Bureau of Investigation of trying to coerce her into making false and damaging statements about a black F.B.I. agent who had brought charges of racism against the bureau.


The M Line and the Hemline: Miniskirt Protocols
While standing, smooth down as much fabric as possible with both hands.
Then cross the knees, bend and sit.
Optional precaution: place purse over lap.
This peculiar choreography is the daily routine for women wearing miniskirts -- extremely short miniskirts -- as they try to grab a subway seat with all the grace and modesty they can muster.

LEAD: Joseph S. Tushinsky, a former audio-industry executive, inventor and musician, died of pneumonia at his home in Encino, Calif., Monday.
He was 78 years old.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: Anna Quindlen's column will appear regularly on page C2 in The Home Section starting tomorrow.


Notrees Journal; Here's a Town That Time, and Also Trees, Forgo
LEAD: In an act of hope, determination or just plain boredom, Kim Baumguardner and her husband, Sam, are planting trees in this dusty West Texas town.
Two tiny shrubs, all but hidden by barbed wire, sit in the center of a newly purchased plot next to the Baumguardner home.
Mrs.
Baumguardner's best friend used to live there.


Swedes Expel Palestinians
LEAD: Four Palestinians who had sought political asylum in Sweden were ordered expelled today for undisclosed security reasons, Erik Lempert, a senior official of the Labor Ministry, said.
The order was issued after Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson's Government met in a special session to consider their appeal against a ruling by police and immigration authorities that they leave the country, he said.


Gabon Debt Rescheduled
LEAD: The Paris Club of Western creditor nations has agreed to reschedule Gabon's foreign debt.
The French Finance Ministry, acting as spokesman for club negotiations, said in a statement today that Gabon's new payments would be made over 10 years, including a five-year grace period.


Boy, 3, Is Found Scalded to Death
LEAD: The body of a 3-year-old boy who was apparently scalded to death was found yesterday by the police in a Manhattan welfare hotel, the police said.


Education; Manhattan College Seeks a New Kind of Student
LEAD: For much of its 135-year history, Manhattan College was the bootstrap used by many blue-collar Irish and Italian families to achieve a better life.
But as those groups continue to climb the social ladder, Manhattan College finds itself looking to to two new groups to survive and grow - children of the affluent and of the urban poor.

LEAD: The Senate has refused to cancel a new 30-year nuclear cooperation agreement with Japan that critics say could promote the spread of nuclear weapons.

China Seeks TV Loans
LEAD: China is seeking foreign loans to help finance the production of more color television sets to meet growing domestic demand, bankers reported today.
They said the state-owned Bank of China was sounding out foreign banks for loans totaling $270 million to expand production of color television tubes and glass bulbs.

6 Artists Get Awards
LEAD: Six American artists - Christopher Brown, James DeMartino, Susan Hauptman, Albert York, Daisy Youngblood and Susan Lichtman -have been honored for their work by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.
Each artist will receive a $5,000 cash award at a ceremony in May.
More than 100 works by the six artists are on view through March 27 at the academy's galleries, on Audubon Terrace between 155th and 156th streets.

He was 74 years old Dr.
Steptoe's family said he had been suffering from cancer.

Bonus in Tennis
LEAD: The Men's Tennis Council has approved a bonus system designed to combat competition from lucrative exhibition events that conflict with official Grand Prix tournaments. ''We want to eliminate the confusion caused when other events clash with Grand Prix tournaments in which players are competing for world rankings,'' said Marshall Happer, administrator of the council.

LEAD: A fire that started in a kitchen raged across Lashio, a northern Burmese city, killing 113 people and leaving 20,000 homeless, the Government radio reported tonight.

New York's Elections Board: Portrait Of a Hobbled Agency
LEAD: The New York State Board of Elections, under criticism recently for its apparent laxity, conducts such cursory examinations of campaign filings that violators of the state's contribution limits are almost never caught and even blatant discrepancies in campaign accounts are often not investigated.


Uneasiness on South Africa Helps Platinum Soar Again
LEAD: Platinum future prices surged a second straight day yesterday at the New York Mercantile Exchange as uneasiness about inflation and South Africa rippled through the markets.


McGreevey Seems Set To Exit On His Terms
After revealing on national television that he is gay, seeing his name become the punch line of countless late-night comedy gags, and fending off a coup attempt from within his own party, Gov.
James E. McGreevey needs only to remain in office until midnight Friday to outlast the state deadline that would automatically force a special election to choose his successor.
Mr.
McGreevey announced on Aug. 12 that he was stepping down because he had had an extramarital affair with a man he did not identify, but his insistence on remaining in office until Nov. 15 set off political, legal and public relations challenges.


Superconductor and Silicon: Promising Marriage Is Seen
LEAD: SCIENTISTS at the General Electric Company have come a step closer to marrying the new high-temperature superconductors to silicon-based integrated circuits by depositing a superconducting thin film on a silicon wafer.
Superconductivity is the ability of a substance to carry electricity without resistance.

LEAD: In sharp contrast to recent practice, the Iran-Iraq war has become focused on offensives far from the major battlefronts on land that Teheran views as decisive in determining the eventual victor.


Serious Crime Rises Again in New York
LEAD: For the second year in a row, the number of serious crimes in New York City rose in 1987, with murders up 5.7 percent and aggravated assaults up 12.1 percent, according to Police Department figures released yesterday.

Education; Lessons
LEAD: In some way, the education of every college student in the country is financed from the public trough.
Taxes pay tuition, taxes buy books, taxes build buildings.
We provide subsidies because, as Jefferson instructed, higher education is for the common good: It trains the country's professionals, improves morals, and forms in students the ''habits of reflection and correct action, rendering them examples of virtue to others, and of happiness within themselves.

Sacred and Secular In Easter Celebrations; Family Holiday Isn't What It Used to Be
LEAD: EASTER is the misfit among American holidays.
In principle it is the most important date in the Christian calendar, but its religious significance has been its secular undoing.
The country, it seems, is too religious and too Christian to ignore Easter, but also too pluralist and too secular to absorb it comfortably as a national holiday.

Is airline competition dying, a victim of increased market concentration and monopoly pricing?

Review/Theater; New American Plays Surface in Louisville
LEAD: In an attempt to revitalize the Humana Festival of New American Plays, Jon Jory commissioned plays from three name writers, guaranteeing them production in the 1988 festival.

For Health Survey, Many Offer More Excuses Than Details
New York City's ambitious effort to give physical exams and blood tests to more than 2,000 people has run into unexpected trouble getting residents to participate, especially in affluent areas.
City health officials hope to use the results to compile a detailed portrait of the city's health, but that means getting a representative sampling from each neighborhood.
Two months into the effort, they have found that New Yorkers, particularly in well-off neighborhoods, are too busy, too wary and just too hard to reach.

House Roll-Call Overriding Reagan's Veto of Civil Rights Bill
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 292 to 133 by which the House of Representatives today overrode President Reagan's veto off a civil rights bill.
A ''yes'' vote was a vote to override the veto and enact the law.
A ''no'' vote was a vote against it.
Voting ''yes'' were 240 Democrats and 52 Republicans.

Small Synthetic Spheres That Can Improve a Kiss
LEAD: IMAGINE a lipstick that moisturized every time a woman puckered up or kissed, or a foot powder that provided more antifungal relief with every step.
These are two of many applications now possible with microsponges, microscopic synthetic spheres that can be ''programmed'' to release cosmetic or pharmaceutical agents in response to pressure, time or temperature.

Ringling Brothers Celebrates The Classic Clowning Moments
LEAD: It's no fun inside a burning clown house, even while the audience is shrieking with laughter.
Shotgun shells keep going off, black-powder smoke squibs keep detonating, and puffs of flame keep exploding alarmingly.
No wonder, then, that clowns will go to almost any lengths to escape: They'll go so far as to jump into a net held by a clown fire brigade.


Court Eases Bar to Embassy Protests
LEAD: The Supreme Court, striking down key portions of a 50-year-old law, today cleared the way for protesters to conduct hostile demonstrations near foreign embassies in the District of Columbia as long as they do not disrupt embassy activities or threaten security.

Orders for Durable Goods Declined 1.8% in February
LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories for durable goods fell 1.8 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today.
Although it was the second consecutive monthly decline, analysts said it did not shake their belief that manufacturing will be a bright spot in the economy this year.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  SKIING  Another Victory for Tomba: Alberto Tomba of Italy captured his sixth World Cup slalom victory of the season yesterday, finishing just ahead of Tetsuya Okabe of Japan in Oppdal, Norway.
Tomba had runs of 57.30 seconds and 55.45, for a combined time of 1 minute 52.75 seconds, 55-hundredths of a second faster than Okabe's.

LEAD: Congress has wisely and firmly turned back one of the most important political challenges to civil rights in recent years.
The vote to override President Reagan's veto of the Civil Rights Restoration Act reconfirms a solid bipartisan consensus in Congress.
It also catches the Reagan Administration, once again, on the wrong side of a civil rights issue.

Satan Worshiper Rebuffed
LEAD: A Federal magistrate has denied a prisoner's request for materials to worship Satan, ruling that Satanism is not a religion and that the knitting needles the prisoner wanted for bloodletting would pose a security risk.
The Satan worshiper, Charles McCorkle, serving a 40-year sentence at the maximum-security Holman Prison for three burglary convictions, had filed a lawsuit in which he sought access to the knitting needles and to books on the occult.

Stormy Style for Bergeron
LEAD: At one point in the Rangers' 3-2 loss to the Sabres Tuesday night, Michel Bergeron stood on his bench, screaming into a hushed and humbled Madison Square Garden and swinging a stick against the boards.
At another point, he prowled the corridor underneath the stands, berating Bob Hall, the referee, and shaking his fists in disgust.


Savings Up in Japan
LEAD: The average Japanese household in a recent survey had $82,000 in savings at the end of last year, up 14.9 percent from a year earlier, according to a Government report published today.
It was the biggest annual savings increase since 1979, when the rise was 15.5 percent.

LEAD: Cancer patients whose bone marrow had been destroyed by therapy regained marrow after receiving injections of their own blood cells, suggesting an alternative to marrow transplants, according to a study issued here today.

Review/Recital; Fischer-Dieskau: The Return of a Meistersinger
LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau probably did not come out of the egg singing ''Die Schone Mullerin'' or ''Dichterliebe,'' but hardly a man alive remembers when the German baritone was anything less than a fully formed master of the song literature.
His career, now 40 years along, has defied tradition in rejecting the stereotype of the lieder artist as a great singer in decline.

Drought Expected at Lake Tahoe
LEAD: The Tahoe Queen steamship cruising on Lake Tahoe, on the Nevada-California border.
After seven snowless weeks combined with warmer than normal temperatures, the March snowpack is way below what it normally at this time, which is normally the peak of the year.
Experts believe the lake will drop to its lowest level since the 1976-77 drought.


Pakistanis Fear Afghans Will Stay
LEAD: Impervious to the present, ageless caravans of nomads are leading their camels across the barren plateau around this dusty garrison town in the desert, heading toward summer pasture even higher than Quetta's 5,500 feet above the distant sea.
They hardly seem to notice the new nomads, who have - temporarily, perhaps - taken possession of much of the land.

LEAD: Over a bitter dissent, the Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law denying food stamps to striking workers and their households unless they are poor enough to qualify before going on strike.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error in some editions, an article yesterday about superdelegates to the Demcoratic National Convention misstated the number of House and Senate members whose office entitles them to be delegates.
The total is 253, not 53.

LEAD: Letters written by Mark Twain in his formative years - nearly half of them never before published and many of them appearing in full for the first time rather than excerpted - will enable scholars and readers to trace the origins of some of the writer's major novels and stories.

LEAD: Horace Rumpole is back.
Despite periodic public protestations from John Mortimer, the writer, and Leo McKern, the actor, that the barrister is just about played out, the grumpy old darling is once again shuttling between legal chambers and Pomeroy's pub, where it is his pleasure to quaff the house wine, sometimes referred to as Chateau Thames Embankment.

Review/Pop; Ruth Brown Before Rock
LEAD: The initials R and B, Ruth Brown points out at the beginning of her nightclub act, don't stand for just rhythm-and-blues.
They are also her initials.
And although Miss Rhythm, as she has been nicknamed, doesn't come right out and say it, as much as any female singer of the early 1950's she stamped her signature on the broad-based black style that immediately preceded rock-and-roll.


Islanders Rise to The Top
LEAD: The Islanders who began a five-game road trip in third place, ended it tonight in first place.
New York routed the Los Angeles Kings, 6-2, helped by two goals from Bryan Trottier, and moved past the Washington Capitals to the top of the Patrick Division.


Saint Laurent: Successes In a Quiet Key
LEAD: If fashion is indeed embarking on a sober, straight and narrow path for fall, Yves Saint Laurent will lead the way.
The master of the classic mode, introducing his collection as usual on the last day of the Paris showings, offered wearable clothes on his own terms.
Except for square-crowned and three-tiered hats, they were not propped up with zany accessories.

Gun Charge for Merchant
LEAD: A candy store owner in Elizabeth, N.J., who admitted to fatally shooting one of two men who he said robbed his store on Tuesday, was charged yesterday with purchasing his gun without a permit.
The merchant, Mohamed Taha, 47 years old, was not charged in the shooting, the police said.
The dead man was shot once in the chest in the store and was found 100 yards away with loot.

Review/Rock; High-Volume Country
LEAD: Fish and Roses and Volcano Suns, two entirely different rock groups who played at CBGB's on Saturday, are both obssessed with musical duration.
Fish and Roses, a trio of bass, drums and keyboards, exudes a Lower East Side, populist intellectuality.
It makes everything short: the songs seem as if they stop and start every 15 seconds, vocals are fragmented and used as just another formal element, the same as the next staggering, collapsing riff.

LEAD: Young &amp; Rubicam's London office will be coordinating the international advertising efforts of United International Pictures, which distributes pictures for Paramount, Universal and MGM/UA in 25 nations outside the Western Hemisphere.


House Panel Rebukes Colleague For Loans From Campaign Funds
LEAD: The House ethics committee today sharply rebuked Reprentntative Charlie Rose, Democrat of North Carolina, teter concludi t that he had ivoroperly borrowed funds from his campaign and then failed to publicly report the transactions.


Books of The Times; One Man's Struggle to Accommodate Feminism
LEAD:  One of the Guys  The Wising Up of an American Man  By Harry Stein  269 pages.
Simon &amp; Schuster. $17.95.


The ABC's of DNA: Students Explore Genes and 'Glops'
LEAD: Two dozen high school students working at laboratory tables in an old elementary school in this former whaling village gave new meaning today to the familiar shout, ''Guess what I made in school today?''


Review/Recital; Contemporary Works for the Flute
LEAD: Patricia Spencer, a flutist long active in New York uptown new-music concerts, offered a recital Monday night at Merkin Concert Hall that contained four world premieres and one American premiere.


Air Wis Shake-Up
LEAD: Air Wis Services Inc. has removed its chairman, Arthur G. Hailand Jr., and declared that the company is not for sale.
Mr.
Hailand and John J. Louis Jr., another director, had submitted an unsolicited bid for Air Wis, the parent of Air Wisconsin Inc.
Mr.
Hailand and Mr.
Louis together own about 334,000 shares, or 4.5 percent of the 7.4 million Air Wis shares.


The Race to Save the Ozone Shield
LEAD: The chemical threat to the life-protecting ozone layer in the high atmosphere turns out to be more serious than feared.
The damage may already be three times greater than the worst future loss assumed in a pending international treaty to cap production of the destructive chemicals.
Even stronger measures may soon be needed.


Dow Rises 1.49; Focus on Takeover Stocks
LEAD: As Wall Street's attention focused mostly on takeover-related stocks, blue-chip issues ended with a small gain yesterday.


Review/Opera; Rysanek's Final Sieglinde At the Met
LEAD: Leonie Rysanek's final Sieglinde at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday afternoon was the occasion for a warm outpouring of thanks to a soulful, beloved artist, and the good will that flowed all around served to keep at bay the depression ordinarily attendant on an inadequate performance of ''Die Walkure.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Brawley Books Found


U.N. Assembly Assails U.S. on P.L.O. Mission
LEAD: The General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution today deploring the United States attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission.


Northwest Airlines Bans Smoking on Most Flights
LEAD: In a marketing gamble, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would ban smoking on all its North American flights.
It is the only smoking ban by a major American airline.


Governor Dukakis Takes a Wrong Turn
LEAD: Conventional punditry has Gov.
Michael Dukakis typed as not very exciting.
But hark!
Having repeatedly skewered one of his main rivals in the Presidential primaries for preaching protectionism on foreign trade, he now veers in that direction himself.
And in the grand tradition of Presidential candidates - and


Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: A FEW years ago, a friend asked his father if he could borrow the car to go to the beach.
His father thought about it, asked some questions and finally said no.
He did not trust his son to make such a trip by himself.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.We recently moved into an old house that has a finished attic.
The roof insulation goes right up to the peak, with a vapor barrier under the insulation, then gypsum board covering this.
This gypsum board is covered with mildew.


Track Group Bars Budd From Racing
LEAD: Zola Budd, the South African-born runner who is a British citizen, was suspended from international competition yesterday by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, pending a review next month of charges that she competed last year in South Africa.


Massimino At Home In Final 16
LEAD: He is pacing near midcourt, running his left hand through his silver-gray hair, his diamond-filled championship ring sparkling, his players round him executing his commands.


Yields Move Lower Again
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds slipped again in the week ended yesterday.


Southern Responds
LEAD: Kansas City Southern Industries said a letter it had received from the New York investor Howard Kaskel to buy the railroad and data processing company for $60 a share, or $588 million, ''appears to be an effort to stimulate trading in Kansas City Southern stock.'' Mr.
Kaskel leads a group of investors who control 11.3 percent of the common shares.


George Lehr, 51, Dies; Teamsters' Fund Chief
LEAD: George Lehr, a former State Auditor in Missouri who was credited with helping to clean up the scandal-plagued Teamsters Union Central States Pension Fund, died at his home here Monday.

Apple and Microsoft Disclose a 1985 Pact
LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. today made public a previously confidential 1985 agreement that gives Microsoft the right to use certain visual displays available on Macintosh personal computers.
But the companies disagree on the limits of the agreement.


Review/Reggae; One World Is the Message
LEAD: Africans, Jamaicans and Americans of all colors jammed the Ritz for Alpha Blondy's sold-out debut New York performance on Tuesday.
Mr.
Blondy, who is from the Ivory Coast, came through for them all: singing in English, French and several different African languages, and playing the by now universal rhythms of reggae, he put on a solid, even-paced show.

Gardening; Nandinas, a Favorite of the 50's, Make a Comeback
LEAD: THE longer I garden, the more I appreciate plants that really earn their keep, those that are of interest in more than a single season.
I am also increasingly fond of plants that have a place in my childhood memories.


Ford Motor Credit Offers 8 5/8% Notes
LEAD: The Ford Motor Credit Company, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $200 million of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD:  Tennis  Wilander and Connors Gain: Mats Wilander and Jimmy Connors, the top-seeded players, easily advanced yesterday to the semifinals of the Lipton International Players Championships, and Yannick Noah joined them by beating Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union in straight sets at Key Biscayne,


Life in the 30's
LEAD: PERHAPS we all have the same memory of the first boy-girl party we attended.
The floors were waxed, the music loud, the air thick with the smell of cologne.
The boys stood on one side of the room and the girls on the other, each affecting a nonchalance belied by the shuffling male loafers and the occasional high birdlike sound of a female giggle.


Currents; Are You Bored With Biedermeier?
LEAD: AN exhibition of urban design studies by the avant-garde Viennese design firm Coop Himmelblau opens tonight at the Storefront for Art and Architecture (97 Kenmare Street, at Lafayette Street, in SoHo).
This is the first solo show for the architectural firm in the United States, and one of the first exhibitions here of what has been called


Democrats' Race Spotlights 52 Delegates in Connecticut
LEAD: Less than two months ago, when the Presidential candidates were focusing on the Iowa caucuses, the New Hampshire primary and the multiple contests of Super Tuesday, the Connecticut Presidential primary of March 29 was merely a speck on the maps of most campaign strategists.


Home Improvement
LEAD: EVEN if you do only indoor chores around the house, sooner or later you will probably need a ladder.
If you take on outdoor tasks as well, you may wonder how to get along with less than two.


Night Must Fall
LEAD: The white Government of South Africa has turned the screw of repression down ever harder in the last month.
It shut down the country's main anti-apartheid organizations.
It silenced individual leaders.
Now it has banned for three months a leading newspaper opposed to the racial system, The New Nation.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article on the Long Island Lighting Company was missing from page B5 in some editions yesterday, and a duplicate version of an article elsewhere about crack appeared under its headline.
Readers wishing copies of the correct article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y.


Resorts Spurns New Griffin Offer
LEAD: International Inc., the hotel-casino concern with operations in New Jersey and the Bahamas, said its board had rejected a sweetened $295 million takeover bid by Merv Griffin, the entertainer-turned-businessman.


Review/Theater; A Samurai And Death: 4 Versions
LEAD: Going into the woods, as Broadway instructs us this season, can be an unsettling experience.
That lesson is now being offered Off Broadway, too, in the famous Japanese tale of the samurai, the bandit and the woman.
It's ''Rashomon,'' of course, the 1959 play by Fay and Michael Kanin based on Akira Kurosawa's memorable 1951 movie, which was taken from the 1915 stories of Ryunosuke


Dole Assails 'Failure' in Democrats' Foreign Policy
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole said today that the Democratic Presidential candidates had rejected the legacy of Harry S. Truman and John F. Kennedy in the belief that the United States ''must not be too forceful'' and ''must mistrust its own power.''


What to Do With $3 Billion
LEAD: J. Hugh Liedtke, the chairman of the Pennzoil Company, now faces a task others envy -spending the spoils of a settlement unprecedented in size.


Jim Jacobs, Tyson's Co-Manager And Handball Titlist, Dies at 58
LEAD: Jim Jacobs, a boxing historian and a co-manager of Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York.
He was 58 years old.


Gas Company Gives Warning Of an Unstable Contaminant
LEAD: Additional cylinders of silane gas may have been contaminated in the same way as one that exploded at a chemical plant here and killed three people last Thursday, a gas distribution company has warned its customers across the country.

Omaha Journal; The Mayor Fights His Toughest Foe
LEAD: In the dimly lighted basement of Duffy's Tavern, Mayor Bernie Simon was being toasted by a boisterous gathering.


Hard Times Not Over For Texas Real Estate
LEAD: Anyone who thinks that the two-year-old financial crisis in Texas could not get much worse needs to take another look at the real estate markets in the state's biggest cities.


U.S. Rebuffed in Fight for $209
LEAD: Criticizing the Government for spending thousands of dollars on the case, a Federal magistrate has ruled that a man who has Parkinson's disease can keep $209.56 that the Social Security Administration said it overpaid him.


HONDURAS PULLOUT SCHEDULED BY U.S.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that American forces would start leaving Honduras on Monday, about 10 days after they were deployed in response to a Nicaraguan offensive against base camps of the contra rebels.


Harlem Fire Linked to Crack Leaves 40 Homeless
LEAD: A fire classified as arson extensively damaged a seven-story apartment building in Harlem yesterday, leaving 40 people homeless.
Residents said the apartment where the fire began was a crack den.

Controversy on Golf Tour
LEAD: What used to be the Tournament Players Championship is now just the Players Championship, but by any name a tournament is not a major championship unless it is the Masters, the United States Open, the British Open or the P.G.A.
Championship, at least according to Payne Stewart.


Curb Sought in Hawaii On Foreign Investment
LEAD: Mayor Frank Fasi has proposed legislation that would stop foreign investors from purchasing some kinds of property in Hawaii, saying the measure would put an end to soaring housing and real estate costs.


Webb to Sell Gaming Unit
LEAD: In a long-expected restructuring, the Del E. Webb Corporation said today that it would quit the gaming business this year and sell its three hotel-casinos, which analysts said could raise about $160 million.


Cavaliers Catch Nets
LEAD: Dell Curry came off the bench to score 10 of his 22 points during a 21-2 fourth-quarter rally as the Cleveland Cavaliers came back from a 17-point deficit to defeat the New Jersey Nets tonight, 105-96.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: Anna Quindlen's column will appear in this space regularly, beginning today.
The Hers column will now appear in The New York Times Magazine on alternate Sundays, starting March 27.


American Classics, Made in Indonesia
LEAD: IN the sweltering heat of Central Java, almost halfway around the world from the stately homes of England, Eastern and Western traditions are combining to re-create the great furniture classics of 18th-century Europe and early America.


Boesky Set To Enter Jail
LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky is in Federal custody and will probably be assigned to a minimum security prison in Lompoc, Calif., a Bureau of Prisons official said yesterday, one day before the stock speculator was required to surrender.
