The ''trees'' are actually tilt-top tables, classic Chippendale or


German Enthusiasm Builds For Volkswagen Stock Sale
LEAD: All of the West German Government's 4.8 million shares of Volkswagen A.G., which go on sale Thursday, are likely to be bought quickly, analysts predicted today.

OUTLOOK ON ARMS UNCLEAR
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would visit Moscow from May 29 to June 2 for his fourth meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


A Playwright Tells Why Men Will Be Boys
LEAD: ''The basic dynamics between the sexes are essentially unchanged,'' said Howard Korder, the writer of ''Boys' Life,'' a stinging play that has just been extended through June at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.


Pill Bottles Even Grown-Ups Can Open
LEAD: New designs for child-resistant pill containers were shown to safety experts Monday, at the beginning of this year's National Poison Prevention Week.


Reagan Education Budget Is Said to Deprive Needy
LEAD: Despite President Reagan's proposed increases in education spending, millions of needy students will not receive critical educational aid if the President's budget is approved, a coalition of more than 100 groups said today.


George Gilbert, Hotel Owner, 66
LEAD: George Gilbert, co-owner of the Raleigh Hotel in South Fallsburgh, N.Y., died of liver cancer Sunday at New York Hospital.
He was 66 years old and lived in South Nyack, N.Y.

Davis Presses His Lorimar Bid
LEAD: Marvin Davis, growing impatient at the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation's failure to respond to his $771 million conditional offer, wrote a letter to Merv Adelson, Lorimar's chairman, threatening to take unspecified hostile actions.
Company officials declined to comment.


Review/Music; Blues, Indiana Style
LEAD: The Kinsey Report, a blues band consisting of a trio of brothers originally from Gary, Ind., plus a friend, have figured out how to make the three blues chords mean something.
Each instrument takes a different sawtooth rhythm, and together, like a bunch of dancers tearing up the floor to independent versions of one beat, they put on a show.


Cuomo Proclaims West Point Day
LEAD: Governor Cuomo with Brig.
Gen.
Fred Gorden, right, and two cadets from the U.S.
Military Academy at a ceremony where Mr.
Cuomo proclaimed West Point Day.
Noting that he was surrounded by Republican legislators, Mr.
Cuomo said that they ''think of the Democrats as occupation forces.'' (Associated Press)


Two-Hoop Circus at the Meadowlands
LEAD: Some of the refrains are familiar by now.
For instance, John Chaney, the Temple coach, and his Rhode Island counterpart, Tom Penders, talked about the lack of recognition the Atlantic 10 Conference suffers because it does not have a television contract.
And Penders, who has somehow cultivated a deep tan during a winter in Kingston, R.I., was asked once again today whether he would consider another job offer.


Hambletonian Bid
LEAD: Du Quoin, Ill., which from 1957 to 1980 was the home of the Hambletonian, the famous mile race for 3-year-old trotting horses, will make an attempt Saturday to regain race from the Meadowlands race track in East Rutherford, N.J.
The race has been at the Meadowlands since 1981.


Court Lifts Last Hurdle For Texaco
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge in White Plains yesterday approved Texaco Inc.'s plan to emerge from bankruptcy and pay the Pennzoil Company $3 billion to settle the bitter legal dispute that has entangled the two companies for four years.


Assembly Panel Proposes Election Board Changes
LEAD: Saying that the New York State Board of Elections has been poorly managed and lags behind similar agencies in other states, the State Assembly Election Committee plans to recommend that the board begin to audit randomly campaign committees and to enter all campaign contributions into a centralized computer.


Botha Under Fire for Exonerating Soldiers Accused of Killing Black
LEAD: Lawyers and opposition politicians criticized President P. W. Botha today for intervening to prevent the trial of six soldiers charged with murdering a prominent black nationalist in South-West Africa, the South African-run territory also known as Namibia.


Richmond Is Spinning: Spiders Are Winning
LEAD: Inside the auxiliary gym, the drum-laden pep band is blasting out modern-day collegiate battle standards like ''Soul Man'' and the theme from ''Rocky.'' The University of Richmond's sprightly cheerleaders, the Spiderettes, brandish their pompons while the grinning members of the Spider basketball team, on the eve of their departure to take on top-ranked Temple at the


Ted Koppel To Produce His Program
LEAD: ABC News and Ted Koppel, anchor of the late-night program ''Nightline,'' have agreed on an unusual long-term arrangement to keep Mr.
Koppel at the network by making him producer of his own prime-time programs, several ABC executives said yesterday.


Marketing Frank Lloyd Wright
LEAD: Frank Lloyd Wright, a legend during most of his long life, has emerged as a growth industry in the last five years.
A commercial, artistic and academic habitat of conferences, exhibitions, books and objects has recently grown up around the architect - a habitat that is expanding rapidly in unusual ways.


Mecham Trial Hears of Warning About Loan
LEAD: A former top assistant to Gov.
Evan Mecham testified today that she had warned that ''people could possibly go to jail'' over an $80,000 loan to the Governor's automobile dealership from a fund intended for state uses.


Advertising; Arnell/Bickford Adds New Donna Karan Line
LEAD: Arnell/Bickford Associates has apparently been doing a superb job for its client Donna Karan over the last four years, since the apparel maker has now awarded the agency its new DKNY ready-to-wear line.
The budget for the first year is expected to come to $2 million, bringing the Donna Karan business to $4.5 million in billings.


Topics of The Times; Still Too Many Lawyers
LEAD: In a recent letter to the editor, Maryann Saccomando Freedman, president of the New York State Bar Association, took issue with an Editorial Notebook about the frustrations of jury service.
The notebook asserted that one reason for interminable court delays was that most legislators were lawyers loath to vote any court efficiencies that would reduce legal fees.


Review/Ragtime; From a Trove Of Rediscovered Joplin et al.
LEAD: In 1985, Rick Benjamin, a 20-year-old Juilliard student fascinated with ragtime music, stumbled into every enthusiast's dream - an abandoned warehouse packed with rare manuscripts and photographs.
Mr.
Benjamin's find was the library of Arthur Pryor, once a trombonist in the Sousa band and later a conductor, composer and arranger who led a touring band and a recording orchestra.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Soothing a Wound
LEAD: When former Chancellor Willy Brandt came to Washington as head of the West German opposition Social Democratic Party in May 1985, President Reagan, who gets along swimmingly with the conservative Christian Democratic Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, declined to see the opposition leader.


Report to Green Faults Training Given Teachers
LEAD: The training of new teachers by the New York City Board of Education is ''notoriously ineffective,'' and the least experienced teachers are often sent to the city's most troubled schools, according to a report prepared for the new Schools Chancellor, Dr.
Richard R. Green.


Law Students Protest
LEAD: Twenty-eight students at the University of California's Boalt Hall Law School were arrested Tuesday for occupying the dean's office most of the day.
The sit-in was called to protest a lack of women and members of minority groups among tenured faculty.
The protesters said white males accounted for 91 percent of Boalt's 43.5 tenured faculty positions, a percentage exceeded only by the University of Chicago among the nation's leading law schools.


Health; Personal Health
LEAD: If you were among the unfortunate victims of the latest strain of influenza or the mysterious virus that has been prostrating people for up to seven days, you may have considered yourself recovered when the virus retreated, enabling you to return to your usual activities.
But in addition to the expected setbacks of a debilitating illness, your body must now also recover from the effects of the treatment: bed rest.

Lucky Might Try Leveraged Buyout
LEAD: The shares of Lucky Stores Inc. climbed another $2.25, to $49, in New York Stock Exchange trading as analysts said the supermarket chain might be preparing a leveraged buyout to exceed the $45 offer from the American Stores Company.
Lucky, based in Dublin, Calif., has not yet responded to American Stores' $1.74 billion bid, made Tuesday.


Topics of The Times; 'Housekeeping' Shift
LEAD: A loophole in New York State's campaign contributions law exempts from public reporting the tens of thousands of dollars in operating funds that supposedly pay for political parties' staff, rents and other routine expenses.
Investigations suggest that ''housekeeping'' funds are often diverted to pay party officials' campaign or personal expenses.


Honda to Pay $6 Million in Rights Settlement
LEAD: About 370 blacks and women who were turned down for jobs by Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. will receive a total of $6 million from the automobile maker in a settlement of a Federal discrimination case, the Government and Honda announced today.


With Rare Unity, House Approves $1.1 Trillion Budget for 1989
LEAD: In a display of collegiality and bipartisanship rarely seen on budget matters, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a $1.1 trillion budget resolution for the coming fiscal year.


Review/Symphony; Pulitzer Winner's Violin Concerto
LEAD: Stephen Albert, who won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 1985, is often cited as an example of the ''neo-Romantic'' movement.
In the program notes for his violin concerto called ''In Concordiam,'' played Sunday afternoon at the 92nd Street Y, he objects to the appellation and points out that the Romantic strain has never really suffered interruption in the 20th century.


Meese Barred From Inquiry on Black F.B.I. Agent
LEAD: A Federal judge today barred Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the head of the Justice Department's civil rights division from any involvement in a grand jury investigation of racial harassment allegations made by a black agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.


Court Lifts Last Hurdle For Texaco; A Four-Year Battle Ends
LEAD: Following are the highlights of the dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company over Texaco's merger with the Getty Oil Company.
Jan. 3, 1984: Pennzoil's board endorses an agreement to buy 43 percent of Getty Oil, including one billion barrels of crude oil reserves, for $5.3 billion.


Vehicle Sales Up in Mid-March
LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks exceeded last year's level by seven-tenths of a percent in the March 11 to 20 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.


Oil Prices Rise After OPEC Sets a Committee Meeting
LEAD: The pricing committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Vienna in early April to review its audit of oil production, OPEC's president, Rilwanu Lukman, said today.


Carl Hildebrand, Steel Executive, 91
LEAD: Carl Hildebrand, former president of Sandvik Steel Inc. of Fairlawn, N.J., died at his Manhattan home Monday after a long illness.
He was 91 years old.


New Study Questions an Operation to Bar Strokes
LEAD: Ten percent of the elderly Americans who undergo a common operation intended to prevent strokes either die or suffer strokes as a direct result of the surgery, a new study shows.


Woman, 26, Is Killed In Gift Shop She Owned
LEAD: A 26-year-old Brooklyn woman was stabbed to death yesterday in a gift shop she owned in the Canarsie section by an attacker who escaped in her car, the police said.

Fouts Retires
LEAD: As expected, Dan Fouts of the San Diego Chargers, who set several passing records during his National Football League career, announced his retirement yesterday. ''It's just that after 15 years, this body has taken about as many hits as it can,'' the 36-year-old Fouts said. ''I feel fortunate that I have my health intact, that I have all my teeth and that I have a few yet unscrambled brain cells.

LEAD: A third of the nation's 3,147 savings and loan associations lost money last year, giving the industry a record net loss of $6.8 billion, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

LEAD: The Atlanta Braves sold the reserve third baseman Graig Nettles to the Montreal Expos yesterday.
Nettles, 43 years old, a former Yankee, led the National League with 23 pinch-hit runs batted in last year in reserve duty with the Braves.
He was in the Atlanta camp as a nonroster player with a minor-league contract.

LEAD: Southdown Inc. said it would raise its bid for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. a second time, by adding $5 a share worth of Southdown bonds to its $35-a-share offer.

Moore, a cement maker based in Stamford, Conn., has been resisting the overtures of Southdown, a cement maker based in Houston.

Cruz, At 40, Swings Hot Bat
LEAD: In the first inning, Jose Cruz sent a curveball from Bert Blyleven deep to right field for a two-run triple.
In the fourth, he saw a fastball and lined it inside the bag at third for a single.
In the fifth, a change-up was lofted easily into center for another single.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Graf and Evert in Final: Top-seeded Steffi Graf won a battle of 18-year-olds yesterday, and second-seeded Chris Evert, 33 years old, beat a player about half her age to advance to the women's final of the Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla.
Graf, the defending champion, swept past unseeded Stephanie Rehe of Highland, Calif., 6-3, 6-1.

LEAD:  Markets


Bridge
LEAD: Two stunning upsets marked Vanderbilt Knockout Team play here Wednesday as the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League continued.


3 Men Attack Officer in Brooklyn
LEAD: An undercover police officer trying to make a drug arrest was attacked in the hallway of a Brooklyn tenement yesterday by three men who the police believe were trying to rob him.

LEAD: The price of the Irving Bank Corporation's stock surged $6.625 in yesterday's trading, to $66.25 a share, after Irving indicated it might be holding talks with a potential friendly suitor to avoid being acquired by the Bank of New York.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Horse Is Rescued From Ice
LEAD: A horse stranded on frozen Lake Champlain for at least two days was rescued in good condition today by state troopers and environmental officers.
Officials theorized that the horse, Mr.
Ed, whose owners were vacationing in Acapulco, had been forced onto the ice by dogs, wandered five miles and then was too scared to walk back to shore.


Bush Continues to Offer Mixed Message on Veto
LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that the civil rights bill Congress passed over President Reagan's veto this week should be ''fully enforced,'' and though he continued to cite flaws in the measure he would not say whether he would have vetoed the bill himself.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Volkswagen A.G. incorrectly characterized the situation of Noel Phillips, chief executive and president of its subsidiary Volkswagen of America.
He has not been dismissed; he remains in the position.

Dr. Leon Ginzburg, 89, Surgeon and Professor
LEAD: Dr.
Leon Ginzburg, a surgeon, teacher and expert in gastrointestinal diseases, died of cardiac and renal failure Saturday at the Beth Israel Medical Center.
He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Pactel Assets Sold
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation will acquire the technical and operational assets of Pactel Spectrum Services, a division of the Pactel Communications Companies, a subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group.
I.B.M. will purchase Pactel Spectrum's assets for cash.
The price was not disclosed, and the offer is expected to be completed in 30 days.


State's High Court Says Some Tenants May Sue for Rent Refunds
LEAD: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that New York City tenants who contend they have been overcharged for major capital improvements to their apartments may return to the lower courts to seek refunds from landlords.

LEAD: The cotton candy is in full bloom now on Seventh Avenue, and this is the surest sign of spring for city people who do not mark the seasons by looking for robins or new greenery on the streets.

The answer, in Mr.
Condo's case, is quite a bit, but not nearly as much as one could imagine.

Our Towns; Bitter Neighbors, Guarded Homes For Mentally Ill
LEAD: Seven nights a week Mario Chacon, a guard for Satellite Security Systems, sits in the empty two-story ranch house at 9 Highland Road and listens.
He never hears anything much.
Sometimes he sits with all the lights on.
Sometimes he sits in the dark.
As carefully as he listens, the most he hears are the nighttime sounds of a suburban street: A car passing.

Seagate Shares Up
LEAD: The stock of Seagate Technology Inc. was the most heavily traded over-the-counter issue today after it was disclosed that Seagate had been chosen by the International Business Machines Corporation as the first outside supplier of the 3 1/2-inch disk drives for its new personal computers.
Terms were not disclosed.


Fatal Train Crash in China
LEAD: Two passenger trains collided head on today in a suburb of Shanghai, killing 12 people and injuring more than 40, the state-run New China News Agency said.
A second report said seven people had died.
The crash was China's fourth fatal train accident in three months.
The Japanese Embassy said that a 193-member tour group from a Japanese high school was on one of the trains and that two Japanese students were killed and 29 were injured.

LEAD: Alan Alda is an actor, a film maker and a person, of course, but he's also a state of mind.
He's the urge, when one is riding in a gondola, to get up and start singing with the gondolier.
He's the impulse to talk over an important personal problem with an entire roomful of concerned friends.
He's the determination to keep looking up, no matter how many pigeons may be flying overhead.

Brisk Trading in VW
LEAD: The West German Government today offered the public its 16 percent stake in Volkswagenwerk A.G., Europe's largest auto maker, and demand was brisk.
The 4.8 million shares were priced at 238 marks, or about $141, each.
The sale will bring the Government about $674 million before expenses of $32.5 million.


AIDS Demonstrators Arrested in Lower Manhattan
LEAD: Protesters blocking traffic near Trinity Church on Broadway yesterday morning during a rally held to criticize the Federal Government's response to the AIDS crisis.
Police said that 105 people were arrested.
The demonstration, sponsored by the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, commemorated the first anniversary of a similiar protest in which 17 were arrested.


Can a Cease-Fire Become Peace?
LEAD: Suddenly and seasonably, peace and hope bloom in Nicaragua.
On Wednesday the Sandinistas and contras backed away from avowed demands and signed a 60-day cease-fire, beginning April 1.
On the crucial question of outside aid during this period, the contras agreed to seek only clothes and food, and get it from a neutral agency, not the C.I.A.


Bonds End Mixed After Early Fall
LEAD: Bond prices ended mixed yesterday after a sharp early slide. as market participants reacted nervously to a sharp drop in stock prices, a weaker dollar and a small additional rise in oil prices.

Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 422 money market mutual funds decreased by $730.4 million, to $278.78 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 114 institutional funds decreased by $1.22 billion, to $78.89 billion.
Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were up $226.2 million, to $82.23 billion.

LEAD: The Detroit Tigers, who already had Billy Bean on their roster, have acquired Billy Beane from the Minnesota Twins.
Beane, an outfielder formerly with the Mets, hit .174 in 10 exhibition games with the Twins this spring.
Billy Bean is hitting .211 in spring training as the Tigers experiment with using the outfielder at first base.


SmithKline Bids for I.C.L.
LEAD: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation has offered $32 a share, or about $340 million, for International Clinical Laboratories Inc., which is $6 more a share than in an agreement reached recently with Corning Glass Works.


Sale by Occidental
LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will sell a stake in its Colombian interests to Repsol, Spain's national oil company, for $272 million.
The proposed transaction includes an interest in the Cano Limon and the Redondo fields, which currently produce 215,000 barrels of oil a day.
Occidental, based in Los Angeles, said it would continue to operate the properties.

LEAD: The state of Florida, a pioneer host to the space industry, now wants a piece of the action: a commercial spaceport.


Judge Dismisses Theft Charges In Transit Case
LEAD: A New York State Supreme Court justice has dismissed theft charges against a man arrested by the transit police decoy squad.
It is the fourth time the once elite unit has lost in court since entrapment allegations were raised late last year, defense attorneys said.


Review/Film; Film: Simon's 'Biloxi Blues,' Coming of Age in the Army
LEAD: WHEN first seen in ''Biloxi Blues,'' the movie, Eugene Morris Jerome is not, technically speaking, actually seen.
He's an indistinct figure in the window of a World War II troop train.
With more purpose than hurry, the train chugs across a broad, verdant American landscape, shimmering in the golden light of memory, as well as in the kind of humid, midsummer heat in which even leaves sweat.

Horne and Lakes
LEAD: The mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne and the tenor Gary Lakes will be the soloists in a performance of Mahler's ''Das lied von der Erde'' with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Jesus Lopez-Cobos at Carnegie Hall at 8 o'clock tonight.
The program also includes a Schubert symphonic fragment (D.936a), a three-movement work left incomplete at the composer's death.


Delay for 'Chess'
LEAD: Preview performances of the musical ''Chess'' will begin on April 11 at the Imperial Theater, one week later than previously announced.
A spokesman for the show, Bill Evans, said yesterday that the delay was caused by the installation of electronic lighting equipment in the floor of the stage.
Tickets purchased for April 4 to 10 may be exchanged at the box office.


Ford Belgian Expansion
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company's Belgian manufacturing plant expects to expand its work force after strong demand for its cars and vans, a spokesman for the Ford Fabrieken Genk works said today.
The spokesman said that the plant, which employs around 11,200, expected to employ an extra 1,700 this year to help increase output.


Gore, in Reversal, Releases Data On Funds Borrowed by Campaign
LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. has released details of bank loans estimated at $1.45 million that were taken out by his Democratic Presidential campaign.
For about two weeks the candidate had refused to disclose the information.

Report Says Lilco Takeover Would Result in Savings of 10%
LEAD: A long-awaited study for the Long Island Power Authority has found that electric costs on the Island would be about 10 percent lower over the next 15 years if the Long Island Lighting Company were publicly owned, officials said today.

LEAD: In this time of fast food for the mind as well as the body, the novels of Charles Dickens remain glorious anachronisms.

Neither G.E. nor Roper would comment on Whirlpool's request.
Roper's stock price closed unchanged at $55 a share today, indicating that traders expected further bidding.

LEAD: The Cleveland Indians, unwilling to start the season with the recently acquired Terry Francona as their first baseman, bought the contract of Willie Upshaw yesterday from the Toronto Blue Jays.

Strike Voted at Jaguar
LEAD: Workers at Jaguar P.L.C.'s Coventry plant in central England have voted to go on strike over plans to increase production, a union spokesman said today.
Members of the Transport and General Workers Union and the Amalgamated Engineering Union voted by a 2-to-1 ratio to go on strike after Easter in the British luxury car maker's first important dispute in three years, a transport union spokesman said.

It Takes More Than Sun To Make a Car Shine
LEAD: The bright days of spring show up the drabness that winter left behind, and one of the more visible reminders is an automobile covered with the residue of snow, sleet and neglect - a car that's crying for a wash and wax.


Inside Trader Loses Appeal
LEAD: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the insider-trading conviction of a former lawyer with a prestigious New York law firm who was convicted last year of stealing information about Colt Industries' recapitalization plans and passing it to others.

How?
With Patina Green, a solution in a 16-ounce container, brush included, that's being offered for $18 in Pottery Barn's new catalogue.

LEAD: Representative James J. Howard, a New Jersey Democrat who served more than two decades in Congress, died this afternoon at the Washington Hospital Center, a day after suffering a heart attack.
He was 60 years old.


New Soviet Income Tax: A Bite Up to 90%
LEAD: Soviet citizens engaged in private business will face a progressive income tax beginning April 1, with rates ranging up to 90 percent, according to an official of the Soviet Finance Ministry.

LEAD: They call themselves That Was Fast.
And fast they are.
Karen Pearlman, an American dancer, and Richard Allen, an Australian dancer and poet, have teamed up as That Was Fast.
Offering works that blended choreography with poetry, they hurtled across the stage Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center.


Invitation for Blind Renter
LEAD: A condominium association that refused to let a blind man rent an apartment has reversed itself after he filed a discrimination complaint. ''We're hoping he's going to move in and be a neighbor,'' said Morris Barnett, director of the condominium association at Century Village here.
The blind man, Larry Tomecek, who is 35 years old, said Thursday he did not know if would accept the offer.

LEAD: ''Cavalcade'' was created toward the start of Lar Lubovitch's recent hedonistic period of choreography, epitomized in the lush, exuberant sweep and flow of ''A Brahms Symphony.'' ''Cavalcade,'' choreographed in 1980, rolls and roils gently along with its score by Steve Reich.
But the seams show in ways they don't in the Brahms piece, which was performed, with ''Cavalcade,'' by the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company on Tuesday at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

LEAD: Since 1926, when the former estate of Spencer and Katrina Trask in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., began a new life as the Yaddo artists' colony, more than 2,500 writers, musicians and visual artists have found refuge from the distractions of the world and created some of America's greatest novels, sonatas and sculptures amid the forests and lakes of this 440-acre retreat.

Bruno's Expands
LEAD: Bruno's Inc., Alabama's largest grocery chain, has agreed to buy 82 Piggly Wiggly stores in Georgia for $30 million in stock, company officials said.
Bruno's, a Birmingham-based company, already has 123 supermarkets.
Under the agreement, Bruno's will buy Piggly Wiggly Southern, a Vidalia, Ga., holding company that owns stores in central and southern Georgia.

Review/Dance; The Ancient Odissi Style Steps Off an Indian Frieze
LEAD: Odissi dance lives on in the ancient temple sculptures and friezes of the State of Orissa on the eastern coast of India.
Neglected in this century, it has been less well known and less practiced than Bharata Natyam.
But in Sanjukta Panigrahi, who performed Saturday night at the Asia Society, Odissi has a distinguished and dynamic interpreter.

Review/Pop; A Jazzy Side Of Cleo Laine
LEAD: Few singers come better equipped to perform the music of Stephen Sondheim than the English pop-jazz contralto Cleo Laine.
Besides an immaculate vocal tone, the qualities that Miss Laine brings to Sondheim are an aura of unflappable worldliness and a theatrical perspective that has noticeably sharpened since her appearance on Broadway in the musical ''Drood.


Judith Somogi, 47, a Conductor; Among First Women on Podium
LEAD: Judith Somogi, one of the first women to become a conductor, died at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I., Wednesday morning.
She was 47 years old and had suffered from cancer for four years.


Colombia Volcano Rumbles
LEAD: A volcano that killed 20,000 people in 1985 rumbled and began spewing a thick column of ash and steam today, and an immediate evacuation of the area was ordered, officials said.
A quarter-inch blanket of ash covered Manizales, a town 20 miles northwest of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano, a radio station there reported.


2 World Records Fall at Swim Meet
LEAD: Tom Jager of Collinsville, Ill., and Artur Wojdat of Poland broke world records tonight in the Phillips 66/U.S.
Swimming national indoor championships.
Dara Torres of Beverly Hills, Calif., broke two American records, in the morning and at night.


Swedish Forestry Group Takeover
LEAD: A consortium of the power company Aga A.B. and the forestry groups MO och Domsjo A.B. (Modo) and Svenska Cellulosa A.B. said they had won backing for a takeover bid of about $950 million for the power and forestry company Graningeverken A.B. from its largest shareholder, Skanska A.B.


Britain Cuts Trade Deficit
LEAD: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed 8 percent in February, while the country's annual inflation rate was unchanged at 3.3 percent, the Government said today.


Review/Recital; Gutierrez Plays Schumann
LEAD: Robert Schumann, in his music critic's mind, fancied a band of Davids eager to take on the Goliaths of musical philistinism, and crystallized their high spirits and his own kaleidoscopic moods in the ''Davidsbundlertanze'' for solo piano.
Horacio Gutierrez played the cycle as the centerpiece of his Avery Fisher Hall recital Sunday evening, but one thought afresh of the underlying spirit mostly to wish he had caught it more vividly.


Jurors Describe 'Wild' Shifts of Opinion
LEAD: With their marathon deliberations abruptly ended by a surprise plea bargain, jurors in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. spoke with reporters for the first time yesterday, describing what one called ''wild'' shifts of opinion and emotion during the nine days they spent trying to reach a verdict.

Track Inquiry Ends
LEAD: After a three-month investigation, the Italian Olympic Committee announced yesterday that Italian officials had falsified the long-jump results at the world track and field championships in Rome last September to insure that Giovanni Evangelisti of Italy would win the bronze medal.
The committee said that disciplinary measures would be taken against eight officials of the Italian track and field federation, including the federation's secretary general, Luciano Barra, and the technical director of the national track team, Enzo

LEAD: Top-seeded Arizona, which has cruised through the N.C.A.A. tournament with routs of Cornell and Seton Hall, continued its joy ride in pummeling Iowa, 99-79, tonight in a West Regional semifinal.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump, chairman of Resorts International Inc., said he was trying to arrange $600 million in bond financing that could be used to complete the Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City.
The money could also help Mr.
Trump meet the costs of buying out the stockholders.

University has $680 million in assets and 22 branches.
The proposal is the latest in a series of recent bank and thrift institution mergers in Washington.

Review/Theater; A Brechtian Curiosity Set in 1930's Spain
LEAD: Brecht himself described ''Senora Carrar's Rifles'' as a ''large step backward'' in his dramatic development, and 50 years after its first performance here it is hard to disagree with his judgment.
Essentially it is a 75-minute tract, and not all the energies of the cast in the current production at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater nor the addition of music and songs can turn it into compelling theater.

Touche Ross Purchase
LEAD: Touche Ross &amp; Company, the Big Eight accounting firm, said Thursday that it was acquiring Meahl, McNamara &amp; Company, a Boston-based accounting firm.
The merger means that Touche Ross will have nearly 500 people in Boston.
Founded in 1932, Meahl, McNamara serves mostly New England clients.
Its specialty is financial-services companies.

LEAD: The Koppers Company asked the United States District Court in Los Angeles to halt an unfriendly tender offer by Beazer P.L.C. because of antitrust considerations.
Beazer had agreed to sell the Koppers aggregate plant in Los Angeles, if the deal was consummated, to satisfy the Justice Department's antitrust concerns.

LEAD: The British Petroleum Company plans to change its name by midyear to reflect its trans-Atlantic operations, a senior executive said today.
E.
John P. Browne, executive vice president of B.P.'s Cleveland-based BP America Inc. unit, did not say what the new name would be.
The company's name has been changed several times since incorporation in 1909 as the Anglo-Persian Oil Company.

Review/Music; Debut of a Choral Group Mixes the New and the Old
LEAD: Choral singing is a recreation as well as an art - hence New York's large, dues-paying, often lumbering groups that command our attention in concerts several times a year.
The other side of the coin offers the smaller, tighter, wholly professional choruses that rise above dilettantism.
An addition to the latter is the New York Concert Singers, organized and directed by Judith Clurman.

Review/Jazz; A Drummer Who Goads The Soloists
LEAD: Tony Williams's drumming fills all the requirements of modern jazz.

Williams and his quintet on Wednesday at the Village Gate (Bleecker and Thompson Streets), where the band is performing through tonight, his jazz technique evoked elemental forces: gale winds, avalanches, tsunamis.

The Misery Hour
LEAD: Evening.
The cocktail hour they used to call it.
We used to drink martinis and listen to the great Erroll Garner on the phonograph.
Well, they used to call it the phonograph.
It played records.
Records were big, circular . . .
Well, never mind.
Anyhow, they used to call them records.

About New York; Thrill of Gluttony Beats the Agony Of Indigestion
LEAD: Carl Herkowitz, a coin collector from Detroit who was in town this week for a convention of numismatists, stopped by the Carnegie Deli for a bite Wednesday night and heard while he was dining that there would be a knish-eating contest in the place the next day.
Once, long ago and far away, Mr.
Herkowitz finished with the overachievers in a submarine, or hero sandwich, group gorge, but he had nearly put away the sweet memory of that challenge successfully met in youth.


CORRECTION
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article Thursday about Chinese plans to cut back on foreign study misidentified the source of reports that only 3,000 students a year would be allowed to go abroad.
That number was cited by Chinese students who had spoken with Chinese consular officials in the United States; it was not based on official Chinese or American figures.


Chambers, With Jury at Impasse, Admits 1st-Degree Manslaughter
LEAD: Robert E. Chambers Jr., who insisted through 13 weeks of an agonized murder trial that Jennifer Levin had died accidentally, yesterday reluctantly said he had lied, that he had meant to hurt her, and he abruptly pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter.

She's almost certain the pronouncement was followed by music, but she wouldn't swear to it because she was still in a small state of shock about being called by a message machine.

Kyoto's Canvas Bags Suited for All Needs
LEAD: THE storefront of Ichizawa Hanpu Kogyo (Ichizawa Sailcloth Enterprises) in Kyoto is so modest it's very easy to pass it by.
The many-paned window of the shop is not markedly different from that of the other old offices and shops on Higashioji-dori, and the earthy colors of the bags visible through the glass blend in with the dark wood, gray roof tiles and copper rain pipes of the shop's exterior and that of other buildings on the street.

ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
LEAD: As a member of A.A., I read your article with interest.
I was distressed to read that the General Service Office of A.A. would not allow recovering alcoholics to handle its finances.
I am the controller of an investment-banking firm in New York City, and wonder what the management of my firm will think when they read that the management of A.A., which knows alcoholics better than anyone, will not trust a recovering alcoholic to handle its finances.

Fancy Leaves to Brighten Corners in the Shade
LEAD: INDOORS separate annual and vegetable seedlings and pot them individually; keep hairlike roots covered to prevent them from drying out; water carefully and put in a shaded location for a day or two until the roots are settled; then provide full sun and use water-soluble fertilizer diluted to half-rate.

WHO'S MINDING THE STORE
LEAD: For more than 30 years my father worked in Filene's, the Boston department store.
As I look back, it seems important that he worked ''in'' Filene's, or ''with'' Filene's.
I don't think I ever heard him say he worked ''for'' Filene's.
There was a spirit of identification - a sense of family, to risk sounding maudlin - that the store's employees seemed to share.

LEAD: About 8,400 gallons of slightly radioactive water leaked into the Hudson River from the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant, the plant's operator said today.

Nepal
LEAD: To the Editor: A few additional words on health and Himalayan travel: I became badly ill in Ladakh in 1985.
At Srinagar I was given Mexoform, an antibiotic.
This and the similar Enteroviaform are sold over the counter all over India.
I learned that they are extremely dangerous - possible side effects include blindness - and are not sold here.

Ghost Train
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Riding the Ghost Train'' (Travel, Jan. 31) confirmed my own experiences with Amtrak.

Unless you are a skillful timetable reader, you don't know till you get to the Sarasota Amtrak station that the first several hours will be spent on a bus from Sarasota to Tampa where the rail trip starts.

Gambling on Life
LEAD: LAST DECEMBER A major clinical trial to determine whether aspirin could reduce the risk of heart attack in men was suddenly halted.
Every other day for five years each of the 22,000 healthy doctors who had agreed to take part in the experiment had taken a white pill; half took an aspirin, half a placebo, and none knew what he was getting.

Does It Pay to File Separate Returns?
LEAD: THE Tax Reform Act of 1986 is creating a new trend: his and her tax returns.
Before, almost all married couples saved money by filing joint tax returns.
Couples who filed separately faced higher tax rates.
More important, they lost valuable tax benefits like the ''two earner'' deduction, which was equal to 10 percent of the salary of the lower-earning partner, up to $3,000.

Islanders Regain First
LEAD: Pat LaFontaine negotiates an ice rink the way a water beetle negotiates a pond.
He skitters across it, preferring a series of zig-zags to the more conventional route.
Even mobile defensemen are left twirling in place from the effort of trying to imitate his path.
Goaltenders, trying to anticipate his every move, see only a darting blur instead of a straightforward forward.

LEAD: IT IS, WITHOUT A DOUBT, THE GRANDEST birdhouse in Virginia Beach, Va.

LEAD: Six Moslem fishermen were shot and killed off Sri Lanka and nine of their companions were missing and feared dead, a Sri Lankan military official said today.

THE GOSPEL ACCORING TO JOY
LEAD: WHEN BILL JOY WAS GROWING up in Farmington, Mich., his father taught him the rudiments of chess.
Young Bill then read every book he could find on the subject and developed a powerful game, yet his father and younger brother, Bob, could sometimes still defeat him. ''He played 20 moves ahead to our two or three,'' Bob Joy recalls, ''and analyzed our moves far too deeply.

The Shapes of Things to Come
LEAD: DESPITE the vast changes that have taken place within 35-millimeter cameras in the last 10 years, including a dramatic shift from mechanical to electronic controls, the outsides have stayed pretty much the same.
The typical camera body is still a pudgy rectangle about the size of a deli ham sandwich with a lens stuck in the middle.

LEAD: A CENTURY-OLD Manhattan landmark is being converted from neighborhood eyesore to New York's biggest youth hostel.

Despite Criticism, Fetal Monitors Are Likely to Remain in Wide Use
LEAD: Electronic fetal monitors have been under attack for more than a decade by some women's groups and parts of the medical community.
But despite research showing that using monitors does not produce healthier babies, most obstetricians say that a complicated interplay of legal and economic pressures makes it almost impossible to stop using them.

LEAD: Even though he was 75 and ill for some time, Romare Bearden's death earlier this month was a shock.
It was clear from his work that he loved everything about art.
He trusted materials, trusted the creative process, trusted the people who spoke to him in and across his paper.
His art grew freer, wiser, more poignant in a way that is rare in postwar

A Veiled Threat
LEAD: TWELVE-FOOT-HIGH walls.
Steel gates.
Dogs and armed guards.
Inside, cool, high-ceilinged old houses, oases of green lawns, servants slipping noiselessly about - and women.
For six weeks last spring I went from one feudal family compound to another in Pakistan.
And always it was the same.
Glasses of pomegranate juice.

Evening Fashion; Maximum From a Minimum
LEAD: THE big news in fashion lately has been the rejection by many women of the miniskirt.
Be that as it may, there is still a segment of the population, mostly young and obviously in excellent shape, that has embraced the shorter styles - or rather, let the styles embrace them.
For these women the mini, especially the mini evening dress, is standard attire.


Unacceptable Image
LEAD: Those Soviet parents who have had mixed feelings about the glorification of Pavlik Morozov may be resting easier these days.
The authorities are toning down the hero image of Pavlik Morozov, who had been held up as a model of Communism since 1932, when, as a 13-year-old, he denounced his father as a class enemy and was subsequently murdered as an informer.

WHEN FEAR CONQUERS
LEAD: In his article ''When Fear Conquers'' (Feb. 28), Douglas Shenson has, in large measure, figured out the key to educating the nation about the dreaded disease AIDS.
He has done so by asking us to reflect on our past behavior as we worked our way through the fear that accompanied another dreaded disease, leprosy.

The Alfredo Kraus Secret For Triumphing Over Time
LEAD: Alfredo Kraus is a tenor of many distinctions, and one among them on which all observers would have to agree is the really unusual preservation of his voice.
We have at the moment a fair number of opera singers clustered around the age of 60 who have lasted impressively well, but Mr.
Kraus, who was born in 1927, has conceded less to time than any of them.

ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
LEAD: Despite its lack of regimentation, A.A. works.
More than three years ago, I learned that there is no single ''correct'' way to become, and to remain, sober.
Some spend their days going from one meeting to another, others attend only one or two a month.
At the meetings, some share their histories and their daily lives; some sit quietly and listen to the others.


CRIME
LEAD: About two years ago Irving Weinman, in his first novel, ''Tailor's Dummy,'' introduced Detective Inspector Lenny Schwartz of the New York Police Department.
Schwartz had some unusual things going for him.
He was a Harvard graduate.
He was literate.
He was smart.
He was likable.
He also at one time had taken a bribe in order to send his son through college, and that was something always at the nasty end of his subconscious - and his conscious, for that matter.

Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
LEAD: The score is tied at 3-3, it's the last half of the ninth, runner on second base.
Here comes the pitch: a hit to centerfield . . . runner is on the way home . . . the throw from center field . . . batter slides . . . the umpire calls the batter out.
Extra innings.
Wait.
The home-team manager asks for instant replay.

POSTINGS: South Bronx Renovation; Mixed Rentals
LEAD: A renovation of four adjacent city-owned buildings under way in the rubble-strewn South Bronx offers a mix of market and low-income rents and has drawn 1,000 applications for its 110 apartments, according to its developers.
The large number of requests reflects not only the quality of the project but also the shortage of livable buildings in the area, said Brien O'Toole, executive director of the Mount Hope Housing Company, the nonprofit sponsor with FGK Development, a private company.

Icons From an Era When Screens Were Silver And Silents Were Golden
LEAD: The cinema is an art that thrives on legend, but it took time for it to develop legends of its own.
In the beginning it borrowed themes and motifs from the other popular arts, from well-established traditions in fiction, the theater, vaudeville, genre painting; and if early movies seemed thrillingly modern when they first appeared, with the passage of time one of their most interesting aspects has become the way in which they frequently preserve the spirit of the 19th century.

MIND OVER DISEASE: CAN HAPPY THOUGHTS HEAL?
LEAD: Leave a pendulum to its own devices and it most assuredly will swing the other way.
So it has been lately with a theory of health and healing that treats the mind as a weapon at least as powerful as the best of modern medicaments.
After nearly a century stuck on the side of the body, the pendulum has recently cut a wide arc toward the mind.

LEAD: LAST June in Indianapolis, children were found playing with vials of blood they took from a dumpster near several doctors' offices.

Practical Traveler; Mixed Signals On Lost Tickets
LEAD: LOSING an airplane ticket can be worse than losing your passport.
United States Embassies can rapidly replace a lost or stolen passport, but you may never get a penny back if your ticket is stolen, or it could take 18 months to recover what you have to spend to get a new one.
There are some bright spots.

LEAD: ''Espressiv: central Euro-pean Art Since 1960'' - an exhibition hunkered down in the basement of the Hirshhorn Museum through April 17 -brings together a sobering dose of grim, gritty art from five countries: Yugoslavia, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Austria.
For the artists represented in the show, the focus is squarely on the human figure, twisted into anguished, grotesque, defiant, occasionally amusing shapes.

WHEN FEAR CONQUERS
LEAD: I lived in Louisiana in the mid-1970's and had the opportunity to visit Carville on one occasion.
I was struck by three things about the place - a sort of decaying beauty, an ethereal quiet and an overwhelming sense of isolation.
At the time, I felt that Carville was in decline and that there would never be a need for another place like it again.


Concerns That Decide the Price Is Right
LEAD: HOW much is it worth?
When it comes to real estate, the value often is not determined by the seller or the buyer but by the mortgage lender.
Banks, which once relied upon their own officers to inspect properties and set a fair-market value before granting mortgages, now pay fees to real-estate appraisal companies to perform the service.

LEAD: At least 40 people, including six children, were wounded when were bombs set off by robbers at a rural fair, the police said today.
More than 20 bombs went off Friday during a fair in the village of Kaliakandipara in Sirajganj district, about 50 miles northwest of Dhaka, according to police officials.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Some days we really suffered, but that's war.
What we really want is to live in peace.
I believe we can stop hating each other.''  - Daniel Verona,  18, after two years  in the Nicaraguan Army.  [ 19:1. ]


Cakes for Easter or for Passover, Two Holidays That Coincide
LEAD: THE weekend of Easter observances and the beginning of Passover coincide this year.
Home cooks will be busy preparing Passover seders on Friday and Saturday evenings or putting together Easter Sunday dinners.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump disclosed yesterday that he had bought the Plaza Hotel for $390 million and would upgrade it into ''the most luxurious hotel in the world.''


Review/Dance; Pieces by Burnside and McLaughlin
LEAD: The program that Chris Burnside shared with Mickey McLaughlin and Dancers on Friday night at St.
Mark's Church contained dances jammed with steps.
Yet the most effective work was a monologue in which clever lines were heightened with a few well-chosen movements.

LEAD: THE EVOLUTION within each medium is a fascinating aspect of contemporary craft.
In fiber, for example, many artists push their limitations by applying textile concepts and processes to nonfibrous material.

LEAD: IN A NICE middle-class neighborhood less than 10 miles from the beach, hundreds of families say they are being held hostage.

LEAD: LAWYERS for the city were moving in two directions as Yonkers responded uncertainly last week to a Federal judge's longstanding order to build low-income housing in predominantly white neighborhoods as a remedy for four decades of racial discrimination against nonwhites, who account for about 18 percent of the population.


Cross Burning in Baltimore
LEAD: A black woman who moved to a predominantly white neighborhood two weeks ago found a burning cross in a nearby park and racial ephitets on a window of her house, officials said Friday.
Lieut.
Larry Leeson said police officers investigating the burning of a 3-foot cross also found ''KKK'' painted in shaving cream on the windshield of a car owned by the woman, Carrie Venable.


The Next Superpower Summit May Be Unrehearsed

Yugoslavia
LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to share with your readers an experience I had in Zabreb.
My wife and I were traveling through Yugoslavia last fall.
In a hotel in Zagreb, at approximately 11 P.M., I started to shake and tremble.
I became frightened and thought I had a heart attack.
My wife called the desk and we were given a number to call for first aid.

18 Die in Philippine Clashes
LEAD: Fifteen Communist guerrillas and three soldiers died in gun battles in the northern and central Philippines, the military said today.
A spokesman said 10 rebels and a soldier were killed in a one-hour battle in Albay Province, south of Manila, on Friday, and 5 rebels, 2 soldiers and a civilian were killed in a 13-hour battle in northern guerrillas attacked an army detachment in a remote village.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Hungary  Question:I have heard conflicting accounts from friends about the amount of Hungarian currency that must be purchased by visitors to Hungary.
Can you enlighten me?
What is the time involved in getting a visa?
Is a visa required for Austria as well? -R.
R., Buffalo  Answer:Hungarian officials say there is no requirement to purchase a specified amount of Hungarian currency.


Attaching Wood to Concrete Floor
LEAD: A SURPRISINGLY frequent, though unusual, home-improvement task is attaching wood to concrete.
Two instances where this is necessary are covering a concrete slab by building a wood or wood-supported floor over it, and installing a partition wall in a basement containing a concrete floor.

Yankee Independence, Yankee Zoning
LEAD: I AM not a native New Englander.
I was born and grew up in the Middle West.
In elementary school, we learned about the group of small states in the Northeast corner of our country where the first settlers battled harsh winters and farmed land that was more rock than soil.
New Englanders, we were told, were fiercely protective of their own way of doing things, a characteristic that time has not erased.


More to Some Books Than Their Covers
LEAD: AN astronomy book from 1474 has two wheels that turn to show the movements of the moon.
An 1850 work on obstetrics has 50 flaps that lift to reveal anatomical details.
A 1977 artist's book contains a real tortilla sealed in Mylar.
A book about Georgia is shaped like Georgia, and Poemobiles have poems popping up from flat surfaces.

Nepal
LEAD: To the Editor: I had the wonderful experience of trekking in the Nepal Himalayas last fall. ''Preparing for Nepal's Rugged Reality'' by Marcia R. Lieberman (Travel, Feb. 21) was well done but omitted one important bit of advice for anyone about to embark on an experience of a lifetime.
I discovered the most important item in my duffle bag was a Katadyn water filter.

Machines That Cut the Mess to a Manageable Size
LEAD: A NEW industry has been developed over the last few years by companies offering to handle infectious waste ''from cradle to grave,'' transporting the red-bag garbage in special plastic boxes and burning it in incinerators or autoclaving.
Red-bag waste is estimated to account for 10 percent of a hospital's garbage, but it can account for more than half of the disposal budget.

Fewer Bursts, Less Bursting
LEAD: THE CBS CORRESPONDENT Bob Schieffer, reporting election returns on one of the primary nights, wondered aloud whether a percentage figure he was giving should be described as less or fewer.
The grammarian on the spot immediately pronounced judgment: when a percentage is used to indicate an amount or quantity, it takes less; when used to describe a number, it takes fewer.

WINNOWING OUR WARHEADS
LEAD: THERE IS A HIGH RISK for the United States in the current strategic arms reduction talks, known as START, that call for a 50 percent reduction in strategic nuclear warheads.
The risk is less in what we negotiate with the Russians than in how we divide up the 50 percent we would be allowed to retain.

The Need to Consider Pathological Gamblers
LEAD: The article, ''Legislators Weigh Raceway Proposal''  [ March 6 ] , outlines many of the ramifications of establishing betting parlors in our county.

Molehills Can Be Mountains, Too
LEAD: The 50-odd piano pieces that Mendelssohn called ''Songs Without Words'' have been largely forgotten.
They are small and unprepossessing, while the symphonies of Mahler are large and unavoidable.
I suspect that every time Beethoven's Ninth takes a walk through our imagination, a miniature or two gets crushed underfoot.

LEAD: It must seem sometimes to lovers of classi-cal music that all the old verities are crumbling under their feet.

When White Water Isn't Enough
LEAD: I AM shooting down the Colorado River in gray rubber raft No. 612 with a mountainy boatman, a headphoned Upper West Sider and a Midwestern couple protected from the spray in see-through rain slickers, like potatoes in a Baggie.
The Upper West Sider is listening to the ''Ride of the Valkyries'' on a Walkman supplied by one of the guides on our 13-day, 235-mile voyage through the Grand Canyon; modern rivermen don't quite trust the crashing river to hold the interest of tourists with contemporary attention spans.

ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
LEAD: ''Objective'' explanations of the A.A. program are informative.
But ''gritty'' facts cannot communicate the essential truth of the program.
Bill Wilson and Bob Smith changed the world, not only for alcoholics, but for families and friends of alcoholics - Al-Anon and ACOA (Adult Children of Alcoholics) -gamblers (Gamblers Anonymous), drug addicts (Narcotics Anonymous), people with eating disorders (Overeaters Anonymous) and scores of others who find they need a program of recovery.

Saving the Chapels of Wales
LEAD: INTRODUCED to Christianity through their native Celtic Church, absorbed into Roman Catholicism and transmuted through diktat to Anglicanism by King Henry VIII, the Welsh waited until the coming of the ironworks, coal mines and slate quarries late in the 18th century and throughout the 19th before molding Nonconformist denominations according to their own image and emerging with dramatic oratory and four-part harmony onto the religious center stage.

THE DANGEROUS MARQUIS DE SADE
LEAD: My wife is neither prudish nor anti-intellectual.
Nevertheless, upon reading one of the works of the Marquis de Sade, she reacted in a way that has come to be regarded as typical of the complacent bourgeois mentality: without saying a word, and having gone through about one-third of the book, she flung the slim volume into the trash can and went straight to the bookshelves to look for a substitute - the apposite word might be antidote - for her interrupted reading.

THAT'S MY LINE
LEAD: THE FIRST COMMERCIAL TELEPHONE RESEMBLED A clunky box camera.
Designed in 1877 by Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas A. Watson, it cost what was then a princely sum: $20 a year in two advance installments.
In relative terms, telephones can now be just as pricey, but they also do much more.
Many function as secretaries, having built-in answering machines and memories that record the time of a call or automatically dial a series of preprogrammed numbers.

POSTINGS: 1690 Mill as a Centerpiece; 7 for Harrison
LEAD: Down by the old mill stream, Burton Handelsman is building colonial-style homes and mending a colonial mill.
His seven-house project in Harrison, N.Y., at a bend in the Mamaroneck River will include the restoration of a 17th-century grist mill.
Built in 1690, the stone-and-wood structure is the oldest mill in Westchester County, said Michael Cassarella, Harrison town historian.

RIGHTS AND CHOICES
LEAD: Don Bredes's disappointment must be painful (About Men: ''Rights and Choices,'' Feb. 21.) But he makes it hard for us to sympathize with him.
He writes of injustice and a man's rights, rather than telling the story of a risky human adventure that failed for very understandable reasons.
He casts himself as victim, rather than as a participant who needs to wonder how he may have contributed to an impulsive and, possibly, mistaken decision, and to the unhappy outcome.

The Incredible Hulks
LEAD: In the afternoon, the gray station wagon left parked on a residential block in Manhattan's Chelsea district still looked like a station wagon.
After dark, the scavengers arrived and removed some of the engine and the rear wheels.
Then, finding nothing else of value, they smashed all the windows, showering broken glass and leaving behind another in the rising tide of abandoned hulks that deface American streets.

Move to End Belgian Crisis
LEAD: Jean-Luc Dehaene, a Flemish Christian Democrat, was asked by King Baudouin today to form a government and haul the country out of a five-month crisis.
Mr.
Dehaene was appointed the King's mediator two months ago to sound out the parties' positions on a new coalition, but abandoned the mission on Thursday after talks failed to bridge differences over the language problem that toppled the Government of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens in October.

Moreover, if it slows down, we grow bored.
No matter how thoughtful television tries to be, it doesn't work unless it commands our attention. ''Moyers: Facing Evil'' is thoughtful; it commands our attention as well.
In the least likely places, it is full of exhilaration.

There is little evidence that either the economy or inflation will shoot up, analysts say.
They predict that yields on the Treasury's 30-year bond are likely to remain within a range of 8.50 percent to 8.75 percent for a few weeks.

LEAD: Passion is volatile in Sinead O'Connor's songs; within a verse, it can become love, anger, lust, vulnerability, defiance or religious fervor.
The songs on her debut album, ''The Lion and the Cobra,'' carefully channel those raw emotions, shifting unpredictably from plea to accusation or from meditation to rock stomp; her voice can be sweet or lacerating, delivering endearments in a bitter rasp or breaking into wordless ululation.

Markets to Close Friday
LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed April 1 in observance of Good Friday.
Most foreign stock exchanges will be closed.
Banks will be open, as will most businesses and Government offices.
The Labor Department is scheduled to report on the nation's unemployment rate for March, and the Commerce Department is scheduled to report on construction spending for February.

LEAD: Ivan Toms, a 35-year-old physician, chose to go to jail for 21 months rather than continue serving as a reserve lieutenant in the South African Defense Force.


Korean Growth at 12%
LEAD: South Korea's gross national product grew 12 percent last year, down from a growth rate of 12.3 percent in 1986, the Bank of Korea announced Friday.
Bank officials said exports accounted for 46.1 percent of the G.N.P. last year, reaching a record total of $47.2 billion, up 36.2 percent from a year earlier.

LEAD: Warriors of the Masai tribe, imposing symbols of a nomadic culture that has journeyed doggedly through the centuries, are caught between tradition and modernity in this rickety outpost nestled against Mount Kilimanjaro.


Early Gainsborough Found
LEAD: The British Museum said today that it was buying an early self-portrait of Thomas Gainsborough that has recently come to light in London and is believed to be the only finished drawing of the 18th-century English painter known to exist.
Dated 1754 to 1759, when Gainsborough was between 27 and 31 years old, the drawing is being bought from a dealer who acquired it in the United States, a museum spokesman said.

LEAD: Three new cast members assembled in ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening.
Douglas Ahlstedt, as Ferrando, came closer than he has in other seasons to fulfilling the promise he showed when he came on the scene in the 1970's.
His tenor rang out bright and true in the first scenes, he acted with spirit, and though he is not a model of elegant phrasing, he did quite capable work in the lyrical movements.

Jet Evacuated at Detroit
LEAD: A Northwest Airlines jet was evacuated tonight at Detroit Metropolitan Airport here when residual fuel vapors briefly ignited, causing what witnesses thought to be a fire, officials said.
Four passengers were injured slightly while evacuating the Boeing 727 shortly after it landed at 8:20 P.M., and the incident forced the airport to close for about 20 minutes.

U.S. Studies Seoul's Ban
LEAD: In the first step toward possible trade retaliation, the United States today began a formal investigation of charges that South Korea's ban on United States meat imports is illegal.
The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said in a statement that the Reagan Administration had accepted a petition filed last month by the American Meat Institute that cntended that South Korea's ban on high-quality American beef and veal was unjustifiable and unreasonable.

Dollar Uncertainty Weakens Stock Prices
LEAD: Amid uncertainty about the dollar, stock prices closed mostly lower after sharp declines in the previous two sessions.


Rig Count Dips in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States fell by eight last week, to a total of 935, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
A year ago, the count was 748.
The rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil, not the number of rigs producing it.


A White Teen-Ager Is Acquitted Of Assaulting 2 Hispanic Youths
LEAD: A white teen-ager was acquitted yesterday of assault charges stemming from what the police said was a bias-related attack by a group of white men on two Hispanic teen-agers in Queens.
He was the second of two young whites charged in the case to be acquitted.

LEAD: Gov.
Evan Mecham complained at his impeachment trial today that he was ''insulted'' that a prosecutor had compared the Governor's use of a protocol fund with embezzlement.


'Unfinished Job'
LEAD: One-third of all baseball job openings in the last year were filled by members of minority groups, the baseball commissioner's office announced yesterday.
But baseball still does not have a black manager or general manager one year after the Los Angeles Dodgers executive, Al Campanis, caused a furor by saying that blacks lack ''some of the necessities'' for those jobs.


The Cry From a Truck Leads to a Victim's Release
LEAD: A pedestrian hearing noises from the back of a truck parked on Eighth Avenue at 43d Street moved closer to investigate.
Trapped inside was Thomas Sambolin, a truck driver who had been delivering supplies to a cafe when he was robbed and locked inside.


Temperature For World Rises Sharply In the 1980's
LEAD: Average global temperatures in the 1980's are the highest measured since reliable records were first kept over 130 years ago, according to reports now coming in from scientists around the world.

LEAD: I'VE never met a computer program that could play a decent game of poker, but Card Sharks will give you a pretty good run for your money.

LEAD: The organization that runs The Hambletonian, one of harness racing's most prestigious events, has agreed to accept bids on the site of the 1991 running of the race, which has been held at the Meadowlands since 1981.


Court Allows Photo Merger
LEAD: A merger between the Eastman Kodak Company and the Colorcraft Corporation is not an effort to force other companies out of the photo-finishing industry, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today.

Construction Talks Advance
LEAD: Negotiators from the United States and Japan have made substantial progress in resolving a dispute over access for American construction companies to $60 billion worth of Japanese construction projects, an American negotiator said today.


Bonds Tumble After Dollar Drops
LEAD: Bond prices tumbled in light trading yesterday, as the dollar continued to decline against other currencies.


South Africa Delays Release Of the Movie 'Cry Freedom'
LEAD: The release in South Africa of ''Cry Freedom,'' Sir Richard Attenborough's apartheid film, has been 'postponed indefinitely,'' the distributors said tonight.


Fine-Tuning Benefits Knicks
LEAD: In the final minutes of the 69th game of the season, Rick Pitino came up with a new lineup, and it brought the Knicks a 114-106 victory over the Dallas Mavericks last night at Madison Square Garden.


Iran Says It Repelled Iraqi Attack
LEAD: Iran said that its Revolutionary Guards beat back an Iraqi counterattack in Kurdistan today and that Teheran holds 540 square miles of the strategic region in northeast Iraq.


Lester Rawlins, 63, Stage TV Actor; Won Tony for 'Da'
LEAD: Lester Rawlins, a stage and television actor who won a Tony and three Obie Awards, died of cardiac arrest last Tuesday in his home on West End Avenue in Manhattan.
He was 63 years old.


Steel Output Up 0.3%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.996 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of three-tenths of a percent from the previous week's 1.991 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 93 percent of capacity, compared with 92.7 percent in the previous week.


INSIDE
LEAD: Pact May Allow Exotic Arms The treaty on medium- and shorter-range missiles may allow each side to field futuristic arms, a Senate report says.
Page A3.
Israel Agrees on Inquiry  The Israeli Government, ending a year of negotiations, says it will cooperate with the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair.


Scientists Identify Fiber Struck First By Dystrophy
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have pinpointed one type of muscle fiber that appears to be destroyed first in the crippling progression of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about the Supreme Court's decision to review a case involving Trans World Airlines misstated the number of striking flight attendants who were told by T.W.A. that their jobs had been filled or abolished after they offered to return to work in May 1986.
The correct number is about 5,000.


Talks on Budget Stall in Albany On Allocations
LEAD: State budget talks, which were said to be on the verge of conclusion late Sunday night, stalled today, apparently because of disagreements over apportioning money for housing, transportation and education.

F.D.I.C. Faces First Loss Ever
LEAD: The Federal fund that insures deposits in commercial banks could suffer a loss in 1988 for the first time in its 54-year history, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's chairman, L. William Seidman, said today.


Athens Unmoved by Protest
LEAD: The Greek Government will continue its freeze on construction work at American bases in Greece despite a protest from the United States, a Government spokesman said today.
Greece first announced the freeze last year when negotiations started on the future of the four major bases and 21 smaller military installations operated by the United States.


Irving Alters Takeover Defense
LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation, which is resisting a $1.08 billion takeover offer from the Bank of New York Company, took additional steps to discourage hostile bidders from acquiring its stock.
Irving said its board had approved an amendment to its share purchase rights plan that would deal with the possibility of a ''street sweep'' under which a bidder who terminates a tender offer then begins buying the target company's shares on the open market.


Hofstra Coach Resigns
LEAD: Dick Berg has resigned as Hofstra's basketball coach after eight seasons.
His team recently finished 6-21.


BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 29, 1988
LEAD:  Markets


Advertising; Hill &amp; Knowlton Wins Three Silver Anvils
LEAD: The Public Relations Society of America has announced the winners of its Silver Anvil Awards, the most respected prize in the field.


Press's Right to View Esposito Records Is Backed
LEAD: The Supreme Court let stand today a Federal appellate ruling that news organizations had a right to see court records including partial transcripts of court-ordered wiretaps on the telephones of Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, and others.


A Rave Review for Navy
LEAD: In rare praise for a nuclear weapons program, the House Armed Services Committee said Sunday that the Navy's program to build an improved Trident submarine-launched missile appears to be on time and under budget. ''The other programs we've looked at had a variety of problems, so this is kind of a man-bites-dog story,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, the panel's chairman.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A2-13  Attempts to aid the contras broke down in the House of Representatives.
Republicans demanded an early vote on renewed military assistance for the Nicaraguan rebels if peace talks fail.
Page A1  A delegation of contra commanders entered Nicaragua to begin talks about the cease-fire.


Amiens Journal; On the Far Right Is Le Pen, Talking of the Deluge
LEAD: Like the stand-up comic he sometimes resembles, Jean-Marie Le Pen, attired in a double-breasted blue blazer and gray slacks, strode the stage, a microphone pinned to his lapel.
For two hours, without notes, he announced the apocalypse that awaits France if it does not reverse an ''invasion'' of third-world immigrants.


Price of Nickel Soars Again
LEAD: Nickel prices soared to record levels again today as the London Metal Exchange reported that its warehouse stocks fell to the lowest level in five and a half years.
The price of nickel for immediate delivery jumped $1,400 a metric ton, to $23,900.


British Group's Hopeful View
LEAD: Britain's trade deficit will widen this year, unemployment will increase slightly and investment in manufacturing will rise by 10 percent, the Confederation of British Industry forecast today.


Mexico to Extend Controls
LEAD: With the agreement of business and labor, the Government today extended through May the wage and price controls it had placed in effect in December.


Nuclear Plan By Britain
LEAD: The British Government said today that it would urge American contractors to invest in nuclear power stations in Britain when that country sells off its state-run electricity industry.


Dedmon Traded
LEAD: The Atlanta Braves yesterday traded Jeff Dedmon, a relief pitcher, to the Cleveland Indians for a player to be named.
Dedmon, a 28-year-old right-hander, had been suffering shoulder problems.
He was 3-4 last season. (AP)

Fashion; Paris Sets the Pace With New Directions
LEAD: If fashion is indeed progressing to a more serious, grown-up stage, French designers will lead the way.
In the fall and winter ready-to-wear openings in Europe, the French, as a group, displayed both imagination and confidence as they struck out in new directions.


Dr. Arthur Vineberg, 84, Surgeon
LEAD: Dr.
Arthur Martin Vineberg, who developed artery transplants at McGill University in Montreal, died early Saturday of pneumonia at the university's Royal Victoria Hospital, where he worked for 55 years.
He was 84 years old.


Lambs of Big East Roaring in N.I.T.
LEAD: Two teams that were among the least of the Big East during the regular season have become the last conference survivors in postseason play.


Carnival Fall Kills Youth
LEAD: A 15-year-old fell 20 feet to his death after he climbed up from under the safety bar on a carnival ride, an official said Sunday.
The youth, Demetrick Welch of Lauderhill, fell from the Orbiter ride when he either tried to get out of his seat or change seats with his sister.


Gulf Canada Resources To Acquire Asamera
LEAD: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., controlled by the Reichmann family of Canada, said today that it had agreed to buy Asamera Inc., an oil, natural gas and gold producer, for $512 million (Canadian), or about $413 million (United States).


John J. Bookman, 76, an Internist And Specialist in Diabetes, Dies
LEAD: Dr.
John Jacob Bookman, an internist specializing in diabetes, died in an auto accident in East Fishkill, N.Y., Sunday while driving back to Manhattan, where he lived and maintained his medical practice.
He was 76 years old.


Advertising; Marschalk Seeks Impact For Olympus
LEAD: WHEN it introduces its Infinity Superzoom 300 camera, the Olympus Optical Company of Japan will be supported by the kind of high-quality creative work that one expects from Lowe Marschalk, as well as some creative thinking from the agency's media department.


DEADLOCK PERSISTS AT AFGHAN PARLEY
LEAD: The Afghan peace talks remained deadlocked today, with the Soviet Union refusing to reopen negotiations with the United States on terms for a suspension of military aid, officials and diplomats involved in the discussion said.


Review/Theater; A Dropout Tries to Restore His Faith
LEAD: Dropping out of Harvard graduate school and turning his back on the 1960's counterculture that has nurtured him, Paulie Bindel comes home to Brooklyn and tries to restore his faith in Judaic tradition.
Paulie is the searching protagonist of Robert Greenfield's novel ''Temple'' and of the play of the same name at the American Jewish Theater.


Florida Hospital Revenue Bonds
LEAD: The Hospital Board of Directors of Lee County, Fla., is tentatively offering $80 million in hospital revenue-refunding bonds for a project for Lee Memorial Hospital.
The financing offers a maximum yield of 8.065 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.


Review/Television; 2 Shows for Young Viewers About Homelessness
LEAD: Will younger viewers pull themselves away from music videos long enough to consider the subject of the homeless?
Two series aimed at young audiences are giving the possibility a shot this week.
This afternoon at 4 o'clock, CBS's ''Schoolbreak Special'' series is presenting ''Home Sweet Homeless,'' and tomorrow at 4 P.M., ABC's ''Afterschool Special'' offers a repeat broadcast of ''Are You My Mother?


DEALER MUST PAY TO TREAT ADDICTS
LEAD: In an unusual application of state law, a Brooklyn judge yesterday ordered a convicted heroin dealer dealer to pay more than $2 million in restitution, with the money to be used to support drug rehabilitation programs in New York City.

Facts About Fat
LEAD: New Federal dietary guidelines advise Americans who need to limit cholesterol to avoid foods containing highly saturated palm, palm kernel or coconut oils.
Pending legislation would make it far easier to follow that advice by requiring package labels to specify the presence of these cheaper tropical oils in processed foods.


Delays Plague Middle-Income Condominium Plan in New York
LEAD: Two years after a coalition of developers offered to build at no profit 3,000 condominium units for middle-income New Yorkers, the group is still awaiting city sites on which to build more than a third of the apartments.


Study of Normal Mourning Process Illuminates Grief Gone Awry
LEAD: MOURNING a loved one is always painful, but some people find the process more difficult than others, either becoming too distraught or holding too much emotion in.
In studying these extreme reactions, researchers are coming to a sharper understanding of the normal course of mourning, and of the signs that it has gone awry.

Macy &amp; Company to an end by tomorrow.

LEAD: A DRUG that has become indispensable in organ transplants now shows promise in the treatment of burn victims, according to doctors at the Southern California Burn Center of Sherman Oaks Community Hospital.

Bamboo and Pyramids
LEAD: ARCHEOLOGISTS have long puzzled over the means Egyptian pyramid builders used to raise and move immense blocks of stone without the help of wheels, pulleys or domestic animals.
A new study suggests that the basic stone-raising tool along the Nile 5,000 years ago was the simple bamboo pole.


Cooper Is Selling Lens Solution Unit
LEAD: The Cooper Companies, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it had agreed to sell its United States contact lens care solutions business to Wesley-Jessen Inc., a subsidiary of the Schering-Plough Corporation, for about $63 million in cash.
The transaction is subject to the completion of Cooper's previously announced agreement to sell its worldwide contact lens business to Wesley

LEAD: Using a small chunk of a new superconducting material, engineers at Cornell University have designed a high-speed, virtually frictionless bearing that spins at more than 1,000 revolutions per second.

Khachaturian bowed several times before the picture, which hung on the wall of Rose Kennedy's memento-filled home. ''It's not fair,'' he said softly.
The Kennedy family and its Hyannis Port complex on Cape Cod have always held a special place in the hearts of many Americans.

Review/Violin; An Exemplar Of Musical Absorption
LEAD: Gidon Kremer is probably the most interesting violinist playing today.
Not always the most satisfying, since his tone can be dry, his formidible technique can turn rough, and his musicality itself can take on a harsh edge.
But he has a capacity for intense absorption and musical thought that leaves our more glamorous violinists very far behind.
