LEAD: Erwin Rommel may be the only German general whose reputation survived World War II; certainly he became the best known of Hitler's soldiers. ''Rommel,'' at 8 o'clock tonight on the Arts &amp; Entertainment cable network, sifts through his life.

Complex Whistles Found to Play Key Roles in Inca and Maya Life
LEAD: EXPERTS are teasing thousand-year-old secrets from the clay whistles, ocarinas and flutes of the ancient Americas, discovering that these old musical instruments are surprisingly advanced in their construction and tonal qualities.

Market Place; Analysts Cautious On Utility Choices
LEAD: UNCERTAINTY over profit prospects and the path of interest rates has made investment firms quite selective in recommending electric utility stocks.


Du Pont Sends a Message on Ozone
LEAD: The Du Pont Company has pledged to phase out all production of CFC's, the chemicals that erode the life-protecting ozone layer in the high atmosphere.
Du Pont, the world's largest producer of CFC's, with sales of $600 million a year, set no specific timetable.
But it said a ''reasonable goal'' would be to cut output by 95 percent by the year 2000 - nearly double the goal set by an international protocol last year.

LEAD: BORON, an element best known for its use as an eye wash and a roach killer, plays a critical role in the body's ability to use calcium to form bone, new research indicates.

A Worthy Quartet Reaches the End
LEAD: From the first tipoff last November until the final shot in last Sunday's regional finals, the college basketball season has been like a furious storm with no discernible center.
It has raged and swept in no particular pattern.


MIPS Computer
LEAD: MIPS Computer Systems Inc., which makes high-speed microprocessors and computers, announced a new microprocessor and the formation of a software company to acquire and distribute programs for its computers.
MIPS, which is privately held and based in Sunnyvale, Calif., pioneered in making high-speed microprocessors using a design philosophy known as reduced instruction set computing, or RISC.

LEAD: Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that he would withdraw Libyan troops from the Egyptian border.

LEAD: Wayne Gretzky will not win the scoring title or score 50 goals for the first time in nine seasons in the National Hockey Leauge, but tonight he established a milestone by reaching the 100-assist mark for the eighth straight season.


South Africans Strike Botswana
LEAD: South African troops killed four people early today in a raid on a house in Gaborone, the capital of neighboring Botswana, the Government said.

Major Gains In Graphics
LEAD: PERHAPS nowhere else is the rapid advance of personal computers so clearly visible as in the realm of computer graphics.
The aisles at the National Computer Graphics Association's annual meeting here last week were filled with demonstrations of flashy computer graphics that until just a couple of years ago were the exclusive domain of supercomputers and mainframes costing hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in some copies on Wednesday from The Associated Press about four people charged in the fatal beating of a man in Harlem incorrectly described statements made by their lawyers, based on information supplied by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.
The defendants did not admit participating in the assault.


Gains in Governments' Pay Equity Reported
LEAD: State and local governments increasingly are moving to pay men and women the same for jobs that are different but are deemed to be of similar value to an employer, according to a private study released today.

The program also features the New York premiere of Robin Holloway's ''Seascape and Harvest'' and Sibelius's Symphony No.

LEAD: A messenger from the Manhattan District Attorney's office was robbed of $4,900 yesterday by two men and a woman in a bank in lower Manhattan, the police said.

April 6 at Avery Fisher Hall.

Rampal will perform the New York premiere of David Diamond's Sonata for Flute and Piano as well as works by Czerny, Franck and Bartok.
Appearing with Mr.
Rampal will be John Steele Ritter at the piano.

Rough Justice in the Chambers Case
LEAD: After 13 weeks in court, including nine days of fruitless jury debate, the murder case of the People of New York v.
Robert Chambers Jr. ended in a compromise plea to manslaughter.
The public heard in intimate detail Mr.
Chambers's bizarre defense that his killing of Jennifer Levin in Central Park two summers ago was an accident that grew out of violent sex.


More Damage Found on Williamsburg Bridge
LEAD: Samuel I. Schwartz, right, first deputy transportation commissioner, and Ernest Langjahr, chief engineer of design, examining an underpinning of the Williamsburg Bridge yesterday.
Inspectors found deterioration in the flanges of three beams and said repairs were under way.
Officials said they hope to have the two outer Brooklyn-bound lanes open by Friday or Monday, at the latest.


Fadeout for Movie Palace in Brooklyn
LEAD: With one final C chord on its mighty Wurlitzer, the Walker Theater in Brooklyn ended a 60-year run yesterday, distinguished as one of the most enduring neighborhood movie palaces in New York and one of the city's most briefly lived landmarks.


LESSONS
LEAD: There are no lectures, no tests, no classes per se.
There are only the immortals - Plato and Aristotle, St.
Augustine and Montaigne, Spinoza, Swift, Melville, Moliere, more than 130 of The Great Books, as they are called at St.
John's College, in what is still, after 50 academic seasons, an experiment in the liberal arts.


Bond Index Market Ends
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade has suspended trading in its five-month-old Corporate Bond Index futures contract because of a lack of volume.
The contract is based on an index of bonds issued by 100 United States corporations.
The Commodities Futures Trading Commission has approved ''dormant status'' for the contract, so the exchange could revive it later.


As the Computer Fiddles, Users Burn
LEAD: Anyone who has used a personal computer has been forced to wait while the machine completed some task.
A University of Texas at Arlington researcher has found that such waiting can produce anxiety and theorizes that such anxiety reduces productivity.

LEAD: On the island of Crete, sometime in the next few days, Greek mythology is heading for an American update.
Stand back, Daedalus, with your wings of wax and feathers; make way for New Aviator, with graphite spars and polyester film and the backing of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Business Technology page on March 9 about women in engineering misstated the source of a quotation by Sandra K. Bidwell of Tucson, Ariz.
The quotation about sex discrimination in the engineering profession was from an article written by Karen Fitzgerald in The Institute, a newsletter published by the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers.


Sundstrand Filing
LEAD: The Sundstrand Corporation, an aerospace contractor, has said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it expects to be fined heavily by the Government because of an investigation into reported overcharges.
Last July, the Defense Department said that Sundstrand, based in Rockford, Ill., had overbilled the United States over two years by more than $100 million on military contracts.


Ruling Broadens Reporter Protections
LEAD: New York State's highest court broadened protection for reporters yesterday by ruling that, with few exceptions, journalists do not have to turn over news material to the courts, even when it was gathered from nonconfidential sources.

LEAD: The military announced today that three top Communist leaders had been seized Tuesday as security forces continued a series of arrests of leading figures in the underground party.


Review/Recital; Schubert Piano Dialogue With Levine and Noda
LEAD: Schubert's music for piano duet, written with parlor performance in mind, is rarely played in public.
However, many of his compositions in the four-hands genre push far beyond the casual dilettantism such a constraint might imply, deserving the best preparation and execution that professional pianists can bring to them.

LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states may not take Social Security benefits received by their prisoners to pay for their support.

LEAD: The California Supreme Court has invalidated the death sentence of a Vietnam veteran because the sentencing trial excluded testimony that the man might have killed two young girls in response to wartime trauma.

LEAD: Since his confirmation as Attorney General in 1985, Edwin Meese 3d has been investigated by three special prosecutors and the Office of Government Ethics.
Questions have been raised not only about the propriety of his personal finances, but about what role he may have played in the Iran-contra affair, the awarding of a Government contract for the Wedtech Corporation and a plan to construct an Iraqi oil pipeline close to Israel.

Fewer Frills for Children at Easter
LEAD: ONCE upon a time, little girls woke up on Easter morning and ran to the window.
If the sun was shining, they could dress up in their new spring coats and bonnets and patent leather shoes.
If it was raining - or even worse, snowing - they would have to plead with their mothers to be allowed to wear their good clothes.


120,000 Blacks Saved From Homeland Status
LEAD: South Africa's highest court today struck down a 1985 decision by the Government to forcibly incorporate a black community of 120,000 people into KwaNdebele, a tribal homeland.


Detroit Journal; Must Cemetery Yield to Airport?
LEAD: These days, other than the oak trees on the hillside, there is nothing serene about the Serenity lot or any other lot at Detroit's Gethsemane Cemetery.


States Agree to Turkey Deal
LEAD: The State of Connecticut has sold 53 wild turkeys to Maine, fetching $143.40 per turkey.
But the money will be going back to Maine when Connecticut seeks to buy fishers, a carnivore once common as far south as North Carolina but now limited to northern New England.
Dale May, a Connecticut wildlife biologist, said officials hope to hasten the animal's return by transplanting a population to the state's northwestern hills.

Talking Econo-Military
LEAD: The phrase ''politico-military'' entered the strategists' jargon about a generation ago.
It was a handy way of reminding diplomats and military men, who tend to go their own ways, that their concerns are tightly linked.
Clausewitz observed that war and politics have shared goals, but he made it sound as though they were alternatives when in fact there are constant interconnections.

LEAD: Look, people exclaimed last week: A new baby boom!
That's surely what the new data from the National Center for Health Statistics seemed to show.
Births in 1987 rose almost 3 percent over 1986.
The total, 3,829,000, is the largest number reported since 1964.
The one-year rise of almost 100,000 births can't be denied, but fears of another unsettling population bomb are premature.

LEAD: SOMEONE once asked a newspaper columnist about the response to a particularly fiery polemic of his. ''Just what I expected,'' he replied. ''A half a dozen letters poured in.''

Court Backs Murdoch In Battle on F.C.C. Ban
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Congress had unconstitutionally singled out Rupert Murdoch with a law that sought to prevent his ownership of a newspaper and television station in the same market.


Stocks Rebound; Dow Up 18.57, to 1,998.34
LEAD: Stocks rebounded broadly yesterday, posting their first advance in four days.


For French Voters, Old Faces of '88
LEAD: The campaign for the French presidency has swiftly designated its two front-runners: President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the leader of the conservative neo-Gaullist movement.


U.S. Increases Refugee Quota
LEAD: Citing an increase in the number of Armenians trying to leave the Soviet Union, the Reagan Administration said today that it will propose a substantial increase in the number of those refugees admitted to the United States.


CBS Sweetens A Pension Plan
LEAD: CBS Inc., which has made a string of moves to cut back the size and scope of the company, said yesterday that it would offer increased pension benefits to about 11 percent of its employees if they elect to retire within the next four months.


El Salvador Seizes Reporters Returning From Rebel Zone
LEAD: The Salvadoran military detained 15 reporters returning Monday from a rebel-controlled zone, seized their belongings and equipment and made a veiled threat against one of them.
The journalists were released after several hours and their possessions - expect for several videocassettes - were returned to them.


Real Estate; Costs Forcing Printers Out Of Manhattan
LEAD: AFTER two years of searching for affordable relocation space in Manhattan, Stan Roth, who has run a printing business in New York City for 31 years, is leaving.


Cuomo Remains Unflustered at Jackson Gains
LEAD: Governor Cuomo said today that the Democratic Presidential nominee should be the person who receives the most votes in the primaries. ''If that's Jesse Jackson, wonderful,'' he declared.


Corrections
LEAD: A story in Science Times yesterday on treating fetuses using the umbilical cord incorrectly identified a hospital at which Dr.
Stuart Weiner performed such procedures.
It is Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.

New York City Bridges Should Be Repaired With State Funds
LEAD: To the Editor:


Spanish Airline
LEAD: Spantax S.A., Spain's largest charter airline, said it was ceasing activities because of debts totaling $90 million.
A company spokesman said that Spantax had canceled all flights, effective immediately, affecting about 20,000 passengers.
Last year, Spantax, based in Madrid, carried 1.35 million passengers to the United States, Latin America and several European destinations, as well as to domestic locations.


AMERICAN BUILDERS WIN PARTICIPATION IN JAPAN PROJECTS
LEAD: Ending one of their most contentious trade disputes, the United States and Japan completed an agreement today that would permit American construction companies to participate with Japanese contractors in building airport terminals, bridges, ports and other large public works projects in Japan.


Bush Nomination Seems Assured As Dole Leaves Republican Race
LEAD: Vice President Bush all but officially became the Republican nominee for President today when Senator Bob Dole, his chief rival, ended his campaign.


Heart Attack Deaths Reduced
LEAD: A two-year study of more than 17,000 heart patients showed that aspirin and the seldom-used drug streptokinase, taken together after the onset of chest pains, reduce deaths among heart attack victims, researchers said today.


Judge Accepts Witness Despite 1975 Hypnosis
LEAD: A Federal judge indicated yesterday that he would permit the prosecution in a Mafia trial to present a witness who had been hypnotized to help her remember an abduction she had seen.


Are Babies Welcome to Dine? Yes, if They're Well Behaved
LEAD: SMALL children and tiny infants can be seen - and heard - on occasion at Le Cirque, one of New York's most glittery restaurants, and most of the time no one minds.


Review/Television; Violence From Sex Bias
LEAD: Is violence against gay men and lesbians rising?
The panelists on ''Metroline'' aren't sure, but they agree that violence is a serious problem.
They also seem to suggest, however, that society shows increasing acceptance of, and tolerance for, gay men and lesbians.
The program, ''The Most Frequent Victim,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight.

LEAD: *
Amoco Chemical Co., Chicago, and Premark International Inc., Northbrook, Ill., said Amoco Performance Products Inc., an Amoco Chemical unit, had purchased the commercial plastics operations of Premark's Datco Manufacturing unit in Augusta, Ga.
Terms were not disclosed.


Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
LEAD: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday.
The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.6483 percent, up from 6.6192 percent last week.

Disney Buys Stake
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company has paid $85.2 million for a 50 percent interest in the Wrather Corporation that was held by the New Zealand financier Ronald A. Brierley.
Last year, Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a La Jolla, Calif., company controlled by Mr.
Brierley, acquired 28 percent of Wrather, a hotel operator based in Beverly Hills.

Neil Williams, Painter On Shaped Canvas, 53
LEAD: Neil Williams, an artist who pioneered in the use of the shaped canvas, died of a heart attack while visiting a friend in New York last Friday.
He was 53 years old, and had recently been living in Brazil.


New-Home Sales Jump By 20.3%
LEAD: Sales of new homes rebounded smartly in February after three straight declines that seemed to be bearing out fears that housing would drag down the nation's economy.


Coach Dismissed
LEAD: The University of New Orleans has dismissed the basketball coach, Art Tolis, for ''just cause,'' apparently intending to avoid buying out the remaining two years of his contract.
Tolis, who said he did not like the implication that he did anything wrong and will go to court to fight the dismissal, was promoted from assistant coach last spring when Benny Dees left to take the job at Wyoming.


Suffolk Votes A Bill to Ban Plastic Bags
LEAD: The Suffolk County Legislature approved a bill today to outlaw the use of plastic grocery bags and other plastic food containers, starting in July 1989.


For Workers, More Paths to Degree
LEAD: In classrooms from lower Manhattan to Los Angeles, automobile assemblers and prison guards, taxi drivers and postal carriers are taking such college courses as ''The Latin American Novel,'' and ''The Abnormal Personality,'' all with the encouragement of their unions.


Noriega Is Urged by Bishops To Quit 'as Soon as Possible'
LEAD: Panama's Roman Catholic bishops called on Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega today to help end the country's political crisis by relinquishing power ''as soon as possible.''


Careers of 2 Who Resigned; Arnold I. Burns
LEAD: Arnold I. Burns, 57 years old, who had served as Deputy Attorney General since July 24, 1986, was not viewed as an ideological conservative at the Justice Department.

LEAD: A young man was charged today with killing an Indian judicial candidate last weekend, and a person believed to be an accomplice was found dead, apparently having committed suicide.

HIGH JUSTICE AIDES QUIT AMID CONCERN OVER MEESE'S ROLE
LEAD: The Deputy Attorney General and the head of the Justice Department's criminal division resigned today, along with four of their top aides.
Department officials said the six quit because of their mounting concern over the legal problems and leadership of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.


Tulane Fight Over Merger Leaves Scars
LEAD: For Newcomb College, the battle appears to be over.
But questions and scars of distrust remain in the aftermath of a fight over Tulane University's decision to merge the faculty of Newcomb, its coordinate women's school, with that of the university's College of Arts and Sciences.


BILL IS REJECTED ON TOXIN WARNINGS
LEAD: The Senate effectively rejected legislation today that would have required warnings to workers that they risk cancer and other diseases from on-the-job exposure to toxic chemicals.


60-Minute Groumet
LEAD: WHEN I am asked to name the one food that responds best to quick and easy cookery, I am always tempted to say mussels.
You simply toss well-scrubbed mussels into a kettle, cover tightly and cook until the mussels open.

LEAD: So for years New York City health inspectors drove up the cost of restaurant meals with a shakedown racket.
I for one, possibly the only one, am sore at the Health Department about this.
I want the Health Department to send me back my money.


Clemson Reveals Tests
LEAD: Clemson University said that since it began mandatory drug testing in 1985, a total of 37 athletes had tested positive, some of them more than once.
In a report that gave few details, the school said that 2,171 athletes had been tested, producing 56 positive results by 37 athletes, some of whom were suspended.

LEAD: As his friend Art Buchwald, the humorist, sees it, Gordon Manning, a staff consultant to NBC News, is ''the man in the middle no one knows'' who ''arranges for things to happen.''

LEAD: N.W.
Ayer, the agency for Du Pont's Corian in the United States since 1982, will now handle it in Europe, taking over from Young &amp; Rubicam.
Ayer has been a Du Pont agency since 1956.


Britain to Sell Rover Group
LEAD: The British Government announced today that it was selling the Rover Group P.L.C., the ailing car maker, to British Aerospace P.L.C. for $:150 million, or about $279 million - well below the price that analysts had expected.

LEAD: The dollar rebounded against most major foreign currencies yesterday as the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve reportedly moved to bolster its value.

LEAD: Embroiled with Wall Street arbitragers who continue to balk at its terms, the group bidding to acquire the ailing First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc. today reduced the percentage of bondholders who must approve its $1.5 billion offer to 70 percent, from 90 percent.

LEAD: Ted Kluszewski, the slugging first baseman who led the major leagues in home runs in 1954 with 49, died tonight after apparently suffering a heart attack.

Store Near School Raided for Cocaine
LEAD: The authorities have seized three kilograms of cocaine, $16,000 and a small arsenal in a raid on a Brooklyn candy store, law-enforcement officials said.
Ten men, including the store owner, believed by the authorities to be members of a Colombian cocaine ring, were arrested at 10 P.M.
Monday after an undercover agent had negotiated to buy five pounds of cocaine.

LEAD: A White House spokesman expressed outrage today over the violence against opposition figures and American reporters in Panama, and he warned that ''there are limits to our patience.''

LEAD: Walt Poddubny's swollen right hand has made it difficult for him to execute the simplest of chores.
Today, finished with practice, preparing for the Rangers' flight to Chicago, Poddubny picked up the morning newspaper.
Painful as that was, it hurt far more to open the pages and fully absorb what he read.

LEAD: WHEN a fifth of New York City's 110 restaurant inspectors were arrested last week on charges of bribery, the safety of every establishment was suddenly open to question.

Washington Talk: Congress; Who Do You Thank When the Staff Gets a Raise?
LEAD: People on Capitol Hill have a choice phrase to describe legislation that contains nonessential, often costly, riders that are added to benefit special interests.
Such legislative packages are called ''Christmas tree bills.'' Last Christmas, a new Yuletide figure came into being here: the mystery Santa Claus.


Islanders Continue To Roll
LEAD: The Islanders, whose coach has found no better a one-word description for his team than ''unpredictable,'' have done the unexpected now for the past two weeks.
They have been reliable, hard-working and consistent, and this type of monotony has enabled them to construct a six-game unbeaten streak.
The players haven't given him much to criticize, and Coach Terry Simpson, basking in tonight's 5-3 defeat of the Flyers, has found himself in the position of having little to mold.

Dealer Finds a Haggadah Is Not So Rare
LEAD: For a while, Aharon Berger, a Brooklyn dealer in antique Judaica, thought he had acquired a genuine edition of the first printed Passover Haggadah, dating from 1482.
That would have given Mr.
Berger only the second known copy of the Guadalajara Haggadah, printed in Guadalajara, Spain.


Hospitals' Handling of Uninsured Patients Faulted
LEAD: Thousands of emergency room patients are annually put at risk of permanent damage or even death when they are transferred from private to public hospitals because they lack insurance, a Congressional report said today.
It blamed the Administration for not enforcing a law prohibiting such transfers.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 345 to 70 by which the House of Representatives today approved a $47.9 million package of assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: A modest but pleasing exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford offers a sampling of quilting techniques and patterns covering almost 300 years.

The show is entitled, ''Drunken Paths and Ladders to the Stars,'' after traditional quilt patterns.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: WISHING that someone sleep like a baby may be more of a curse than a benediction.
The brain of a sleeping child works differently from the brain of an adult.
There is a link between the 3-year-old who sleeps so soundly that he does not wake up when you carry him from the car to the house and get him undressed for bed, and the toddler who frightens the whole family with his screams of terror a few hours after he goes to sleep.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: SLUGGISH drains in sinks and tubs rank high among household annoyances.
However, remedies for drain woes are usually simple.
If the problem is addressed early, restoring a sluggish drain to full effectiveness or even clearing a drain that has become completely clogged seldom require much skill or effort, and may require only a few tools.

Health; Personal Health
LEAD: For the Zuni Indians of New Mexico, the modern rallying cry is ''Ho Chikwa: Weykkya Hanukwa.'' It means, ''I outran diabetes.'' The popular saying reflects the fact that running and other modes of exercise have become central to the lives of the Zuni, 40 percent of whom develop diabetes by the age of 45.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. I want to build a brick walkway without using cement or mortar.
Can I just set the bricks into the soil, or should I put down a bed of sand first?
A.
It is best to put down a sand base first; otherwise, the bricks will sink into the soil.
Dig out the soil to a depth of at least four inches; then spread a two-inch layer of sand on the bottom as a base for the bricks.
